description:
I'd do back just for the flavorful salsa and warm chips! I got the Garlic Shrimp burrito and at first I thought there wasn't much shrimp but at the end found they were almost all on that side. Had it been actually mixed up properly I would have enjoyed a bit more. I'd go again but given it was $15 
I'd be more interested in trying another place first. 

Also the employees were nice, in particular the  cashier I talked to!
author: Melissa S.

description:
Classic SF super burrito, I'd say for a "chain" type burrito spot, the burritos are pretty delicious and can definitely hold their own in a city with some LEGIT authentic spots. 

That being said, definitely on the more expensive side so keep that in mind.
author: Matthew O.

description:
The good: 
The food here is decent and fresh. Maybe it's not Super Saiyan level #authentic, but get the stick out your ass and stop obsessing about intellectually untenable concepts like authenticity.

The bad: 
They charge a surcharge for guacamole in your burrito (that's OK in and of itself). And between me and my family, we've probably paid for several dozen burritos' worth of money in additional guacamole charges, only to end up with no guacamole in the burritos. Not exactly sure what's up with them and their cooks, but this has happened for a long time now. Even when you explicitly tell the person on the phone to make sure they get guacamole in your burrito. So if you like donating money to a for-profit endeavor, go ahead and do your thing at Little Chihuahua. Otherwise, consider other options or just accept that their absentmindedness will lead to your being ripped off repeatedly.
author: Ehsan S.

description:
We've been here a couple of times for a quick bite. 

The burritos are pretty dope! They lightly burn the tortilla which gives it a nice burnt/smokey flavor in some of the bites. The meat can be a little dry in certain bites but you can't really notice it with all the other delicious stuff in the burrito. The carne asada burrito is the best in my opinion. 

I don't recommend the tortilla soup, although I did get it without the queso fresco. They leave the chicken in giant pieces so you'll need a knife to eat it properly. Alternatively, I just forked out the chicken because it was chewy and flavorless.

Lastly, use their roasted tomato salsa on EVERYTHING! It will not disappoint.
author: Yuchen L.

description:
Situation
- Ordered a takeout order of a Super Chicken Burrito and tortilla chips over the phone (June 2018)

Overall
- A little more than $21 for a burrito and chips
- The super burrito was a smaller than a regular-sized burrito's at other taqueria's
- The burrito was decent
- The restaurant used to be quite good, but the quality seems to be decreasing and the price seems to be increasing quite a bit
author: Dipesh G.

description:
Potentially controversial statement (let the burrito wars begin), but I think this place is better than La Taqueria.

I custom make my own by adding plantains into a Super Burrito. Highly recommend.
author: Alex L.

description:
This place is so close to almost perfect but missing key things that I look for in a burrito or taco. I'm thrilled with their Pico de Gallo (best around), salsa selection is good, chips are awesome , and the fact they have a cabbage slaw makes me so happy. Cute decor, too. 
However...
As a vegetarian and not liking black beans my options are limited, which is sad. Also, the bathroom could be cleaner.
author: Rachel D.

description:
Another five stars for something I had for the first time only as of last night (and after living next door to TLC for four years, this is a bit of a shame...) - their Tortilla Soup. Ironically I liked everything but the tortillas. The cheese, avocado and just the right amount of spice are what made it 'just right' in my book.

My seven-year-old son has his usual, which he likes to refer to as "The Adam Special". I think most youngsters would like it -- a beans/cheese/rice/guacamole/sour cream burrito. His favorite.
author: Camille L.

description:
The food is gringo decent but the prices have tipped past outrageous into ridiculous territory. $15 for a burrito. Really? 

Also, while I'm on my soapbox, 1/4 teaspoon is not the right serving size for guacamole in a $15 burrito. I got all the way down to the bottom before finding any trace of it. Complete rip off.
author: Joseph S.

description: Tasty, responsibly-sourced south-of-the-border food. Om Nom Nom!
author: Chris D.

description: Every time I try out a new Mexican restaurant. I try to order the best signature burrito or the best crowd favorite burrito they have to offer. I ordered the garlic shrimp burrito and I simply thought it was delicious. It had an amazing taste from start to finish. It taste so good with or without they're hot sauces but who am I kidding? A burrito without hot sauce is like pizza without the cheese. The place had a very at home type of vibe. Almost like eating at your very own dining table. Great place to bring the family for some authentic Mexican food. The location wasn't a busy area and parking was not hard to find. I had a great experience and will have to try out more selections off the menu!
author: Ramon C.

description:
I ordered the regular Tostada Salad ($10.95) and thought it tasted ok. It was very Americanized. 

I liked the crispy tortilla shell although most of the shell was soggy from the dressing. To make my salad more flavorful, I grabbed some more mild salsa from the free salsa bar. The cheese pieces were huge (think 1"x1"x1" cubes) and did not seem to match the salad too well. I would have preferred shredded cheddar cheese. I ended up scooping some of the mango pieces out because it tasted a bit weird. The mango pieces were a little spicy. 

I think I will only come back if I cannot find something else to eat in the area.

Random note: If it is cold outside, I recommend not sitting near the door. The door doesn't close all the way and you will have a lot of fun closing the door every few minutes when someone walks into the restaurant.
author: Kristina M.

description:
I really appreciate the gluten free burrito option.  I just had my first burrito in 5 years, the garlic shrimp.  Not sure why it was so SWEET, it tasted so sugary when I want my burrito to taste savory,
but the tortilla was great.  I actually am paranoid that it WASN'T actually a gluten free tortilla, because it tasted and felt and held together EXACTLY like a flour one.  I am praying they didn't switch it up.  I'm sure they know what they are doing.

Next time I'll try a meat, hopefully more savory/salty than sweet.

I love their chicken soup, and other healthy options.
author: Avi S.

description: Just a bland belly bomb, rice beans some meat, guacamole etc......all bland and booooooring
author: Kevin F.

description:
We were looking for a late dinner and decided to try out The Little Chihuahua. They have a ton of different options so we figured everyone would be able to find something to eat! I got the burrito- I contemplated trying the chili verde tofu, but decided on the pollo asado instead. The burrito comes with rice, beans, cabbage and salsa. I decided to make it super by adding in guac and some other yummy goodies. The burrito was pretty good, BUT I was definitely jealous of everyone who got the enchiladas, because those were really good. 

I took a few bites of their enchiladas and loved the red sauce on them. They were moist and flavorful. Looking back, I would have gotten the enchiladas instead for sure. They were really good. 

The only thing I would not recommend is the horchata. It was incredibly grainy. It tasted very chalky. It was okay once it got watered down by the melted ice, but definitely not enjoyable.
author: Courtney O.

description:
Oh, you have no idea how much I want to hate this place. My first encounter with it was while living in the mission, it was one of the first "gentro" taquerias in the neighborhood. I just hated peeking into its spotless interior, it's clean windows, the lovely symmetry of its logo. I sneered every time I walked past.

Then I tasted their al pastor and plátano burrito. They are ridiculously tasty. That plátano burrito is probably the best vegetarian burrito I've ever had. And the al Pastor burrito is lip smacking good, though unlike any al pastor burrito I've encountered. 

I absolutely never think of this as a place to quench my desire for a burrito. They are so unnaturally tasty, they are like what a wrap is supposed to be. Burritos weren't made to be so flavorful!

So when I can stomach the bitter aftertaste of displaced artists and people of color, the food here goes down just fine. Otherwise, it reminds me of when that dude was eating that steak in the matrix. The only way it can exist is in a world that exploits your homey's.
author: Mario T.

description:
Opens late, decent for post drinking grub.

I had the smothered baby burrito with chorizo and it was good. Prices are slightly on the high side and the margarita was kinda diluted.
author: Christina N.

description: The food was great.  Loved the atmosphere and the guys working there.  Everyone was upbeat and welcoming.  We are definitely happy we found this place while visiting San Francisco.
author: Michelle D.

description:
We came on a Sunday around 2 and split the posole & carne Asada burrito. 

They do charge for chips and salsa but it's pretty cheap - and they do have a salsa bar with like 7 options & jalapeños. 

They use grass fed beef & you can definitely tell, make your burrito super with all the good stuff for like 1$ extra. They don't skimp on the ingredients.

The posole was perfect because it was kinda chilly outside & I haven't had it in sooo long. It's not spicy, so if you want a kick add some tapatio they keep on the tables. They use purple corn which is different than what I'm used too, but if I had to guess it was healthier . Good portion & perfect to share.
author: danielle a.

description: $42 bucks for two burritos and a veggie taco delivered. They could at least throw in some chips and salsa. Tasty tho.
author: Sheviche R.

description:
The Little Chihuahua is OK.  Sadly not the best Mexican food I've had and certainly not what I expected when having lunch near the Mission District.  Maybe we should have eaten in the MD? 

I ordered a chicken quesadilla, usually one of my favorite menu items at any Mexican joint, and this one was just OK.  There was plenty of meat and cheese, and the peppers were nice, but overall it seriously lacked...something.  There was no punch of flavor, no personality.  I ended up putting A LOT of salsa on it.  Luckily the salsa is unlimited...

And that salsa was good.  All three (?) that I tried.  A must get - the chips!  Yes, you read that correctly, you must order a bowl of chips.  Super crunchy and I was shocked at the larger-than-expected bowl we got for 50 cents!!! 

Order the chips.  Try all the salsas.  Maybe skip the quesadilla.
author: Alyssa R.

description:
They have really tasty food but it is so overpriced. 

I got the tortilla soup to go and this is how filled it was. And it was $9.50
author: Henry C.

description: I'm so happy that I decided to stop by this place. Best burrito I have ever had. I'll definitely come back!
author: Golfy Z.

description: This was hands down the best burrito I have ever had. My wife and friends loved their tacos and quesadillas. Totally recommend eating here for great quality Mexican food!
author: Charles W.

description: Messed up our ordered (put the meat I wanted in my husband's enchilada and vice versa). And their "margarita" was absolute crap. Tasted like very sweet orange juice, looked like orange juice, and I swear there was not an ounce of tequila in there. I don't really understand how that qualifies as a margarita...
author: Maansi D.

description: Their tacos are so good! I was here for the weekend and the sign said sustainable seafood or something and I was coming home from the bar and they were still open (till 11p) and I couldn't not stop. So I had a fried plantain and tofu taco and they were incredible. And then I went the next day and had garlic shrimp and wild mushrooms taco. They're so full of flavor! So perfectly done. Recommend.
author: Kate O.

description: Very good flavor in al pastor and shrimp tacos. Quick service around 3pm. Good salsa too.
author: Awmber M.

description: Of all the Little Chihuahua locations, this one is the best and most consistently delicious. As a vegetarian/pescatarian leaning diet, I have to say that their plantain burrito is incredible - all the usual fixings with rice/beans, etc., but the sauce and salsa has a slightly smokey flavor and the grilled plantains are sweet, soft, but firm and you don't miss any protein. My other favorite here is the garlic shrimp burrito - again with the smokey flavors it has all the feels of a summer bbq in burrito form.
author: Farrah N.

description: Ambience is good . Really hard to get a table on Friday evening for obvious reasons . Baby burrito was big enough for a full meal . Chips and guac were great aswell
author: Namrah S.

description:
TLC is a solid Mexican inspired restaurant off of Divisadero and close to Duboce. They serve typical Mexican dishes such as burritos, tacos, salad, sangria, chips + guac/salsa. TLC isn't super authentic, but they still serve tasty food that seems like it's of decent quality. Burritos are about $12-14. I come back here when I'm in the area and am craving my favorite dish here: the plantain burrito.

The interior is pretty small, seating maybe 25 people. Service is nice.

I ordered and really enjoyed the:
Plantain burrito
Garlic shrimp burrito
author: Sean W.

description: Great place for vegetarians. I had the nachos with green Chile tofu. They were delicious. The food was high quality, the salsas were delicious, and the vibe was pretty cool. Will definitely come back here more often when I'm in the city.
author: Jenna T.

description:
Thanks for packing my pozole soup in the most fragile container ever with a loose lid, stacking everything and jamming it into a tiny paper bag. Guess what happened when I drove not even one block with it? The entire damn thing spilled all over my car. 

I get that you're trying to be eco friendly with your compostable stuff, but please pack to go food in a sensible manner.
author: Alexander W.

description: Wow. I've hit a decent amount of spots in SF for burritos but these were next level. I ordered the Al Pastor burrito and it is the best I've ever had. For a pretty packed day, the place was incredibly efficient. They had clean tables, attentive employees, and a great handle of the not-sober customers. After tip, my burrito ended up at about $15, so these are definitely on the pricier side. However, it was absolutely worth it. I'll be back!
author: Manuela R.

description: This is a pretty good place to get Mexican food. It's reasonably priced, clean, and the food is pretty tasty. My friends and I shared the steak quesadilla, chips and salsa, chicken enchilada, and a steak burrito. The burrito and quesadilla were very good but the enchilada didn't have that much flavor. The service was fast and we didn't have to wait to get a table. I'd say it's worth checking out but it definitely didn't wow me.
author: Tanya C.

description: My bf and I were starving and looking for a place to have lunch. We stumbled past this place and decided to take a chance. It's an order and pay at the counter and then seat yourself and they'll bring your food out to you type of place, I got the regular carne asada burrito and my bf had the al pastor specialty burrito. And we also got an order of chips and guac. We stuffed our faces with the chips and guac. It was pretty good. And they also have a salsa bar in case you run out of guacamole or want some salsa for your entrée. Finally the food came out. My burrito was tasty but again I was starving. There was plenty of black beans, rice, salsa and beef. I was able to eat probably ¾ of it before I had to give the rest to my bf. I think I filled up on those chips and guac. I think I could've finished the burrito if that's all I had. I also tried a bite of the al pastor. Pork was tasty. A solid choice for lunch.
author: Alison W.

description: I always make sure to stop here whenever I'm passing through! Agave wine margarita and enchiladas verdes are my go to every time.
author: Shannon H.

description: Got the garlic shrimp burrito but it wasn't bombastic for the price ~15. There weren't that many shrimp pieces in there. Tasty but not legendary. Great salsa selection though.
author: Y W.

description:
Left a bit disappointed. The best part was the many different fresh salsas they have for their customers. YUM! 

From all the reviews mentioning the nachos was delicious but it's not. The chips was soggy. Too many beans, not enough cheese. The carnitas were lacking in flavor. I got the enchiladas as my entree. The sauce was really good, as well as their Spanish rice but i think the tortillas they used was way to thick, way too MUCH!! Not a fan. My friend got two tacos. He said they were good but wasn't anything amazing. 

It's a small place and first come first serve seating. Good luck finding a seat during rush hour.
author: Sandy B.

description:
Bombbb.com
Got the al pastor taco and plantain w black beans taco -- 2 filled me up w the margarita which was unique but delicious (usually a 3-6 taco guy at typical taquerias)
Definitely will be back!!
author: Matt D.

description: If you can't get there. You can order on Caviar.com or the app. Do yourself a favor and treat yourself. I just ate a carnitas taco and will eat the burrito later after my Jameson and ginger ale . This place never disappoints.
author: Larry S.

description: Had tacos which were average at best. Needed a quick bite from walking around all day and this was good to last us till dinner. Not going back but not bad.
author: Mishkat L.

description:
Although I can't say The Little Chihuahua is my favorite Mexican joint, this place serves up some Tex-Mex, but also traditional Mexican food that can appeal to people. Located on Divisadero, this place is close to all of those little small shops and eateries that can appeal to many. With other Little Chihuahua joints in the city, this place must be doing something right! My mother had read about this place and we decided that on a stroll through Lower Haight and Haight Ashbury, we'd swing by! 

FOOD: Pozole. Burritos. I must say that the pozole is quite tasty with a nice red soup base and all of the right fixings in it. It was a solid stew that could stave off even the coldest of San Francisco days. The burritos, albeit quite pricey for what they give you, was good. I got the fried plantain and black bean burrito (vegetarian friendly!) that was quite tasty. The sweetness of the plantain mixed in with the richness of the roasted red bell pepper made for a pretty filling burrito. Although a bit different than your typical carne asada burrito with pinto beans, The Little Chihuahua does add a bit more to your traditional Northern California Mexican food.

SERVICE: Standard

Make sure to get that smoky chipotle salsa at the salsa bar as you walk to your table. It was quite tasty and added that little extra something something to whatever you're eating!
author: Albert H.

description:
This place makes me sad.  It's definitely not the traditional burrito you would get from a taqueria in the mission, and not different enough to think it's an California twist on Mexican food.  It's expensive and disappointing

I asked for a burrito without meat or grilled vegetables. I paid for "super" but didn't want sour cream.  There was hardly any cheese or guac and it was mostly beans. $12 for a mostly bean burrito, plus you'll pay extra for greasy chips on the side. I would have been happier with Chipotle.

The two positive things: the salsa bar is decent and the staff is friendly.
author: Rachel R.

description: There are so many good Mexican restaurants in the city and TLC is definitely in my top 5. I love their garlic shrimp burrito and their salsa selection. The interior decor is pleasant for in door dining and creates a cozy vibe! It's a great local neighborhood place to visit when you are craving Mexican food on Taco Tuesday!
author: Neda P.

description:
I ordered $70 worth of food for delivery. My delivery order was lost.  It was never received. I called Chihuahua and they told me it was my problem. That the company that they choose to use to deliver their food is the problem. It is not their problem as they told me..  

This is an example of a bad company. I don't care how your food tastes. I don't care that you have gluten-free options. What I care about is whether you are  a reputable organization and you are not. You are part of the problem. You do not protect your customers. You are responsible for me losing $70.  When I told the gentleman on the phone that I would never order from them again,  his response was,  "well you don't have to." 

Bad business - discouraging !
author: Sharon H.

description:
I've had a string of average experiences. (I don't think I've written these many three star reviews in a row before.) Such was the case with Little Chihuahua when I ordered our weekly office lunch through Forkable on Friday, September 9th. I believe it arrived around 12:30pm.

Custom Burrito: Your choice of a tortilla, beans, and a menu option served with Mexican rice, salsa, cabbage salad and pico de gallo ($9.45)
*Beans (organic): No beans please!
*Tortilla: Spinach Tortilla
*Menu Option: Carne Asada (100% Grass Fed) +$0.50
*Make It Super: Yes (w/sour cream, jack cheese, & guacamole) +$1
*Smothered Burrito?: Red guajilo sauce
*Notes: NO SOUR CREAM, NO RICE

The burrito itself was pretty good. The carne asada had a nice smokey grill flavor. Not sure what cheese they used, but I couldn't really taste any cheese. And the guac was actually on top of the burrito instead of inside. That didn't bother me much as I didn't eat the tortilla so I just took the insides out and ate the burrito that way. Their site says they charge an extra $1.50 to get your burrito smothered, but Forkable didn't note that extra charge. I guess that's better as they smothered my burrito with green chile instead of the red sauce. Was a little bummed because of that. Not sure if it was Forkable's or Little Chihuahua's bad though.

If the cheese had been more prominent and they had smothered the burrito with the right sauce, I probably would have given them four stars. If they ever appear on Forkable again, I may give them another shot. The rest of the burrito was pretty good.
author: Elena N.

description:
This place is not at all authentic. Living so close by to TLC and relatively far from the Mission, I've tried a fair amount of this menu and am regularly disappointed, the biggest let down of all being the chilaquiles. The chorizo is bland and chips are stale. After living in Arizona, going to school in a border town, and moving to San Diego, maybe I'm used to a different type of Mexican food.

Regardless, I'm bummed as I really wanted to like this place for the sheer convenience. I'll probably still go in the hopes that something changes.
author: Steph L.

description:
I wouldn't make the claim that TLC serves the best Mexican food I've ever had, but I love this place anyway! No matter what you're craving, their huge menu is sure to satisfy, their ingredients and self-serve salsas are fresh, and their prices are reasonable. 

Apart from the food itself, I really appreciate the casual, chatty vibe, particularly at the Lower Haight location. Staff and patrons tend to be friendly and well mannered, which goes a long way in a tight space.
author: Reese H.

description:
I've always loved TLC ever since the first time I've eaten here.  I like their philosophy and their food.  It seems each time I go they just get busier and busier at least at this location.  Maybe because they're pretty solid.  

My go to is the Plantain burrito even though I'm not a vegetarian because its just as filling and there's something about the slight sweetness from the plantain that my taste bud loves. Tostada because there are so many wonderful things in it and both the soups, pozole and tortilla because it always warms me up on cold gloomy days in the city.  Their salsa bar is great especially with their free chips until our last visit.  We didn't get any so I'm assuming they are no longer gratis.  Still food is tasty and service is nice.  They also have sangria and decent beer selection.
author: Naty D.

description: Love the tostada salad - good portion size and can do any meat you like. Love the ingredients and eating the delicious bowl at the end! Solid choice for tacos as well, but the salad is surprisingly my go-to at TLC.
author: Abby H.

description:
Holy smokes. Set aside authentic because I can't be a great judge of that. This place is delicious! A little pricier than I was expecting, but after eating my meal I was totally ok with the price. Sustainable/organic and all that jazz.

Unfortunately you can't get a marg here, but there is wine and beer available. 

I had two phenomenal tacos:
1. Al Pastor Pork with guacamole, cabbage salad, smoky chile and pineapple salsas, chopped cilantro & onions.
 2. Garlic Shrimp with cabbage salad, sliced avocado and topped with garlic & tomatillo salsas, chopped cilantro & onions.

I am a major fan. Deeeeeeeeeelish.
author: Paige A.

description:
If you care more about where your ingredients came from than how they taste, the Little Chihuahua is for you. Basically Chipotle for hipsters - solid, Americanized Mexican food that happens to be organic, grass-fed and so on. In a just world its sheer virtue would make it tastier than it is. 
San Francisco has hundreds of really good Mexican restaurants and taquerias - try them.
author: M W.

description: Gluten free tortillas were pretty good! Burrito size is not comparable to more hole-in-the-wall-y places like Taqueria Cancun or other spots in the mission, but I was still plenty full. Free bowl of chips for the table and self-serve salsa bar tho
author: Sarah L.

description: Cannot go wrong ordering anything at this little Mexican spot. It's self service and a little bit cramped- but the food is so worth it! I got the al pastor pork quesidilla (amazing) and also tried the tortilla soup (little more watery than I expected but still super flavorful and a generous serving of avocado). The hot sauces here are also delicious - really liked the chipotle and habanero. They also serve beer from 21st amendment brewery and half 1/2 off wine bottles on tuesdays - so good
author: Sam M.

description:
Making Taco Tuesday delicious.
HANDS DOWN what an amazing place.  I love their Ensanada Fish Tacos.  They do not skimp on the fish and the black beans are just to die for.   I think this casual eatery is truly worth the wait and makes me want to try the other locations.
author: Elizabeth R.

description:
This is a fun restaurant with solid, if not hugely authentic, Mexican food. They have good quality ingredients and lots of delicious choices. I have had a few solid burritos and have also enjoyed their tacos. I like the carne asada. 

Allergy note: my experience has been that they are a peanut and tree nut safe restaurant. I have a friend with severe nut allergy issues who has been eating here for years. Please always talk to your server and carry any medication with you.
author: Sven S.

description: Pricey for what it is. Al pastor is dry but the burritos are pretty good. Salsa bar is awesome.
author: Kaitlin T.

description: Very solid Mexican food. I got the salmon tacos and the carne asada tacos. The salmon was better but it was also very close to their closing time. I'll come back and try them again during their peak hours.
author: Abe M.

description:
Not the most traditional, but will hit the spot. 

A "healthier"version of Mexican food with a self serving salsa bar. Walked in at 7:30 on a weeknight and it was packed. Be prepared to share table seating with others. Chips cost extra. 

Ordered: 
Garlic Shrimp Burrito $9-  Pretty good flavoring, but I still added some of that mole salsa. Burritos don't come with a side of rice and beans - if you don't pay for it. The shrimp was cooked *almost* to the edge of getting overcooked, so it was still good. Didn't have that fresh pop though, if you know what I mean. 
Chips $2- Crunchy goodness. Hit up that salsa bar for a taste test. 

It wouldn't be the first spot I'd pick if I had a hankering for Mexican food, but I'd be down to go if I was in the area and other people chose it.
author: Michelle C.

description: I am very pleased to have discovered Little Chihuahua. Great food and great salsas. Apparently they use only high grade ingredients, free range chickens etc. , which is surely one of the reasons why it sets them apart from many other taquerias. Tostada salad was fresh and tasty. Enchiladas are also very good.
author: Rumi R.

description: I like this place and the ingredients are supposedly top notch but the burritos are always a little watery so I just can't get behind the flavor like some of my other favorite spots.  Good chips and salsa bar and they have a good selection of beverages.  They also have gluten free wraps if that's your thing which is not very common.  I am probably in between a 3 and a 4 on this one.
author: Justin M.

description: We've been going here since they've opened back to whoever that was. We no longer live with walking distance but whenever we're back in town we B Line it to little chi! Brunch on the weekends we're always great with the plantanes and the huevos rancheros. The salads were our go to healthy and filing dinners. They've come long ways since they few tables that were in there and very few bodies. Now we generally have to get it to go since it's so packed. Go anyways, to won't regret it.
author: Raylan W.

description:
In a search for San Francisco's best salad?  Meet The Little Chihuahua.  Let's be clear:  I'm not suggesting that The Little Chihuahua has authentic Mexican cuisine nor am I asserting that their offerings are "the best of" across the board.  I wouldn't know, having had only one item.

But when you leave a place imagining how soon you can come back for the same thing you just ate that counts for something.  As you drive home across the bridge thinking how you can't wait to come back here with your friend, that counts for something else.  

When I ordered The Little Chihuahua's Tostada Salad ($10.95; with carne asada $1.50 extra) the friendly guy at the counter asked "have you had our salads before?"  then told me that I was "in for a treat; they're really good".  

That man speaks the truth.  

I ate at the Noe Valley outpost of TLC 5 years ago and - because I assume my yelp review was accurate - ordered the exact same thing as I did on my visit to this location.  Even though I thought this menu offering was quite good in 2011  it's clear that some things do improve with age.  TLC has had 5 years to achieve perfection and, with their Tostada Salad, they've done so.   

The Divisadero location isn't much to look at so it came as a complete surprise to find something so satisfying inside.  Looks don't count for everything though and when you see, then taste, this salad all other views will dim in comparison.  

Looking for a best in class salad?  The search is over.
author: Tracey A.

description: I just received a my $20 burrito and couldn't believe my eyes and nose.  This place burned the entire tortilla and peeled off the large burnt areas and left the small burnt areas.  My burrito looks and smells weird and I'm floored the restaurant would wrap and send something like this out for delivery!  #soconfused
author: Hanah L.

description:
This place is a little diamond in the rough, nested in between many other little restaurants. Their salsa bar is packed with a lot of different varieties to keep you going until your food arrives. 

We ordered enchiladas and the tortilla soup, which ended up being he star dish of the night to me. Cheese cubes, avocados and chicken with whatever wonderful blend of spices they added was absolutely delicious. 

Very authentic food and great customer service, we'll definitely be going back next time we're in SF. Happy to give this place 5 stars.
author: Eric T.

description: I had high hopes, but the tacos are were very average. I ordered chicken and shrimp, al pastor was slightly better but not great (tasted from a friend)
author: Sakshi D.

description:
This place is my go to burrito spot. In a city that caters to meat eating burrito lovers The Little Chihuahua is a haven. Try the fried plantain burrito. Just do it. It is incredible! My friend best described it, "It's like a burrito but a donut in the burrito!" Wise wise words by that young man. 

Also all their other stuff is good too.
author: Cynthia G.

description: This place is awesome! I got the veggie enchiladas, chips and split a carafe of margaritas with friends. They also had a salsa bar with several types of salsas to try. Everything was delicious! I highly recommend this place!
author: Anna A.

description:
I've been coming here regularly for around 2 years. Imho, this place has the best burritos in San Francisco. 

Incredibly high quality ingredients. Amazing salsas. Charming atmosphere.

It is pricier than other similar burrito joints in the mission, but the quality makes the extra $1-2 worth it
author: Craig M.

description: We've only ever had the taco salads but they are very good. This isn't the place for authentic Mexican food, but I enjoy the flavor of their salads with the pollo asado. I skip the bowl tortilla since its flour-based and substitute for a bed of tortilla chips instead. Fresh ingredients and predictable quality.
author: R A.

description: Ate here tonight with my roommates, and overall, and we agreed that we would come back again. There were a couple of things that stood out to us- it was very time efficient! You ordered at the counter and then found your own table, which we actually preferred. The food was good- big portions. I had the salmon tacos, which had a lot of salmon in them, which I was excited about, but it could have been seasoned more. I would have wanted it to have more of a kick. My friends had the enchiladas, the tortilla soup, and the fish taco, which they all enjoyed! Definitely not the best Mexican food I've ever had, but tasty and good value for your dollar!
author: Sonia S.

description:
Plain and simple: the Little Chihuahua is known for their fried plantain and black bean burrito because it's stupendous. As in, stupid good.

I also lust after their grass-fed carnitas, rich tortilla soup, premium salsa bar, and their signature smoky sauce. I could slather it on (almost) anything!

They are one of the few Mexican eateries in SF to offer gluten-free tortillas, and I'm so thankful as this allows me to satisfy my insistent burrito cravings. You know a restaurant is doing everything right when the establishment is perpetually full.

Now if only I could finally learn to spell the word "chihuahua" sans googling!
author: Jelena Z.

description: Is it like a mission taqueria? No... but hey, they've got a solid menu.  They're a little pricier than most taquerias in the city as well, but if you're in the neighborhood and craving a burrito, it's a good spot.  For those who need it, they also have gluten free tortillas, which means you can actually order a burrito instead of only being able to eat a taco... although they have tacos too, so it's a win win.  Well sorta, it's about $14 for a gfree burrito so it's a win for the tummy and a lose for the wallet...
author: Jen P.

description: My wife and I were both very pleased with the great walk up counter service and lightning fast food delivery to the table. We really liked seeing they purchased from sources that use sustainable farming as much as possible. Ended up ordering chicken nachos, tortilla soup along with carne asada & ensenada fish tacos. All the food was delicious, beers were cold, and salsa bar had something for everyone! We will be back on our next trip the Bay Area! Nice work y'all:)
author: Bry M.

description: Great spot for some great Mexican food. Friendly staff and you can tell they use quality ingredients.
author: Arsia A.

description:
Love this place...food is still amazing.  Vegetarian beans are still here! I always get the mushroom enchiladas with no queso fresco and green sauce. mmm!

They have a sauce bar with some yummy sauces.
author: Monica J.

description:
Great food and awesome staff!!
I've been to the Valencia street location and the Haight location and they are both great.
author: Matt G.

description:
*2 weeks Later*

After calling to notify them of the soupy burrito, the girl claimed she would mail me a coupon for a free entre. Still no coupon after 2 weeks. Called again on a Thursday. The guy took down my information: name, phone number and address. He claimed he needed to check with the "head honcho" to see if the coupon had been sent out. When I asked him to repeat my information to make sure he had it right, he hung up on me... -.- Thanks guys, way to treat your $15-burrito-paying customers.
author: Frank F.

description:
I really wanted to like this place way more than I actually did. After picking my copy of Rupi Kaur's Milk & Honey from The Booksmith, we were hungry and looking for a Mexican restaurant in the area that would satisfy our cravings. I had The Little Chihuahua bookmarked and had heard great things about it. I had heard that it was not only a little hipster but also healthy, organic, with a focus on offering sustainable and wholesome Mexican food without sacrificing taste. That was something I could get behind!

Walking in, the ambiance and concept of the restaurant was lovely! I loved the dimly lit lights and the whole atmosphere of the place. The place can get crowded on weekends and nights, but make sure to order before you take a seat! We ordered the al pastor and garlic shrimp burritos and a large serving ($1) for chips. 

I loved the salsa here. If anything, come here for chips and salsa!! The salsa flavors are incredibly dimensional and delicious. There's even labels and spicy levels. I really enjoyed the roasted one and the green one. You can really taste the difference in these tortilla chips. They taste healthier, cleaner and less oily, which I loved!!

Al pastor burrito: I enjoyed this one more than I expected. The flavor was alright but it wasn't ohmygod amazing like so many other places Mexican places I've been to. The meat was probably the standout part of this dish but it still wasn't spectacular. The flavor didn't strike me as unique or flavorful. To me, it was actually kind of bland. The overall taste of this burrito was just average, nothing that I would ever crave or return for.

Garlic shrimp burrito: Okay, I really really wanted to like this one. I love garlic and I love seafood so this was right up my alley. The garlic flavor hits you immediately but that's really all I tasted from it. The burrito overall was quite bland and I felt like I was just chewing a mush of ingredients without any prominent or spectacular taste coming from it. My tastebuds were not impressed. 

Especially at the price point of $25 for about two burritos, I expected a lot more from this place. As much as I tried to, I couldn't bring myself to really fall in love with either of burritos we got.
author: Nancy T.

description: Some of the best burritos outside the mission. I particularly like the way they cook the tortilla.. Mmm
author: David S.

description: I won't be coming back here!!! You guys need to update your menu online because the prices are wrong. I thought my meal would be $5 cheaper than it was. When I brung this up to the blonde chick working the cashier, she had a really nasty attitude about it, like I was bothering her. Sucks because, you guys are over priced, food isn't all that, and you have a cashier working there with a stanky, rude demeanor. So, it might be a good idea to adjust the prices online, so that others don't have to receive the same treatment I did.
author: Nelani G.

description: Came in Sunday for bruch, loved the pozole. It wasa little pricey but overall clean restaurant and great food. Parking was a pain but we managed.
author: Eva P.

description:
I went earlier today and had the Breakfast Tacos! Loved it! I'm definitely a fan!

I also had the taco salad too, which was fairly decent too. Huge portions though! Come hungry.

They also have the standard chips and salsa served like other Mexican restaurants.

This is definitely a good addition to the Haight neighborhood and a local favorite. Depending on the time, you could find yourself waiting in line for quite some time.
author: Chinsin S.

description:
Amatuer spot with modernised over-priced Mexican food. If you never had the Mexican food bug than you will probably be ok with this place. Once you go to Mexico or experience the more authentic places over on 24th its hard to be impressed by this place. 

I am reading good things about the al pastor here... I never tried it. Are they using a rotisserie like in Mexico? I doubt it. If they are, I may have to give it a second chance and try their most basic taco.
author: H K.

description:
After TLC, I'm convinced LA isn't the only place for a great taco.

-Wild Mushroom: Loved this! I nearly forgot I wasn't eating meat from the huge portion and texture of the mushroom medley. A must order for any mushroom lover. 
-Al Pastor: The meat portion of this is generous. I'm pretty sure I was full after the mushroom taco alone, but I could not get enough of the flavor of this al pastor. The chewiness of their corn tortillas were also a hit with me. Don't forget to stock up on the salsa bar!

This place is also pretty walkable from the Haight/Ashbury area.

Loved it! Will be back the next time I'm in town.
author: Nicole L.

description: This review is strictly for the shrimp tacos and burritos, which I've had a couple times. I want to like this place but I still don't get the rave reviews. The shrimp are small and lacking ummph. I've had both the regular and the garlic and found the garlic to be out of place (this is weird because Im usually a garlic fiend). I think you can get a better shrimp burrito/taco at El Metate, Papalote, and La Corneta (these spots have better seasoning and bigger shrimp). I also like El Farolito's, but that's just bc they use large shrimp cooked in a ton of butter. :)
author: Jean L.

description: The food is always packed full flavor. Place is always keep clean. Also place is always packed. Try anything cause no matter what you choose to eat its amazing! Very fast and several things are ready to go. Nice prices.
author: Madeline C.

description:
It was a late night in SF and my friend and I were craving burritos but weren't sure which Mission restaurant was well-known for the best burritos and we were also lost. In hindsight, I think we were looking for El Farolito but we came across this place. It was more expensive than the price range we were looking for but we were hungry and tired so we settled. 

I ordered the garlic shrimp burrito, which had avocado, black beans, rice, garlic salsa, and pico de gallo. It was just okay - the shrimp was kind of rubbery and for $12.45 I was expecting better. With so many options for Mexican food in the area, this restaurant just doesn't stand out.
author: Jack V.

description:
Great burrito. I get grilled chicken and shrimp. I wasn't a fan of the shrimp-flavorless. but the chicken flavor was amazing! 

Next time I'll go with just grilled chicken.  Fast, polite service.
author: Veteran m.

description:
Once, this place was my favorite spot to eat in the city (right when they opened and around 1-2 years after that).

Then something happened- they changed owners, or, having created a reputation of serving HUGE,  delicious tacos, they tapered the serving sizes down and again til we have what we have today- miserly portions, often served far too cold- as was the case today, when I returned for the last time. 

1 star for the salsa bar and nostalgia.
author: Grizzle J.

description:
Asked & paid for a Carne asada  super burrito to go, received a regular burrito, 95% rice, 5% meat, nothing else. Definitely not worth $14. Made me wish this spot was a Gordo's.

The staffs were friendly though.
author: William Y.

description: Cute spot, a little overrated and expensive. Wouldn't consider their food to be authentic, but it's a good location so I'd recommend it for a quick bite to eat before drinks or a night out.
author: Marie C.

description: An absolute favorite of mine! Been here more than two dozen times over the past few years of living in SF. Why? I like organic corn, I like knowing that my meat wasn't pumped full of hormones/chemicals, the staff are always friendly, the line moves fast, the salsa bar is tasty, they have gluten-free tortillas for a burrito, and the price is right. BAM, keep up the good work guys!
author: Jacquelyn M.

description:
Been here twice now - the first time I got the shrimp burrito. Flavor was good and the shrimp had a nice char but it was over cooked.  Went a second time and had the shrimp taco; this time the shrimp was cooked perfectly!  

There is a salsa bar available and was delicious!  Nice Mexican restaurant to visit if I'm in the area.
author: Tiffany L.

description: I really don't understand the hype about this place. The burritos were so small and hardly had any meat or anything in them. Don't come here if you're hungry.
author: Hel D.

description: Overpriced for a teeny tiny burrito. It felt disrespectful to Mexican food and overall was just trying too hard. There's unlimited pico de gallo though ~
author: Jin M.

description: The smothered burrito was yummy ! The taste was authentic...Its a bus-your-own table kind of place...Its difficult to get seating place n most likely it won't be cleaned after previous occupants..
author: Tejashree M.

description: Quality meet options, big portions, delicious taste, small and usually cramped, slightly overpriced....all that being said, worth it. I come here regularly and will continue to. The taco salad with half wild mushrooms and half chicken is perfect. Order ahead and take out is the way to go tho!
author: Leah M.

description: The plantain and black bean burrito wasnt that good. Tasted like a mushed banana randomly found its way in my burrito.
author: Hanna M.

description:
I was only ok on the spicy shrimp burrito. It was surprisingly spicy, so be warned if you're wimpy when it comes to heat. Also, if you're looking for a fattt burrito, this isn't it. Don't get me wrong, it's still plenty filling, but I know people sometimes scoff at burritos that aren't the size a newborn baby. 

The salsa bar is great. Very fresh an flavorful choices. You have to pay for chips (boo)

I definitely want to go back to try something else. I think I got confused by the menu or panicked or something because I didn't realize they had regular burritos too (steak, chicken, etc) that you could customize the type of fillings and got distracted by the pre-determined burrito menu items (i.g. shrimp burrito)

It gets a crowded fo sho.
author: Kelly G.

description: loved the scent of smoky pork and rice. Great blend of spices; a very clean flavor. I could, however, have appreciated a variety of items to add into our burrito, i.e. corn salsa, peppers, lettuce.. nevertheless, food was great quality. i was even impressed with their burrito wrap: soft, not soggy, and toasted to a certain crispness. i imagine i would have given them 4-stars had they included more vegetables for us to add into our burrito
author: Vicky T.

description: TLC has some of the best guacamole I've had in San Francisco! They also have a good salsa bar. The fried plantain and refried burrito is a good vegan option (minus the cheese and sour cream). I've been to the Divisadero location mostly, but it seems easier to find parking and a table at the Valencia location.
author: Rebecca H.

description:
Very friendly staff, always very polite.  

I've tried a lot of the menu, but my favorite is the shrimp tacos and tortilla soup.  Ingredients are always fresh and of a high quality, highly recommended
author: Terence T.

description: Pozole and salad are great options. Had the carnitas burrito for first time tonight and was very disappointed, barely any meat, no guacamole or cheese despite being super option and overall tasted like a bean burrito.
author: David M.

description: Delicious little neighborhood joint. My fiance got the Taco Salad and I had 3 of their tacos. The carne asada taco was amazing. Come with an appetite!
author: Jordan K.

description:
Want to get a great meal, cheap price and leave satisfied, well then you have come to the right place.  Upon walking into the front door, you are quickly greeted with a family style, quaint restaurant.  The style here is place your order at the counter, take a number and pick a seat.  Since the place was crowded we did have to sit with some random's.  

I ordered the garlic shrimp burrito.  After reading the menu, was craving some beans and rice and thought that I would test this one out. The serving size as very filling, however after I consumed all of the salsa, it lacked some flavor.  I could only consume about 3/4 of it purely because of getting full not due to taste.  

They do serve organic chips, a cool idea!  There is a salad bar set up, where you can pick which kind of salas you would like.  They are rated on spiciness as well.  I enjoyed the floor of the salas and chips the most.

Throughout the restaurant there are photos of Spanish objects with the word listed below.  If nothing else you will leave the place with a full belly, and having learned a few new Spanish words.
author: Brittany W.

description: Good Mexican food. The Agave-wine Margarita is cool. Staff is friendly. Sunday 7:30pm was busy and took 15-20min to get the food.
author: Parker G.

description:
Delicious burritos!!! My boyfriend's favorite is the garlic shrimp - so amazing. Juicy pieces of shrimp - mouth is watering now - and the garlic flavor is strong so if you're on a date, share it so neither of you have to worry about your breath haha.
I did a bit of a custom order with the wild mushrooms and al pastor super baby burrito. It was the size of a regular burrito which was surprising considering it was "baby" but no complaints here! Great flavor and texture - I was super satisfied!!
Really personable staff (:
author: Mio W.

description: This place was delicious! We came here for a quick dinner while visiting my step-brothers Thanksgiving weekend. It's a small, self-seating restaurant where you order up at a counter and they bring your food out to you. The salsa bar is wonderful - our favorite was the roasted tomato salsa. The pico de gallo wasn't bad either. We ordered a pitcher of margaritas and they were pretty good - a tad bit sweet, but overall, good. I ordered the guacamole enchiladas - three enchiladas with a side of beans and rice. The enchiladas ended up coming out without the guacamole inside (as did one other persons in our party). Once we brought it to their attention, though, they were very quick in calling a manager out and remedying the situation. It wasn't a big deal so we told them not to remake the enchiladas. They brought out bowls of guac instead - just as good :) Their guac was delicious, their enchiladas, were delicious, and the rice and beans were flavorful! Overall, I really enjoyed this place and highly recommend it for a quick mexican meal!
author: Ritu D.

description:
Tried to go to Nopalito for dinner one Thursday night and realized we didn't feel like waiting (the wait was an hour) so we strolled a bit and found TLC. 

I had never been here before and was a bit skeptical but was actually very happy and satisfied with my meal. 

I ordered the Carne Asada Plate, chips and guac and a glass of cab. LOVED the carne asada plate - was able to make my own tacos!

Definitely ordering the burrito next time, it looked amazing!
author: Ilana B.

description: The plantain and black bean burrito or taco are amazing! The staff can be a bit pretentious, but overall a good place.
author: Robin O.

description: One of the best Mexican food joints in the city. I love going here and it never disappoints. I love the veggie burrito and the chicken tacos. Everything is organic which is great.
author: Karim N.

description:
All the right flavors, and what a lovely bunch of food!

The setting is just perfect, and the vibe is excellent. When you look around you see people smiling and eating. 

Shrimp burrito. The food of the gods.

Come here, read the wonderful menu, order as much as you can happily manage, and enjoy!
author: William M.

description: The Fried Black Bean Tacos are amazing! It's truly so good that I haven't even bothered to order anything else on the menu. It's also great in Burrito form too! They're Chipotle salsa is one of the best salsa's I've ever had. It's great with chips and just about anything and everything on their menu! It's great for a quick and delicious bite to eat.
author: Jackie K.

description:
Great Carnitas, fresh quality ingredients, and you can call in your order, which is really useful since it's often extremely busy. 

The only negative is that I'd say it's not worth it to upgrade to a Super Burrito. They never put enough guacamole/avocado in it (which is the whole reason I order a Super Burrito!)
author: Stephanie C.

description:
I used to be a regular here but realized over the past year that prices have gone up and portions have gotten smaller. Not sure if it's just when order to go but just ate a $12 dollar burrito that was size of what I think of being a kids size or baby burrito. I've had great enchilada plates there so think this is mainly a issue with there burrito portions.

I think their flavors are great but when I leave hungry after an expensive burrito I am pretty disappointed. 

Overall I just hope they can step up their portions and would go back if so.
author: Jamai L.

description: The salsa was the harbinger of the great meal to come.  He ordered a garlic shrimp burrito which was amazing. I ordered enchiladas,  one carne asada and one pollo asada, covered in green sauce. Truly incredible.  We slowly washed them down with the refreshing house margaritas made from agave wine and fresh squeezed Orange juice. We look forward to coming back and enjoying more relaxed fabulous meals.
author: Michele A.

description:
We wanted some "healthier" food, so we came here for some chicken nachos.  So good.  It was PACKED on a Friday night, but we still managed to get a table.  Even though it was crowded, the line moved quickly and food still came out without me getting hangry.  

I definitely recommend the nachos, they're on point:  good ratio of toppings, crisp chips, and a side of salsa from the salsa bar.   YUM.
author: Lyn C.

description: Delicious and freshly made for sure. I have ordered almost the whole menu already and reordered and reordered again. My favorites are the fried plantain & black burrito, and the salmon taco. But the whole menu is a killer. Give you try and you won't regret it.
author: Ana A.

description:
The food is fast casual with solid ingredients.
The sauces are good.
The meat is great.
The taco bowels are definitely worth looking into if you want more greens and a nice portion.

Portions are moderate, enough the fill you up not enough to break into two meals.

This is in Alamo square not in the mission so if your looking for a authentic taqueria your going to have to go there, but if you want ingredients that are sourced well for a fresh taste and want something relatively fast go here.
Also beer is on tap and in bottle which is great because beer always goes great with Mexican style food. 

Also I work in the area and stop by here now and then.
The guy who works the front (who's name I don't remember unfortunately) and is always wearing Hawaiian shirts is awesome. I've come in with my partner who because of a restricted diet usually adds or makes orders a little more complex and he whizzes through it no problem. His suggestions are informative and genuinely hospitable. This isn't a spot I frequent extremely often or enough to be a regular every week kind of customer but every time I'm there I see this guy going above and beyond with me or someone else.
author: Lauren C.

description:
Really this place is jut ok. .  It's too costly for things that are easily a fraction cheaper elsewhere. Also it took too long for my Taco to come. Also they charge for chips. The salsa verde isn't real & felt like it came from a jar or can. My beloved Taqueria SAN Jose & La Corneta has more authentic tasting Taqueria items. I only came here outta convenience. Truthfully for what I paid for at TLC, is 2 days worth of meals at Taco Bell/ KFC & other places. I don't plan a return visit unless it's really 
needed. 

Pros: 
1. convenient for being in lower Haight by Divisadero & Haight as a Taqueria. 
2. Salsa bar & water jug. 
3. Very clean & romantic setting.

Cons: 
1. Very overpriced for such simple items! Many taquerias in the Mission & Excelsior are more affordable.
2. Too crowded & noisy. 
3. Due to online ordering, they don't have a separate station or team doing them so ordering a taco takes about 30 minutes on a Wednesday evening.
4. Overrated.
author: R C.

description: Not very good food. Its all organic Wich is nice and all but doesn't make up for the how bad the food is. I had a shrimp burrito was over all unsatisfied. Wouldn't recommend this and probably won't come back. It was also expensive as are most places in this area.
author: Eric B.

description:
Pathetic.  Just pathetic.

First off, when you order a burrito, you expect to be fed a BURRITO! The burrito I ordered (Super steak burrito) was the size of a snickers bar! I was definitely not myself after eating this.  The charge: $29.00.  

Lord Jesus! Talk about inflation! We must be headed for the end of the world because this place definitely marked up the price and skimmed on the ingredients.



Do not eat here.  Ever!
author: Brent M.

description: I've tried a couple dishes here, but my favorite is the garlic shrimp burrito. Really good and flavorful, and definitely enough to fill you up! The other things I've had here weren't as exciting to me, but I come back here again and again, just for that garlic shrimp burrito. Try it!
author: Grace D.

description: I had the garlic shrimp taco and the margarita. The taco came with two tortillas and several shrimps. I split the contents onto 2 tortillas and made 2 tacos. On the first bite, the garlic taste was prominent. I enjoyed it. I added jalapeno. It tasted great. The salsa with chip was amazing. The margarita tasted refreshing. Overall I enjoyed myself and would certainly come back.
author: Carina L.

description: After eating here I felt like a "Fat Chihuahua". I came to visit from orange California and it was great food. I had the bfast burrito and the stacked enchiladas. Both were great but if I must choose I'd go with the enchiladas. The two beverages which are a must were the sangria and the home made horchata. Will be back.
author: Christian O.

description:
TLDR: Pretty pricy for Mexican food, especially since everything looks like something a frat boy could whip up in his kitchen while in a drunken stupor.


We were in the area looking for places to eat, I ended up picking this place over Thai food because it was pretty hyped up. I decided to get a burrito to share with my BF since we had both been snacking quite a lot and were already pretty full. I got a shrimp burrito +guacamole to go for $13.50 and went back to our friends place feeling pretty good about our purchase.

Once we got back and pulled it out, we realized it was less of the giant burrito explosion we had expected and looked a little more like the frozen burritos you find in convenience stores. Undeterred we excitedly cut our burrito in half ready to eat. The first thing I noticed was there was a lot of shrimp which was good, but the shrimp was also completely unspiced. It tasted like someone threw it on a wok for a few minutes and added salt. There was also a glaring LACK of guacamole in the burrito. The rice and beans were at least the right texture, but it was pretty flavorless. In the end, most of the taste came from the shit ton of salsa that we had to pile onto our burritos. 

I'd give this place a 2.5 stars but the fact that they didn't give me my guacamole is effed up and pushes them down to a 2. I'd probably never come back here again because you can get waaayy better Mexican food for way cheaper pretty much anywhere else.
author: Melissa Z.

description: YES! best tacos in the city and monstrous. Love this place and the salsas.
author: Mike A.

description: Not impressed. Ordered in for a prawn burrito. Small shrimp, small burrito. Fifty cents extra for chips? Fuck off.
author: N'olo J.

description:
Pros 
- food is delicious. Great tacos. 
- reasonable prices 

Cons
- often busy and tough to find a table
author: Greg M.

description:
- I've been to this place over 50 times and I can't get enough of it.
- My two favorites are the carne asada fajita burrito: the steak is so juicy and the grilled peppers and onions are a great touch, and the al pastor burrito: the pork is amazing, and it pairs really well with their pineapple salsa.
- Don't forget to get some salsas! Their chipotle salsa is amaze-balls.
- They take Apple Pay, via Square! Love paying with my phone :-).
- You can always order ahead via phone, and your order is prepped super quickly (between 5-10 minutes).
author: Wesley K.

description:
Where do you go to grab a takeout lunch while waiting for your car to be washed?
That's what brought me here on a sunny weekday afternoon.  It's about 1.5 blocks from the Divisadero Touchless Car Wash.  The line was a bit long and the tummy was grumbling loudly.  Just one search on my Yelp app and, voila!
There are tables for self seat dining  but many just hung outside on the steps to enjoy the summer weather.  The dining room was about half full as the cashier called out names for order pickups.  After a quick study of the menu, I ordered a Super chile verde chicken burrito with pinto beans, hold the sour cream (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q&select=wCxMiOHLg6UAzmhLreEXrw) with a side of chips for an extra $0.50.  Needing to rush back to the office after this, dining here was not an option.  While waiting at a nearby table, I noticed their salsa bar which had six or eight flavors to choose from.  I chose the pico de gallo and the ranchera sauce (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q&select=nzXz2mO9kPvvDpdlMIgOrg) which were perfect contrasting flavors for my need.  I'd have tried every flavor if time wasn't a factor.  After about eight minutes, I walked towards to counter to inform him that I would be back after picking up my car, but, guess what, he handed me my order instead.  The food ranks a three plus as I am spoiled with La Corneta being my go-to spot close to home.  The big pluses are for the sauce choices and the speediness in filling my order (+0.5 star).  Didn't know that this is one of many editions of restaurants and the prices are a bit higher than I'm used to ($11.00 and change before tip).  Sold 3.5 stars, rounding up to four.
If I'm hungry again while waiting for my car to be washed, this is probably where you'll find me.
author: Mike C.

description:
My favorite Mexican in San Francisco. Why would you ever visit that other place that starts with a "c"? --oh yeah, they're cheaper. But this is so totally worth it! The steak and shrimp burritos are my favorite (respectively). Full of flavor, filling, and it comes in a baby size for those of us who don't want to get fat! Oh, and did I mention? They have gluten-free tortillas too.

The Noe Valley location is cleaner than this one. But I bet this one is busier.
author: Omar Y.

description:
A little pricey, but boy is the burrito delicious. I was on my vegetarian day but seriously craved a burrito -- which is, unless you settle for something crappy, one of the least vegetarian food there is on the planet.

Until I came across the black bean and plantains burrito here. Whoa, this is serious! There's a kick in the burrito, as well as sweetness coming from the plantains. The flavours are well balanced, and gives your tummy a serious "oomph" when you finish the whole thing, because it is hefty.

Next time I'm in the neighbourhood I'm heading here right away! Or, if they would like to open up a branch in the peninsula... *hint hint*
author: Alice C.

description: Get the nachos. End of story. They have the best and biggest nachos in the city. I'll go get my car washed down the street then hop over to devour the nachos. They give great portions of all the toppings too.
author: Jenna G.

description:
TLC should stand for Totally Loaded with Carbs. Because that's exactly what makes it full of tender lovin' care...care for those newly formed love handles.

FRIED PLANTAIN & BLACK BEAN BURRITO with cheese, roasted red bell peppers, rice, sour cream, smoky chile salsa, pico de gallo and fresh cilantro & onion, $9.95 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-little-chihuahua-san-francisco?select=iITHl9nJkHqQTnr_PKXApA#KNuPZB_rhmYgIXewRZkbWg). Comes with your choice of beans, mexican rice, salsa, cabbage salad and pico de gallo. Holy moly this is addictively good. The fried plantains are smushily sweet and pair well with the numerous savory and herby ingredients. I was so glad I had leftovers so that I could experience this burrito twice in one day.

I also tried my friend's CARNITAS TACO on an organic corn tortilla with cabbage salad, cilantro, onion, fresh salsa and guacamole, $4.25 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-little-chihuahua-san-francisco?select=LrVL4_c7vwIGD9WvKRMi6Q#S1bt8uFudyyBUJa4JywFnQ). Not gonna lie, it was kinda bland. I would pass on this one.

Additional info: seating is communal tables. Order at the front, grab your free chips, go crazy at the salsa bar, wait for your order to be delivered, devour said order, and bus your table.

CARBS FO' DAYS. That's how you do it.
author: Adele F.

description: Swung by for some tacos after playing pool at The Page. It's a cute little spot that kind of gives off hipster vibes --not your typical taqueria. I got 2 fried fish tacos. They were drowning in dry cabbage, but the fish underneath was pretty good.
author: Patricia L.

description: Really great mexican food. Would not have expected it to be a chain restaurant! Tostada salad was amazing.
author: Jeffrey Z.

description:
WOW AMAZING, so fresh, so flavorful, so absolutely perfect. This pollo asada taco salad I had was an experience. Where do I begin? The crispy shell it came in for one...there was some kind of cinnamon in that flaky yumminess. The black beans were so home made tasting it made me smile in appreciation. They use spring greens rather than the usual mix of romaine and iceberg you commonly see in taco salads. & it really works sooo well. Now about that salsa or dressing or whatever it is. This is the special sauce that I was loving and attempting to deconstruct. Mild spiciness, mango bits, citrusy zest and just the right amount throughout the salad.

TLC does taco salads right. I can't wait to try the other items!!!!
author: Lisa K.

description:
Three words: gluten free tortillas! 

I haven't had a burrito since a doctor last instructed me to eliminate wheat from my diet. Needless to say, I was super stoked when I saw that Little Chihuahua offered gluten free tortillas.

I came here with two friends on a rainy Saturday evening for dinner. I got the baby burrito, and my two friends got a super burrito and chicken enchiladas. You place your order at the counter, get a number, grab your own salsa, and seat yourself. I wouldn't say they're my favorite Mexican spot, but I will definitely be coming back in the future. 

Beware, there isn't much seating in the restaurant, and it was a bit packed when we went. The seating is in the form of long tables (think school cafeterias) and you might have to sit right next to other diners. If you're looking for a more intimate place to eat, I'd look somewhere else. If you're going after a casual and tasty meal, I'd give this place a shot.
author: Cindy Y.

description: The veggie plantain burrito is delicious, add guacamole + salsa and it becomes spectacular. Went at 6pm on a Sunday evening and it took about 20+ minutes to order food and take it to-go, maybe order ahead.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
The Little Chihuahua is OK.  Not the most authentic Mexican restaurant, sadly. 100% Grass-Fed. The place is small, and operates on a first come, first serve basis, like a taco truck, but in a established building. Not totally alot of room for the seven of us on a Friday evening.  

You just order at the counter, and then they will serve you the food, otherwise you bus yourself when you are done. 

I went with my sister's family for dinner. We ordered alot of different items.  I started out with the TORTILLA SOUP.  It was piping hot, with spicy chicken broth (but not alot!) served w dice chicken, avocado, queso fresco, fire roasted corn & tomato. Garnished with Pico de gallo, tortilla chips, and guajillo chili's. This soup was AMAZING!  I have to say at least half of us ordered the soup.  Next I ordered the GRILLED SHRIMP TACO, with cabbage salad, sliced avocado, garlic & tomatillo salsa chopped cilantro and onions.  That was OK. However it was lacking in flavor. 
With our meal I had a Watermelon Agua Fresca to drink. It was quite refreshing. 
For my main I ordered THE SIGNATURE LITTLE CHIHUAHUA TOSTADA SALAD, diced chicken, organic mixed greens, avocado (a quarter) , Pico de gallo, quesco fresco, black beans, cucumbers, mango salsa, & roasted bell peppers with a lime-cilantro dressing served on top of crispy tortilla shell.  While it was good, and huge, I think the flavors were a bit off. I'm not sure if it was the mango salsa or what.  I didn't think I would be able to finish it, but I did manage to eat a good chunk of the salad (minus the crispy tortilla shell bowl). 
TLC also has a salsa bar with about 6-8 different salsa's. I think my preferred salsa was the Chipotle salsa. I liked the smokiness. Their chips are average, served warm.  Our whole table ordered some Guacamole & Chips, a little watered down for the Guac, not what we're use to. My sister & family ordered burritos, tacos, enchiladas, along with the Mexican rice & beans. They thought it was pretty good, however, laking again, that punch of flavor. Like I said, not very authentic mexican, but not a horrible dinner either. 

TLC is super casual.  My overall impression?  With all the Mexican places out there, including my two absolute favorites Lisa's in Daly City and Tacqueria San Bruno I think you can get more bang for your buck at either of those places, and the food is wayyyyy better. 

I don't think I would return to TLC unless I happened to be in the neighborhood. It was also very crowded and noisy.
author: Janet T.

description:
This place is a hole in the wall but serving really good authentic Mexican food. I've ordered their special garlic shrimp burrito(12$) on whole wheat with black beans. Burrito beat my expectations hands down. The taste is superb like in expensive restaurant, hints of garlic till the last bite but balanced and not overwhelming. Ingredients are proportionate and complement each other with each bite.

Salsa bar- free and so much variety; I have tasted three of them and all were very mild, fresh and tasty! I think it was done on purpose so you can actually taste the food and not the spice of salsa. 

Place is packed but well worse the wait. I will try their famous grilled salmon taco next time I visit.
author: I R.

description:
Maybe the burritos are good, but the tostada salad and the quesadilla were lacking.

Tostada Salad with Camarones: Oversauced beyond belief. I actually couldn't finish it because it was dripping with sauce. Couldn't taste the ingredients. And there were like only 5 teeeeeny tiny shrimp in my salad. SHRIMP ARE CHEAP! Give me more shrimp. That being said, the tostada shell of the salad was Delicious. 

Quesadilla with Chicken: Looks beautiful but it was kind of flat. Everything was too soft. You expect a quesadilla to have a more toasted and crustier shell. 

We went tonight and it was surprisingly packed for 9:50 pm. We waited in line behind 3 groups to order at the counter. At least we had chips to tide us over as we waited for our food; the salsa bar (especially the habenero) is pretty darn delicious.
author: Sylvia L.

description:
Maybe not the most authentic Mexican food you can find, but it's delicious, affordable, and extremely customizable/health-conscious! A lot of delicious options for vegans and vegetarians out there too :)

You can choose your beans, tortilla (spinach, wheat, etc.) and most things on the menu are under $10. I've tried the baby burrito and the fajita burrito and both were really really good and chipotle-sized (yas!). They also have a salsa bar and yes, load that baby upppp

They also have a breakfast/brunch menu that I've yet to try!
author: Jingxi Z.

description:
1 - DELICIOUS FOOD - fried plantain and black bean burritto is so delicious and unique. Debatably better than a san diego cali burritto!

2 - SALSA BAR - expected the tasty pico de gallo, but the tomatillo and roasted red pepper salsas are out of this world!

3 - FREEish CHIPS - think they are charging 50 cents now but u get a huge basket of them and they are fresh and delicious and just the perfect thickness.

4 - DRINKS - housemade horchata - do it!

5 - Service is great, guy at the counter made me and my friend smile, what more can you ask for for!
author: Kimia M.

description:
I ordered the "Fried Plantain & Black Bean Burrito With cheese, roasted red bell peppers, rice, sour cream, smoky chile salsa, pico de gallo and fresh cilantro & onion."

Wow, this was honestly amazing.  I was transitioning into a vegetarian diet and was delighted to find an amazing burrito without meat.  The plantains were cooked perfectly and provided an amazing texture that complimented the flavors of the black beans and other ingredients.  I would honestly say this was one of the best burrito's I've ever head in my life.
author: Cole D.

description: I got the Chile Verde tofu burrito  and it was good but I felt it was lacking some flavor. The chips that cost about 60 cents were hot and delicious.
author: Kimberly G.

description:
The first couple times I came here I was unimpressed. I think a few more times and I have had it, I gave it a chance but I'm just so unsatisfied. I have decided its going to take a ton of peer pressure to go back. 
However, they earn one big star for the amazing salsa. 

Why the two star. the food has always been a huge disappointment, a huge overpriced disappointment. It's not overpriced by much, just enough dissuade me.

The carne assada had always tasted "off" and the most raved about item on the menu is poorly endowed. Poor little burrito. 

I'm just not sure why there's no good reasonably priced Mexican food in this neighborhood. 

This place its not Ben approved!
author: Ben M.

description:
As am owner of a half chihuahua and half pug I understand this name. It might be a little restaurant but it's food is intensely delicious. Ok maybe that is not where the name came from but the food is intensely delicious.
Their plantain burrito always hits my spot. The other day I upped my burrito by adding beef. Honestly, I preferred it meatless. It takes away from the taste of the plantains.
But next time I am going to get a tostada salad bowl. The girl next to me got one and it made my burrito look mediocre.
author: Julianna I.

description: Got a pastor burrito paid $13 to come and find out it's a plain burrito barely any meat should've ordered a regular bean and rice burrito since that's what I basically got
author: Leslie L.

description: TLC lives in a little restaurant home in the Haight. When busy it is hard to find a seat or get some elbow room. The line ordering and mostly self-serve model works well to get people in and out. Food is very good whether you're getting burritos or tostada salad as the meats are high quality  and well done. Think about it as Hipster Chipotle with a little more gourmet.
author: Ed L.

description:
Chicken Super Burrito was mighty tasty and sadly there were no leftovers for me to enjoy.  El Farolito still holds #1 as my fav burrito spot but if you don't want to trek it to the Mission, then this is your next best bet.  A bit pricier but still worth it.

Communal style seating, so you could be making new friends and/or overhearing other patron's conversations as there's 2 8 tops and a few 2 tops in the restaurant.
author: Jill S.

description:
Food was very good, however they could do a better job keeping the place clean.  There was a pair of underwear under a table. The problem was that  when I mentioned it to one of the employees, he did not seem surprised. 
If the place was clean, I would definitely have had a better experience. There was food (chips and napkins) all over the floor.
author: Jo G.

description:
There's something wrong with you if your paying 4.50 for a taco EVER. It was a good carne asada taco but no better then a street taco by a long shot. I hope these cooks are being paid properly because they must know how absolutely outrageous the price per taco is. 

You don't even have topo chico. 

-Frank
Latino
Tex-Mex
Proud San Antonioian
author: Frank B.

description:
I've loved this place for years but it's been declining for a while and it's reaching new lows.

The management seems to be riding on laurels and doing nothing about it. Half of my friends won't eat here anymore. I'd like to count myself among them but there's nothing else I like on the street.

The biggest issue is the front of house. The owner needs to stop hiring hippies that don't bathe and start doing random drug tests -- there are lots of people who would be happy to work here and would put a good face on the business. I'm sick of giving my order to a stoned cashier who always gets something wrong.

...as I'm writing this over a hugely screwed-up order taken by a guy with bloodshot red eyes and BO. Wrong chips, no cheese, guac on everything though I asked for none, and almost no meat on the $5 taco. This happens all too frequently.

Portions have been shrinking, charging for a pittance of chips. The bussing area is disgusting. It's a matter of time before more long time patrons like me become pushed to writing negative reviews.

But it's not hard to fix. Please fix it!
author: Jono S.

description: Was a lot better when they first opened. Good food, but small portions and so expensive! Living in the neighborhood I'd rather go to the mission to get a decent price and good portion burrito.
author: Oriana S.

description:
I've had a loooooot of Mexican food in San Francisco since moving here. This city has a rich Mexican heritage, and the food testifies to it. But no taqueria has failed to meet my expectations as much as this place. To be clear: this is the worst Mexican restaurant I've eaten at in San Francisco.
