Let's start with my drink: a margarita. All wrong. These are the classic elements of this beautiful drink: tequila, triple sec, and lemon/lime juice. When mixed together in the right proportions, they are fantastic. My margarita tasted mostly like lemon juice and sweetener (maybe agave syrup). If that sounds like lemonade to you, it's because it tasted like lemonade to me. Served in a tall 16oz glass filled to the rim, I couldn't detect the tequila because the cocktail had been so diluted. This is amateur hour. Not to mention that it took a good 10 minutes for my boyfriend and I to even get our drinks in the first place--after we were served our food.

Oh yeah, the food. My Al pastor burrito was a mess. While the pork was marinated, it had such a weak texture that it might have been microwaved. Served with a heavy dose of refried black beans and rice, there was nothing stand-out about a burrito that cost $12.

I'm lucky that I didn't order the quesadilla. My boyfriend had a chicken quesadilla filled with sauteed onion slices. The chicken was bland.

The restaurant tries way too hard to present an upscale ambiance. It's just pretentious. It's like the owners walked into Troipsueño and decided to copy everything except the delicious menu. This overpriced establishment can't compare with Nopalito, which is less than a few blocks away, or El Rancho Grande, which is worth the walk from here.
author: Robert F.

description:
You had me at shrimp garlic burrito.

Okay, so maybe this filling dinner wasn't ideal before a show at The Independent, but it happened and I regret nothing.

The small, dark burrito/taco spot on Divis lived up to all the hype. The menu is filled with clean, colorful options ranging from veg to full carnivore. And if you're crazing an ice cold tecate or marg to wet your whistle, you're in the right spot.

Perf spot for a quick dinner with friends or quick burrito pick up to take home and binge like last season of Girls.
author: Rachel H.

description: Great, cozy and very friendly place. Loved the sangria and tacos. Perfect place for special occasions, get together or just to chill.
author: Finley O.

description:
This is such a knock off of a taqueria. 

10 bucks for two chicken tacos that are dry?? Not to mention the fact that Weezer playing over the sound system. 

Feels like cultural appropriation to me...
author: Spiferina P.

description:
The tostada salad is BOMB! 

I also tried their garlic shrimp burrito, but the star of the show was definitely the tostada salad. 

The server was really helpful when recommending and even offered free tortilla chips with our order. There is a also self-serve salsa bar with lots of choices. 

This is a great spot to pop in for a quick lunch with some friends!
author: Justine H.

description:
I am on a mission to save the endangered plantain burrito. I did not know they even existed until I went some friends took me to Cu Co's last year. My five star review of that place did not save it from going extinct - but hopefully TLC will fare better. 

I Alta Vista'd "plantain burritos" and the search results show only Cu Co's (closed) and TLC as having them. So this may be the last wild refuge of its kind!

Hopefully this place will stay open - and others will embrace the plantain burrito filling!
author: Stuart F.

description: My first time coming here. Came with my girlfriend and my two older sisters. I ordered carnitas nachos with rice on the side and I thought it was OK. A lot of food for just one person, which is great, but the chips were really stale which is why I gave them a 3/5. My older sister got the carne asada tostado salad and that was really good. I would recommend that instead. Other than that, the place is really small and was packed by the time we got our food on a Tuesday night. Prepare to not find parking at all, but that's normal in the city. Would definitely come back again, but just for the tostado salad.
author: Kristian L.

description:
The Little Chihuaha. TLC. 

Okay, it's pricier than most of the Mission taquerias. But you know what? TLC uses higher quality meats and compostable takeaway containers. More recently, they began charging for chips because they're made from organic corn and were probably tired of people just throwing them away casually, wasting precious food. 

While I get that people are pissed 'cause this place doesn't have the same price points as a lot of taquerias, TLC's business practices are more environmentally conscious, while the classic Taqueria model is more conscious about cultural preservation. Not knocking either, I'm from San Diego and love classic Taqueria food. But it's reassuring to know that the meat you're eating is from animals who were grass-fed and pastured and that the containers will be easily broken down in the composting process.

If you want to spend less $$, you're still going to get tasty food, but it will be with lower quality (i.e. factory-farmed) meat, accompanied by a bunch of plastic that's just going to get thrown away. Again, not knocking either option, and many people do not have financial access to places like TLC, but if you have the money to spend on quality, at least once in a while, then why not?

I've frequented the Divisadero location far more times than this location, but have gone twice in the last two weeks because TLC on Valencia is closer to my work.

My favorite thing to get has always been a regular salmon burrito with black beans. Eat that thing with tons of the roasted tomato salsa, because it's the best I've had in the city. The past couple of times I've come to this location I've gotten the Ensenada fish tacos and they are so good and crispy fresh! These Ensenada ones aren't grilled, they're fried, but do not feel greasy or heavy. 

With Negra Modelo on tap, you really can't go wrong.
author: Megan D.

description:
This place was absolutely amazing-great service and great food.  I ordered the plantain and black bean burrito with a child tomato tortilla and they were more than happy to make my burrito spicy for me.  Great flavor, perfect amount of size and good/big portion size.  Their salsa bar looked a bit messy, but the two salsas I tried (out of like 6?) were really great.

If you order ahead of time and are picking up, there's a separate register you go to on the other side of the line, which is somewhat hard to get to because of how many people are in there.
author: Sonam J.

description:
Such a good go-to spot in the neighborhood. 

I only order two things: 

* Fried Plantain & Black Bean Burrito: with cheese, roasted red bell peppers, rice, sour cream, smoky chile salsa, pico de gallo and fresh cilantro & onion. - Delicious and filling! Plus they have gluten free tortillas!

* Tortilla Soup: Spicy chicken broth served with chicken, avocado, queso fresco, fire-roasted corn and tomato, garnished with pico de gallo, tortilla chips and guajillo chiles. - I could live off of this soup. I try making my own... but I just can't get it quite right - so I'll keep getting my fix at TLC! 

I'm sure everything else is wonderful - but it is so hard to try new things when you have not only one but two go-to options. 

The Little Chihuahua has saved me on many nights where - 1) I don't feel like cooking 2) I want something in walking distance 3) I don't want to spend $30 on dinner 4) and is just plain delicious. 

Plus the staff is A++
author: Shannon H.

description:
Nope...went back and got a super chorizo burrito. Asked for extra meat and they charged me 16 bux.

Burrito came out and it was one of the smallest burritos Ive ever had in SF.

Sorry. Ill stick with the usuals unless someone else is payin the bill.
author: Mario W.

description: A little dirty, but the burrito was great. Loved the salsa bar! Their chips were really good too. The burrito had great flavor, but I upgraded to the super burrito and could barely taste any guac or sour cream. I actually thought they left it off until about halfway through.
author: Lauren S.

description:
This place is realllly good and I am not sure if I'm happy boyf introduced me to it bc my mouth is very pleased or if this was horrible bc now I"m gonna get really effing fat.

We drunkenly stuffed our faces between holiday parties with a garlic shrimp burrito and carne asada nachos. Everything was awesome. + their salsas, beyond awesome.

They take credit, yay.
author: Vivian H.

description:
We just love this place!  I've never had a dish I didn't like.  Their eye for quality ingredients touches every piece of their food and I love how they prioritize local sources.  Particular favorites for me are the chorizo nachos (DANGEROUSLY good), carne asada enchiladas, and any kind of burrito.  Their chipotle salsa is also excellent - we regularly take a little bit extra. :-)

This place is small, so expect to be seated very close to other diners, but the atmosphere is very relaxed and everyone is eating delicious food, so the close quarters doesn't seem to bother anybody.  Everything is wooden, which adds a nice rich note to the atmosphere.  Service is friendly, if slightly brusque - this place is busy even at random times in the early afternoon, so the cashier (who doubles as a waiter) has time to listen carefully to your order (including dietary restrictions) but not enough time to chat.

One more great thing about Little Chihuahua?  They're *great* at gluten-free, even for celiacs!  They have a small kitchen, but they are very careful and knowledgeable about cross-contamination if you let them know that you have a medical reason to avoid gluten.  Almost everything is gluten-free to begin with - the only danger zone is the flour tortillas for the burritos, but they will happily make things on separate pans for you to be extra-safe.  Also, gluten-free tortillas that don't instantly fall apart!

It's a staple for us Lower Haighters!  Thanks Lil Chu!
author: Erin S.

description:
I get the same thing at every Mexican restaurant, each and every time. The carne asada quesadilla. I'm a "purist" when it comes to my quesadillas, preferring just the carne and cheese for the most part with that perfect buttery tortilla. Don't get me wrong, I love pico, guacamole, etc. but I like for those to be outside the quesadilla for dipping/adding because otherwise it makes the quesadilla too soggy. And a big part (for me) about the perfect quesadilla is how each quarter of the quesadilla has ample or roughly equal amounts of meat and cheese. You know what I'm talking about...there's some places that put their meat and cheese mostly in the middle of the quesadilla and then when you cut it into four pieces, you're left with the two outside pieces being practically nothing but tortilla and maybe a sliver of cheese? A good quesadilla for me has four pieces that are hearty, yummy, and gooey. The downside with Little Chihuahua? My quesadilla came with 2.5 good pieces, with 1 piece basically almost completely tortilla. Not impressed. 

The other negatives:
-At $10.45 it's one of the more expensive carne asada quesadillas, especially compared to the ones on the Divisadero corridor
-50 cent charge for small bag of tortilla chips, $1.00 for a large; it's not expensive, but it's not free like the others on Divisadero are (El Rancho Grande, El Burrito Express)
-The chips themselves were not great 

The good:
-Salsa bar with 5 different salsas, including tomatillo, habanero, chipotle, and pico de gallo

Verdict? El Burrito Express reigns supreme for the best carne asada quesadilla on the Divisadero corridor.
author: Will H.

description:
I think this was a solid 4 star Mexican restaurant. The restaurant is pretty small, although the food comes out fast. I'm not sure yet how busy it gets on the weekends, but I can  imagine that waiting for a table could become an issue here. 
 
In my opinion it was not really a $ meal as it was a few good bucks over Not really a 1 $, 10+ a person, but I am assuming that this is something that I will be getting used to pretty soon.  On to the meal - we got free chips that tasted really fresh and were hot which was nice because we were sitting by the table and people kept on coming in and out and leaving the door wide open =/ 

We tried the tostada con camarones and quesadilla con carne asada. 
I can already tell that I am out of Indiana because the quality of the food is so much better over here! (sorry Indiana, also I'm still in newb mode where I am just extremely impressed with everything). The carne asada was very flavorful, I would hands down get it again. The tostada came in a fried type of tortilla bowl. It was a little bit boring overall, but that fried bowl itself was delicious. 

I'm not sure when I'm going to come back because I have so many new places to try, but I would definitely come back and I try the brunch (and eat more carne asada).
author: Sharon R.

description: Very good burritos. Even the vegetarian (with grilled vegetables rather than a meat burrito minus meat as they often are) is delicious. Lively atmosphere inside, great salsa bar. And you can take something to go into The Page next door if you want a Pliney or a cocktail with your dinner.
author: Matt J.

description: This place is ok. I don't really wanna slam this spot because the people who work here really seam to hustle. But dam... the food is just super lame not good not bad just lame. Picture a pretty lame dry burrito with not much happening inside sort of the hotel art of SF Burritos. I remembered the first time I tried to make a burrito when my college credit card only allowed me to shop at a local gas station for ingredients. Two burritos and pitcher of ok agave wine margarita make 55 bucks;  well for that much guys lets get it together. I guess we're paying for the atmosphere cause theres no table service/bussing.
author: Sebastien R.

description: we stumbled upon this place during our epic urban walk-about. a great find! Ensenada fish tacos and salmon tacos were delicious and substantial. service was fast and very friendly! yeah ... it's a might bit spendy for tacos - but in my mind, it was well worth it!
author: Shelly B.

description:
100 Best Things To Eat In SF Before You Die 2013

#56 Fried Plantain and Black Bean Burrito at The Little Chihuahua

My first time ever ordering a burrito without meat, oh the humanity! A small sacrifice to make to try something new. The burrito felt fresh and vibrant without that heavy, greasy, weighted down feeling. I definitely felt texture was lacking and was looking for something besides soft. Their chips and salsa were great and complimented well with the burrito.

Overall Thoughts

While my carnivorous cravings were not quenched, it was still a well made burrito
author: Eddie W.

description: A notch up from Chipotle. But Overpriced.  Food not memorable but ok if you are really hungry. If you are in the area try it as I did but can't say I'd go out of my way. Enchiladas were meh. The chicken was flavorless. The enchilada sauce again just ok. Oh and you to pay for chips. I would think at these prices they would offer complimentary but it seems like this is a rarity these days. But they have a self serve salsa bar. The salsas were good with a varied selection consisting of pico de gallo, green tomatillo salsa, red hot sauce, jalapeño, and smoky hot chipotle sauce. The food mediocre if you know what Mexican food should taste like...and it isn't this.
author: Review L.

description: This place is wonderful. Amazing food. Great ambiance. Wonderful customer service. I love that they use well sourced meats and veggies, that's definitely one of the reasons I go here often. I've had one issue with them that keeps repeating and that's the fact that they almost always forget to put guacamole in my super burritos. This has happened more than once to me. But when I mention it to them, they're usually great at taking care of the issue.
author: Sara B.

description: Amazingly good food! Vegetarian friendly. We got the regular nachos,  breakfast tacos, friend plantain and beans burrito, veggie burrito with chile tomato tortilla and the grilled veggie tacos for 5 of us. All great!!!
author: Harini R.

description: Fajita burrito was a good choice. Splitting it was not. Burritos are not big here. They're not bad for one person, but they're not the Chipotle sized ones I'm used to. Salsa bar was so cool. I love making my own salsa mix. Chips were $1.00 but totally worth it. Great stop for lunch.
author: Brian F.

description:
We stopped by Little Chihuahua after a recommendation from a friend and it didn't disappoint. The staff is friendly and I like that they were blasting rock music instead of cheesy ranchero music.

The horchada is great! I also ordered a watermelon agua fresca, but was horrified to find that it was made with spearmint. Luckily the staff was great when I explained that I'm allergic to spearmint and traded it for a pineapple agua fresca, which tasted much better.

My boyfriend got the carne asada super burrito, which was good. It wasn't amazing, but it was a solid burrito. I liked the garlic shrimp burrito okay. It has a little bit of kick to it, which I wasn't expecting. It was much better with lime squeezed on it, but I will definitely try the plantain and black bean burrito next.

They have a large array of salsas to choose from and we especially liked the tomatillo. And their draft beer is only $3!
author: Casey S.

description: Was not impressed, ya'll. We got the Shrimp burrito and Chilaquiles. The chilaquiles were ok, but the burrito was mediocre at best...
author: Val K.

description:
Have been here a bunch of times, and always thought they made great tacos. Finally posting a review because they now have full-size gluten free tortillas! 

Seriously, this is the first time I've been able to have a burrito in six years. The Little Chihuahua made my weekend, and I will be making a point to go back frequently.

I got the plantain and black bean burrito, which was delicious. Sweet, smoky, and cheesy. Totally filling, but not gut-busting. Yum!
author: Nikita B.

description:
I like the over-all design and concept of the place but I think the food is really bland. I mean, you get the heat from most of the things I've tried (carne asada tacos, burrito, etc.) and from the two stores I've been to...the meat has no flavor. Even the beans have no flavor. 

Stars for friendly staff. But idk, I'm not a fan of bland.
author: Dominique S.

description:
Took a short walk over here from Alamo square. I ordered two garlic shrimp burritos and a carne asada taco for takeout.

Garlic Shrimp Burrito - I usually opt out for beans but one of my burritos has beans in it. Not cool but I can live with it. There was plenty of shrimp where each bite had a piece in it. The rice was pretty good and went well with the avocados. Overall it was pretty tasty but a little soggy.

Carne asada taco - This was $5 and I really don't think it was worth it. There were two corn tortillas, chopped up steak, and cilantro/onion mix. The steak was a little dry and overall it was lacking flavor. Salsa might have saved the day on this one but I didn't get any.

I order three items and got 3 little oily baggies of chips. I really wish they threw in some salsa in my bag. Overall this place is just what 3-stars is about... A-OK. Might be a different experience if I actually dined in.
author: Michael C.

description: is little chihuahua the place to get a hole in the wall mission style burrito? no. do they use fresh ingredients, organic when possible? yes. the little chi is my go-to mexican joint in lower haight, though the bar is set pretty low in these parts. gotta give it up for fast service, consistency, and convenience. garlic shrimp burrito and pollo asado tostada salad never fail here.
author: Marky E.

description:
I've been going here since they openend and until recently I loved their Burritos.
Actually I still like them, but find due to the price increase - $10 + for a Super Baby Burrito has exceeded my eating out quota for a "Burrito".  It's just a Burrito folks and maybe it's the fact we are now in "Fashionable NOPA", but still.

The folks are Really nice, they remember your name but I find the restaurant a tad "tired" a bit on the "dirty side" and music often "too loud".

No doubt they wil continue to be successful and even flourish, but I'm taking my $10+ dollars to the outer limits where I can still get "change back".
author: Marla B.

description: Great quality and atmosphere.  As a Vegan, I love their child verde Tofu burrito and fried plantain burrito.  Their salsas and agua Fresca she are divine too.  Highly recommended!
author: Roy J.

description:
I have been on the fence about TLC since I moved to the Lower Haight. I guess I was turned off by the prices, portion sizes and the fact that its always crowded even with 5 people in line to order/waiting for food which I think gets to me the most.

When I do go, I get the super burrito which is pretty good but not "super" whatsoever. This would be a kids burrito at any other Mexican place. On the flip side, their ingredients are solid so I don't feel like curling up in a ball and hiding from the world after I eat it. But for $11+ I would expect more food.

All in all, this place is growing on me.. especially since I found out I could call in my order!
author: Zack C.

description: Absolutely worth all the reviews it already has! The parking can be challenging during peak times but the flavor makes up for it BIG time!
author: Joshua B.

description:
Vomitous. Really and truly disgusting. 

Against better judgement, I ordered the garlic shrimp burrito, and only because I was so hungry  my stomach was eating itself did I come close to finishing this..."burrito."

Avoiding hyperbole as best possible, this was the worst burrito I've ever had, hands down, and I probably would've fared better dumpster diving for half-eaten sandwiches. 

If you're craving Mexican food, do yourself a solid and go anywhere but here. Sorry TLC, but you aren't serving up Tender Loving Care, just sad food
author: Pete J.

description:
The al pastor was delicious in the burrito I had.  Surprisingly juicier than most others around.

I like spicy.  However when I ordered, I was warned off of it because "the guys load it up with habanero sauce."  So I had some of that sauce on the side for the chips instead, and boy what a reminder that spiciness is subjective.  To me, it tasted mostly of vinegar.

Decor was fun:  lotería motif on the wall-hangings.
The long, shared tables maximize capacity in this small space (which is good, because on a weeknight, this place was packed.)

I wouldn't say not to a return visit, but as with so many other places around, I'd be game to try something else next time I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Ken B.

description: This is my favorite Mexican spot in the city. No matter how much I want to try them all, I can't stop coming back here. It'd be awesome if they had some kind of frequent customer burrito card or something though! I almost always get some version of the super burrito, and it's great with any of their meats. It's definitely on the pricier side for a burrito in the city, about $12-13, but it's definitely worth it and fills me up perfectly. It's usually fairly crowded for meals, so bringing a big group isn't the easiest, but you can usually get a table for 2-4 people no problem.
author: Brian G.

description:
The setting was pleasant (even when it got full), the music thoughtfully curated, the service extremely quick (less than five minutes for a large burrito) and the food was just great. I got a diet coke, special burrito (with complimentary corn chips and sauces) for $14. 

Would thoroughly recommend. Don't ride your bike home though. The extra weight in your gut will make the hills of San Fran even harder to tame.
author: Toby H.

description:
Most excellent carne asada and shrimp burritos. Tortilla soup and salad w/ protein are great too. Perhaps more fundamental, is a solid salsa bar, among the best in terms of quality and variety. 

Negatives: a bit expensive, no free chips, and the restaurant smells.
author: Steve T.

description: Mediocre food at high prices.  Their horchata is excellent, as are their salsas.  I paid $12 for a bland al pastor burrito and they have the nerve to charge for a small bowl of chips.  With tip, I paid over $20 for sub par Mexican food.
author: seth c.

description:
This place is great and it's one of the only ones I'm aware of besides some of the establishments in the mission and in the outskirts of SF that does not charge much for chips and salsa, which most places in central SF do. I think that's awesome...really they didn't start charging until very recently and that is only because they started serving organic chips I believe. 
Food was delicious, they have beer and other refreshments, atmosphere is lively and although it can get busy, if you walk by at the right time, you can walk right in. Definitely recommend it.
author: George M.

description:
Best nachos in the city!!! I occasionally get a hankering for some cheesy, beany, salsa laden nachos and let me tell you, after a month in Asia, boy, do these nachos deliver. 

TLC also has excellent burritos, salads, and tacos--Another personal fav is plantain burrito. Check out this spot or any of the other TLCs throughout the city, your tastebuds will be satisfied and delighted!!!
author: Reena T.

description: Took me a while to try this place (been living in the hood for a few years), and boy was I missing out. The Plaintain burrito is AMAZING. To get it vegan, simply ask for it sans cheese and sour cream. When I ordered it this way, the cashier automatically asked if I wanted to sub those items with guac - um, YES. Also ordered chips and guac and got the biggest container. Very much looking forward to returning in the near future.
author: Jon T.

description: I had one of the best taco salads ever here today. Super fresh ingredients make all the difference. The tacos looked awesome, too. We'll be back.
author: David K.

description:
The real deal! Believe the hype :) 
I had the carne asada regular burrito with plantains and it was pretty awesome! Love the option of sweet plantains and that they put the entire thing on the flat top griddle to char the outside once it's done. Delicious!
author: Semuteh F.

description:
Uhmm, it's definitely unique. If your looking for authentic Mexican this isn't the spot, but then again, San Fran is NOT the town to have a mexican craving in. LOL  Anyhow, it's actually kind of good, once you accept the fact that The Little Chihuahua does it's own thing, the food is actually kind of good. My cheese enchilada was sweet, oh and it comes with veggies in it not just plain cheese but that anyone who reads the description would know--I've never experienced a sweets stuffed cheese enchilada before but once I understood that this isn't the norm interpretation of Mexican the food taste good for what it is. 

Like my good friend says, "go-cuban in SF." She is riiiiight.  oOH but the Guacamole is phenomenal but they should call it Spicy guacamole, because it is spicy. Theeee best I've ever had!!
author: Nai Q.

description:
Little Chi-waaow-waaow (Boom Chicka-Wow-Wow).....


I'll have you know that this is weird Mexican food. It's like whole foods ingredients for Mexican food. How do I explain it? It's so quality that even the spicy sauce isn't even really spicy. Whatever. I am the type of person that can care less about quality ingredients because I for one still like McDonalds. SUE ME. I will say that I didn't need any extra sauces from the condiment stand and ate my Super Carne Asada burrito alone. The hint of lime just made this burrito delicious. It doesn't make you feel tired but makes you feel full which is what I liked.

The downside is that it is expensive for a burrito and the sizing is ridiculously small. I bought a super burrito with the hopes of it lasting me for tomorrows breakfast or lunch lol. When I looked at it, it was like a regular size burrito, or an xl taco bell "bean burrito"! I'm not joking. I am like a 100 pd girl and scarfed it down as my bf drove home.

When I am making tech money, I'll frequent but for now I'll just smile when I pass or come here when I have a decent paycheck.
author: Sweets N.

description:
TLC is a great place to get Mexican food if you don't want to feel "weighed down" afterwards. I feel like I can actually get something I'd consider "healthy" here. :)

That being said, I usually get a super burrito, with varying meats (they all seem good). 

The flavor that really stands out in their burritos is their salsa. And like all other reviewers say, the salsa bar is great too, so chips are a good call if you want those.

Note, there isn't much sitting room, so when you arrive you'll worry that you'll get a seat. But usually turnover is good enough so by the time you get your food you can find a seat. BUT I wouldn't come with more than 4 people unless it's off hours. 2 would be easiest to find a seat.

TAKE-OUT SECRET: If you order on the phone for take-out, you can bypass the line and pick up the food in the corner next the register which has a separate person take care of you.

Price: On the high side for a burrito, but it's tasty and "healthy" :)

Check it out for yourself!
author: Peter M.

description:
Small and cozy spot in between upper and lower Haight.

Tacos were delicious, but the tortillas are pretty damn big and heavy -- since they double layer it, two should be more than enough for one person. Otherwise, burritos are a good way to go.

Meats are fresh, flavorful, and packed on. I really enjoyed both the carna asada and shrimp.

Bonus: full salsa bar and tons of locals. Really friendly service.
author: Anthony N.

description: My favorite Mexican food place in the city.  I especially like the chicken tostada salad and the fajita burrito.  Everything is freshly made and you can snack on chips and a variety of salsa flavors while you wait.  The line can get quite long on weekends/evenings, but it moves pretty quickly.
author: Jeff A.

description: My husband and I went to TLC on one of our first dates and as our relationship has grown, so has our love for TLC burritos. When we got married, we both coincidentally included how much we love eating TLC together in our vows. Love it and all the people who work there.
author: A P.

description: When I dream, I dream of the plantain burrito here. And I'm not even vegetarian. It's that good. Get it. I'm seriously drooling even thinking about it. Also, I think the price point is very fair for what you're getting. There are many delicious Bay Area burritos to be had, but this is by far my favorite.
author: Ashley A.

description:
I can see why people like TLC, the 90s group from Atlanta. They were tight. I guess I can also see why people like TLC, the overpriced burrito joint on Divis. There's a hip, holier-than-thou vibe to this place that San Francisco people love. But the Mexican options in this area are very limited, and they're open late for SF, so I've been here several times.

The burritos are somehow mediocre (one exception, see below) despite having high quality meats and beans. I tried the plantain and black bean burrito since those are two things I love but it was a massive letdown. Same goes for my standard burrito orders, super steak or super chicken. Both were so weak, I'm not sure why people love them so much.

The chips here are good, but the salsas are among the worst in the city. There are five or six different salsas at the salsa bar and all are terrible except for the chipotle one, which is tolerable. Even the habanero salsa, the only one with some kick, has no taste to it. 

There are some bright spots however, which is why I give three stars instead of one. The garlic shrimp burrito is excellent. I also really enjoyed the the shrimp enchiladas and beef enchiladas, both with red sauce and refried black beans. I don't know if they were worth as much as I paid for them, but they were quite good.
author: Joseph N.

description:
We were SO happy with our food at TLC! The salsa was fresh, the corn chips were plenty, and the tacos I enjoyed were amazing. 
We went at 3:30ish when there was no one else there and were able to get our delicious food quickly and have a nice conversation with our cashier. It was a great casual atmosphere and exactly the kind of local, fast, high-quality dining experience we hoped for in San Fran!
author: Mandy L.

description:
Stumbled across this place a few years ago and was pleasantly surprised. Fresh ingredients and not your typical kind of Greasy Mexican food. 

I've been back a couple times, very very good food!
author: Chris L.

description:
I think I could like this place more if it wasn't so so so crowded. I guess that's part of its charm, though. The service was great, the food was great, the salsa bar and the unlimited chips are great.

The only thing was the awkwardness of getting a table. The rule is to sit down once you've ordered so people can filter out of the place as new people come, etc. But some people don't know or don't care and I witnessed 3 awkward and tense conversations between people as they tried to get seats after they'd ordered from people who sat down before they ordered.

I would definitely come back for the food but maybe at a time when there are less people there! It was so hectic that it was hard to enjoy the deliciousness on the plate.
author: Michelle K.

description: Incredibly average for a $12.50 burrito and a Coke.  The service here was friendly and the salsa bar was nice.  It was difficult to get in and out of the lined up tables with huge chairs.  The burrito was smaller than most taquerias but had a good flavor.
author: J B.

description: It was ok, got the tofu tacos and found them to be a bit on the bland side. I think it's quite a bit overpriced for what it is (can only speak for the tofu), but the service was fast and the atmosphere was comfortable. Works in a pinch.
author: Jenna B.

description:
Amazing Mexican food. You can really taste the quality of the ingredients when you come here. From the delicious chips to the Carne asade, everything has a delicious and fresh taste.

My go to is the carne asade nachos. I can eat a whole order when I'm really hungry, but be warned it's a lot of food. You really can't go wrong with anything here. 

My friend and I get really lucky everytime we come here since there magically happens to be a seat available. I would try to come either earlier or later so you can get a table.
author: Harsan S.

description:
This may have been the best burrito I've ever had. 

I eat a lot of burritos. My sample size is huge.
author: Matt F.

description:
I used to live literally across the street from TLC on Divisadero and the apartment had a non-functional kitchen, so you bet I came here often. 

It is good, for sure, but honestly, it is a little pricey for Mexican food. An order of a carne asada quesadilla and a drink really should not cost $15, but that's San Francisco for ya! BTW the quesadillas are pretty good, so be sure to give them a try. The plantain burrito is a healthy and delicious option for those seeking meatless options. I highly recommend the tortilla soup (but be sure to ask for extra avocado). Their brunch is tasty and not that expensive! Be sure to get the chilaquiles topped with two fried eggs. It is honestly big enough to share, so you and your date can spend on that drank. 

It isn't authentic and not that cheap, but give it a try and I'm sure you'd be hooked.
author: Michael G.

description:
HEADS UP YA'LL. 

They just jacked up their prices and reduced their portions across the board. 

Chips will cost you. They shrunk the size of the containers at the salsa bar. They tacked on another buck or two to everything on the menu. A super BABY burrito will set you back $9. A regular-sized burrito has crossed the $10 mark. 

The grub is good, but this spot benefitted from a lack of competition for a long time. For the cost disparity, it's not significantly better that any of its competition. Go somewhere else.
author: Rob G.

description:
I walk by this place all the time and never realized it existed, such a small gem behind a narrow entrance. 

First time having garlic shrimp in a burrito :) Expect a lot of shrimp in your burrito; I had to take out some of them. Free nachos and couple of dips you can try. I found their nachos pretty blunt but given the size of burrito you don't really need to eat anything else.

No frills, relaxed environment.
author: Revna A.

description: All around great restaurant. I like the burritos and the Pozole Rojo soup. As for burritos I normally order a Al Pastor special, a breakfast burrito, or a super burrito. They have 5-6 salsa's which are all excellent. Fast service and high quality ingredients make this a standout in the Divisadero area.
author: Adam M.

description: Muy Excelente! Whenever we're nearby it's a treat to stop in here, and the food really is damn delicious. It's an order at the counter type deal, and you know I went true with the carnitas burrito, Really rich in flavor, this does not disappoint. My pal had the tostada salad and it looked bomb as well. Chips are $0.50 extra, but with a notorious salsa bar you're obvi going to get those. I was feeling tomatillo yesterday and it's chunky and fresh! They are famous for their plantain burrito, but I'm not a fan of platains, so I opted out. Make sure you try this place!!
author: Alyssa J.

description: Sustainablish, fresh, solid salsa bar and sweet staff come to mind of this neighborhood joint...I figured I'd write a review since they've saved me from starvation or eating horribly many a times... chicken tortilla soup is kind of amazing:)
author: Danielle S.

description:
$13 dolla super carnitas burrito.  W.T.F.  

(with 1 dolla tip)

and slimy floors.
author: Jordan G.

description: I've been going to The Little Chihuahua for almost 7 years now, and they've consistently been right on the money. Delicious and excellent quality every.single.time!
author: Christopher S.

description:
The bar is high for burritos here in SF. So, it's 3 stars for solid burritos reasonably close to where I live only because places like El Farolito are so mind-blowing. 

These certainly get the job done but tortillas here leave something to be desired (they're on the drier side), and other ingredients are fine but not super flavorful. I recommend the Garlic Shrimp or Plantain & Black Bean burrito from their Specialty Burritos menu. I am a big fan of the fact they have "baby" burritos. 

I'm not clear on why salsa bars matter so much to people, but if they matter to you know that TLC has one.
author: Jessica H.

description: Had a great burrito!  Salsa was really good.  Flavors were impressive! Small comfortable location. We don't usually get Mexican food in the city,  but were happy that we tried this place.
author: Randall C.

description:
For once we decided to roll by the seat of our pants and not make a dinner reservation for our evening in the city. Note to self: don't so this ever again. After many many delicious beer tastings around various Castro bars we knew it was time to find something yummy to cap off the night. We did try to get into Starbelly but a 90 minute wait didn't work for us. So after much deliberation and a few more beers we found TLC on the Yelp app and headed off to the Haight. 

TLC is fine for a quick dinner but my main problem with this place is that its pricy for what it is. Almost $10 for a burrito (super) that's mostly filled with rice and beans, really? Don't get me wrong, I love rice and beans but would have liked a little more meat. 

Service was friendly and the kitchen puts the food out fast. Lots and lots of menu choices too so even the pickiest eater should be able to find something. 

Food..

Cheese Quesadilla -  Im pretty sure their version was supposed to have more in it according to the menu. Mine was simply a tortilla with melted cheese in it. This did make a decent vehicle for salsa tasting. The best salsa by the way was the pico de gallo. 

Carne Asada Super Burrito - Decent sized burrito but that bulk was mostly made up as I mentioned before, rice and beans. The meat itself was really tasty but there was so little of it that I was left wanting more. 

Guacamole - A little to loose from what Im used to but tasted pretty good. The chips that came with the guacamole were good and salty, a huge plus in my book.

House-Made Horchata - Pretty much a glassful of chalky grit. The worst horchata Ive ever had. Not much else I can say about that. Sandchata!

If you're in a hurry and not on a budget TLC will fill your belly rice and beans style!
author: Alexander C.

description: Disappointing. Seriously over-priced burrito. Nearly 50% more than what I'd pay for an arguably superior burrito (taste, maybe not quality) in the Mission. On the plus side, the salsa was pretty good, but not worth returning for.
author: Michael H.

description:
I had an unpleasant experience at The Little Chihuahua, and I want to share it so maybe others may be treated better in the future.

My friend Amanda and I went last Thursday to get burritos to go and as soon as we left with our burritos, she realized her wallet was missing.

We went right back to look for it, as she had just payed and we only stayed in the "waiting line area" next to the condiments, so if she had dropped it, it would have been there. It wasn't in sight. 
So we told the staff her wallet was missing and I must have happened there. 
The staff shrugged, as if it was none of their business. 
We were kind of bummed, so we decided to call the restaurant and ask for the manager. 
We told hime what happened, Amanda wanted to leave her phone number with them, just in case the wallet turned up, but he didn't seem interested. 
Amanda asked "What are you supposed to do if your client get pickpocket in your restaurant?" and he replied "I don't know what to tell you".

Now, I understand it is not their fault if Amanda's wallet was stolen, but they could have handle it a little better. 
We were treated like we were waisting their time, but a crime happened in their restaurant, so they should have responded better.
author: Amira T.

description:
This place is freaking AMAZING. Run, don't walk and get a plantain burrito with a tomato wrap.. If plantains aren't your thing -- Garlic Shrimp Burrito! You really can't go wrong with Little Chihuahua. 

Pro-tip: Now they're doing delivery via Caviar
author: Alison Y.

description:
After a long day I was fantasizing about eating a Chipotle bowl, but the closed Chipotle is miles away so I opted to try The Little Chihuahua instead, which sources from sustainable farming. Parking is horrendous here after 6pm and the island prevents U-turns, resulting in a few lost parking spots. 

I do like The Little Chihuahua's salsa bar but their burritos were just average. Ordered the Garlic Shrimp Burrito, Carne Asada Super Burrito, and Salmon Tacos. I was expected flavorful mixture of meat, beans, cheese, rice, and sauce but each dish was bland. The burritos were a mushy mess and the taco was not memorable. I would have accepted neutral flavors for the super burrito and taco but I want some garlic flavor for the Garlic Shrimp Burrito. Not worth the long wait in line and arduous parking conditions.
author: Andrew W.

description:
I like chihuahuas, especially Remington (Remy), my friend's sweet gray chihuahua. I also really like the Little Chihuahua! Every couple months we have the Little Chihuahua cater lunch at work. It's always a very popular lunch. I've also had eat-in and take-out from this location a few times. You order at the counter and then the food is brought to your table. Here are the highlights:

- Just two doors down from the Page - perfect when you've been drinking and need some sustenance!
- The plantain burrito (around $9.95) is AMAZING, a vegetarian's dream burrito!
- The salsa bar boasts 6 delicious salsas, two of which are pretty spicy
- They offer beer and wine
- The tostada salads are big and yummy - you can get camarones or any other type of protein (about $9 - $13) - the only strange thing is that they use a salad dressing on this salad (not typical of other tostadas I've had)
- My friend ordered the pozole which also was great especially since I love soup-y dishes

The prices aren't cheap but the offerings are good and I'll keep coming back!
author: Meghan P.

description:
Still one of my favorite burritos in town. 

Super baby burrito is the perfect size.

Stock-up at their salsa bar.
author: Mike P.

description: This is the most healthiest Mexican food I've ever eaten! I had the tostada salad and the greens were like a spring mix with this bomb ass salsa with mangos and cucumbers! It's a fairly tight space so eat fast because the it fills up fairly quickly. The salsa is self-served which is great because you can get as much as you want!!! It's definitely a place to go multiple times! Price is good for the quality you are paying! Gluten-free tortilla chips!
author: Khrystal L.

description: Maybe my favorite Mexican place in SF.  Sure, it's not like Cancun or La Taqueria, but everything is absolutely incredible.  I frequently order and then go to The Page next door.  Garlic shrimp burrito, chicken fajita burrito, plantain burrito... All so delicious.  I always get the retried black beans and the habanero salsa.
author: Alden S.

description:
Great local place, fantastic salsa selection. Don't drive if you want to eat there because parking is murder. 

Garlic shrimp burrito one of the best in the city. Halfway through eating I'm always tempted to call back and order another, but it ends up being perfectly filling. 

A little more expensive now that you must pay for (organic) chips. Get around it with take out and tortilla chips from Safeway.
author: Tyler L.

description:
Absolutely caught me by surprise. I was imagining another chain in the wall (yeah I just made that up), generic fresh mex. taco shop - instead I was blown out of my seat. The roasted pepper salsa is so on point, I have no other words to describe it. You'll be going back for 4ths and 5ths.

Loved their cryptic/dia de los muertes art on the walls.

Tacos are large from what I remember and filling. Quality is great. I would come back to this place anytime.
author: Briget P.

description:
Love this place, they now do gluten free burritos which are awesome if not too much rice and beans and not enough veg sometimes. Overall all the food is really good, you can rely on friendly staff and a clean eating area. 
We eat here most weeks and I would not hesitate to recommend the or any of their locations (we have been to all of them) to anyone.
author: oscar o.

description:
I had the super burrito with pollo asado. Really good preparation and the cabbage that comes along with it is a cool change up from most burrito places.

I would say it's worth a shot for anyone in the mood for fast service and a good solid meal. Nachos are great too!!
author: Colin H.

description: The place is pretty small. The food's good. We had tacos and they are delicious. However the Margarita's little bit overpriced.
author: Fei S.

description: Yum! Great food. Can be a little busy but to be expected. A great place to get a margarita and a ($12) shrimp burrito. A bit pricier than some of the other hole-in-the-wall places, but LC has a nice ambiance and is still cheaper than a lot of places in the area.
author: Abigail S.

description: Decent food that is over priced. ... Also, strikes me as odd and unethical how high they charge for employee mandate (and double charge) compared to peers. Not a big deal, but just Kinda shady
author: Dan K.

description: If you thought chipotle was bad this location is what it look liked after the ecoli scare. To start off the floor plan of this place is the worst. The cashier is right next to the busiest part of the restaurant and to top that off right next to the pickup and literally right in front of the bathroom. Because that's what I want a restroom right by lingering while I order my food and rub elbows with patrons yelling for their orders. And the stoner behind the counter with the long hair and stupid beanie has no organization skills most of the time forgetting that chips and guacamole mean you get chips. Save yourself the time and money and go to a real taqueria in the city. They might not understand you but they get your order right. The little chihuahua is right, a small beezy that keeps barking and annoys you.
author: Lyn D.

description: I feel terrible writing this but who gets guacamole wrong? My husband just came home from this place with one burrito and a side of guacamole with chips a $20 total bill, terribly overpriced, and everything tasted bad. The burrito had whole black beans which to me is always a bad sign, the rice was not tasty and the so called grass fed carne asada, we only found two tiny pieces in the entire burrito that's total deception. The pico de gallo was not fresh, it unfortunately tasted harshly refrigerated, the onions were raw yet soggy which isn't right. We wanted to splurge on a healthier option and feel completely ripped off. I'd love to be proven wrong but unfortunately we are so saddened by how terrible the taste test was and the lack of quality authentic ingredients.
author: Cindy G.

description:
This was my very first time finding a place to eat on Yelp that I actually went to. Also my first time using the Yelp app to find what's nearby :D.

I had time to kill and do not come to this area very often as I do not want to bother looking for parking. But since I was parked at the DMV nearby I decided to walk here and try it out. I was having trouble finding this place because I was looking for a red rectangular store sign based on this photo (just noticed now that this photo was uploaded in 2009 -___- totally forgot to check): http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-little-chihuahua-san-francisco?select=EGRMmpSgG64-EmycJ_CirA#CjWaCEH9G73j0mRHt5WYrQ

I was just right across the street from it but did not notice it because they change the rectangle to a circle (no recent photos I guess :p). The entrance was quite small but the place was packed with people on a Thursday afternoon, nice ambience. Ordered a garlic shrimp burrito, as I saw recommended on the Yelp app. First thoughts, this is some quality aluminum foil lol. The burrito was alright, they didn't skimp out on the shrimp and it had quite a good kick on the spice. Also kind of dry so be sure to have something to drink. After finishing the burrito realized I totally forgot to get some salsa for the chips. sadface.jpg
author: Hui L.

description: Love this place. A little expensive but the burritos are delicious and their salsas are great (love the pico and chipotle). Always a quality choice.
author: Tristan E.

description: Looking for delicious gluten-free option? I get the pozole every time with a side of rice...and black beans when I'm really hungry. The soup is flavorful and I love that make sure you get a good chunk of meat still falling off the bone. The rice is fluffy and balances the soup well. Black beans are simply solid.
author: Cat T.

description:
I've never been a more satisfied vegan than when I'm chowing down on the Fried Plantain & Black Bean Burrito. 

If you order it with no sour cream / cheese, they'll add their amazing guacamole instead (which I'm certain you should add anyway). 

Their salsa bar is delicious, too! And a great way to warm up before your burrito arrives.
author: Tori M.

description:
Not bad, not amazing. Neutral.

And pretty pricey for Mexican. But I guess it comes with the neighborhood.

But the guac was delish!! With a great lemony zest. And lots of texture.

The chips - thin (& broke a little easily in the heavy guac) but at least light on oil.

I'm a sucker for "unique" items and went with their award winning Plantain Burrito. Good.. not mindblowing by any means. It tasted like exactly what it sounds like - a burrito with plantains. Which could've been cooked more, in my opinion. I like 'em real soft & squishy.

Should've gone with my guts and gotten the garlic shrimp burrito. Next time.
author: Ziyan C.

description: The agave wine margarita was a delicious refreshing meal opener. The tostada salad was awesome as well :) loved everything about this place ..
author: Shilpa P.

description: Only come here if you have nothing else to do; I waited a half hour for a mediocre to-go burrito. Ridiculous.
author: Mike B.

description:
Oh heck yeah. The food is excellent. - brilliant mild twist on traditional Mexican dishes. Grilled Garlic Shrimp Burrito - mind blown! 

Tortilla chips excellent, seat yourself cafeteria style makes for lower costs dining.
author: Greg F.

description: One of my go-to spots in SF. Reliable, friendly, delicious salsa bar. The baby burrito option is genius and while I always want the full size, sometimes the baby version calls. Enchiladas, tacos...doesn't matter what you get, it's filling without the gut bomb and served with a smile. Little chow is that local spot you can bring anyone and know they'll be satisfied.
author: Kate V.

description:
The food is great here, but the service is pretty crappy. I've lived around the corner from this place for six or seven years now and over the years, there has been a steady decline in not just the service but the apparent happiness of the employees who work here. When they answer the phone, they generally will growl at you and place you on hold for several minutes, even if the store is completely empty. They have a dedicated call-ahead takeaway line but it's primary purpose now seems to be to give staff another reason to bark at you if you line up in it. 

All in all, I always leave this place wondering why I returned -- the food is good, but it's negated by their shitty service at the front counter.
author: Mark D.

description:
Solid tacos/burritos, though nothing revelatory. Seems to be popular with the Haight hipster set. It's definitely less authentic Mexican and more Cali-Mex. Service is average and so are prices for the area. 

The Al Pastor Burrito is rather recommendable.
author: Robert K.

description:
We ordered our meal from TLC via Caviar, so this review will only pertain to the food we received:

I ordered a carne asada super burrito and wrote in the Notes section to please leave out any onions and pico de gallo (I'm allergic to onions, they make me ill for dayyyyys). What do you know, my first bite is filled with onions and pico. I spent the next twenty minutes dissecting my burrito for all traces of onions. The rest of the burrito tasted ok, but it ruined the experience for me.

My boyfriend ordered the chile verde chicken quesadilla which is listed as: "A toasted flour tortilla filled with roasted mild poblano peppers, sautéed onions, and jack cheese, served with guacamole, sour cream, pico de gallo & cabbage salad on the side and [...] chile verde chicken". It also came with mushrooms [NOT LISTED] which he hates. The guac, pico, and sour cream [NO CABBAGE SALAD IN THERE] was piled in a corner of the container and made the quesadilla mushy. Perhaps put these sorts of toppings in plastic tubs? 

While the food arrived hot, the items ordered did not come as we ordered them...not the best food experience here, and I probably won't order again.
author: Liz G.

description:
My friend took me here when it was 4:30pm and I said I was hungry for dinner already. He said it was good we were there early because sometimes it's difficult to find a seat! I ordered the Tostada Salad with chicken and he ordered the Baby Super Burrito. We got a number and a basket of tortilla chips and we were off to get waters and salsa from the fresh salsa bar. 

A little while later, our food was at our table! My friend's burrito seemed like the perfect size, so the regular burrito must be massive! My salad was huge! A giant bowl filled with lettuce, diced chicken, a quarter of an avocado, and black beans at the bottom -- it was one tasty dinner! The lettuce was lightly dressed, just the way I like it and the chicken was flavorful. I didn't think I would but I pretty much finished a good chunk of the salad (minus the crispy tortilla shell bowl). My friend devoured his burrito and had some of my salad.

The chips were just okay, but the salsa was REALLY good. I like spicy and they had some really spicy salsa! 

When we finished up, we bussed our own table and were out the door! I thought the prices were average, so I don't really see the savings of having customers buss their own tables, but I'm not too bothered by it. I'd like to come back and try their tacos and other offerings, while hitting up the salsa bar again! Good food, good service, and clean facilities!

NOTE: The bathroom is tiny and definitely not wheelchair accessible.
author: Leana L.

description:
An SF institution of -- not necessarily authentic but nonetheless delicious -- mexican food.

On this visit we had a fantastic al pastor burrito with pineapple salsa and the carnitas tostada salad but it's really pretty hard to go wrong. 

Often crowded with shared seating, but it's good value and definitely recommended.
author: Amy D.

description:
The al pastor burrito was to die for.  I loved getting into the zone while eating it.  Definitely a keeper!  We also had chicken enchiladas which were less impressive so I'd pass on that next time.

Great selection of salsas too!
author: Ada C.

description:
I got takeout from The Little Chihuahua with a couple of girlfriends. We walked in around 6:30 on a Sunday night and the place was poppin'.  And everyone was pretty good-looking, FWIW.

We got guacamole + chips and I had the garlic shrimp burrito. Very delicious.  Their salsa bar was also pretty amazing.  Considering how busy they were, we didn't wait long at all for our food.  I'd definitely go back next time I'm in the 'hood.
author: Hannah C. R.

description:
Good fuss free food. 

Keep in mind there is not enough room to sit sometimes. Went on a friday night and had to fight for a table after waiting some time.
author: Kristan B.

description:
Not much umami unfortunately. The meal was fine but... the chips were the highlight.

The steak was pretty good quality I admit but for some reason it just didn't quite come together.
author: Uncle L.

description: Wish I could give half stars, this place is definitely a 4.5 for me. I have braces so a lot of my orders can sound weird or like I am being fussy. But whenever I ask for my beans, rice, carnitas and sour cream they always put it together for me in a nice little box and never make me feel like a difficult customer. I really like the carnitas, something about the cinnamon with the savory spices is great. This isn't the most "authentic" place I guess. But the food and service are great!
author: Leah R.

description:
Way too expensive for average Mexican food. And chips ARE NOT INCLUDED, which has got to be the most rediculous thing ever, considering the cost of preparing fried tortilla chips!!

We got a few tacos (which were beyond mediocre) and a baby burrito (dry and tasteless) to go, and the bill came to $28.60!!! Ok, so not the cheapest Mexican food, but wanted to try there organic fare. Then I asked her if the chips were in the bag and she says "no, sorry those are extra!" So I say "$29 for food and you don't include a small bag of chips?" 
"No there $.50"
So much to my dismay, i hand her the $.40 she just gave me in change, and she says "sorry there $.50 not $.40!" 
At this point I'm completely disgusted. There are way to many taquerias in SF to waste my time and money with these guys!
author: Sean G.

description: Omg best Gluten free burrito I have ever had , I came in to get tacos and when the server who also works the register informed me about the gluten free tortilla I was in heaven and also when off the only places I have seen that serves 100% organic grass feed beef. This place is a block from where I stay and am so happy I found this place . There is no other place I would want to get burrito from . Great services and off course amazing food ! I would give this place 10 star if there were more stars .
author: Muna B.

description: Everytime I go to San Francisco I eat here! This is probably my favorite Mexican food on earth. Fresh and great quality of food. The location is great, the restaurant is nice. I've ordered the veggie nachos and the burritos. The salsas are also great. I just wish it wasn't so difficult to find a table.
author: Frank K.

description: Very solid mexican spot - is it the most authentic? no. could i eat it every day? yes. Make sure you order ahead for take out otherwise the lines and waits can be long. I usually get the chicken burrito or the steak quesadilla. The staff is always super friendly even though the phone is ringing off the hook
author: Stacie C.

description: Well this place was not much of a surprise for me. At first I thought it was going to be an awesome experience and it turned out that it just wasn't. I ordered their Pollo Asado Quesadilla which was alright but it definitely made my stomach hurt afterwards. I didn't finish all of it. I also ordered one of my favorites: Agua de Horchata and it is a little ridiculous that it was $3.75 for a regular size. Are they freaking crazy? I don't even know if it was real. It tasted as if it was a premade mix....not cool. The service was a little irritating when ordering because I was standing in line for their "pick up" orders register and when I was next, the guy told me I had to go to the other register "for here" orders. Seriously? Anyways, as the first time being there, I don't think I will be heading back any time soon.
author: Hector C.

description: Great neighborhood burrito spot.  My go to for a quick bite.
author: Ryan J.

description:
Mmmmmm. Just had the carnitas quesadilla for pickup. Tasty. It had grilled onions and peppers inside with guacamole, pico de gallo, and sour cream on the side. Their chips are good and 1 of their salsas is super duper spicy.

Props for being part of the dining at Outside Lands guys!
author: Marty J.

description: The best option for gluten free great burritos in SF!  Excellent quality fresh ingredients grilled chicken and grass fed beef, wow! Not the huge burritos some places make, but nice medium size hearty enough for me! They also have other tortilla options: gf, regular, spinach, tomato.
author: Darryl B.

description:
This place is killer. 1st off, free chips salsa. Can't really be that in SF cause so few spots offer that. 2nd, guys who work there are super nice. Menu has LOTS of options for Mexican food. Burritos, enchiladas, tacos, nachos, salads and a lot more. And seriously, it's all good! 

But my favorite thing to get is the breakfast burrito. It's honestly the best I've ever had. You get the option of bacon or chorizo (made at 4505 meats) but I like to go with half and half. It's a big burrito too and always fills me up. Definitely would recommend that or the carne asada enchiladas.
author: John H.

description:
Look I was absolutely wasted upon eating here but I am 95% sure my review would hold up the same had I been sober. Drunk me wanted a steak quesadilla. And that plus some fresh hot chips is exactly what I got. Salsa bars can either creep me out (communal food hand space naw thanks) or be gifts from god. In this drunken case 'twas a gift from god. 

This place is pretty damn delicious for being absolutely shall we say San Francisco'd? (tattd up cashier bros) but like idk man the food was de.fucking.licious. And said bros were super nice. 

The food came out fast and was on point. They also have beers on draft. 

Get some.
author: Ryley P.

description: The tortilla soup warmed my heart on a brisk San Francisco day. Come at an odd hour to avoid the wait for this tiny spot. Avoid the temptation to get full on chips and salsa. Be okay cramming yourself into a tiny space (when in Rome, right?). Enjoy the casual atmosphere and quirky personality of this place!
author: Vanessa H.

description:
There are no refried pinto beans, only refried black, and for someone like me, that matters. I'd rather spend way less money on a much better burrito from any regular taqueria in the city than wait in line for this place. It was so packed, finding a table was reminiscent of being a high school cafeteria. You get in line and pay for your food, then maybe get a table by the time it's ready. Probably right up someone else's alley, but I prefer somewhere simple like Gordo's to this place.

Chips were good, though, and they grilled the burrito, which made it much tastier than it would have been otherwise.

tl;dr if you want a fast, delicious burrito, go to any taqueria in SF. if you want a sit-down, plate full of beans and rice Mexican food place, go to Tommy's or Celia's. This place hits neither mark, but somewhere in between, which serves no use to me, unfortunately.
author: Morgan B.

description:
I love visiting my home town...ok city....of San Francisco! There are always awesome little places to eat popping up. 

Little Chihuahua was a new find for us. We were invited to meet some friends for brunch.YUMMY!!! And total bonus that they try to stay as organic, and fresh as possible! 

I have Chili Relleno with eggs, and thanks to a recommendation from the person taking my order, threw in some chorizo. I am sure it was Organic chorizo! BAHAHAHA....WHO CARES??? It was delicious!!!  So good.

It started to get really crowded, so go early, and eat happy!
author: Kent T.

description: One of the better mexican food places in SF for sure- The enchiladas were great. I will be back to try more! the burritos looked spectacular.
author: A. D.

description:
After waiting at the dmv for 4 hours with no light at the end of the tunnel, I gave in to my starvation and came for a cheat meal to gorge on a burrito. Small restaurant sign to see and dark exterior, but once you walk in the restaurant has a laid back friendly vibe. 

Great salsa selection and 10.75 for a carne asada super burrito is not terrible but it is more expensive then a burrito in the mission by about $2. The tortilla on the burrito has a nice toasting to it as opposed to just warmed or steamed. They add a lil zesty sauce in the burrito and it has a nice tang to it. Good stuff but not mind blowing.
author: Christopher K.

description:
Love this place, I took my friends visiting from Germany yesterday. They loved it as well. 

I ordered the Carne Asada Quesadilla, the quality of the food was great, fresh and flavorful. The food was prepared pretty quick, service very friendly. While having our dinner, the restaurant was always packed, shows their good reputation. 

I always stop by when I am in there area! For my gluten free friends, they offer now gluten free tortillas!
author: Carolin M.

description:
Great find in the middle of a SF walking adventure with my wife.  I'm a huge al pastor fan and this was the best I've ever had. Huge chunks of the most tender, flavorful pork. I went taco, should have gone burrito. Also had the plantain and black bean taco as a curiosity. It was pretty good but paled in comparison to the al pastor. My wife had a pollo asado burrito that was fantastic.  The chips were ok but were important vehicles to carry the amazing salsas. The chipotle was my favorite with the tomatillo a close second. 

The place is clean and a decent price for the freshness and quality of the ingredients. I wish I could go back but home in San Diego is calling!
author: Trent C.

description: Awesome food. Great service. It was my first time, the cashier wasn't as interactive as I would have like.
author: Tamara R.

description:
Apparently I am one of the last to know about this place- over 800 reviews at 4 stars and I never heard a peep of this place...

My husband dragged me here. i confess the name was off putting. But I digress- damn you little Chihuahua this place was great! 

The line was out the door. The place is small. You order at the counter. Plenty to choose from. The menu was filled with delight. The salsa bar was colorful, plentiful, and delicioso!!! 

I had the tostada salad with carne asada while my husband enjoyed the shrimp burrito. All the ingredients worked beautifully together and were super delicious. Great "new" find for us!!
author: Michelle I.

description: My burrito was so good!! My company got nachos and amazingly good. Nachos could be shared by two people.
author: Jeanette B.

description:
Disappointment ensues. 

I ordered a super baby burrito with carne asada. The carne asada was grisly and it looked like they either forgot all of the "super" ingredients or mixed up my order. I wanted to love this place but it just didn't live up to my expectations. Within walking distance are Nopalito and Green Chile Kitchen, both better.
author: Amy L.

description:
Little Chihuahua was packed at 4pm today on an average Wednesday. With just a few seats available and a surfeit of take-out orders ready to go out the door...

..need I say more?

Well, yes: Get the grilled shrimp tacos. They're a taste explosion. 

I'm officially addicted to this little gem called "Little Chihuahua."
author: Jennifer O.

description: Tried the garlic shrimp burrito and a horchata here and both were pretty good. I loved the chairs and stained glass windows, and that finding a table wasn't difficult at all. I thought the space could've been a little bit cleaner but overall I liked the food.
author: Jamie B.

description: Great place. Had there Chilaquiles with chorizo. It was amazing, would recommend them. I am Mexican, so I will be giving them my seal of approval. Two favorite hot sauce were the tomatillo and roasted tomatoes. The horchata is also a plus. Keep up the good work little chihuahua.
author: Pablo P.

description:
Sad to say that the last few times I went the food was kind of bland. At first I thought it was because a cold or something, but sadly this persisted. 

Also, last time I ate there on Wednesday there was a piece of metal from a scrub brush in my black beans. They did feel bad about it and gave me a free drink. (They offered me a meal but I just ate...) And, to be honest, I would rather find a piece of clean metal from a scrub brush in my food than almost literally anything else. It means they wash their pots and pans! Yay... But seriously, rinse a little better next time. ;)
author: Daniel C.

description:
I was expecting amazingness. I got mediocreness!!
The friend we stayed with in San Fran suggested we eat here for our 4th meal (technically just a LATE LATE dinner, after driving for 7 hours!) I wasn't even that hungry so I was going to skip eating all together, but when my friends got their food I had change of heart. I thought Ohhh, I'll just get something small....
I honestly wish I hadn't wasted my $7 and change.
author: Erica W.

description: Great spot for a filling tasty Mexican meal. Came here for dinner after passing by countless times but never going in. Its a pretty small place but I did not have a problem finding a seat to dine in quickly. I ordered the super carnitas burrito which was priced the same as most Mexican restaurants in the bay. They have warm chips which was a great surprise since most places have cold stale ones towards the end of the night. The salsa bar was the best part in my opinion. Great tasting salsas of all varieties. The burrito was pretty good, not better than the mission burritos but definitely above average. Overall I left feeling happy and full, I would come back again.
author: Josue V.

description: Good place for take out. I like the plantain burrito (RIP Cuco's) and the shrimp burrito. Not particularly authentic but a decent place.
author: Ryan Y.

description:
Really good. Not sure if the hype of SF burritos made it taste better. First visit was 100/100 second was 70/100. #1 doesn't take a day off or vacation. They could take over #1 with some consistency but after multiple visits after (only because i
They're located close to home) I don't think they will make top 5 burritos. Lack luster and poor service will only be a small part of their downfall.
author: Connor C.

description:
I sampled the black bean and plantain burrito as well as the prawn burrito. Both were solid-- not spectacular, but they tasted good and had plenty of flavor. I applaud them for the black bean and plantain due to its unique nature and Caribbean-Californian fusion. 

The spot is trendy, with dimmer lights and a more hipster crowd. They have a really good salsa bar, and decent beer selection. 

I would return next time I get burned out of the mission style burrito for one of their unique offerings.
author: Neal C.

description:
This is my first quesadilla at little chihuahua. I've heard many extol the awesomeness that is little chihuahua. I cannot follow suit.

This was absolutely the worst quesadilla I've had, and I've eaten college cafeteria quesadilla's every day for a semester. I'm now 35 and have also had a range of both low and high end foods and can honestly say, this is a quesadilla made for people who have no taste buds.

The chicken is dry and flavorless, I run into bites of cheese as frequently as I have sex (I infrequently have sex), and I don't understand why there are partially cooked onions in my overpriced quesadilla. I will preface this next sentence with "I know this will sound racist and..." there are many people of non color that eat here that should have clued me in to how inadequate this quesadilla would be. 

I took a bite of the burrito my friend was consuming, and it was better, but this quesadilla? I can't. How can anyone mess up a tortilla and cheese? Look no further, I have found those people who can do so.
author: Chris Y.

description: I'm really not one to write negative reviews but my breakfast burrito today had so many raw onions in it and it was very hard to eat. Actually it was borderline gross. I spent a lot of time picking all of them out. Who wants a bunch of raw onions in their breakfast burrito? Not me. The roasted tomato salsa also tasted like water. I've never had a problem with this place before, but my burrito was so hard to eat and it cost $15 dollars, I don't think I'll be back.
author: Katrina S.

description:
I think of this as the "yuppie burrito place". It's ok, it is, but there's just this VIBE to it that's a bit too hipsterized for my taste. Nothing is wrong with it, per se, and I do even like the fact that it's organic but I dunno, when I'm in SF I prefer to eat in the Mission or even, these days, in Oakland (that used to be burrito sacrilege, I know, but there are a few decent places over there these days). 

I like that they let you choose your salsas. I like the free chips. The burrito was ok... But, again, there was something just kinda... Off about it. Both in terms of how the ingredients worked together and also in terms of the size. It was comparatively small! When I get a Bay Area burrito I want to be able to have it for at LEAST breakfast as well as lunch or dinner. I was almost able to finish this one.
author: Jen K.

description: I'll keep it short and simple: The "Super" Burrito is not so super. And at $11 and some change total, the ingredients better had been wholesome and/or organic or whatever they promote (granted it was good and hearty over all), because again the Super burrito is really a REGULAR BURRITO. So one star off for that. Don't deceive the people! Lol. The salsas are good. Don't know how the chips are because they have that ridiculous sign that has a ridiculous excuse as to why they can't have chips come with the orders, which are already expensive enough as it is.
author: Marquis A.

description:
A tiny little joint a short walk from the California Pacific Medical Center where I've spent the past 9 days...just visiting a patient. 
This place has cool decor, a small kitchen, a varied menu and the best carne asada enchiladas I've ever had. 
The tacos are large and in charge, the burritos dank and there's bottled beer as well as a tap with three options (Anchor Steam being one of them). 
It's just real good Mexican food.
author: Jennifer C.

description: Very good food, kinda pricey. But the portions are so big, makes it justified for the prices. I enjoyed the black bean refried bean option. I misused one star for lack of seating. If you live close by, Togo is best. Food is good, very tasty
author: Michelle M.

description:
Life Changing. I've had one of the best burritos in my life from Little Chihuahua. I took the Fried Plantain and black bean burrito and added shrimp and avocado. My burrito was bigger than his.. And I ate the entire thing. I couldn't stop eating it. The tomatillo mixed with habanero salsa was my jam! 
Now please open one in Oakland, preferably on my block.
author: Ayana I.

description: Live half a block away and have been going here regularly since it opened and quality is still high but quantity has dropped dropped significantly. The super steak burrito I got tonight was anything but super when it comes to size. If I'm paying the ridiculous price of $11+ for a burrito I would hope that it would be of the classic overstuffed San Francisco variety and not leave me hungry. Too bad, I guess I'll have to find a new favorite restaurant.
author: Paul W.

description:
I can't finish a whole burrito myself... so it always makes me happy when restaurants have little options to satisfy the smaller appetite.

I've had a few burritos from here, but my favorite is definitely the baby super burrito with carnets. The super burritos contain guac, which i think is crucial for any burrito. However, the "baby" sized burritos are definitely a more reasonable burrito size and don't leave me feeling disgustingly full.

Sometimes there can be a wait - but definitely worth it!!
author: Michelle L.

description:
I am new to San Francisco and was warned early on that I needed form an allegiance with a particular burrito joint. I haven't tried enough places yet to know if The Little Chiuahua is "the one" but it is certainly in the running. 

I went with a group of 4 on a Wednesday night. We arrived around 8pm and it was drizzling outside. The place was still bustling so I imagine it's probably pretty crowded at peak dining times. 

My friend and I both ordered the "baby" chicken burrito with all the fixins. The baby burrito is what people in many other parts of the world would simply call "a burrito." Plenty large to satisfy my medium sized appetite. I wasn't even able to finish the whole thing. The chicken was tender and seasoned very well. The flour tortilla was appropriately fresh and soft. And all of the ingredients were combined in a cohesive, delicious way. They have a limited but satisfactory drink selection. And they serve warm tortilla chips upon request. There's also a self serve bar with different types of salsas. 

The environment is clean and well lit. It's definitely a very casual setting-- a place to visit before (or after) a night out. 

Overall the experience was pleasant and I would return. One of the girls in our party got sick to her stomach a few minutes after eating but we are pretty sure it was unrelated to the food because no one else in our group got sick. 

Will report back after my next visit!
author: Carson S.

description: Late night Mexican food in Haight/ Lower Pac Heights area with nice generous portions on each order. It's small so you may have to stand around but locals usually just come and pick up. My go-to spot if I can't make it to the Mission.
author: Linda L.

description:
