Giving TLC a 5-star rating for their nachos and service. Nachos are eNOMous; especially tasty are the carne asada and chorizo options. As far as I can tell, the meat is locally sourced. 

Quick, fairly cheap, and ultra vibe-y. Staff seems happy to be alive.
author: Wesley K.

description:
This is a 3.5 star review.

Little Chihuahua is a pretty great late-night restaurant. Delicious margaritas, delicious guacamole.. and okay tacos.

I hate to be a debbie downer, but the tacos at little chihuahua weren't as awesome as I'd hoped. I'm much less worried about authenticity than I am with flavor - and Little Chihuahua just didn't deliver.
author: Benjamín S.

description: One of my favorite burritos in SF. Have been to this location for lunch and ordered online from Caviar. The burrito is fantastic every time. I normally order the black bean or pollo asado super baby burrito, which is the perfect size for me. Chicken is cooked well and I love the guacamole. There's something unique and delicious about the tortilla here. If you dine in, there is a great array of salsas and a nice, sunny atmosphere. I've never had a problem getting a table on the weekends, but I've only been at early lunch time and could be beating the rush. One complaint about the dine-in experience is the tables can be a little messy when they are busy, but that's minor.
author: Ana D.

description:
Eh. It's slightly upscale Mexican food for white people. Not doughy suburban white people a la Chevy's, but pasty white people a la The New Mission. I had been in the mood for Mexican food, but I didn't realize that this spot was 'Mexican-inspired.' Not knowing anything about the ownership or style of this place, as I was eating my food I thought 'this spot has got to be the brainchild of an Anglo hipster.' And I wasn't wrong - as I later found out from an episode of 'Check Please! Bay Area,' on which the Noe Valley branch of this restaurant was reviewed. 

The shrimp enchiladas were fine (not phenomenal), ingredients fresh and quality, and the salsa bar and chips were pretty OK. However, the test of a Mexican place for me is tortilla soup and I was SO not impressed with their version - almost a clear broth (tortilla soup should be reddish and in many cases is thick), fatty chicken thigh (granted, I'm a chicken breast snob), and not much 'tortilla soup' in this tortilla soup. Granted, I'm a bit of a Mexican food snob, having been raised on it and my adopted mom being from Guadalajara and throwing down real Mexican food, so there is that, but I have just so little patience for 'nouvelle (insert ethnicity here)' cuisine of any time - I raked some taco place in Silverlake over the coals for that shit, too. It was just all very guero to me and i pushed it aside after a few bites. Le sigh. 

The place was filled with ironic facial hair, glossy young tech recruiter types, and a preponderance of smartphones - a chilly, disconnected vibe. I disliked the 'bus your own table' bullshit, not because i mind doing it, but because your average restaurant patron does a piss poor job of it. 

If you're looking for fresh, clean, 'Mexican INSPIRED' food, by all means, have at it. Many people seem to love it and I hear the seafood tacos are good, but for a down home authentic Mexican experience, look elsewhere.
author: Cake M.

description:
I'm giving this place 4-stars based exclusively on the plantain burrito. I think paying $11+ for a burrito in SF is a bit ridic, BUT the plantain and black bean is a unique and scrumptious combination, so occasionally worth the burrito-outside-of-the-Mission premium. 

This location is pretty small and can get crowded, so if you're trying to eat in, plan on hovering over a table until someone leaves.
author: Lindsey B.

description:
It's my neighborhood Mexican place! The burritos are good (although, nothing special when you consider all the great stuff happening in the Mission) and the line for pickups is nice and convenient. I always get the Al Pastor Burrito -- I know, I know: boring. I tried that trendy plantain thing, but it wasn't for me. Maybe too many plantains? I'll stop there because I know there are some loyalists on here that might take issue. 

The only other thing I'll criticize is their diminishing chip count in to-go bags. It seems like there are fewer and fewer chips every time I go. I counted last time - 8 chips! Maybe I'm just imagining things.
author: Michael M.

description:
TLC could convince me to move next door. I kid, I kid. BUT, I really wish there were more Mexican spots in Nob Hill, or at least surrounding area. We're seriously lacking in that arena, but enter delivery (a la Try Caviar) from Little Chihuahua! 

I had home sweet San Diego on the mind and was craving some authentic eats. Time and again, I can never finish burritos. Sad. Solution? Enter the baby burrito. I was pleasantly surprised with the size, given it's supposed to be a mini-version of the regular. This was no two-bite snack, but the real deal! Really flavorful green chili pollo, rice, beans, and salsa. There's also an option to add all the fixins'. Chips were tasty (and still warm!) too. I'll be back!
author: Brianna M.

description: Little Chi-wha?-wha? This is the epitome of your neighborhood spot. Chill, easy going brunch place. Come for the chiaquiles and add a side of quad. It's a small place, so don't be surprised by the wait. But the food is excellent
author: Vince E.

description:
I am glad I believed the hyper over the fried plantain and black bean burrito. The burrito was unbelievably delicious. Its a vegetarian's dream! Perfect amount of beans, plantains, cheese, salsa...omg need I say more?! You absolutely have to make a stop here if you are in the area because you will not be disappointed! The service here is very casual, as with most small Mexican eateries. They give you an ample amount of DELICIOUS tortilla chips and I enjoyed sampling every one their salsas from the salsa bar!

LOVE.LOVE.LOVE this place!
author: Surge C.

description: Little Chihuahua in general has some pretty good things - Taco salad is delicious, plantain burrito is delicious - BUT this review is about the breakfast burrito. You must be warned. You will ruin your morning if you have this - not good. Something about the consistency of too many black beans, something watery about the experience. I've tried it twice. JUST DON'T DO IT. I'm sorry Little Chihuahua I wish it were otherwise.
author: Susannah C.

description: This place consistently delivers delicious tacos, burritos and a great casual vibe. I like that the food is fresh, really tasty and consistent.  The best thing on the menu is the plantain burrito.  It is pricey, though, so be aware.
author: Chris M.

description:
Garlic Shrimp Burrito. Garlic Shrimp Burrito. Garlic Shrimp Burrito!

Ya' hear me?

K. good. just checking. 

Free salsa bar also good if you're up for experimenting with what salsa goes best with your food.  In my tour of SF one burrito at a time I would totally give this an 8/10. Not to be missed.
author: Liss T.

description: Crazy delicious tortilla soup. I've never had tortilla soup this amazing before! I'm not even super into soup or anything. It's spicy and fills you up! Highly recommend!
author: Sami Y.

description: The carnitas tacos were delicious and so flavorful, they reminded me of barbacoa  style tacos. Also the garlic shrimp burritos are flavorful and super filling.
author: Jen C.

description:
I didn't have the food this time around but I did get a rootbeer float which was made with ice cream from Humphrey Slocombe. It was really tasty that the people I finished it before the people I was with even got their order. I have heard the food is really good so I'll have to try it next time I'm in the area. If I hadn't already have eaten I would've probably gotten a burrito. 

The staff here are really nice even when it's ridiculously crowded. Prices seemed pretty reasonable. If you can't make it to this location, they have another near The Mission.

The communal tables tend to fill up quickly as well so plan accordingly.
author: Amy J.

description:
About a year ago, I had my first little chihuahua experience...and I thought it would be my last.  I did not like the food whatsoever...it was plain, and just blah.  So why did I give it another try?  Well, Wifey's work gave her a gift card awhile ago...and I was craving a burrito.  Sure, why not?  Let's give it another whirl. 

So we walked in and I ordered a chile verde chicken super burrito, no beans, add grilled veggies on a spinach tortilla.  Oh, and I also ordered arroz con leche.  We grabbed an array of salsas...they have a whole bar for your amusement...and took off to eat our meal at home.  

To my surprise, the food was excellent.  It was super flavorful...the chicken was tender...and I absolutely loved the grilled veggies.  The salsas were decent...not the best I've ever had...but good enough to slop over my burrito and dip my tortilla chips into.  

The arroz con leche was freakin wonderful!!!  The rice was perfect...the sweetness was omg great...I love the cookie stuff they put as a garnish...ugh, it was just dang good.  

Little chihuahua totally redeemed itself...as the terminator once said...I'll be back!
author: Jen W.

description:
3.5 stars! 

TLC has a cult of fans that love them, so please don't hate me for giving them this rating, for I am an extremely picky mexican-food eater who was blessed to have lived in socal/san diego where there are an abundance of authentic, really good, and really cheap mexican food. 

I came here for a late lunch around 1:30pm yesterday with a friend because we had heard good things about this place. The restaurant is definitely a nicer, more "upscale" mexican restaurant, especially compared to those hole-in-the-wall taquerias in the Mission. 

You order at the cashier first and then are given a basket of chips to go find a seat and sit down while your order is being prepared. I loved the habanero(? it's the spiciest one) salsa and the pico de gallo, but the chipotle (or whichever the medium salsa is) seemed suspiciously thick, almost paste-like, for it to be called a salsa. Nonetheless, the salsas I tried were good, for the most part. 

I ordered the Garlic Shrimp burrito, and I have to say it was decent, but not amazing especially for the higher price tag compared to taquerias. It was pretty flavorful and had a clean taste, and the garlic taste did shine through, but I felt that the burrito was mostly rice and very little of every other ingredients that went in. For the $12 pricetag on the burrito, I would've appreciated a bit more generosity with the shrimp and maybe avocado, since I found myself taking multiple bites that seemed to just all be rice. (That, or either distribute the ingredients better because i had maybe 2  bites where it should just be all the shrimps that were in the burrito)

My friend ordered the breakfast burrito, and she also said it was okay, but not worth trekking out to this area of SF to spend $10-11 on. 

It's not the most authentic mexican place I've been to and again, I think the price is a little discouraging seeing that you could probably get an authentic taqueria burrito in the Mission for half the cost with more well-distributed and plentiful ingredients. But, I think the flavors were mostly there, so I feel like I wouldn't go out of my way to come here again, but I would stop by if I happened to be in the area and was craving mexican food.
author: Judy B.

description: Ok...it's San Francisco, who doesn't enjoy a burrito. This place has the best Al Pastor burrito. The salsa bar is very fresh and the chips are made in house. Although the chips aren't free, the quality is worth the extra buck. The dining room is small but family friendly and the staff is very efficient. With a few locations, this place is a must try.
author: Thomas B.

description:
I ordered a quesadilla of pollo asado together with chips.
Based on previous reviews, I expected an awesome taste but it was just normal/meh... Too much sauce for me.

Their service need to improve. They're not rude but a smile and kind words are always appreciated.
author: Josep T.

description:
The restaurant is small, but it's well furnished and designed. The service is excellent and the food came quickly.

We ordered a couple burritos, which were both extremely good, enchiladas, also really good, and guacamole to share. 

No complaints at all about the food. The only thing is that we expected something a bit cheaper because it only has one dollar sign marked on Yelp, but I think it deserves another one.
author: Andrew F.

description: Oh, how I love The Little Chihuahua. The plantain burrito is SO delicious. When I'm really craving a burrito, I venture to this little gem in SF and get my favorite burrito. Go and eat here. NOW.
author: Jessika V.

description:
My favorite texmex food joint on Divis and worth the walk from Mcallister. Consistently great food/service, clean and pleasant dining area. Food is always SO fresh. 

+ Guacamole Enchiladas are my absolute fave at this joint. Greatly portioned and will leave you full with enough leftovers to take home. The poblano peppers are love. Don't know what it is about me and avocados but it makes me forget about the cheese/sour cream I leave out, making everything right in the world again. 

+ Super Baby Burrito is exactly what it sounds like. I like chicken burritos (b/c what's up, protein?) but just read on their site's menu that you can ask for Salmon...wassup Omega-3sss? This is the perfect size for me, even when my levels of hunger vary.

*eat all of the above with their chips = main recipe for happiness. 

+Salsa bar is on point and delish, but not a big fan of the Chipotle salsa.

major ++:  they have $3 beer on tap (you're welcome)
author: Kat L.

description: Not impressed. Ordered tortilla soup and nachos. The soup was not very flavorful and meat was not cut in manageable sizes. And red sauce on nachos? Don't get it....
author: Shengyin G.

description:
This place is beloved by locals and tourists alike.  The baby burrito was big enough for a full meal.  I was psyched to see that they had tofu, but didn't love it when I tried it.  The grilled veggies were great, though.  

I paid 8$ for a good sized, very fresh super burrito and chips.  There was ample seating, friendly staff.  Great place for a girls' lunch.
author: Missy M.

description:
Awesome!!! LOVE this place!! My family and I got the fish tacos and two tostada salads with salmon---which is basically this massive taco salad, but infinitely more delicious, better quality food and filled with different flavors. We are a healthy eating family too so it was nice that the quality of food was top too.

The only mistake we made was getting an entrée for each person because the portions are big. One entree was definitely enough for two or even three people (which also helps bring down the price too!) 

A Must-go. Highly recommend TLC and will be going back soon for sure.
author: Sahar H.

description:
Great food! Slightly pricey for comparable quality in the Mission, but I'd come back. I ordered the wild mushroom taco, arroz con leche, and the plantain/black bean burrito (I took some of it to go, I swear). Both of the savory items were really tasty, and the portions are definitely large. Chips come with your order, and the salsa bar is varied and un-watery, and includes a crazy spicy habanero salsa if that's your style.

The surprise standout - the arroz con leche!! This was the best rice pudding I've ever had (beats Loving Cup!). The tequila-soaked raisins added a nice kick, and the cinnamon-y gingerbread biscuits on top did wonders for the texture. It was huge, but I could've had two more.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Reasonable price with great Mexican food options. 

I came here on Sunday expecting to get a burrito and was surprised to find out they serve brunch. I tried Mexican french toast with plantains and bacons topped with maple-agave syrup. The dish looks more like crepes to me since plantains and bacons are wrapped inside the battered flour tortillas. If you're in the mood for something sweet and different, this is a great dish to try.

Huevos Motulenos (a variation from Huevos Rancheros) is another dish we tried. Instead of tortillas, the dish is served with crispy corn tostadas. The dish came with royal hams, refried beans, queso fresco and mexican potatoes. I'll give this one a 3 star, since the potatoes are a bit overcooked and mushy. 

I'll have to come back here to try their burritos sometime soon!
author: Saran R.

description:
You can find affordable Mexican street food in TLC. I went in on a Sunday afternoon, when I had my burrito craze. 

Good:
- The Special Al Pastor burrito (from the special menu, with pineapple salsa) is very juicy and balanced (every bite has everything!). 
- Good selection in the open salsa bar. 

Meh:
- The pork stew is bland.
author: Omer G.

description: I'm a big fan of their tortilla and chicken soup. They are both so good!
author: Karla V.

description: I love TLC's baby enchiladas. The portion sizes aren't baby at all. It's very filling to eat and is one of the best Mexican places in the heart of Mission.
author: Vhalerie L.

description:
The food is pretty good (would've given 4 stars) but the delivery service - Caviar - they use is a total mess.  It takes forever, is really expensive (esp. as a New Yorker used to Seamless) and the delivery people are totally incompetent.  

My food came with everything spilled and crushed, the bag split wide open, and a replacement dirty/used bag from the driver's personal belongings around the whole mess.  I didn't even want to eat the food after that.  

Also, it would be nice if they took the effort to look at what you ordered and include the right utensils.  I had a soup and there was only a fork and knife in the bag.  :(

Ditch the Winkelvoss-backed crappy delivery service and it'll much better.
author: Jules M.

description: Sadly, they've deteriorated. This place has been my go-to for years, especially for the signature garlic shrimp burrito. But I was sorely disappointed tonight by the sour service and greed. It was 14 bucks for the burrito, and they've even started charging an extra buck for the chips. Funny, there was no line and plenty of tables were empty too.
author: John H.

description: The quality of food changes depending on how busy the place is.  I live a couple blocks away and this is my go to place.  I've given them several chances over the course of a year and quite honestly I'm fed up.  Either the food is overlooked or the size of burritos changes each time I go in when it is busy.  Let's see some consistency here.
author: bobby o.

description: Delicious garlic shrimp burrito and horchata! So filling and satisfying. Highly recommended!
author: Angela C.

description:
The burrito was so disappointing, it ruined my day; I just felt like fighting with people -- namely my fiancé who endured the brunt of the beast (love you, Andrew!)

I got it "smothered" with some sort of sour vinegar sap they dare to call green chile.  It was rolled so carelessly that everything fell out when I finally managed to cut through the tough, behemoth folds of tortilla clumped along the edges.  Inside, the only non-sour flavor I could taste was strangely sweet.  The chips were kind of tough and somewhat stale and the salsas had a weird aftertaste.  I was stoked they had al pastor, but surprise! it was nothing more than big flavorless cubes (yes, cubes) of pork.  

If you've never had good Mexican food, perhaps they'll manage to fool you with the carved sun chairs and Dos Equis in the cooler.  But if that doesn't apply to you, don't waste your money.
author: Yelena K.

description: I need to go here more often because this was one of the better Mexican places I've been in the city. They have great burritos and a really cool and friendly vibe going on here. It is small but I love the atmosphere and sometimes a good alternative for great Mexican if you don't want to "deal" with the Mission. Bueno!
author: Derek S.

description: A must stop while in sf.  The black beans plantain burrito made the long trip from nyc worthwhile. Younger Brother raved about this place but I was skeptical until I had the burrito and the carnitas nachos. Only reason they are not getting 5 is that it is a very small place and tables are too close for comfort, but lots of folks doing take out.
author: A A.

description:
(I really hate doing the 5-Star review thing. There has to be a distinction in tastocity, but if this is all yelp* has for ratings, then this is a well-deserved 5-Star.)

¡¡¡Oh, mi Perro!!!

I went to the Lower Haight location for "Brunch" on Sunday morning. I had eaten "Brunch" once before at their Noe Valley restaurant a few years ago and had been meaning to get back again to try a different dish. I had the Stacked Enchiladas (Corn tortillas stacked and filled with Jack cheese, sautéed Poblano chiles and onions, Mexican potatoes, black beans, and braised pork. Smothered in a red Guajillo sauce and topped with two over easy eggs, chopped avocado and Cotija cheese.) and a glass of Sandía Aguas Frescas.

I ordered the entrée "sin los trozos de carne de cerdo". It was excellent. It literally had "layers of flavours" to it. The Guajillo salsa that is on it was very tasty, too. They make their watermelon aguas frescas with fresh mint mulled into it, which really freshens it up a bit more. 

Not only is the food there great, but they offer five different fresh-made salsas from which to choose to use on with the complimentary corn tortilla chips. I tried some of the Habanero (excellent), Chipotle (excellent, and probably my favourite of the three I tried), and Roasted Tomato (very good, just not as excellent as the other two).

If you would care to read a bit more detailed (and rambling) review, please click on my Profile here and check out my stupid li'l breakfastary 'blog-thing which has the link there.
author: Brian M.

description:
Little Chihuahua is amazing!  I have been here a few times and each time it gets better.  This time I had enchiladas (1 carne asada, 1 shrimp) which came with your choice of beans, and rice.  The carne asada was grilled (as it should) and had a smoky/bbq flavor.  The enchiladas were complex (not just cheese and meat).  Full of manchego cheese, grilled plabanos, grilled onions, and the meat.

They also have a nice selection of vegetarian options.  The salsa bar is a must with the fresh, hot chips
author: Alan H.

description:
Went there with a colleague from Singapore who never had Mexican food and we both enjoyed the dishes . I would definitely go back next time I'm in SF.
Restaurant is a bit cramped but we did managed to get a table even on Sunday.
author: Silviu T.

description:
Cute name but the tacos didn't live up to my hopes. There's a few branches of TLC and we stopped at this one on our walk to Golden Gate Park. We've now encountered lots of places with this style of ordering - go up to the counter and place your order, then grab a seat. I was in the mood for tacos but didn't realise the only served soft shell ones, so that was a disappointment. I had shrimp (camarones) and chicken (chile verde chicken) which came to around $11 - reasonable value for lunch. I also like that they have complimentary tortilla chips and a counter of dips/sauces to help yourself to. 

There's something about a soft taco shell that I don't really like - I think it's just a bit too bland for me. So I mostly stuck with the filling and was impressed with the portion sizes. All in all though, they were just ok - not packed with flavour, could have used more coriander and needed sauces added to it to pep it up. I think we were lucky having such great tacos in Mission the other day, so that has set the bar pretty high. 

Staff were friendly and helpful, and the restaurant was pretty clean. It was a decent place to spend 30 minutes but I wouldn't rush back.
author: Briony C.

description:
For  take out - 5 stars. Our Tostada steak salad was great and fed both of us. Chips and salsa were also great.

For eating. 3 stars. Too loud to hear the person sitting next to you. Not enough space.Just too crowded.
author: Neuy D.

description: Huge portions. Great vegetarian options. Plantain burrito was tasty and super interesting. The baby burrito is pretty big; don't try to eat the whole regular burrito size. Burrito was well-constructed and ran no risk of falling apart, if you can fit it in your mouth. Carnitas were fine.
author: David B B.

description: Big fan of this place. Service is awesome and the food is great. I got the Carne Asada burrito and it was the bomb. Will definitely be coming back.
author: Richard A.

description:
In our goal for unique and tasty burritos in the Bay area, we hit up The Little Chihuahua, which we'd seen listed on a best of Bay burrito list some time ago. What intrigued us was the interesting sounding "plantain" burrito. Another option aside from meats, beans and rice? I'll give that a shot!

We came in on Saturday, a bit after 1 pm and the place was packed, despite the later lunch hour. I wasn't even sure we'd get a seat, but we managed to get a separate table. There's several shared table options if you don't mind rubbing elbows with strangers or if you come in with a larger party. Our order consisted of a chicken burrito and the plantain burrito with a side of chips. 

There are several different salsas of varying heats available for the free chips you get with your order. I actually found the pico de gallo hotter than one of the others, which seemed odd. One of them was an amazing garlic-flavoured salsa, and there was also a smoky chipotle sauce that I tried but couldn't handle the heat from. Combined with the fresh chips, it was definitely a good appetite whetter. 

Our burritos came out pretty quickly given how busy it was. The plantain one was actually pretty large, especially in comparison to the chicken burrito! I unwrapped and dug in with excitement. 

There's not much I can say to it other than "wow"! There was a huge range of flavours and it's not a lie to say that there was a party going on in my mouth, and I couldn't quite figure out what the hell was going on. The not-overly sweet plantain mixed with tomatoes and beans and cheese and chiles and who knows what else. It was such a unique flavour experience, I was literally blown away.

The chicken burrito was also a hit. We finished off as much as we could, then cleared our table and headed out. 

We didn't eat for quite awhile afterwards, finding that these burritos were extremely filling and long-lasting. I think we started craving dinner around 7:30 pm. 

When the plantain burrito made it onto one of the Bay's lists for burrito places, they weren't lying. This is worth going to and checking out if you're looking for a unique taste sensation. Happily two thumbs up!
author: Cassandra J.

description:
Great food, great ingredients, and unique offerings.

Good service, can get crowded. Definitely a hot spot in the neighborhood. It's casual/fast dining with upscale food/quality, you bus your tables, but they call or bring your order to you, and there's a mellow vibe about it that I appreciate. 

Many reviews here are a bit severe about "authentic Mexican", which is laughable, because isn't that always the case? Unless your abuela is running some fly-by-night restaurant operation out of her kitchen, any spot is chastised for being inauthentic Mexican food. This one was never posing as such, and their food is obviously California inspired and makes use of the excellent local products and modern/popular food niches. 

Get off your high horse, people - It's a gem.
author: Jane H.

description:
I think I've successfully managed to enjoy all three essential meals of the day at The Little Chihuahua. First stumbled in hungover and majorly in need of some mimosa action. 

Holy buckets. 

Just trust me and get the whole damn carafe of mimosas before you peep that brunch menu. (The french toast, breakfast tacos and chile rellano have my complete blessing)

Burritos are always on par (Put some of that habanero salsa in the garlic shrimp burrito. Go ahead. I'll wait while you're swooning) and if you're big on eating a burrito out of a bowl then the tostada salad will not let you down. I mean, seriously. That thing is bigger than my face. (twss)

It can get super packed and seating is a relative free for all but if you can manage to figure out the crowd timing, you're primed to be golden.
author: Kelsey G.

description:
Authentic Mexican?  No.
Authentically delicious?  Yes. 

Walking distance = plus
Tasty salsa bar = plus
Pretty solid food in the mecca of non-mexican food = plus   
With a little "guidance", wouldn't kick it out of bed for eating crackers....

I've gotten (at different times):

Chicken Quesadilla: B
Good flavor, a little mushy.  Will ask for a crispier one next time...  BAM!

Fajita Burrito w/ steak: B 
Sans the beans.  I like to think they have the proportions of the different ingredients memorized in their heads.  And that they used those same quantities, only w/ out the beans.  Resulting in a very small burrito.  **DOH!!**  Next time, I'll request extra of everything else, to make up for the difference.  

I'm confident, it will turn out wonderfully.  lol.  

Until next time, my furry friend.
author: CatwomanRoar M.

description: Place is a little small and salsa is 3 out of 5 but burritos are pretty good so if your hungry make sure you get the fajita burrito or the super burrito !!!
author: Complex D.

description: One of the few burritos outside the mission that is worth having.  They do a great job here.  Loses one star because the pricing is nuts! These babies are not cheap.
author: Nick A.

description:
Contender for best vegetarian burrito in the city, the plaintain and black bean is amazing (but a bit too sweet for me) -- I usually go with the wild mushroom. You can also get multiple things mixed! Hellloooo mushroom and tofu burrito.

Would be better if the tofu were more flavorful a la Papalote
author: Alex Y.

description:
I love LC. There, I said it. I love it. Whether it's going crazy with carnitas nachos (two words: do it), or a lighter plate (1 enchilada and a side of grilled vegetables), there is so much to like here. For breakfast, you will be missing out if you don't get the chilaquiles. Sure, you may need a nap after them. And yeah, you'll probably be eating steamed broccoli for the remainder of the week's meals. But it's worth it, my friends. It's worth it. 

The only disappointment is the unappealing lettuce they use for the salad. The salad would be unstoppable with something that wasn't a bitter, bagged mesclun-like lettuce mix. But you know what, I'll get my little gems elsewhere and be happy with everything else.
author: Bern S.

description: Mediocre service--this is a casual place, where you order at the counter and your food is brought to you. However, the guy taking the orders fully ignored us for several minutes while he answered the phone and prepared to-go bags...all without even greeting or acknowledging us. He also got our order wrong (they put meat in my nachos), even though he seemed to acknowledge that he was making everything vegetarian for me (i.e. warning me that they cook their beans in bacon fat). Aside from that, the food was really delicious. Amazing nachos and enchiladas, and the margarita was deliciously tart and strong.
author: Adrienne P.

description: One of thee most flavorful burritos I have ever ate in my life! A few months ago, I yelped various Mexican restaurants that were located in San Francisco and bookmarked the ones with the highest ratings. This place was one of them. Very friendly customer service and very nice ambiance. I ordered a baby super grilled chicken burrito.  It definitely exceeded my expectation! Believe the ratings, they're accurate. ..
author: Jasmine R.

description:
San Francisco, this is an intervention. 

You can't go on like this, paying ridiculous amounts of Google money for decent food. It's getting silly. It's embarrassing. You're drunk and you're disappointing your parents.

The food is relatively fresh, and in general, pretty good (carne asada is their best meat option in my opinion) and I usually let their prices slide because, as you hear so often, "everything is expensive in the city." 

Today was the last straw though, when I paid over 13 dollars for a chicken quesadilla and a Coke. It wasn't a bad quesadilla. In fact, it had fancy things, like "onions" in it. Yes, the cheese was a bit too gooey and the chicken was a bit dry but it was serviceable and I probably wouldn't have bothered to leave a review if it wasn't for the sneer and slight glance the cashier gave to the tip jar, when I didn't leave what was left of my money there. 

San Franciscans, we're better than this.
author: Baron C.

description:
Went on a Sunday Brunch with 2 kids. Nice little cozy joint with about 20 tables. We ordered the 

- Mexican French Toast - not too good, bacon was burnt almost and it's a bit hard to eat
-Breakfast Burrito - AWESOME !!! I love it. Filled with sausage, rice, eggs and some yummy sauce wrapped in a tortilla. 
-Chilaquiles - the guy was right when I asked for his recommendation. He said you'll need to take a nap after you ate that. It was realllly really good and we wanted to take a nap after, actually the youngest one did in the car. Nacho like serving with a fried egg on top, order it...total food coma for us
-Breakfast Tacos with fish - Fresh, refreshing and just want to eat more and more. 

This is the place to be if you want some serious Mexican brunch. I will definitely return for their a la cart.

Try to go before the rush hour, parking was easy as it was a weekend, got the spot right in front of the restaurant. We left around 11:30 and the place was filled.

My new favorite spot !
author: Vicky M.

description: The breakfast Mexican French toast is by far the most spectacular brunch ever had by man. Fried plantains, bacon, and maple syrup... my god. Lunch/dinner options are also great, large portions for a good price. I'll be back soon!
author: Duncan C.

description: Pricey -- you'll spend $12 - 15 all in for a meal here that you could get for $8 - 10 elsewhere, but their ingredients are supposed to be organic, grass-fed, etc. Flavors are not mind-blowing as you won't find fall-off the bone tender meats or richly flavored sauces, but they're good enough for a solid meal.
author: Christina J.

description: Walked past this place always wanted to stop.  Like the order at the counter but quality food vibe.  Great for a quick dinner but does not skimp on quality.  Had a shrimp taco and a pork with pineapple salsa taco.  Negro Modelo on draft for $4 and a salsa bar.  These are the best tortilla chips I have had in the city, much thinner - I am not a big fan of the thick chips that seem to be everywhere in San Francisco.
author: Alison K.

description:
Little Chihuahua never disappoints.  We've been going since it opened, and watched it go from half empty and building it's rep, to packed all the time, and food and service quality stayed at it's original high level.  Brava. 

I'd call the food Mexicali and have never had a bad meal there.  It's on my go-to list for comfort food --- about once a month I have to go and get the tortilla soup.  The salsa bar is great - something I've really missed since leaving Texas is constant access to excellent chipotle.  

It's a great space for two or a group.  Cozy and hipster-cute.  While it's always packed, seems like spaces magically open up as soon as you get your food.   

The service is always awesome - quick and friendly.
author: Sandra M.

description: I found this place by using Yelp when I was visiting the area and WOW did it pay off. I was there during brunch time (when they add a few special brunch options to their menu) and ended up ordering the breakfast burrito with chorizo (YUM and YUM). Absolutely delicious. The fresh salsas at the salsa bar were all delicious and hot but not crazy. Love this place. Wish I lived in San Francisco so I could go there when I got the munchies. ;-)
author: Eric M.

description:
They have Pacifico, Negro Modelo, and one other beer on tap for $3 each!
The salsas are delicious. The chips are nice and thin.

I had an al pastor taco and my wife had a tostada salad. Everything was perfect! I felt like I was on vacation in Mexico while eating here. I've been wanting to find a place like this in the city for so long. I can't wait to go back. Nice decorations too!
author: Tomas P.

description:
Left a bit to be desired. The tostada salad dressing was good, but the salsa or something in it was too spicy and distracted from the overall dish. 
Decent pricing and free chips and a salsa bar - even though I didn't care for any of the salsas...but cute decor, friendly and quick service. 
Not sure if I'll be back but I won't knock it either. It didn't taste traditional but it has nice options for vegetarians.
author: S. M.

description: Small and casual Mexican. Very little seating.  I hear such good things, but I was not terribly impressed.  It's good  - but given the wealth of Mexican options in SF, only 3 stars.
author: Greg B.

description:
This place has not just great food...but friendliest faces evah! I have tried the tacos and also quesadillas and never disappointed! Warm chips while we wait with salsas to choose from, too. 
Warm and friendly, who couldn't fall in love with this place?
author: Pam S.

description:
After reading all the reviews I decided to try the Garlic Shrimp Burrito here. Came here on a friday night and the place was pretty crowded but got a table in about 20 minutes.

The girl taking the order was super nice and we got our food pretty quick. The burrito was just a-okay, there was hardly any flavor in it. San Francisco has such good Mexican food that I don't think we should compromise on flavor at all.

I think the salsa bar may have earned them an extra point. Unlike the burrito the salsa bar actually was really good.

I still want to come here again to try the Plantain burrito, will update the review if that makes me change my mind about this place but there's nothing special about the garlic shrimp burrito.
author: Saadullah S.

description: The little Chihuahua was good, super casual but the food was pretty good. I was with a group of 4 and I got the taco salad which was delicious and everyone else got burritos. The garlic shrimp burrito (that I had a bite of was really good!) Also, my sister, who is vegan, got the chile verde tofu burrito with veggie refried black beans, and a chile tomato tortilla and it was surprisingly awesome! but the ambience environment was just okay, it was super crowded and it felt very hectic. It is just a personal preference of mine but I love to sit down relax over good food and good conversation so that is all it was lacking but even then I am still giving it 4 stars (3.5 if I could).
author: Samantha J.

description:
We came on a Sunday evening around 815, 830pm and BOY was it packed!!!!! We were so surprised as we walked in to see the line wrapped around the tables, but it was a good sign that the food must be good!

Stood and line and browsed through the menu. You have the standard items like quesadillas, tacos, and burritos (super, green chili, red chili, etc). Also on the menu are the specialty burritos including the garlic shrimp burrito, black bean & plantaines burrito and an al pastor burrito. Two soups are also there to round out the menu alongside the drink options.

The line went fairly fast and we were able to customize our orders once at the front with wheat/spinach tortillas and getting an al pastor quesadilla even though it wasn't on the menu. Sat down, filled up on a ton of the salsas at the salsa bar and chowed on the big bowl of chips & salsa for awhile. Finally realized they had accidentally given our order to the table next to us, so we went to the counter to clear the confusion. They were really nice and gave us a side of guacamole for the mistake. Food came out relatively quick after that.

Was happy with my shrimp burrito as the shrimp was the plump kind and plenty in the burrito, not the small baby shrimps. The al pastor was also juicy in the gigantic qusadilla. Food was good, but not necessarily cheap compared to other options in the Mission. But then again, we're not venturing all the way to the Mission for our Mexican food craving ---- 5 stars!!!

Venue also reminded me of my ol' Berkeley days. Crowd was mixed and all super friendly in the communal tables :)
author: Angela S.

description: I go here at least once a week. Their black bean and plantain burrito is the bomb! You can either drop in and eat there or order ahead for pickup.
author: Dane W.

description:
We (my husband and I) came here a couple weeks ago on our quest to try 52 new places in 52 weeks. 

I am shocked that we've never been to this place before; a hidden gem on Divisadero. I had the quesadilla and my husband had the enchiladas and we each had a Jarritos. Even though both were good, of course in this city it's easy to have had better.  But that wouldn't preclude us from returning. The ambiance was good, the waitstaff very helpful, and it's on a fun stretch of Divisadero (which in my opinion could become the new Valencia). We will be returning!
author: Melissa N.

description:
I've been itching to come here for a while, as I heard they have great salads, I finally had a chance to stop by today.  

Ambiance:  the place was less 'divey' then I expected.  It was cheerful and clean and cosey.   I think this is a good reflection of the food as well. 

Food: 
Tostada salad:   I ordered this vegan, which meant they skipped the cheese and salad dressing (which has egg).  I ordered it with the wild mushrooms.  The salad was very big and tasted really good. The mushroom were great, and so were the other marinated red peppers and such.  I wish this salad had more beans though, I ended up eating too many unhealthy nachos to fill up.  Next time I'd ask them to give me extra beans in place of the cheese.  Also note the salad was a little bland without the dressing, but not too bad as it still had some mango salsa and marinated veggies.  

Beef quesadilla:  this is what my husband had. He liked it a lot and wants to go back. He said it wasn't very authentic, but a very good example of a typical Americanized one. 

I liked the self serve salsa.  I love tons and tons of salsa and was happy I could take as much as I like. :).
author: Evelyn N.

description:
Great alternative to a burrito - try the tacos, $4.25 each and they are VERY generous with the meat. I got two chicken tacos and both of them were overflowing with large chunks of the nice part of the chicken. Plus they COME with guac (no extra charge like 99% of other places) and free chips. 

Tip: Beer on tap is cheaper and you get a pint. They've got pacifico, negra modelo and anchor steam on tap.
author: Sonya Z.

description: Food Posioning: Me and two friends ate here on 02/15/16 she had the typical food poisoning symptoms that night (prawn burrito), I had them the next morning (Pozole), the other guy was fine (Fajita Burrito). I contacted LC about this - no response so I contacted the City. One star for food poisoning with no response from LC. One additional star for all the previous good experiences I had with the pozole prior to the incident.
author: J S.

description: After leaving nightlife at the Academy of Sciences, TLC was one of the few places that opened late and was close by to where we were. Parking was difficult and we had to drive around Divisadero for awhile, we finally found a spot. The place was busy and very cozy, you have to order at the register first before you take a seat. I ordered a steak burrito and then took a seat. The total cost for my burrito and diet coke was $14, which is pretty expensive for a burrito (I know, I know they have grass fed beef, organic and so on...). I really enjoyed my burrito, it was good, it was a lot smaller compared to Gordos and Chipotle, but it was fine. The tortilla wasn't moist or soft where it sticks to your teeth and had a bite on it, which I really liked. If I end up back here, I'd get a burrito again, I just wouldn't go out of my way to spend that much money on a burrito.
author: Lily S.

description: Best tortilla soup. Tacos are too big. (no, that's not really a problem) but be forwarned. I order one and split it into two. I like the atmosphere. It's simple and pleasant. Fresh, clean Mexican food. They use high quality meats so you'll pay a little more for it. Did I mention the tortilla soup??  Oh, and If you take stars off because it's too crowded, you suck and have no business reviewing a restaurant
author: Fareed R.

description: Awesome carne asada burritos, like that they grill them, but the chip charge has to go
author: Barry Z.

description: Basically, this place is the best spot to get good Mexican on Divis. Love their plantain burrito (with carnitas, yum!). Their salsa bar is on point and their food is delicious.
author: Morgan M.

description:
This place is SO good. Food is always fresh, excellent, consistent.  TLC has struck the perfect combo (equal parts chill and competent) of quality/service/price-point that holds -- thrives!-- when the [small] place goes from three diners to thirty (in thirty seconds).  Regardless of how busy they are, no aspect is ever sacrificed.  I actually believe (unbelievably) that the time between ordering at the register and food arrival  has been exactly the same every time-- ~ 4.0 minutes.  Seems impossible, but I can attest to this marvel, in all sobriety.  Are they wizards? Cylons? 

They're very nice too -- the people who work there. (Not Cylons probably)
Anyway, it's a safe bet at any hour -- they seem to be open whenever I walk by -- and even when calling in a pick-up order, they mean it when they say come by in five minutes.  As convenient /easy as getting fast food, but of course a billion times better.  Has a happy + lively atmosphere as well.

I am guessing that their patronage is primarily locals from the neighborhood--Divis./Haight--who walk in a few times a week maybe.  That IS the coveted vouch, though: SF locals (surrounded by great food options!).  My friend (she lives two minutes away!) was actually the one who took me here first.  I haven't tried the more unique things on the menu, but my boyfriend says the plantain burrito is really good.  He's gotten that several times, but now he's on tacos.  He's actually a coveted vouch as well, if you knew him, because he's very uhhh discriminating about food.  He's not on Yelp, so this is two-reviews-in-one; I'm his proxy.  No hesitation: a true thumbs up.
author: Lisa C.

description:
Heavenly burritos, expertly executed.  I want to eat one literally every day, but that doesn't seem like a good lifestyle choice unless you work out like Michael Phelps.

-- First thing that strikes you as you bite into one - the freshly-made tortilla.  Impressed, you bite on.  Also, FYI, 95% of other burritos across the country will never taste good to you again.

-- Then the filling - delicious.  I strongly recommend the black bean and plantain burrito.  The sweetness of the plantain plays against the rest of the heart filling.   

There will be food coma later, but it will be a million times worth it.  

(Their chips are also delicious.)
author: Yekaterina M.

description:
The cutest little hole in wall restaurant! 

You know it's great Mexican food when they serve authentic chips and salsa with every order. Good vibes, good service, and good food! 

The price is right for the portion they serve! Will definitely come back :)
author: Michelle N.

description: It didn't taste like authentic Mexican food. I got the burrito and it was okay not the best I have tried. There are other Mexican restaurants in mission that are really good compared to this place.
author: Jorge C.

description: What is there to say that hasn't already been said? This place has the best vegetarian burritos in SF, period. Veggies, get the fried plantain burrito with only a half order of plantains: to die for.
author: Siobhan L.

description: Delicious! I got the fried plantain and black bean burrito even though I'm not a vegetarian and it was DELICIOUS! My husband got the al pastor tacos and was equally pleased. Highly recommended.
author: Emily S.

description:
Chihuahua here, chihuahua there. 
Everybody wants it everywhere. 
Sing it loud and life can be so easy, 
Ohhh Chihuahaha!

The Fried Plantain & Black Bean Burrito with cheese, roasted red bell peppers, rice, sour cream and smokey chile tomato salsa, pico de gallo and fresh cilantro & onion for $8.95 is INSANE! Pure genius to add plaintain. The chicken could use more flavor, and chips could use more salt. 

I had this delish burrito before seeing Foo Fighters, Dave Matthews, Eddie Vedder from Pearl Jam, Tony Bennett, Neil Young, Mumford & Sons, Santana, Arcade Fire, Beck, Norah Jones, and other awesome bands. Good music, good friends, good Mexican. Couldn't have asked for a better Sunday. Please open one in Russian Hill, we need you Chihuahua!
author: Stephanie M.

description:
I eat at Little Chihuahua at least twice a week. I send people to eat here almost everyday. It is the #1 go-to when there's nothing at home and I don't feel like spending more than $15 to have a clean, satisfying meal. 

There are plenty of haters who can't handle the line, even though with a little intelligence you wouldn't have to wait in it. There are other haters who prefer the "authentic" burritos of yore. But really, have you missed out on the food movement? Do you really not care what is in that burrito? If so, then please, go elsewhere. There is nothing for you here. 

And what, you'll serve anything I order with a side of fried plantains? You must really love me. And not once has anyone ever had any attitude or exasperation over the phone or at the register, as you could reasonably expect at a place so constantly slammed. 

I love it. I love it. You're totally missing out if you get a burrito anywhere else (except Papalote. That place is actually a BFD.)

Got kids? Go to the Noe Valley location. You'll fit right in. El Divisidero is decidedly the worst layout ever, but I'm not eating the layout. I'm eating a black bean and plantain burrito or a tostada salad. If you want space and a shorter line, head to the Valencia Street location. Hipsters frown on this Mission location for some reason (which keeps it pretty empty.) Probably the same reason they like shitty beer. And yet, they love the ultra-white Tacolicious (as do I.) But I'm not here to understand hipsters. I'm here to eat! 

And, I have had dinner at this place for over two weeks in a row, without fatigue. Just sayin'.
author: Steven P.

description: Nice place with a chill vibe and great decor - particularly the sunny chairs. Ordered the steak nachos (good not great - meat was perfectly tender tho) and mango margarita (made w/agave wine rather than tequila) was orange flavored and excellent.
author: David R.

description:
Great burritos, quesadillas. I love their house made salsas. This joint is small and cozy. While this establishment is a hole-in-the-wall type of place, it serves up awesome food, has great decor, and offers a simple concept that is perfect for San Francisco. The overall vibe blends perfectly with the neighborhood that it is located in.

This is a sure stop for me almost every time I am in the area
author: Josh O.

description:
The place is relatively clean and the two stars are for that and the nice warm tortilla chips/ good chipotle salsa but I thought the food was overprice and put together badly. Maybe it was a bad day but I felt like my polla asado taco was not only dry and overheaped with sauce and limped veggies but not particularly fresh. This dish was $4.25 and I have had cheaper tacos with better tasting meat/ simpler veggies/ no goopy sauce in other SF places.

The tortilla soup was overspiced, the broth felt weak/ thin, and the flavors just did't marry. And somewhat overpriced at almost $8. Now, I don't mind paying for a great soup; if you want a good large bowl enough to split with a friend of two, check out Don Pico's version in San Bruno. Yes, it's over $10 but it's huge and flavorful.
author: L C.

description:
Coming from the land of amazing burritos (San Diego), I didn't know it was possible to find a great tasting burrito up in the Bay.

And then I encountered the...

+ Plantain burrito- 5 stars- Fried plantains made it a good consistency and not too squishy and it went surprisingly well with the black beans. Unique and a little sweet, def a MUST TRY.

+ Garlic shrimp burrito- 5 stars- LOVED that I could taste the hint of garlic with the shrimp- yet it wasn't overwhelming. Avocado made it even tastier.

- Carne Asada nachos- 2.5 stars- chips tasted stale, carne asada was burnt... was not impressed and wish I hadn't ordered it.

Loved the fresh complimentary chips and the salsa. 

Be aware that you may have to wait for seating while holding those delicious chips... the place isn't very big and you can't snag a table until you have ordered.
author: Emily C.

description:
I tend to be more of a larger dog person (golden retrievers and labs and whatnot), but this place is still pretty great. 

I've only been in SF for about a month and within that month, I'd say, conservatively, that I've eaten 76 burritos... many of which were purported to be 'the best some-kind-of-burrito in some defined-area'... and yet the two burritos I had here (both sober, a somewhat necessary aside) remain at or near the top of my list. Here are some reasons why:

1) Really great chips/salsa bar
2) Tons of protein options
3) Hugely filling 'Super Burrito' option (w/sour cream, jack cheese and guacamole)
4) Quaint atmosphere and solid staff/service

Everything was pretty good to great, and while there's a ton of good mexican in this fine city of ours, this place gets a solid 5 stars*. 


______________________________


*Note: This may or may not have something to do with the fact that I don't have to walk more than a block or cross a street to get here from my apartment.
author: Jake D.

description: Honestly one of the best burritos I've had. Ever. I am someone who can handle spicy but this burrito with the habanero salsa I put on it really kicked my ass. You get some chips for the table and about 5 salsas to choose from. You order at the counter and they bring the food to you. Really cool staff there too!
author: Jeffrey H.

description: Ahh little chihuahua you did me wrong! Both of us had "intestinal distress" after eating here. Coincidence? You decide!
author: James S.

description:
This place is straight up amazing. I've been coming here for years and its the best place for affordable and incredible Mexican food. 

The tacos are huge. Two tacos are more than enough, The tortilla soup is great. The margaritas are plenty delicious. 

Consider that this place is SMALL and during dinner rush hours it is packed! 

Community style seating is the protocol during rush hour so it can be less intimate if you are going for that. The kitchen kills it and really hustles so your food comes out promptly but it can get pretty loud.
author: hi boss hi wife a.

description:
What a nice little neighborhood burrito joint. 

Well, tacos too. 

The tacos, in fact, are piled high. All the meats I tried (chicken, pork, asada) were very good.

My favorite, the "smothered" burrito, was excellent. A solid plank of a burrito, surrounded in a moat of garlicky red sauce. Delicious.

It does get crowded around lunch (so i've heard) and dinner time and it's a small space, so don't be surprised to wait a few minutes.

I'm a fan and would go back.
author: Jefferson S.

description:
1000th review! And it's a 5 Star! Little Chihuahua is TASTY goodness... so I eat here a lot. Maybe too much? Chicken tortilla soup is always on point, hot with fresh fixings. Steak anything is delicious, can actually taste the marinated grilled flavor. Enchiladas are gooood, and the beans and rice are legit. Salsa bar is a huge bonus, and it's consistently fresh and full. My girlfriend loves the mushroom quesadilla so much she won't really try anything else! 

Again, I eat here a lot. I'm ending this review and calling in an order for takeout :)
author: Eric O.

description:
After waiting way too long for a table at Nopalito that never appeared, we made our way to The Little Chihuahua and were almost immediately greeted by bursting burritos and delicious chips and salsa. 

You order at the back counter, they've got Pacifico on tap at a pretty awesome price, and the food is cheap and delicious. There's a wide range of salsa: some of it is pretty dang hot, my favorite was the green variety. I ordered the garlic shrimp burrito upon a recommendation by a friend and it was one of the tastier burritos I've ever had. Very clean and filling without being a ridiculous gutbomb, despite my ability to polish off the whole thing. 

A solid neighborhood spot, I sure wish there was one around the corner from my house.
author: Kathleen M.

description: I've ordered the Carne Asada Tostada each time, and until I get a piece of stringy beef and don't crave the cinnamony tostada shell, this will continue. The cotija cheese in cubes and roasted tomatoes definitely stand out. The place is good for smaller parties, as there is limited seating. They have a nice "don't sit at the tables until you've ordered" policy, which improves the capacity flow. Also, takeout orders are usually 15 minutes or less if you want to beat the crowds.
author: Ryan L.

description: A Fajita Chicken Burrito Bowl (no tortilla) was not on the menu, but they made it easily enough. It came with rice, beans, and tortilla chips. There were many types of self-serve salsa available too. My food was pretty good! The restaurant was a bit narrow, but there were plenty of tables for customers.
author: Marc B.

description:
Had a grilled veggie burrito on spinach tortilla - SO good! 

Came here for a friend's birthday dinner and munched pretty hard on their chips and salsa waiting for the burrito. Was pleasantly surprised how quickly it came. I'll definitely be back :)
author: Maggie F.

description: I have eaten here several times over the last few years.  One time I got sick from the chicken tacos.   After that it has been awhile before I returned. Today I tried the nachos.  They were terrible,  soggy,  cheap cheese and watery guacamole.  I am not sure what the hype is about.  The salsa had the taste of vinegar being added to it.  The only reason I can think of to add vinegar is that the salsa is old.  With all the great taquerias in the city I am not sure why this place does not have better quality food.  It really is sub par.
author: mi m.

description:
The Independent theatre was doing a free showing of The Dark Knight Rises and I convinced myself to see it for the fourth time.

Ha, just kidding, no convincing necessary.

Since we had an hour to kill, I thought dinner would be a great plan. We headed to the Little Chihuahua for burritos. I got the baby super carne asada burrito (you get a choice of beans with Mexican rice, salsa, cabbage salad, and pico de gallo. And since I got the "super," it came with sour cream, jack cheese, and guacamole). The "baby" version--which is supposedly a smaller version of their burrito--was massive and definitely filling; I can't imagine what the non-baby version looks like. Anyway, washed it all down with a bottle of Mexi-Coke.

The chips and salsa was great, as was the salsa bar. I'll need to try this fried plantain burrito everyone keeps raving about. 

Next time...
author: Adena B.

description:
My roommate suggested this place because she thinks it's got the best burritos in town. I necessarily agree with that...however, I do think they have best chips I've ever munched on!

I got the baby burrito and my friend got the super burrito....they were about the same size. 

Anyway, delicious!
author: Margaret R.

description:
Adorbs.

Lovely little place to get San Francisco-ed Mex-American food -- plantain/black bean burritos, sustainable seafood tacos, wild shroom empanadas, etc -- a solid selection of tasty treats whether you keep it light with an organic salad or fat ass it with a cheese quesadilla, you'll be a happy camper -- love the DIY salsa bar, and a side of guac is definitely worth it (even it it does need a bit of salt).

Roll up, order, get a number and wait -- three shrimp tacos = $14, the burritos are around $9?
author: Rachel N.

description:
love this place!

unlimited salsa bar?!!!

big portions

healthy options too

easy parking

oh how much i love their tacos and shrimp

i wouldnt mind getting one after work today.

my favs are:

1.Al Pastor Burrito (very good and BIG too!)
2. Tortilla soup -- not to salty like other mexican places and there is just right amount of chicken.
author: Carol Y.

description: Yum yum yum! Got takeout on a Friday afternoon. Very happy with plantain & black bean burrito (sans bell peppers) and horchata.
author: Anna K.

description: Excellent, amazing, delicious food. Restaurant is tiny and was packed when we got there, but the line moved very quickly and we decided to take our meal to go. Water jug with cups for while you wait and their salsa bar is yummy! We got a couple different tacos and a burrito and they were all awesome for the price! Really reasonable!
author: Gage B.

description:
The first time I came here was under duress (I wanted Noaplito but was outvoted).
I think it tainted my view of the food.  I've been dissing it ever since.  So, imagine my surprise when circumstance brings me back and I have one of my tastiest Mexican meals in months.

We were a few blocks away at the Independent for the NFC Championship game (GO NINERS) and needed some quick grub.  We got take-out from Little Chihuahua: super nachos with the works and the plantain burrito with the works.

I don't know if it was the all the beer or that sweet, sweet Niners victory but I couldn't deny it: the food was off the chain.  I will definitely be back for those two items, maybe during the Super Bowl (I'm superstitious where the Niners are concerned).
author: Olivia W.

description: eh tried them twice. Not really a fan of anything but the grilled pineapple salsa. everything seems to spicy from the guac to the salsas to the meat. The carnitas was alright. Gave them a second shot for my boyfriend. Wont go back a third i don't think.
author: Jesse D.

description: Loved this little place. Cool vibe. Great Pozole. And it's just around the corner from The Page, which is a super cool bar...I recommend a visit before dinner... and maybe after :)
author: Chantill L.

description:
I just moved to Noe Valley and my two friends were visiting so I wanted to take them somewhere on 24th. They wanted Mexican so we chose the Little Chihuahua based on yelp.

It had a casual ambiance and we went around 6 on a Friday and it was not crowded at all- we were able to sit right away!

I got the tostada salad with chicken and loved it! It was unique compared to your normal tostada salad..but in a good way I thought. 

(Menu says: Our signature salad made with organic mixed greens, black beans, avocados, pico de gallo, queso fresco, cucumbers, mango salsa & roasted bell peppers with a lime-cilantro dressing served on top of a crispy tortilla shell.)

The queso fresco was in the form of little cubes, and the lime-cilantro dressing was a great touch. My friend was more harsh of a critique of her tostada salad.. she didn't like the red peppers&mango salsa and said she wanted more 'true mexican' food rather than Spanish. (too each his own i guess!)

My other friend got the chicken tacos and had zero complaints. Hers was a much smaller portion than the tostada so she left feeling reasonably full rather than feeling completely stuffed like Shell and I. 

Overall a pretty good experience!
author: Christie B.

description:
review TOTALLY overdue. Only been here twice and I love it. The food is great and the place is chill. The service is nothing to complain about and the atmosphere is casual/chill/nice.  The food has been delicious and SPOT ON, both times. The place filled up in a matter of 5-10 minutes after getting our food. Boy, did we get there at a good time. I think the amount of people in the place also speaks for itself.

Recommend:

 - Fried Plantain Black Bean Burrito
 - Breakfast Burrito

Also recommend:

 - This place (as if you couldn't already tell from my rating/review)
author: Hannah K.

description:
Oh man, I can't believe it took me so long to "discover" this place. It's amazing!

Every time I come here now, a decision must be made. Plantain or Garlic Shrimp? Plantain or Garlic Shrimp?! If only there was some way to combine the two. So far the only solution is the just bring a friend, each order one, cut in half and swap halves. Consume Garlic Shrimp first, and save the sweet Plantain burrito for "dessert".

Even though the margarita is made with wine and not tequila, beware! It's stronger than it seems.
author: Rachel H.

description:
This place is fantastic.

Best chicken quesedia ever.
Nachos were to die for.
Get the pitcher of sangria, it's amazing.

Very very happy, and not so expensive.
author: Scott S.

description: I really liked the spicy cabbage.  Nice neighborhood vibe in the store and nice people.   My son liked it but prefers the carne asada burrito at Papalote and El Faralito.
author: Colette H.

description: Burritos and beer - yes please. This was a really chill spot and the food was really good. A bit tight on space, but somehow it seems to work.  You have to order before you sit so it can be a gamble as to whether there'll be a table when you're ready on a busy evening but the flow usually works out and people know not to linger when people are waiting for a spot.
author: Angie A.

description: The little Chihuahua is where I go to get BIG burrito's. It's not just the size, the taste is bomb.com. They serve you up a great tasting burrito, and at a good price for what you get.
author: David T.

description:
I was about to say "Best Burrito on the West side of the city", but since Divisadero is the divider and Little Chihuahua is on the EAST side of the street, I guess that wouldn't be West now would it?

But in any case, the burritos are as good as any you'll find in Haight, Castro, or NoPa.  They're whipped up fast, brought to your table, and are gigantic.  Taste wise, they always have the right level of kick.  

Don't miss the Pacifico on tap, and if you're not looking for a burrito, try the wild mushroom enchiladas.  To die 4.  Seriously.
author: John H.

description: Burritos were delicious and reasonably priced. We walked in and it was packed, I was concerned about finding a table but it was a quick turn around and we found a table by the time we got to the counter. Good salsa variety and menu options with quick service. The only reason I didn't give it 5 stars was that it wasn't amazing. Don't get me wrong it was good and I'd return but it wasn't unique or memorable flavors.
author: Gina B.

description:
I usually come here for the Mexican brunch. You should go early (before 11 am) because there are not many places to sit. If you dine-in, you can take advantage of the unlimited salsa bar. 

I used to love this place when I first moved here. Nowadays, the meat tends to be overcooked. Also, they gave me a horchata that gone bad. They were willing to replace, but I expected better.
author: Koh K.

description:
Fried plantain and black bean burrito.  Super.  That's all you need.  The sweetness of the plantain combined with the tang of sour cream and guac....it makes you sit up straight and hanker for more.

If you need something to wash it down with, the sangria is tasty and potent.
author: Sohini R.

description: Very good tostadas with lots of vegetables and good flavor. But the restaurant ambiance is terrible. Dungeony- dingy - dark - and there's a sinister artwork - one of a horned devil prancing around. While I am tempted to recommend to my friends with family, the atmosphere and decor is just not kid friendly imo.
author: Bryan S.

description:
We've never really hung out too much in this neighborhood but we had some friends in town who were staying by here so we needed a lunch spot to check out.  We of course checked out our trusted Yelp and found Little Chihuahua and again was not let down.  This place is pretty small so don't plan on coming here with a large group as they don't take reservations.  We had seven people and we were able to secure a table pretty quickly but the place really filled up quickly around lunch time.

I had the fajita burrito with chicken and it was very tasty.  They had a great salsa bar too and some of the salsas were nice and spicy.

Great spot and wish it was closer to our house because we'd be there much more often.
author: Blake B.

description: The burritos aren't the greatest. The tortilla's are always on the stale side, in my opinion. And the chips aren't my favorite. The service is alright. Dining area could be cleaner.
author: Grey Z.

description: Mexican food created by white people, for white people, cooked by Mexicans.
author: Jules P.

description: Pretty average food had breakfast and chicken burrito, tables are dirty. Not coming back don't know what the fuss is about
author: Vaibhav S.

description:
Little Chihuahua is Mexican food gone healthy. Not exactly low-calorie, but the food is fresh and tasty. Unlike many Mexican joints, Little Chihuahua has made-for-humans portion sizes (get the baby burrito if you aren't hungry). Nearby El Castillito has that monster burrito to fulfill all your self-destructive tendencies, but go to Little Chihuahua for a satisfying bite.

My go-to is the super baby burrito with carne asada, but on a rainy day, I enjoy the chicken tortilla soup or the pozole. I prefer the meat fillings here because they are so frickin' flavorful, but their veggie and seafood options aren't half bad.

Restaurants with tiny dining areas are so trendy in SF, and Little Chihuahua is one of them. Surprisingly, I have always been able to find a table within 5-10 minutes of ordering, even during peak times. If you're not in a rush, hop on over to Duboce Park to enjoy your burrito amongst frolicking dogs.
author: Oriana W.

description: After an extremely long and terribly disappointing journey in which I sought out San Francisco's best taqueria--a process rife with late-night Mission excursions and far too much rice--my tired soul can finally rest. This place is incredibly awesome; for some inexplicable reason they manage to capture the finest flavors and make a burrito that is TRULY worth recognition. Plus the atmosphere is just rad.
author: Anon E.

description:
Love this place! Truthfully, I eat here way too often but it's hard not to! Their steak burritos and shrimp tacos are really great. Their tortilla soup on a cold day hits the spot

 If you want a to-go order I suggest calling 10-15min ahead. There is a separate line on the left for pick up orders. This place gets packed!
author: heather m.

description:
My go to for a late dinner takeout. The al pastor special burrito is the tits. Also live the verde salsa at the salsa bar is quite a treat.

If you got some extra dollars to drop do your own surf and turf and ask for a half shrimp half steak burrito.
author: Berk K.

description: Solid Mexican food minus the hormones, the posole was awesome! Burritos were smaller but great fresh ingredients you get what you pay for. salsa bar with a great advo salsa and plenty of pickled peppers will def be back.
author: Ribec F.

description:
This is my go to burrito shop since I live a block away.  They have very good burritos and I especially like the creativity of their vegetarian option: the plantain burrito.  So delicious.  I havn't tried anything but the burritos, but I'm sure it's all good.
Pro tip: call ahead 5-10 min and skip the line.
I don't give it 5 stars because it's a little pricey for what you get, and honestly there is better Mexican food for cheaper in the Mission.
author: Solomon S.

description: My girlfriend said that she finally understand my love/ slight obsession with burritos. She is more of a lobster roll girl but when she shared a chicken super burrito with me, her eyes have been opened to the glory known as The Little Chihuahua. Her experience can be described as a symphony of flavor explosion in her mouth. Well done.
author: Connor C.

description:
I've eaten here far more times than I would care to admit. Kind of a yuppieish version of the taqueria, but you can't argue with the product. Carnne Asada burrito w/ guac and black beans on a whole wheat shell tastes solid and lets me pretend I'm being healthy. 

Gets four stars instead of five because the burritos are a tad on the pricey end, and yet still leave my stomach feeling like it has just been in a taqueria.
author: Alex F.

description: The food is good but their hygiene should be a lot higher I feel that it doesn't speak very well when you find hair on your food pretty disgusting.
author: Ulises S.

description: Not sure how this place got 4 stars. The food is less than mediocre.  Had the posole Rojo. Looks delicious but rather bland until you add the lime, then it's okay. My friend got the Carne asada enchiladas.  They pour this ketchup tasting tomato sauce on top. Extremely bad sour taste. Rice is bland and dry.
author: Alex P.

description: Garlic shrimp burrito! ¡Que rico! I only wish the shrimp were jumbo shrimp otherwise it was a perfect burrito. My family enjoyed the salmon tacos and the carne asada. They also offer gluten free tortillas which is nice. Next time want to try the plantain burrito and the tequila ice cream!!
author: Bella B.

description:
So after yelping for a place for our group of 11 my sister found this place that alleged good food.  The place is very small, so don't be fooled by the fact that it says it is good for groups.   Because we showed up early for dinner, the man behind the cash register was kind enough to let us sit before ordering. Other customers sat in the middle of large tables, which made seating a bit of a hassle, but fortunately for some considerate souls we were able to connect 3 smaller tables together. So be prepared to forage for seats if you have a larger group.  
On to the food.  Being from So Cal I was skeptical that we would find anything better than the delicious caliber of Mexican food we are used to.  Sadly, my skepticism was confirmed.  We ordered a variety of burritos, a chicken tostada, and the tortilla soup.  It wasn't terrible, but was very mediocre. I am sure we will not return because this place is way overhyped in what apparently is an authentically Mexican food starved city if this is so highly yelped and loved.
So I guess the bottom line is this: if you're from a place that has many great Mexican eateries, you most likely will not be impressed.
BTW one stall dinky unkempt restroom for those who like such details.
author: Deb L.

description: Most quesadillas and burritos are over $9~$10, but the portions are HUGE! Great service, relaxed atmosphere.
author: cassy f.

description: Just arrived in SF and were looking for something good to eat for dinner and stumbled on this great little Mexican food restaurant. Just walking into the restaurant you could smell the how good the food was going to taste. This is in the top three Mexican food restaurants that I have ever eaten at to date and I love Mexican food.
author: Rick L.

description: With the guidance of a local friend, we split a garlic shrimp burrito and some carne asada nachos. Zero regrets.
author: Dessa R.

description: Had a great shrimp burrito here. Even had menu items that were easy for young my children. Atmosphere is great...loved the friendly staff. Will definitely go again when back in San Francisco.
author: Andrew N.

description:
Vibrant atmosphere, nice location, passable food. 

I dined at TLC recently, on my way to a concert at The Independent. It was a decent, quick alternative to Nopalito, our first choice, which had a one hour wait.

I ordered the shrimp enchiladas with red sauce and my dinner companion had the cheese quesadilla. 

My dish was accompanied by refried beans - very good - and rice, which was a bit dry and tough. The enchiladas, despite being slathered in sauce, were also somehow dry. The shrimp was not de-veined. That's a but of a culinary turn-off for me but I plowed through, nonetheless.

My friend's cheese quesadilla, simple as it was, seemed serviceable. To be fair, He is not as particular about his Mexican food, and I could tell he enjoyed it. The guacamole that came with his entree was very tasty.

The Little Chihuahua was packed and seems to be thriving. I'd classify it as sharing the same cooking style as Nicks Crispy Taco's. Its laid back, casual yet bustling atmosphere are its charm. The food is more Californian than Mexican and many people like it just fine. I'm just a bit spoiled for choice in this town and think I'll save my pesos for taquerias that try harder.
author: Carole B.

description:
Food;
Wild Mushroom Enchilada - It was pretty good and seemed up to par for the value.
Chips -  Came in large bowl to split between two of us.
Salsa Bar -  Decent selection and pretty tasty Pico De Gallo. 

Notes:
you simply seat/bus yourself. They have a separate line for pick up. 

Experience:
This was my first time here. I would come back and explore more options. I liked the stained glass and the relaxed settings. I'm rarely in this neighbor hood but it was nice find.
author: Sean G.

description: this is my new go to spot for healthy burritos. the fried plantain and black bean burrito is good. I highly recommend this place for healthy, good quality Mexican food.
author: Anthony A.

description:
3.5 to 4 stars for this great little neighborhood spot is just about right.....

Affordable, clean and kid friendly....

They have a wide ranging menu... We tried a soup and a buritto...Both were tasty and filling. The guac was chilled and flavorful.. Lots of salsas as well.

Oh yeah, 3 dollar pints of Anchor Steam...

We will be back..
author: Joe B.

description: Let's see, what can I say about this branch of TLC. It's definitely pricey. There are so many obvious places where you can get wayyy better food for half the price in the Mission. The quality of the food is great which is why I totally understand the high rating, but I still can't justify paying 5 bucks for a taco. I ordered two tacos actually, the mushroom taco was fabulous, the chicken taco, however, was satisfactory to say the least. I think this is a great vegetarian Mexican option, but I have to say I've had better. A little seasoning on the meat would not hurt.
author: Shruti S.

description:
Pretty average Mexican food with a white people twist (as in nothing is spicy).

Nice atmosphere and a few interesting burritos (Plantain Burrito) but none that are that great.

Good chips, but the salsa lacks any kicks.
author: Tis T.

description:
Talk about washed out mexiCANT.  I know they're catering to the hipsters that can't handle heat or spice but it was ridiculous on how busy it was for the "eh" quality of food they had.

Call me spoiled, call me a traditional taqueria lover, but I just can't handle overpriced mediocre Mexican food.  Go to the Mission, for Christs sake.
