Taqueria La cumbre, La Taqueria, Tres Amigos, ANYWHERE!  Not effing here!  Unless you happen to live here and are hung over as hell.  My friend had the plantain burrito- he absolutely loved it.  The idea of starch on starch on more effing starch made me heavy just thinking of it.  I had the Shrimp tacos.  Lacked flavor, and a little over cooked.  In my opinion, they tasted frozen, but I could be wrong.  Just a bad batch, perhaps?  Hmmm hmmm. 

If you want washed out, so-so  Mexican food with a cool decor a cold beer and an unreasonably long ass line, check it out.  Even if you did want non-traditional mexican tex mex a la "la salsa" but without the restaurant chain feel, check out Papalote.  At least their shiz is flavorful and healthy.  BAM! But, If you want authentic... please, just go to the Mish.
author: Cat A.

description: Awful food. Yet another over-funded tech boom business lacking substance and passion. All hype. Chicken taco was a disgusting lump of bland, boiled meat. Just reminiscing about this meal makes me feel nauseous.
author: John W.

description:
I absolutely love this place. What I love about it most are the hours. It's just what I need for a late night meal. The place is a little small, but it is adorable with beautiful painted windows that look like stained glass. It's an intimate setting where couples flock to and I would recommend coming with a no more than three other people because most tables seat two and it's possible to combine a couple of them to seat four. Still, four might be pushing it. This place is great for take out because you order in line before you nab a table and they'll bring your food to you and you bus your own table afterward. So for these type of quick places, this is definitely a fancy one for its caliber. 

There's a great salsa bar and I loved every one, though the chipotle salsa was probably my favorite. I liked the smokiness of it. I got a tostada salad because it was written on the board outside so I figure it had to be good. You get a choice of meat and I went for the carne asada of course. I don't think there was enough carne asada on it, but it was pretty good still. The salad part of it was composed of arugula and other mixed baby greens that seemed fresh. I also liked that there was about a quarter of an avocado on it. The tostada wasn't hard and very crunchy. They give you a large bowl of chips and they were still warm, so that was a nice touch. We think they keep them under a heat lamp or something.  The sangria was super delicious! It was just the right balance of fruit and wine. It was the best sangria I've had in a while. The horchata was not as great. It was nice, light and refreshing, but threading closely to weak. It was actually pretty powdery at the bottom too, so that was no good.

There are so many things I want to try the next time I come back like the fajita burrito, pozole rojo, pollo asado tacos, and even their $2 cupcake!

Thanks to Gabriel H. for the good find and suggestion.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
My friends seemed to like their burritos, but I ordered a "baby burrito" and the guy at the counter says "you should try the super baby burrito!" 
"what's the difference?" I asked
"You get sour cream and guacamole"
I love both of those so I agreed, and he charged me accordingly, (he successfully upsold me).  Unfortunately I took my order to go, and when I got home, the burrito I unwrapped was dry and disgusting, and there was not one drop of sour cream or guac on it. I ate about 3 bites and threw it out. It wasn't a great burrito to start but the guac and sourcream would've at least made it edible. Totally angry too because I paid the extra for it. 

My recommendation would be to skip this place altogether, and if you do eat here, do not get your food to go. At least that way you can check they made what you ordered.
author: Monica G.

description: Really good nachos & shrimp burrito. Wine margaritas are creative & yummy. Atmosphere feels a little rushed for in house dining.
author: Fanny M.

description:
I love this spot. My bf decided to welcome me with some yummy Mexican food when I arrived from SFO one night.  We didn't dine in, so this will just be a review for the food.

We tried the chile verde chicken enchiladas, a super burrito, and the camarones tostada salad. The enchiladas were great. Good amount of chicken and just enough of the chile verde to not become overpowering. I didn't have much of the super burrito, but it did look yummy and quite large. Tons of black beans in the burrito. As for the camarones tostada salad, I loved it! The restaurant was nice enough to put the tostada shell in a separate container from the actual salad so that it didn't get soggy :)

Overall, great food and a pretty great price. I had the food about an hour after it was ordered and it was still tasty.
author: Leanne M.

description: It's not too much money, but it's not very good Mexican food either.  Ended up eating there because not much else was open at the time, but it was the saddest Mexican food I've had in awhile.
author: Big Baby Jesus C.

description: This spot is definitely going to become a neighborhood go-to.  I had the Al Pastor Burrito and my boyfriend had the Garlic Shrimp Burrito. Truthfully, I'm not a fan of sour cream or cheese in my burrito (or taco) and so I'm not as enamored with the mission style super burrito as others are. This burrito, however, was delicious, flavorful and moist. I enjoyed all of the interplay of flavors - the smoky spicy adobo sauce contrasted nicely with the sweet pineapple and the brightness of the pico de gallo.  My boyfriend's shrimp burrito was equally flavorful.  Small space - it can get busy/cramped but the lines move quickly as well as tables. However, if you and all your co-workers are looking to drop in happy hour style on a Fri, I recommend getting there early! They have a handful of two tops on the right side and a couple of communal style tables on the left. Can't wait to come back!
author: Alison H.

description: I ordered the salad with wild mushroom. Very fresh. Also the style and music make me really relax. Great place!
author: Yang S.

description: Used to be my favorite place.  The food is still good, but in the last few months they started nickel and diming you.. 10cents for to-go orders, 50cents for chips, 40 cents for employee health.  Totally changes the feel and my allegiance to the place.
author: Bobby H.

description:
Saturday night and need a new burrito fix. Gordos....eh been there too many times and its okay, Panchos....no thanks, Burrito express I love it , everyone else vetoes me.

what does one do? YELP! The little chihuahua is really really good. They use superb ingredients (niman ranch, rocky chickens) the flavors are really good. They have the wildest cupcake....(chocolate 3 chile cupcake) sweet and than really hot.   They are really busy so that is a good indicator of the quality.

Great place to dine at (parking is pretty tough) or great for take out. I highly recommend the food.
author: David G.

description: Great food and pleasant service. I had enchiladas in red sauce - my all time favorite! I really loved the ones they made. I got their plates to-go sometimes, on my lunch breaks. I recently switched offices, so I will miss them until I come through for dinner some time...
author: Julie W.

description: Yum! I have only tried one thing. I get the black bean plantain burrito every time. I am never disappointed and am always fully satisfied.
author: Melissa J.

description: Great and very flavorful vegetarian options! My favorite is a baby burrito with wild mushrooms, chile verde tofu, or grilled vegetables and black beans
author: Jessica L.

description:
Little Chihuahua has superb quality and unusually tasty dishes. For example, when do you hanker for a mushroom taco? Like never, right? But I do 'cause the Little Chihuahua mushroom taco is so amazingly delish. They also have an Al Pastor that is unusually good. I prefer the traditional Al Pastor I find in other more traditional taqueria but I like Little Chihuahua's and I do appreciate the seasoning. 

Given the extraordinary expense of Nopalito nearby, you'd expect this place to be just as snooty and overpriced. But Little Chihuahua is an honest, more humble version replete with unusual flavors and high quality ingredients. The prices are more than traditional taquerias but this aint your standard Mexican fare. Definitely worth a try. But get there early. The line starts forming shortly after 6pm. See you there!
author: david b.

description:
I really enjoy eating  Little Chihuahuas....

wait thats a different review

This place has delicious food and it can be hard to get a seat sometimes so I recommend getting it togo--
The guac is so fresh and delicious and the burritos are also filling. The carne asada is always on point but the chicken quesadilla has got to be my go-to item! You can eat half and take the other half as lunch the next day--DELISH leftovers!

Also, there's this boy named Thomas that works there, who often is seen with a lil' newsboy cap--he's my favorite chihuahua!
author: An-Nhien L.

description:
I gave them 4 stars based upon more than half a dozen meals there over the past year or so.  For tonight's dinner it would be two (2) stars.  

One of us ordered shrimp tacos, same thing he orders every single time we go there. It is always fresh and never spicy.  Tonight he only ate half of it and was having hot flashes.  

I ordered chilli verde chicken burrito, the special with sour cream and guacamole.  I got shrimp with avocado, no sour cream or guacamole.  When I realized the mistake, I decided to just go with it as I hadn't tried that before.  It too was spicy, but somehow bland.  I think it was one of their special burritos I later figured out.  

We liked this place so much we  will go back and I'll update or downgrade my review.

Oh and I told the person who took our order that they have so far the best tortilla chips of any Mexican restaurant we've tried, he agreed, not tonight, tasted like they forgot the salt.
author: Timothy S.

description:
Thank you yelpers!  I was at the DMV around the corner from here for almost 3 hours and I was starving, I read all the great reviews here, and I was craving some mexican food.

I ordered the carnitas burrito and an horchata, came out to $11.  PLUS they give you a bowl of chips.  You have free range over their salsa bar, which has about 5 different salsas to choose from, everything from tomato salsa to habanero salsa.  I really enjoyed my tightly wrapped burrito, it had some good chunks of pork in it.  

The horchata wasn't as good, it was actually very powdery, which I'm assuming they used some kind of box mix.  If their horchata was better, I would have given them 5 stars.

Great place, I think I'll be back for some tacos or try their garlic shirmp burrito everyones' talking about.
author: Kevin W.

description: The best al pastor in town, is tender and cook slowly in a delicious sauce! I highly recommend it in the burrito! Always fresh and the salsas are amazing.
author: Gustavo F.

description:
The chips are blah
the salsa es muy bueno
the burrito is friggin'-magnificent.
ambiance cozy.
author: Alexander M.

description:
Not really noteworthy after all the hype.

We got the garlic shrimp burrito and the black bean and plantain burrito. I never had a black bean and plantain burrito, but i didn't find find it all that great. I thought the garlic shrimp burrito was better.

Note: Parking may be a pain if you're there during peak hours. We spent 15 minutes looking for parking!
author: Jen H.

description: This 5 star review is for the Al Pastor tacos. They are the best around especially when you get the verde salsa from their exceptional salsa bar. The mushroom quesadilla is really good too!
author: Michelle G.

description:
Been there last night for the first time.
Welcoming and colorful place.
Loved the Chile Verde Tofu Burrito!
It was packed but we didn't wait long at all for our food.
I'd definitely go back next time I'm in the 'hood...the cashier...she is cute ;-)
author: Michael S.

description: I love tacos and this place is amazing! A lot of meat and super tasty! Also, the place is more cosy than most of the fast-food taquerias around the city.
author: Martha L.

description: Their service is great and nachos and al pastor burritos is deelicious!
author: Hey Y.

description: In the city for the day stopped in for some food and it was great. Good service got the food out fast and it was great. Clean and friendly, I will be back.
author: Skylar N.

description:
Decent mexican food, occasionally you'll get a bay leaf in the mouth and that will just throw the whole meal off.  

I take friends here who want decent mexican in the haight.
author: Alex H.

description:
The first stop in a quest to find San Francisco's best breakfast burrito, and this place sets the bar high.

$9.50 for their 2-meal size breakfast burrito, stuffed with the perfect amount of eggs, bacon, refried beans, potatoes and cheese, topped with fresh onions, salsa, Mexican cheese, and cilantro.

There was no wait at the Divisidero location while right down the street at NOPA the line stretches like its Black Friday at Wal-Mart.

I'll be back
author: Thomas M.

description:
For a whole world of reasons, moving out of the Lower Haight was probably the best decision of my life, and I miss nothing about it... 

...Wait, except for The Little Chihuahua!!! My friend once told me that their steak is marinated in crack, and I believe it to be true. Usually, I don't gravitate towards restaurants that have unappetizing words in the title (small dogs don't really do it for me) but make an exception for this place! It is sooooo delicious. I always get the steak burrito with lots of salsa and Jalepenos on the side, and it's always so good. I think they have another location in Noe, which I've never tried. Just writing this review makes me hungry, I may just have to head to my old stomping grounds and have a burrito for lunch ;)
author: Lauren B.

description: leaving hungry after an $11 burrito is NOT OKAY. fajita burrito sin carne. it was TINY. thanx for the $11 baby burrito, dung bangers. decent flavor but not worth repeating; $8.50 would've been appropriately overpriced. it wasn't nearly as delicious OR as big as an $11 burrito ...accompanied by a doublepriced glass of horchata which also was remarkably unremarkable. still hungry after both of those. TLC if your goal was for me to never return, you win this time
author: Loren B.

description:
Plantain burrito. 'Nuff said. 

The food here is consistently good. They have baby burritos in case you aren't too hungry and a free salsa bar. Seating can be a little rough, especially during peak hours, but it's normally manageable. This place has been a staple of my diet for several years.
author: Kyle F.

description: The guacamole enchiladas were AMAZING! It was super busy, but we were able to find seating about 5 minutes after ordering.
author: Kelly W.

description:
This particular diner is perfectly incredible. Everything is conducted while using highest attention, and it's distinct as soon as anyone stroll within the home. I arrived on it's own in addition to sitting in the chef's countertop where I saw this bartenders put together this many delicious cocktails readily available. I'd this Mezcal Palomita, which in turn received a great smoky flavour in addition to reminded me personally of mezcal I'd when within the mountain tops of Guerrero. 

To begin, they provide hot garbanzo espresso beans rather than the classic poker chips in addition to salsa. Pretty hot! I requested this duck confit huarache, lead along with cabbage, queso fresco, in addition to chorizo. An interesting accept the original dish. Beloved it. I additionally received this ceviche, which has been similarly scrumptious in addition to received any environment friendly tomatillo sauce, far more this model I have welcomed in Peruvian eating places. 

Their own java will be brewed France push and also a butter almond cookie will be supplied gratis towards the end of one's meal. A thing I have overlooked will be how the waitstaff had been tremendously warm and friendly in addition to valuable. Their own assistance had been such like point in addition to seamless, I had been motivated to be able to keep any thirty money tip on our thirty seven money meal. They will chatted me personally upward in addition to produced me personally think very welcome. When i go back from the restroom, our paper napkin had been already folded revealed, something I have simply or else welcomed in high-end eating places. This particular location will be an absolute must, and this also assessment won't even continue to do rights to the treasure!
author: James T.

description:
Cute little place with faux stained glass windows and kitschy decorations, but I wish the food were better. Had the standard super burrito with carnitas. Certainly tasty, but it came out to around $10 plus tax for a burrito that I'd have paid about $6 for in Mission proper. The salmon/wild mushroom options definitely are unique here though, as are the fried plantains you can have them pop in. Horchata was nice here though, without the chalky residue you get at some places.

probably should have tried their sangria..
author: Kevin L.

description: We originally stopped by spontaneously for margaritas (which they don't have), they only have a small selection of bottled beers.  The meat they use is really flavorful and you can tell its pretty good quality. My friend got carne asada nachos and they were sooo good, loaded with toppings.  You definirely needed a fork to tackle them.  I got the chicken tortilla soup and I didnt really like it.  The broth was pretty bland and the tortillas chips they used in it were soggy before the soup even got to our table.
author: Angelica  C.

description:
If your hangover has made you rrreal hungry (or hangry, even), The Little Chihuahua will hook you up quickly and affordably... so you should go there sometime. 

Anything on the brunch menu will probably do the trick, but I recommend the chilaquiles with chorizo. Now, m'friends, chilaquiles are one of THE best hangover helpers ever created (pho is #1). Here, they are made well. They toss a bunch of fried tortilla strips in a savory sauce and then throw a bunch delicious stuff like fried eggs on top of those and it's just a sloppy mess. Order it. I know what's best for you.

It's counter-style service, so you order and then they give you a number. They have complimentary chips and a whole salsa bar, so I recommend you get on that too.

Go on. Do as you're told. You'll feel better.
author: Annie D.

description:
I was in the neighborhood, and I had a sudden craving for Mexican food. I didn't feel like going to my usual places so I pulled up the yelp iPhone app, did a quick search, and stumbled upon The Little Chihuahua. What a great find!

I suppose you could classify this place as a taqueria, but its slightly more expensive. Probably about 20% pricier than the average taqueria in the city. You get what you pay for though. 

To start, it's very clean. And while most taquerias don't exactly splurge on furniture, this place has nice wooden chairs with a sun carved into them. Nice touch.

As for the food, it's really good, and I'd say its probably 20% tastier than the average city taqueria too :-). The salsa bar is great. I really enjoyed the flavors.

I was in the neighborhood, and I had a sudden craving for Mexican food. I didn't feel like going to my usual places so I pulled up the yelp iPhone app, did a quick search, and stumbled upon The Little Chihuahua. What a great find!

I suppose you could classify this place as a taqueria, but its slightly more expensive. Probably about 20% pricier than the average taqueria in the city. You get what you pay for though. 

To start, it's very clean. And while most taquerias don't exactly splurge on furniture, this place has nice wooden chairs with a sun carved into them. Nice touch.

As for the food, it's really good, and I'd say its probably 20% tastier than the average city taqueria too :-). The salsa bar is great. I really enjoyed the flavors. My enchilada was also really good. It's getting a five star review based on its comparison to other taquerias, not to other full service restaurants. I look forward to returning and trying some of their specialty burritos!
author: Kevin H.

description: I just can't justify paying $20 for two cold burritos, especially when they didn't even put the right ingredients in them. Maybe they have amazing breakfast burritos, but I'm not so sure I'll bother finding out. Disappointing and a waste of time/money.
author: tamara z.

description: Bougie yet fantastic Mexican restaurant with great food! The tacos I ordered were large versions of the normal tacos one expects when they go to a Taqueria; $5 for a taco would seem like too much until you see how massive these things are, and they don't skimp on the meat! The seating is interesting since it is mostly dining tables with a couple of two-seat tables on the side, so if you're by yourself and it's at a busy time you might have to occupy a single seat at the larger tables.  Service is excellent and servers are friendly.  I'll be coming back for the Fried Plantain Burrito!
author: Eric L.

description:
For an almost-vegetarian like myself, there are few things better than the black bean & plantain burrito at the Little Chihuahua. And if you're thinking that the prices aren't great, just check out the size of these burritos. It's a beautiful thing.

The staff is very friendly, helpful, and the decor is cute. Also, it's a great location if you're taking the bus to Divisadero.

So worth it.
author: Jiordan C.

description: This review is for the Horchata only.. Oh my god it was awful. It was stringy, sour and had no cinnamon in It. I am no expert but that was definitely not normal. Do not get the Horchata!
author: Milla K.

description:
Best food around.  This is a staple restaurant in my eating out quiver.

The burritos, tostada's and enchiladas are all great.

It gets crowded during dinner time.  Phone ordering is easy.  Prices are reasonable especially based on the quality of food!

Enjoy...
author: Dave B.

description:
It was my first time here. We arrived shortly after 11 and just beat the rush. This place fills up quickly.

I ordered the chicken super burrito - wet with green sauce. We were given a generous bowl of warm tortilla chips and set off to explore the salsa bar. The salsa options were obviously freshly made. After munching for a few minutes, our orders were served.

My burrito was delicious. I ate the entire thing and I felt like one of those little obese chihuahuas that just rolls/waddles down the street.

It was so good..like, so, so good. I'm sad we're leaving town tomorrow because this could definitely be a place I visit on a weekly basis.

Oh, and even though it's in the Haight neighborhood, it's not obnoxious like pretty much everything else near the Haight Ashbury area and it's not saturated with tourists. 

Love Little Chihuahua!
author: Rosie P.

description:
The Garlic shrimp burrito is DELICIOUS. So is the fried plantain & black bean burrito. And the chips/salsa. Now that I think about it, I haven't tasted anything here that I didn't happily devour. 

Super nice staff, and adorable small space. But it can get crowded on the weekends, so be prepared to take the food to go. If you're not planning on eating at the restaurant, call ahead to place your order, and skip the line!
author: Kori M.

description: Came here around 4 on a Tuesday. Had to wait 5 mins to order since there were only 3 people working (2 cooks & one taking orders).  Its a small place,  inside is nicely styled and tidy. I ordered an el pastor and a salmon taco. The proportions are pretty big,  one taco = almost 2 sssdeervings. Definitely worth it
author: Patricia G.

description: Wasn't this a Papalote at one point? Well it certainly still tastes a lot like a Papalote and my recent shrimp burrito was pretty killer, though a total gut buster. Cute little space, good chips, and solid burritos. Wish it was closer to my house... the burrito places near me aren't cutting it!
author: Jeremy S.

description:
I've been here many times and on most occasions I order burritos.  Most of the time when I order burritos I get carne asada or carnitas.  I've ordered both here and they both taste great.  The meat is higher quality than most other mexican restaurants i've been to in the city.  

I tried the plantain burrito here and it is fantastic.  I'd recommend trading half of your plantain burrito for half of your friend's burrito if you chose to go this route.  Plantain burritos are a little too sweet for my taste, but great nonetheless. 

This place didn't get 5 stars just because I'd like to leave room for something better if I find it.

Bottom line: Go here and order a burrito you would normally order then try a plantain burrito.
author: Chris L.

description: Found this place on yelp and decided to give it a try. I had the chicken tortilla soup which was great. I also enjoyed their salsa bar and their chips are really good. They have pico de gallo salsa which I heart. The food is delicious and different from your regular mexican fare.
author: Alice H.

description: The best way to describe the delicious burrito I had here today is "homemade". It tasted fresh, natural, and on point. Super bomb, sad I already ate it all. :(
author: Kay S.

description: Great mexican food, everything is delicious, seating can be a little hectic but don't let that deter you.
author: Daniel J.

description: We ordered two burritos to-go: carne asada & fried plantain. What a unique little find for a burrito filled with fried plantains!! It was savory, it was sweet. So so good. It was filled with the usual suspects: black beans, rice, roasted red bell peppers, rice, sour cream, pico de gallo. Our orders also came with a side of chips, and the salsa was self-serve. The pineapple salsa was delicious, but super spicy! Watch out!
author: Leslie P.

description: This was my 2nd visit - much better than I remembered. I had a very tasty carnitas taco plate and Sangria. The portions are generous, and the food and sangria were both flavorful. I dare say it was delicious. Service is very friendly and the atmosphere is casual and relaxed.
author: Alexandra R.

description:
no. no. no. 

I have lived in SF for 20 years and in CA my whole life. this is terrible mexican food. My 11$ burrito today was awful. It was cold, had a terrible balance of meat/cheese/rice/bean... terrible.  It was sour due to way too much sour cream. Worst of all... it was small. Expensive and small. I keep coming back here because I live around the corner and wonder if I am crazy or my last experience was just an off day. Nope. Just really bad. 

If you want a small, expensive, sour, cold burrito then take a chance. The chips are stale too.

Save yourself the effort. La Taqueria is totally amazing and Papalote is a good solid burrito as well.
author: Jayne M.

description:
This is a great little spot in the lower haight...we took a short break from The Page to grab a bite right around 11pm

The half wild mushroom and half chicken quesadilla was really delicious and this is one of the few places in the area that has AL PASTOR!!! meat of the GODS. Although it's prepared a little different than I'm used to. It was tasty.

The portions are very generous...they give you awesome chips with your order and enough guacamole to cover every bite.  How many times have you been somewhere, order a side of Guac and get a thimble full...These guys at Little Chihuahua seem happy to provide enough for the whole meal.

On top of that, super friendly staff, plenty of room to sit and a nice atmosphere.

I'll definitely be going back.
author: Daniel D.

description: I was excited to try this place because it had four and a half stars and great reviews on Yelp but I wasn't as impressed as others seem to have been. It could also be the fact that I have the highest of standards for Mexican food. I ordered the chicken quesadilla, which comes with pico de gallo and guacamole on the side. Although, the food was not by any means bad, I just felt that it could have had more flavor, particularly the chicken. It costs about $11 for the quesadilla, which I think is a little overpriced. On the plus side, you receive complimentary chips and they have a wide variety of salsas too. I also had the chance to try their sangria and that was a wonderful afternoon treat.  Bottom line, it's a decent place to try but I probably won't be back again.
author: Stephanie M.

description:
This was my favorite veggie (i normally ordered without the grilled vegetables) burrito in San Francisco until I tried the Chez Maman Papito super burrito.

So lime-y and has a great crunch with the cabbage inside! They make it super quickly and the chips they give with it are great as well.

There's a bar with a bunch of salsas if you eat in, which is great. I'm a huge fan of this place and will likely find myself here again!
author: Neeharika B.

description:
As someone who loves Mexican food but occasionally tires of the city's ubiquitous foil-wrapped burritos, I'm always on the lookout for a restaurant that puts its own spin on south-of-the-border cuisine. 

Little Chihuahua distinguishes itself with organic ingredients, a killer salsa bar (try the chipotle), and left-of-center menu options like the plantain and black bean burrito and an enormous tostada salad that's topped with mango salsa and queso fresco.

Their dining room is always clean and big enough for large groups. Oh, and they take credit cards.
author: Karin H.

description: The tortilla soup looked a little lackluster but tasted quite good. I really liked how for takeout, they separated all the add-ins into a container so that nothing would get too soggy during transit. The mix-ins included really outstanding avocado chunks, some salsa, peppers, and tortilla strips. They all went into the soup quite nicely and everything was well-seasoned. The only part I didn't find to be too interesting was the cubes of questo fresco, which were pretty bland. The restaurant itself was ridiculously crowded on a Weds night, but they were well-equipped for take out.
author: Lisa K.

description:
Coming from the East Coast, I think every establishment serving Mexican food on the West Coat is great. The Little Chihuahua also felt authentic.

I ordered a regular toasted flour burrito with pinto beans and grilled vegetables. It was well wrapped, packed with flavor, and just generally sensational, especially with the accompanying yerba mate. It took about eight minutes for my order to be delivered, which seemed like just the right amount of time to efficiently prepare a burrito, and for me to settle in at my place.

Movement here is kind of difficult. With tables framing the central walkway to the order counter, the restaurant feels really narrow: at first the organization doesn't make any sense. But when you look up from your exquisite burrito and look around, it all comes together. This place is comfortable because it's snug. People share tables, art fills the wall space, and the chairs are giant and (probably) handcrafted. The Little Chihuahua is really nice!
author: Brian C.

description:
Black bean and fried plantain burrito!!?????? 

'Nuff said! 

Seriously though, so far, TLC is the only place that I know of that offers a burrito with plantain in it! and it is Yum yum yum!!! Their guac was delicious too. It's a cute little place with blue interiors and interesting art adorning the walls.

While we waited for our twin burritos to be served, we munched on fresh and crisy chips and 3 different kinds of salsas. They have a mini salsa bar and one can get their choice of salsa and some other condiments to go with their food.
author: Kinjal S.

description:
I've been on quite the plantain kick recently (read: for the last 24 years of my entire life), and Little Chihuahua's veggie burrito may very well top my list of SF plantain favorites. In addition to the delicious plantains, it's stuffed with red peppers, black beans, this absolutely delicious tomatillo salsa, and loaded with my possibly favorite condiment of all time, sour cream. And before you sass me, sour cream totally counts as a condiment!

The veggie burrito is the only thing I get here. My boyfriend likes their chicken nachos and their garlic shrimp burritos, which I sneak bites of in secret because they are also both great.
author: Rebecca P.

description:
This Chihuahua may be little (what with only a handful of tables throughout), but the flavors they serve up are nothing if not big and bold. 

Blah, blah, plantain veggie burrito is amazing, blah, blah. Of course you should order this. There's a reason why everyone raves about it. 

But, should you rock up at breakfast time, it's allll about the chilaquiles. They do 'em well here. It's no Primavera at the Saturday Ferry Building Farmer's Market - no one will ever top those - but they're pretty darn good.
author: Christina S.

description: Ordered the Garlic Shrimp Burrito from trycaviar.com.  Flavors were so amazing that I didn't even notice the fact that there weren't very many shrimp in the burrito.  Chips are nice and salty.  Salsa was okay.
author: Jennifer G.

description:
I came with a friend on a Wednesday afternoon.

I had carne asada tacos.  Tacos tasted fresh.  Not too spicy.  Service was not as fast as a Chipotli but right speed for a better quality place.  My friend loved her burrito.

Sangria was delicious!
author: Carlo Dolce Vita A.

description:
Breakfast Burrito review only!  

So I heard they had a good breakfast burrito at LC and I like their burritos in general so I was psyched to finally try a BB.  Unfortunately for me the way they make it here is a bit too 'wet' for my tastes. 

There are too many flavors competing against each other and I prefer my breakfast burritos to be a lot simpler.  There was a lot of salsa and hence lots of tiny chunks of tomatoes which added to the 'wet-ness' vibe.  It's also a fork and knifer and definitely of nice proportions.

The potatoes were not well done enough for my tastes (i like 'em crunchier/more crisp overall) and it was lacking in cheese.  

The staff and everyone are awesome here though!
author: Gene X.

description:
A group of friends and I were looking for a place that we could become regulars at; as we all just recently moved to the city, it was imperative that we found such a place. A friend that lived nearby recommended this burrito spot after hearing some good reviews. We ordered up an assortment of burritos. I asked about Horchata, the unknown dairy-based beverage that I only hear about in songs. When the cinnamon-sugar concoction was exposed, I knew it had to be mine. Weeks later, we still go back every Sunday for a tall glass of horchata, with light ice, and pair it with one of the super burritos, stuffed to the max with your favorite ingredients.

What stands out at the Little Chihuahua is the great music: every evening we hear our favorite tunes including the Strokes, the Killers, and many indie artists you only imagined were available on your secret Spotify playlists. Beyond this, the service is great. We've adopted the name "Horchata crew" and love connecting with these guys; from the friendly people up front to the kind guys that are serving it up on the grill.

Their salsa bar is one of the best in the city that I've tried; even better than what's down in the Mission. You have to try their Chipotle BBQ salsa, a bold flavor addition to any burrito or taco. I will say that the Shrimp burrito was a bit weak in flavor, but toss on the guacamole and I can't imagine a single food item on the menu flopping.

Go visit. Tell them the Horchata Crew sent you!
author: Nathan O.

description: I recently had the "world's best burrito" at some place in the Mission and I admit, it was FANTASTIC. I was skeptical at the thought that any other place would compare. This place did. Their plantain burrito was insane. If you're a meat love, ask for it in addition to it, but it's great on its own. The atmosphere is nice and friendly, and prepared to get cozy because it's mostly communal seating.  Ai Chihuahua!
author: Ben Z.

description:
they make some great customized burrito for me.. 

1. no rice,
2. half and quarter/quarter (mushrooms, tofu and green veggies)
3. black beans
4. whole wheat pita.
5. lots of guacamole.. 

everytime i get half to eat here and half to go.. and i can never take it home since i end up eating it there only.. its so good yum. .
author: Nihit S.

description:
I don't know.
Perhaps my tastes are geared towards that down and dirty, after a night of foam partying in Rosarito and stumble buzzed to the taco stand style of tacos but Little Chihuahua didn't make me rwar with pleasure as some of my recent jaunts for Mexican food.

I've been there in a pinch, on my way back  to Pac Heights from the bars down in the Haight or just being in the hood and while it is tasty, doesn't quite scream to me as "authentic".

That being said, their food IS pretty decent with better quality ingredients than most Mexican places I have recently jaunted to.They have a great salsa bar, tiny tables where you get to introduce your neighbor to your ass every time you need to get up, and fun atmosphere and chill employees. 

Sadly, I was starving the last time I was there and was so excited to eat my plantain burrito that when I got home and took it out of its little brown bag I sort of went looking for the rest of it. 
                                               It was small. 
I know, I should really stick to lady like portion sizes, but after a 5 mile run and a yoga class and walking 20 minutes from my house to Little Chihuahua and 20 minutes back, I was hoping to eat a burrito the size of a small newborn.
author: Kathy K.

description: Grabbed a bite to eat for the family as take out. The place is small and served first come, like a taco truck but in an established building. Not enough room for the seven of us on a Friday evening. The ordering over the phone was easy, and they had the order ready in 15 minutes. We had the Enchiladas, a Special Burrito, Quesadilla, and the Tostada salad. The salad was by far the best. The rest was average but good. Large portions, 4 orders fed the seven of us.
author: Jared C.

description: Wow. Best burrito I have had in sf!  And great salsa selection!
author: Daniel A.

description: If I could give them 3.5 stars I would. I would say this place is reliable. Food is "Mexican" (Mexican inspired) and does the job bc it's a healthier take on the typical Mex fare you get at this price point but it's not the tastiest around. They do claim to get many of their ingredients locally, which I applaud, and have vegetarian black (and veg. refried black) beans. They are always pleasant and courteous too.
author: Sandy G.

description: Had chicken enchiladas and horchata. The horchata was great but the enchiladas left a lot to be desired. They lacked flavor and didn't taste anything like real enchiladas. This place seems to cater to those who are not that familiar with authentic Mexican food.
author: Lynee L.

description: They were very nice and helpful. My daughter thought she was getting beans with her meal, but was incorrect. The staff brought her some complimentary beans. Thanks!
author: Mark B.

description: Garlic shrimp burrito was really good. Habanero salsa muy hot. I like that. I came in just before they closed they were nice about it.
author: Keefe M.

description:
I love you Little Chihuahua! Your guacamole! Your beans! Your green chile tofu and wild mushroom options! The way your tortillas are fresh and chewy! The crunch of your chips and the spiciness of your many fresh salsas! The potency and deliciousness of your sangria! The baby burritos!
Everything tastes soo good, just need to get past the busy-ness to heaven.
author: Cori W.

description: Great place to get a burrito. I loved that you can choose what type of tortilla you want (flour, wheat, spinach, etc.) and they have $3 beers on draft. They also give you a bowl of tortilla chips when you place your order and their salsa bar is awesome. What caught me by surprise were their protein options. I got the salmon super burrito and I've never heard of salmon being a protein option before. I'm glad I got it because the salmon was really delicious and moist. The only negative critique I have of this place is that you have to bus your own table. I don't think you should have to bus your own table at a restaurant where you tip. Also, I'm 5'2 and I wasn't able to reach the container where you leave your plates. I literally had to jump to place my plates in the container, which caused the plate to break.
author: Hana K.

description: Is there such a thing as a Little Chihuahua-holic? I think I might be one, if such a thing exists. I get mad cravings for the tostada salad with salmon and the burritos (plantain and black bean), as well as the corn chips (really good ones) and salsas if I don't have them at least once a week. It gets very busy at times, but the staff are friendly, efficient and keep it all moving along well. The music is usually good, there are cute fresh flowers on the tables and the pictures add to the whole relaxed feel. My neighbourhood favourite, conveniently located next to a yoga studio, so you can stretch, then satisfy your hunger!
author: Allison C.

description:
Definitely NOT your run of the mill hole in the wall mexican place. Though the place looks a bit run down, the food is EXCELLENT. I've enjoyed pretty much everything I've had from them.

Carnitas burrito - meat is tender and all the other ingredients are fresh
Tofu burrito - VERY good burrito for whenever I want to go vegetarian (not a lot)
Chicken enchilatas w/ green sauce - this sauce is why I come back. It is seriously the tastiest thing I've ever had in my life. The chicken was also moist and tender as well.
Garlic Shrimp burrito - holy cow is this thing awesome as well. The garlic is not too strong but still obvious on the shrimp. Definitely get this if you are looking for something out of the ordinary

I love their salsa bar as everything is made fresh and every single salsa is good. I kid you not. I love the tomatillo and pico de gallo myself.

This place can get pretty packed on most week nights and seating is first come first serve. If you can, call in and take it home if you live close but don't forget to load up on the salsa.
author: edward k.

description:
I've been dying to find a place near my hood that makes a good ol' fashioned enchilada plate with rice and beans and this place fulfills are requirements for a low, low price! Mexi-vibe mixed with hipster feel, this place knocks out great tasting food. 

Pros: Salsa bar. Cons: Noisy space when crowded.
author: Jasmyn M.

description:
I absolutely love this place. 

They have this super burrito which is like everything amazing that should be in a burrito in perfect proportions. But then they have this "Baby" super burrito which is perfect for me because I have no self control when it comes to burritos. Usually I eat the whole burrito no matter how big it is and then get sick. But, with the baby super burrito, I can eat the whole thing and not be deathly ill afterwards. Win! 

My friend swears by their tostada salad, which I've never had, but looks amazing.

They also have a delicious salsa bar and good beers. I haven't tried the sangria, but I hear good things. 

If I wasn't worried about Mexican food making me fat I would eat here more than once a week. Easily. 

The only reason I have it 4 stars instead of 5 is because it gets mad crowded in there and can be difficult to find seating. But the food is so damn good I go anyway and brave the crowds.

Eat here at least once. You will not regret it.
author: Sarah G.

description:
I'm not usually a fan of Chihuahuas.  Any girl that has had one just perplexed me.  They aren't cute!  They are whiny and aren't fun to play with.  They snarl.  I'm just not a fan of Chihuahuas.....until I met this Little Chihuahua.

Yes, you've read about it other reviews and the plantain burrito is great.  I made the mistake of not ordering it and instead order the breakfast tacos plate.  The breakfast tacos were good but I caught myself staring across the table at my girlfriend's plantain burrito.  You can even say it influenced met to believe my breakfast tacos weren't as good as they actually were.  They were solid...but I left with a desire to have my own plantain burrito.

The guacamole here is good and cheap!  The chips are decent and the salsa bar offers quite a nice variety.

People love burritos here.  I didn't really pick up on the infatuation with burritos in the bay area until recently but everyone was eating them.

The place can get packed but it wasn't too much of a wait to get a table.  Can't wait to go back!  If you know of a place like this in the Peninsula area, please let me know!
author: Sanket K.

description: Kind of disappointed with the food. It was a typical fusion joint, which seemed way too overpriced for the portion and taste. If you care about what you get for your money's worth, this isn't the place for you.
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
My favorite Mexican food, hands down.  Not just a taqueria, but a super taqueria.  I live outside of Sacramento, and I'd almost drive to SF just to eat here.  What a happy accident that we found this place a year and a half ago.  We have been 5 times, and I wish we could get there much more than that.  There has been only one trip in that time that we did not make it to The Little Chihuahua.  

I have had a chicken burrito, the breakfast burrito three times, and the tostada salad w/carnitas this time.  All amazing!  My husband has had something w/shrimp (I don't remember what and the nachos.  Also amazing!  My son has had soup, cheese quesadillas, and the (most delicious) pinto beans.  He loves it!  Will be trying the black bean & plantain burrito next.  Cannot wait!

Can't say enough about this gem of a restaurant.  Can you ship?
author: sheree f.

description:
You must try the Plantain and bean burrito with Carne Asada. Delicious! Skip the margaritas... and definitely fill up on their delicious tortilla chips. 
The line can seem long but usually moves very quickly.
author: Marisa C.

description: Love this place. Especially the shrimp quesadilla. Wish they'd open a location on clement st. Inner Richmond could use a solid mex joint.
author: Jennifer E.

description: There are no words for the garlic chicken burrito! LITERALLY THE BEST BURRITO I HAVE EVER HAD! I am genuinely allergic to gluten and this is one of the few Mexican restaurants I can eat at that always can provide gluten free tortillas. The ONE time in a year they ran out of GF tortillas, they provided me with half off 2 corn tortilla tacos for the same ingredients of the burrito. The BEST, most accommodating, Mexican restaurant I have EVER been to in SF.
author: Julia L.

description:
The first time getting food from here I ordered 2 super burritos. 
1st, the burrito is tiny. Like the size of a regular burrito. Please name accordingly 'cause you be foolin' like hella folks. 
2nd, we didn't get any guacamole or sour cream in our burrito. Like, I didn't want beans and added extra rice to accommodate the extra room I was expecting there to be, but no. Apparently asking for extra rice means subtracting guacamole and sour cream. 
I don't get it. What compelled you to think I didn't want guacamole? I didn't click "no guacamole" on my order. I would have noticed and thought it was out if character and I clicked it. 
I wasn't able to complain in person because I had it delivered so that's why I'm complaining on here. Sorry guys but meh.
author: ashley f.

description: After you do a bike tour of SF, THIS is where you go for a burrito.  Eat it slow and enjoy... you're gonna love it.
author: Amanda P.

description: From a tourist's perspective, it's nothing special. Definitely overpriced for what it is. It doesn't taste bad at all but it's just not worth the price tag. Got the carne asada enchiladas and they were okay. So for tourists from SoCal or other big cities with a lot of Mexican options, you're better off going somewhere else.
author: Billy B.

description: I should have read these reviews more carefully before ordering. I walked down from a friend's apt I'm watching while on spring break after finding this restaurant on Yelp to fulfill my hankering for a taco. A great vibe awaits with several long tables that seat 8 on one side and a few 4-squares on the opposite. It's small, casual, and inviting. It was pretty full and I happened to catch the 'tween time when everyone else already had food and seemed to be near the end of their meal.  I ordered two tacos:  one wild mushroom and one carne asada. Yes, the organic menu grabbed me too. 15-minutes later a plate was practically tossed at my #44 as I patiently waited for food and wrote in my notebook. No pleasantry, just a "Here." with a seeming harumph as the 20-something woman walked off.  What lay before me looked OK, but not even as yummy as most of the taco trucks around SF. Two open-faced, double tortilla tacos with some lettuce and lime slices on the side. (The usual fare for a street taco.) The meat was a little tough and the wild mushrooms didn't have much flair. Both were served with a heavy hand of tomatillo sauce, so I skipped the yum salsa bar that everyone has raved about. (Too bad that.)  These were not tacos that I would recommend nor return to.  If I'm out this way again, I'd rather head over to Nopalito (also in the neighborhood) with more quick and welcoming service and tastier food. However, if one of my pals insists, I would look over the more stellar reviews and say "I'll have what she's having," while pointing to one of these 5-star notations. Oh, and the prices are quite decent at $4.50 and $5.45 per taco depending on the ingredients.
author: Dana J.

description: I stopped by a couple weeks ago. And it was a day the owner Andrew was in. I have been to this restaurant many times and I loved it until I saw how the owner treats his employees. I usually observe things around me when I eat alone. And I was facing the cash register so I saw this man treat the some very good workers like they were nothing but trash. I will not support this man and his business any longer. I feel so strongly about this that I made an account just to post this. I went up and asked for his name, and I swear this man fakes an accent. This man is part of the reason the world is the way it is: people like him are in government.
author: Cely B.

description:
I like what they're doing here. comfortable place, decent grub, reasonable prices.

AMBIANCE
Comfy, warm, wood benches, happy people, good atmosphere

FOOD
I've tried a chicken burrito and a plantain & bean burrito. Both do the trick. They're not incredibly amazing burritos, but they're fine. They taste good, and actually kinda unique.

GUAC! This needs some work. It's fresh, and I will always order it, but it's slightly sour.

Salsas are fine, but not addictive. The habanero salso goes well with the plantain burrito
author: Shawn S.

description: The Plantain & black bean burrito is AWESOME! Love the unusual & unique items on the menu. Not your typical Mexican joint in SF.
author: Sarah K.

description:
700 reviews is a lot, so I'll be brief.

The food is pretty good, but not great, and maybe even a little pricey.
author: Herbert S.

description: tried this place out with friends..i like the cafe and experience overall..but, i wasn't a fan of the food not were my friends. their meats were very savory and not tasty.. i've had much more delicious carne asade..
author: Mridula P.

description:
One day after work, I found myself on Divisadero bored as all hell. I wanted to eat, yet my choices were burgers (pass), pizza (pass), I even though of giving this one place which earned themselves one of the most disgusting reviews I've posted int he history of my Yelping days - but (pass), Hervivore (pass), sit-n in fancy (pass). I was just f'ked. Nothing looked good. I was about to walk to the Upper Haight and find food.

But that was just a ridiculous choice, right? This is SF, this is Divisadero, I should find something. Then this chick started talking to me. She told me what she did, where she worked, where she lived, so what the hell, I asked her where she thought I should go eat. She walked me to two different places. I swear you'd thought she was getting paid for this. Then she recommended this place.

Who cares, the point is I didn't throw up. I paid under $10 for a decent burrito. The place was packed and everyone was rather friendly. I even had the table next to me invite me to sit with them and have a beer with them. 

I should have tipped the girl who recommended this spot. I really should have.
author: Alexia R.

description: Cheat day..really rainy out today too. Anyway, stopped here for lunch today, had a super burrito. Good size and it tasted great as well...fresh ingredients and really filling. The lime-cabbage slaw on the side was excellent....will definitely be back to try something new. I had to deduct one star because it's a tiny little spot and was packed, so I had to wait for a seat for a little bit before I could sit down and enjoy my meal.
author: Michael K.

description: Over priced bland Mexican food for people from the Midwest. There are so many cheaper and better places to get a burrito in San Francisco, move along.
author: Chris W.

description:
I don't know why I do it.

Every time I get something other than my regular order, I just end up feeling like I a cheater. 

tacos? enticingly delicious!
pozole? seems like the only way to go on a cold San Francisco day!
enchiladas? yes please!

but after the initial euphoria, the moment passes, and I think back to what I could have had and hope that next time I remember to resist the temptation and stick to my super baby burrito with pollo asada and refried black beans (to go).
author: Jane K.

description:
I love this place! The food was delicious, the service was friendly and fast, and the ambiance is like a cute little cafe you can hang out at and chill with some friends!! Five stars in all categories!!

Food: 
1) Carne asada nachos: Best nachos EVER!! I loved the tender cubes of carne asada that they generously sprinkled throughout the dish! The cheese was so flavorful and the chips, guacamole and everything else was just the bee's knees! I couldn't get enough of this!! 
2) Garlic shrimp burrito: not that this was not good, but relative to everything else...this burrito totally got overshadowed! If it was the stand alone thing that I got, it would think it's SOO good but because I had all the other dishes to compare it to, it just didn't step up to the plate to be as good as the other dishes! Still a solid delicious choice to order though!
3) Tortilla soup: SO FLAVORFUL and filled with soooo many ingredients!! There were cubes of chicken and cheese (that looked and tasted like tofu), and so many other things! I was totally digging this soup! 
4) Tostada salad: Served in a big taco bowl shell, it was the perfect mix of greens and salad dressing! I often don't like my salad drenched in too much dressing, but this place did it right. Salad at it's best (presentation and taste wise!). 

Ambiance: 
Like a cute little cafe that you can hang out and have a cup of coffee with a friend and just chat for hours...but it's a restaurant, not a cafe. Just gives you that feeling like you don't have to rush and you can just hang out and take your time. The decor is really bold and artistic! Very fresh vibe! 

Service: 
You just order at the counter and then they serve you the food but otherwise you bus yourself when you are done. 

Price: 
For food this good, it was totally worth it. I think all of that came out to be around $30. 

Overall: 
I'm sold on this place! Can't wait to come back and have me some YUMMY Mexican food!!!
author: Amiee H.

description:
My 1,100th review and my 2,000th burrito. 

(Not lying either, plus like my Met-Life blimp-like body shock many of you).

This is also true, I'm also recording all my burritos and trips to every taqueria I've been to. Chalk up another taqueria visit, because this is my first time to Little Chihuahua for a place I've heard that they make a Plantain Burrito. For a somewhat Burrito-enthusiast like myself and recent obsession with Plantain Bananas on almost anything, I was enticed to try the unique burrito. 

For $7.95+ tax, I get the usual filling that I find in a standard burrito. But instead of the meat, I get the Archipelago sweetness in my "silver-bullet". I'm used to burritos with meat-overload, but the sweetness of the Plantain tasted awkward with the other key ingredients. Don't get me wrong, but I think the restaurant has created a great burrito for other people. But for a burrito-lover like myself, I might pass on this special burrito. 

Just like any little Chihuahua(dog), this is a very cute place with limited seatings, in which I'll be back and try other foods. But I'll definitely skip the Plantain Burrito.
author: Matt G.

description:
- Yummy salmon tacos.
- Good burritos.
- Generous portions.
- Good variety of salsas.

Another neighborhood favorite.
author: Vandana N.

description:
Yummy food, good salsas on the salsa bar, and friendly staff, as well as a good margarita. The downside? Seating can be a pain in the arse.

I really like the chips they serve, and there's a yummy salsa bar where you can get as much as you want of several different offerings. I really like the pico de gallo, though everything I've tried has been good. There is also free water and cups next to here, which is a touch I like.

Both times I've gone I've gotten an enchilada because I want the rice and beans on the side. The most recent time my pollo asado enchilada was lukewarm and the cheese inside wasn't completely melted. That was a bummer, and I would knock a star off for that, but my previous enchilada (chile verde chicken) was really tasty. There were four people in my party and they all really enjoyed their food, so I would still go back. Even the vegan was able to find something yummy to eat (and hers was better than mine).

Overall, I'm a fan, but I'm hoping the enchiladas aren't lukewarm next time! Also, I need to find the magical time where there aren't a tone of people so I don't have to jostle for a table. I haven't had an issue with that though.
author: Sydney K.

description:
Being born and raised in San Francisco, I was a little skeptical about this place when I first walked in - my first impression was "expensive yuppie burritos" (compared to all the excellent Mission district taquerias).

I couldn't have been more wrong - the super burrito here is by far my most favorite burrito in the entire city!

Pros: Burritos, chips, salsa
Cons: None
author: Anthony B.

description: Been meaning to try this place for forever, and I'm glad I finally did for lunch when I was last in San Francisco. It's a tad pricier than your local taqueria, but the hipster vibe and healthier-looking menu sort of make you expect that. Also (in true Mexican cuisine fashion) the portions are ginormous. After some deliberation on which tostada salad to order, I went with the suggestion of the woman working there and got the camarones (shrimp). Nom, nom, nom... their salads have EVERYTHING in them. Juicy shrimps, organic mixed greens, black beans, avocado, tomatoes, cheese, cucumbers, mango salsa, bell peppers, lime, cilantro... am I missing anything? It was sooooooo good, just soooooo big. I tried my best but I probably only finished half of it in one sitting (though it didn't really look like I made a dent in the crispy tortilla shell bowl... which is also delicious btw). The sunny shade of blue paint and literally sunny furniture in here also made me happy. I'll be back for the brunch one day.
author: Kate V.

description: We have been coming here since they first opened, and the place used to be great.  But, over the past year or so, their prices went up and portions decreased.  Worse, their food preparation has also been incrementally deteriorating.  Last night, we reached our limit: our super burrito with two meats was TINY (way too much tortilla skin) and our tostada salad was burnt, shrimp cold & tasted out of the can, and beans were cold & barely there. Since this was not a one-off, we will not be going back.  Street Taco, up the street on Haight, is a more reasonable alternative, in our view.
author: Julia E.

description:
Randomly stopped in this place and was so glad I did!

Highlights:
-the plantain and black bean burrito is SO good! 
-salsa bar has great variety and chips were served warm
-friendly staff
-casual atmosphere
-quick service
author: Larissa A.

description: We love their burritos, especially with plantains!  I have only done takeout but the place looks clean and the people that work there are nice.  No complaints.
author: Nicole D H.

description: Amazing salsa bar! Great tortilla soup and salads too. It can sometimes be hard to find a table, but that's part of the charm. Love this neighborhood spot.
author: Jeff L.

description:
MMM...plantain black bean burrito!

Have picked up food from here a handful of times before or after watching UNC games at Danny Coyles. Had their Sangria for the first time the other night and it was pretty good but its the plantain black bean burrito that keeps me coming back.
author: Kate M.

description: The place is really tiny... But the food is awesome! Authentic Mexican! Really gold! Its a must when in San Fran
author: Vivian A.

description: Delicious burritos, great salsa bar and fast service! Solid Mexican food and it is open pretty late which is good. I like the tofu burrito- super baby is the way to go!
author: Julia W.

description:
This is an awesome burrito place! They are delicious, huge and good value. I made the "mistake" of ordering their super burrito, which is ridiculously massive and has sour cream and guacamole by default. If you just want a burrito, a baby burrito will be just fine for most people, trust me.

They've got plenty of choice and you can even choose the type of beans you want.

The employees are very friendly and you get your food pretty fast for such a busy place.

Be warned, it can get very crowded in the evening, so if you're looking for a quiet place, don't come here.
author: Nicolas S.

description: Ordered to go food after practicing Yoga next door.  Love their tostada with Carnitas. It was a very big tostada and good enough for two people. Love that they put Avocadoes on top. I have yet to try their fried plantain burrito that everyone is raving for. Will definitely be a regular to this place ,especially since its right next door to Yoga Garden.
author: Claudine V.

description:
I was honored to be able to do a photoshoot of the food and restaurant for the owner a few weeks ago.  The food is incredibly fresh, and they treat you really well.  I had lunch there as well after the shoot, and it was probably the best Mexican food I've ever had in the bay area!

Talking to Andrew, the owner, it really seems the restaurant is going down an awesome path and will just continue to get better.  They're opening up a new location soon too!  That is great news.

Here's some pictures of the food and restaurants: http://artchang.com/food-photography-17
author: Art C.

description: My wife and I were supposed to meet friends at Regazza across the street but the wait was just too long so we came over to get a quicker, casual meal at the Little Chihuahua. We are all vegetarians and got the guacamole tacos (I honestly am not sure if there were even avocados in this), mushroom quesadilla (cheese and mushrooms, kind of bland to me but my wife liked it), nachos (standard, nothing great but not bad) and the vegetarian burrito with plantains, which ended up being okay. The overall meal wasn't bad and it was nice to have vegetarian options but we probably won't be back for some time.
author: T K.

description: I recently tried the chips and guac, spinach baby burrito with chorizo and enjoyed a few beers. This is an excellent bite when you've had a few drinks and are craving Mexican. However, if you are looking for top notch Mexican, I would steer you elsewhere. The chips here are just average and not hot, the burritos are good but nothing spectacular.
author: Madeline S.

description: I've been here a bunch of times and I feel like nothing stands out, everything from the meats to the salsa are very bland. Their food is very fresh and they are generous portions but I feel unfulfilled none the less.
author: Jeff C.

description:
If I could give 0 stars I would.  Im typing this to you as my stomach is still gurgling.  I was woke up this morning at 1am and from 1-3pm I was suffering from food poisoning which I comes from the uncooked shrimp from the garlic shrimp burrito.  I knew the shrimp wasn't cooked all the way from my first bite, but i was eating with someone who took me out, the place was super busy and I didn't want to make a fuss!!! HOW STUPID WAS I! I just ate around the shrimp hoping my friend wouldn't notice how disgusted I was with the burrito.  I ate around the shrimp to less than 1/2 and told my friend I was full.  I was already disappointed when I ordered the burrito with none of the 3 salsas they put in it (who the hell uses 3 different salsas for one small ass burrito) The pungent garlic salsa was overwhelming to the point where you couldn't enjoy the garlic.   I will never be returning the to DOG!!!  My friends shrimp looked the same and i'm wondering if he is okay but he says it's his favorite so maybe he is used to it! If I had sick leave at my job i would not be at work today its just that bad.  I hope the homeless person I gave my left overs to is okay!!!

AFTER TALKING TO MANAGER HE WAS VERY SORRY AND SENT ME A FREE ENTREE COUPON WHICH I WILL BE GIVING TO MY FRIEND.

update: HE NEVER SENT COUPON!!
author: Ishtar P.

description:
One of the better burritos in the neighborhood.

They're known for their plantain burrito but I'd say skip it - get the breakfast burrito instead. 

Don't forget the chips because their salsa bar rules!
author: Murphy O.

description:
Fried plantain burrito with veggie black beans.

Delicious.

Despite big flavorful plantains, intermingled with fresh salsa, rice, beans, and a sweet smoky sauce - Little Chihuahua - still fails short of  Papalote's super fish burrito.

But their prices are great. They offer different portions, for those who can't finish a whole huge burrito in one sitting (I have no problem doing this). They have wine margaritas and sangria.They have a unique selection of tasty sounding burritos. And they're fast.

I wish this place had been around when I used to live in the hood. If you're looking for a take-out snack to take to the park, or are looking for a new burrito experience - check out Little Chihuahua.
author: Jessica T.

description:
Dear Little Chihuahua,

You have the worlds best Tostada! I made this yelp account just to express my love for this place. You guys have the best food and service in San Francisco. 

A true diamond in the rough.
author: Peter B.

description:
The Little Chihuahua: AWESOME. 

I work in the Mission and have lived in such latino hot spots as Los Angeles, Ca and this is up there with some of the best burritos I've had. 

I am particularly fond of the plaintain burrito. It may not be authentic, per se, but it is DAMN tasty. 

Their horchata sucks so bad I can't even describe how much I hate their horchata (I have horchata from different places at least 3x a week)  but I am willing to look past that given how good all their other food is.

The dining room isn't very big and good luck trying to get more than 6 people to sit together. 

All in all - a great place to eat. 

If you're looking for a place to go afterwards there's The Page and Madrone Art bar.
author: Carlos A.

description: Over a year and a half later and I still have this place on speed dial!  You know it's a local favorite when they're busy at all hours-- even that awkward "linner" hour (lunch/dinner ~3:00).
author: Jamie B.

description: I won't lie: I thought this was a pet supply store for about four years. So it was a delicious surprise for me to recently discover its kitchen turns out tasty pozole and yummy burritos. The dining room is crazy crowded, but somehow more cozy than annoying. And the endless stream of locals constantly popping in and out for take-away confirms you've stumbled upon a neighborhood favorite. Hell, the house-made chips and fresh salsas alone make this place worthy of your attention.
author: Gregor G.

description:
Yum! Sustainably farmed, organic, fresh and affordable! It is my favorite lunch spot AND their agave wine margaritas are strong and delicious. I have frequently thought that if I liked to hang out their it would be my drink of choice on many evenings. The only thing I would change is that I'd like internet, but it's usually too crowded for people to take up space working anyway.

Highly recommend: Quesadillas, easy on the cheese(there will still be plenty), half chicken/half veggie. Also the salads are awesome.
author: Johna G.

description:
Like all the other reviewers, I love this place. I'm such a fan of the plantain and black bean burrito that I've failed to branch out into anything else. So, so, very good. I have tried a bite or two of the shrimp burrito as well, and that was great too.

They also have an excellent salsa bar. Although it sounds strange, I'm not actually the biggest fan of salsa as a food group, but even I found something to love here.
author: Lindsay M.

description:
The burritos, salads, and ice cream are out of this world. Fresh, and inspired.

The service was chipper and fast.

The ambiance was nice.

The place was open late-ish on a weekday, which is nice. 

How could it be made better? ... offer up free cilantro at the salsa bar.
author: Ian S.

description: I'm not certain the food here is better than Taqueria Cancun, but they are certainly a shorter walk.  I recently got two rounds of nachos that were expertly constructed with heaping portions of meat (carnitas and pollo adobo).  The best part were the extra chips I was given to help if the base layer of chips got too soggy as they are likely to do when nacho-ed.  I haven't had the burritos here, but I assume they are reliably good like their sister spot on 24th.
author: Jeremy G.

description: The people who work here are very nice. The salsa bar is good. The restaurant itself was filthy. And it's basically shared tables. I had chicken enchiladas. The cheese never melted inside, so it was chunks of warm chicken, with balls of cheese, wrapped in a cold tortilla, slopped over with a room-temperature red sauce that tasted like it was dumped out of a can of Ragu sauce. I don't get it. My partner had mushroom enchiladas, and was convinced that they were "reconstituted" mushrooms (I have no idea what that means - oh wait: he says - "dehydrated and then reconstituted with water"). Even if they were not reconstituted, they tasted like they were. Two people, two enchilada dinners, two non-alcoholic beverages: $26 (excluding tip). So far, this was our worst meal in San Francisco.
author: Morris R.

description:
Could possibly be the BEST burrito joint outside of Mission!  

Faves:
Plaintain Burrito
Tostada with either Steak or Chicken
Chicken Tacos
Agave Wine Margarita  (absolute must have)

The chips and salsa is pretty good as well and I definitely want to try out their desserts next time, especially the rice pudding with rum soaked almonds and the root beer float with tequila ice cream.  One thing to note, the place is rather small and pretty difficult to get a table if its busy.  Either get there early or get take out.  Otherwise, really solid place to get your burrito cravings satisfied.
author: Joel C.

description: I think I've just had the best burrito of my life: the Al Pastor burrito with sour cream. I've had the Al Pastor burrito in the past, and it was good, but this one today is beyond. It's clear someone cares a lot about what they're cooking.
author: Angela K.

description: The plantain and black bean burrito, w/ added chicken was so delicious.  It's these small hole in the wall places that give SF a good name...  Staff was so friendly too.. :))
author: Paul C.

description: While finding a place to sit was annoying, the food blew my mind!!! We are talking about knowledgeable staff, tasty food, and so many options for vegetarians:) I ordered bean & cheese with rice, tofu, avocado, pico. Redonkeylas how delish!:)
author: Diana S.

description:
My go to Mexican item at a new place is a super chicken burrito.  I was impressed by Little Chihuahua when I moved down here last year. Too bad they weren't on that 100 best Burritos list a while back - they are way better than some of the places in the Mission that *did* make that list.... The salsa bar is nice too.  I do prefer takeout here though - when it gets busy, and you have to bus your own table, which is fine, and then sort out compost, etc. you might want to wash your hands afterwards, but the bathroom is way in the back where you order and very crowded...  Maybe the layout could be better but the food and atmosphere is great!

Update 4/25/15:

Recently tried the carne asada burrito, which is very tasty, but not that much carne is included. More recently I ordered this again, and added extra carne. I was told it would be a $3.75 upcharge, and agreed to it. My girlfriend ordered a plantain burrito with garlic shrimp added (also very tasty), with a $2.50 upcharge. I guess what we didn't realize was the initial price of these items as it was a phone order, which was $11.50 & $11.95, respectively. Didn't get the total over the phone, which ended up being $32.31, with the SF surcharge - and the guy at the counter didn't make the prices up - so a $3 tip, so basically, $35. For two burritos. I asked for one of the larger plastic containers for some salsa to go, and then the guy that just rung me up says, "Well technically I'm supposed to charge you for tha...." I took the cup and said thank you very much. 

Not really sure what to say about it. The food was good. Just didn't seem right.
author: Zac W.

description:
I LOVE this place and go there all the time. It's like a "regular taqueria" except the food is sustainably raised and fresh, so you don't have to wonder about the quality of the meat you're eating. 

The only downside is the a**holes who grab a seat before they get in line. Do NOT send a friend to a table to stake it out while you wait for 20 minutes in line. UNcool. FYI here's the order of things: 
1) Get in line. 
2) Order. 
3) Get your number. 
4) Walk to a table if there is one. If not, wait for one.

Otherwise, enjoy! Great food!
author: Jennifer B.

description: I am not giving these guys five stars because their plantain burrito is fantastic (and their other burritos aren't too shabby either) and I am not giving them five stars for their nectar of the Gods chipotle salsa.  Nor am I giving them five stars for their customer service which is exceptional - they go out of their way to make sure that they get your order right every time.  No, I am giving them five stars because they have gluten free tortillas.  I live with a kid who was recently diagnosed with celiacs disease and was devastated at not being able to enjoy all the foods he loves including burritos.  Not only does the tortilla taste great to him but its filled with fantastic Little Chihuahua ingredients.   SF has so many great burrito restaurants but The Little Chihuahua gets love because they get just about every detail right.
author: Lou R.

description:
Fried Plantain and Black Bean Burrito ($9.72). I'm plantain-obsessed, so I was obviously a fan. The chips were a little over-salted for my taste, but who cares about chips when there are plantains?!

You order at the counter, so it's easy to get food to go. But if you manage to get a table you can order beer, wine, agave wine margaritas, or/AND sangria.  

This is definitely a solid place if you know you're going to get a different type of burrito. It's definitely not a typical taqueria and should not be compared against them. Go here when you want a hyper-American spin on a burrito.
author: Talia G.

description:
I like Little Chihuahua

they try hard to source better quality ingredients

they have REALLY good roasted green and roasted red salsa

the interior is casual chow and dash - but not fast foody feeling like someplace like Pancho Villa

They separate their garbage into trash, recycle and compost - though it is mostly up to the customers to throw it into the proper spot - so look out for it

they have truly vegan beans (not cooked in lard) that taste good and not blah

they're fast and still good

Downside --- consistency is sometimes lacking --- something you order one time may not be the same next time you order --- may also be good but I do like to be able to order and get the thing I like
author: Dizzy L.

description: Visiting from MIAMI. Love the no frills atmosphere and authentic Mexican dishes. A must try if you are in San Francisco.  We had the sweet plantain and chicken burritos which were both amazingly good.  The authentic chips certainly helped.
author: Brian M.

description: Decent mexican but doesn't come close to rivaling the Mission.  Take the $5 Lyft south.
author: Chris C.

description:
This place has made a couple changes that have made it even more awesome!!! 

1) They've rearranged/added more seating. This has helped open up the front of the restaurant so you don't feel crammed in when your waiting for takeout orders. 

2) They've added a second register for people picking up takeout orders. This is extremely helpful!!! Before, you had the choice of waiting in line with everyone else, which could sometimes take up to ten minutes even though your order was ready or just cut to the front of line and have to deal with dirty looks and under-there-breath obscenities from other patrons. 

I also finally got to try a breakfast burrito from here and it was AWESOME!!!!
author: George A.

description:
This place is great. 

salmon tacos. wild mushroom taco salad. salmon burrito. 

done and done! 

I could eat here every other day for sure, I love this place. Fast service, super friendly staff, and excellent food. definitely on my top list.
author: Saskia S.

description:
carne asada taco salad, plaintain burrito, chicken quesadilla... YUM!  i love everything at this restaurant.  I like to consider it white-people mexican food.  You know: black bean options, real leafy greens, jack cheese.  Fun atmosphere; I enjoy the bench seating with pillows and stain-glass windows.
  So, now that my mouth is watering, I think I'll head down there and get something scrumptious for lunch!
  minus 1 star because i think they can ramp up their salsa bar
author: Laura M.

description:
I got a little more than I bargained for at The Little Chihuahua. All I wanted was some good mexican food, really, I swear.

Instead, I got a taco salad with a side of incredibly-drunk-man passed out on the seat.
