Not gonna lie, it was kind of amusing watching him bang his nose against the table and then bang his entire body against the floor once he 'slipped' out of his chair, still passed out. Unfortunately, the dude was like 6'5 and 200lbs+, so no restaurant employee was planning of carrying him out of there anytime soon.

I still managed to eat my taco salad amongst the busyness of 4 men carrying the drunkie out, the police grabbing him and the restaurant staff re-arranging the tables- and yes, my taco salad was delicious. Tons of veggies, nicely dressed, crunchy fried tortilla and lots and lots of cheese. It was bigger than a newborn baby, so I couldn't finish it, but damn it was good.

So, assuming that the spectacle is not a Little Chihuahua regular (or is it?) I'm gonna go with 4 stars for food, pretty tasty.
author: Emily G.

description: If you don't want to travel to the Mission to get the really good stuff then this is a good alternative. Slightly pricier than places in the Mission and more hip/cool place then the dirty burrito joints that turn out awesome food in other parts of the City. Their salsa bar is pretty top notch and the guacamole is super tasty, right amount of smooth avocado and spices. Chips are refilled at your request and there seems to be never ending business coming in. Carnitas burrito was OK nothing special and the size was questionable, Super Baby, should have gone with the Super. Wasn't much to the Super Baby, but that's my fault, had the weird feeling of eating more tortilla rather than goodness nestled inside of it. I would say a Super is a normal sized burrito elsewhere.
author: Ezra B.

description:
Excellent burritos.

Salsa bar is quite tasty. The chips are a bit hit or miss - of excellent quality when they hit (when they're fresh?) and of acceptable quality when they miss. Beer selection is limited but good. 

Possible flaws: They have other, non-burrito, food that may not be as good? More expensive than other burrito joints that are (almost) as good.
author: Paul L.

description: The burrito did not live up to the high expectations. I ate half there, and saved half for home only to find a long black hair in the second half... I really wanted to like this place, but the hair was a deal breaker.
author: Camille d.

description: I've been to both locations a total of 3 times, and I don't know why I keep coming back.  The food is just okay, and the prices are crazy.  Two little shrimp tacos... for $13?  Thats just stupid, and I'm stupid for coming back.  Mexican food for rich white people. (two stars, because the food isn't horrible).
author: Jesse C.

description:
This is one of those places which makes me sad thinking that I'm not in SF. 
They have the best horchata ever! Ok, I admit it's the first and only time I had horchata, but I don't think it can be any better. Especially in combination with their baby burrito, which was actually quite filling. 
And the people working there are so friendly!
author: Jay F.

description:
Tacos de camarones were really good
Also had some nice smoked tomato salsa
author: Kevin S.

description:
After hiking through a super windy Land's End (something else I highly recommend), it was time for a good margarita and some Mexican food.  We decided to try The Little Chihuahua and I'm glad we did.  Not only are the margaritas generous (a full glass instead of those measly half-glasses you usually get), but they are made with agave wine and oranges, which gives them a slightly sweeter taste, but just as good.

You get a bowl of chips and self-serve salsa after ordering. I loved the roasted tomato one, which had a nice kick to it.

I got the camarones enchiladas and was happy to see they weren't doused in cheese, like most places do.  There was a healthy amount of shrimp in the 2 enchiladas, and the rice and beans were served on the side.  I got mine with the green sauce, and was actually able to finish both.

The Little Chihuahua has a great, casual atmosphere, and we'll definitely be back the next time we're in the hood.
author: Ashley T.

description: Ate here my first time in the Castro. It was an incredibly delicious meal. I can't speak highly enough about it. The flavors were so deep and rich and to be honest, nothing can beat the free buffet of various salsas.
author: Shawn M.

description:
i'm giving 3 stars just because the tortilla soup was good good 
if i hadn't ordered it i'd give this place 1 star...... thats how bad the enchiladas were. maybe it's because i'm puerto rican and i know how their suppose to taste but these enchiladas are literally flavorless flavorless there is no flavor at. all 
if i want to eat empty calories i at least want the food good but these enchiladas were empty in taste and time 



did i mention how bomb the soup was though :-)
author: Gigi M.

description: Salsa bar is fresh and delicious. Tacos with black beans & rice plate was excellent.
author: H H.

description:
"Yummy, yummy in my tummy!"

On a recent trip to SF, we decided we wanted something out of the normal touristy areas. We YELP'ed and found that Little Chihuahua was nearby. Seeing all the positive reviews, we decided to give it a shot. And boy were we pleased!

We tried their pork pozole, garlic shrimp burrito, and the horchata. All three were very delicious! The spices in the pozole were spot on! And I would know, I'm Mexican and visit my family in Mexico quiet frequently where I always have fresh, authentic pozole. 

The service was good and the staff is very attentive. The place is a bit on the small side but that gives it a homelike feeling. It also has no restroom so make sure you wash up before arriving. 

I will definitely make it a point to visit the Little Chihuahua next time I am in the neighborhood.
author: Josue G.

description:
Plate of nachos was gigantic and delicious- meaty, cheesy, fresh goodness covered nearly every chip on the plate.

The tortilla soup was extremely salty, but was otherwise flavorful and quite good as well.

I was really impressed. I'll be back.
author: Kim T.

description: Very delicious and quick. The veggie enchilada was tasty, and it was great to wash it down with the Agave Wine Margarita.
author: Shannon H.

description: Great burrito joint! Friendly & timely service! Fun fact: they have bunch, check it out.
author: E.R. F.

description:
My first "wet" burrito! Turns out I like it wet!

High quality burrito, really tasty with a good spicy sauce.

It feels like a slightly higher class Mexican restaurant.. maybe even date spot Mexican, it is a fun atmosphere especially later on weekend nights as people head in after a few libations in the local bars.

Service was friendly and fast.

Overall great experience!
author: Chris M.

description: I ordered a delicious garlic shrimp burrito and an agave wine margarita. Overall very good! Will definitely come here again.
author: Douglas M.

description: Love their Chile Verde Chicken, with fried pinto beans. The burrito are delicious here, always leave full here.
author: Krystal S.

description:
Every once in a while, the perfect set of circumstances put you right on the path to a delightful discovery. That's what happened to us when we stumbled across The Little Chihuahua in San Francisco.

The circumstances were being hungry, being in the mood for something a little bit unique, and concerned just a little bit about how much we would spend for our lunch. Our feet and our circumstances placed us right outside the door of this charming spot and the rest is history.

The atmosphere was welcoming and cheerful, the menu was varied and highly affordable, the food was delicious, and the beer was delightfully cold and surprisingly priced.

I had the black bean and plantain burrito. It was as wonderful as I suspected it would be -- fresh delicious ingredients and wonderful salsa from the very clean and well equipped salsa bar. My companion had some combination plate which I cannot recall because it was enthusiastically proclaimed to be too delicious to share.

I think this reached up into the realm of 5 stars for me because of the very friendly and helpful service, the attractive decor, and the very compassionate price on the beer.

I'm certain that when we are in this neighborhood again, returning to The Little Chihuahua will be on our minds.
author: Vincent L.

description: Still good food but the recent price hikes have a burrito above $13 before tip and 50 cents for chips. Time to cut back, sorry lil' doggy!
author: Sch T.

description: Very nice Mexican foods in a good price range. My school is near so I would love to visit again sometimes. Besides, casiher waitress is super hot. I am not kidding. You check the place out and agree me on that bros.
author: Jake B.

description:
My friends have been telling me all sorts of great things about Little Chihuahua, but I've always been hesitant to stop in since I'm not huge on Mexican & Green Chile has always been my neighborhood go-to. But oh man... HOLD THE PHONE. I am a true fan & total believer. I was as soon as I walked in and saw that their chalkboard was highlighting a Humphrey Slocombe tequila ice cream float. Anyone a friend of Humphrey's is a friend of mine. So, I ordered up one of these delicious suckers, chomped down some tortilla chips & chunky salsa and devoured a Plantain & Black Bean Burrito. And let me say this... I don't typically go for vegetarian dishes, but I could not resist the appeal of a plantain & black bean burrito. What a combo of deliciousness.

Beware, it is teeny tiny up in here, so be prepared to do some work to snag a table and squeeze into it. My friends tell me that no matter what time of day they've been here, its always been packed. Next time I'll likely be taking my goods to-go.
author: Tiffany M.

description:
Super(b) Burrito! 

Definitely the best burrito I've ever had.* The quality of the ingredients really makes it stand out. the rice and the quality of the meat were just awesome. It's a little on the small side but i imagine a lot of people like to take theirs away. Service was surprisingly fast for a made to order (non-assembly line) joint, and friendly. I will be back here as often as I can and my waist line allows. 

*I live on the East Coast.
author: Justin L.

description:
Amazing plantain burritos and salsa bar, fast, good prices, I am addicted.
Taco salad is sooo good.  Horchata is great.
author: Elena G.

description: I love the communal eating. Super fun and socal. Service was extremely fast and everything was tasty. I got a carnitas and a tofu taco. Good size but tofu could have been seasoned a little for more flavor. I also got some delicious fried plantains. All in all very pleased with my experience there. I will be back.
author: Maey P.

description: After reading other yelp reviews I decided to check this place out but was very disappointed:( The food wasn't good (except for their nachos). I love Mexican food and am always looking for a new place but I wouldn't come here again.
author: Shanna M.

description: Garlic shrimp burrito + sangria + chilaquiles = solid Tuesday brunch. I was so pumped to try this place after seeing the glowing Yelp reviews and I was not disappointed! This place is small so I can see why most people order take-out, just be warned of some cramped seating. There's also a nice selection of salsas, from super mild to gringo spicy. What this place likely lacks in authenticity it more than makes up for in taste and freshness. It's not a standard cheap taqueria but one burrito (~9-10 bucks) will tide you over for at least half a day, so it's not a problem. Overall, this place is definitely worth checking out!
author: Rina M.

description:
Best mexican joint that I know of. Period. Let's put it this way: two friends of mine from San Diego (you know, that city right by Mexico) came to SF and I showed them this place. They loved dinner there so much they went back for breakfast the next morning! They both said it was the best Mexican food they'd had. Ever.

When you go, try the plantain burrito. It's a wonderful mixture of sweet/savory in a burrito! Can't go wrong with this vegetarian dish, and I'm a meat eater!
author: Dan F.

description: Don't get the hype about this food, we ordered the shrimp burrito. It was chewy and tasted like it was frozen. Will not be returning.
author: Jangalina J.

description:
Love this place.  Great burritos and such.  Delicious pozole as well - for those chilly winter/summer/all nights.  If you come on a weekend night and you love to sit, you'll be better off getting take out.  Literally every single chair was taken at every table when I was there.  It's SUPER happening.

Oh get your burritos "smothered" with red or green salsa (for +$1), or, make sure you at least pour some of the salsa from the salsa bar (+$0) onto your boring dry burrito.
author: jon y.

description: I can't believe I lived in the lower haight for so long without stopping into the little chihuahua! Finally made it here today for some delicious carnitas quesadillas. Lost one star because when I asked if there was cilantro in any of what I ordered they said no, and then there was some in the pico di gallo (it just tastes like soap to me). Will definitely be back!
author: Eliza D.

description: One of my favorite burrito spots in the city. The Garlic Shrimp burrito will blow your mind and be sure to grab extra salsa! the line gets long but well worth any wait and it moves quickly. A great spot for dinner with friends or a weeknight splurge!
author: Samantha A.

description:
I was meeting a friend for dinner last night and requested someplace with a margarita, as it was cinco de mayo and I had to work all night after dinner. She suggested this place. I got excited reviewing the stuff on Yelp, and I was not disappointed.

First off, what made me come there (the margarita)--this doesn't really taste like a margarita. More like a tequila sunrise. They use some sort of juice (orange?) and agave wine, I believe. But that being said, it is absolutely delicious and I'm a bit of a margarita snob.

Everything comes with chips and the best part is that the CHIPS ARE GOOD! Usually places like this come with crap chips that taste like cardboard and are a waste of calories but not here. Crispy, crunchy, light, salty, and free. It's genius.

The salsa bar is awesome. Go for the Roasted Tomato salsa. It has a healthy kick but isn't too spicy (I LOVE the spiciest ones, but this one has the most robust flavor and it'll satisfy you even if you want something that burns your mouth off).

My friend raves about the tortilla soup and it looked really good. I got the tostada salad with wild mushrooms and it was DELICIOUS. Light, great flavor combos, good sized salad. It was really great.

The interior is great, only not-ideal part is that you might be sitting at a big table with tons of people right next to you, so not very good for private conversations.

Also, someone asked us to leave yesterday. I totally understand that they were really busy and people needed to sit down. But being at a sit down restaurant where I'd spent a good amount of money, it still feels weird being asked to leave. But I guess they do what they have to do. I'll be back to try the black bean and plantain burrito.
author: Courtney A.

description:
Awesome burritos with great ingredients.  I tend towards the veggie options here, which are all good. The plantain, mushroom, and grilled veggie burritos are all stellar.  I tend to abuse the salsa bar here, but they don't seem to mind. 

It can be a little loud at this location at peak times, but there's also one in Noe valley for a more laid back experience if you happen to have a car.  It's definitely not a purists burrito place (in the sense of being a mission-style joint), but they don't try to be and I like them better for it.
author: Bob L.

description: Tacos yummy. Organic corn chips and good salsa bar. Very laid back and can take your time eating. A little pricey but worth it. Short walk from CPMC Davies. Will definitely be back.
author: alibee i.

description:
I really adore this place for some pretty cheap Mexican that doesn't make me feel gross.

The people behind the counter are always super friendly to me, which I love. Nice little beer selection. My favorite items are the shrimp quesadilla & the baby super burrito with carne asada.
author: Kristina C.

description:
The best burritos in the city.  Unlike most places, the ingredients actually taste fresh.

Make sure to get a horchata and the plantain and black bean burrito (eat with habanero salsa for an amazing mix of sweet and spicy).

Grab it to go -- seating can be a bit cramped.
author: Ethan B.

description: Came again and got a tostada salad. It was okay, a little heavy on the dressing. Love the cheese though! Wish I had added a protein but I didn't think of it when I called it in. It was ready pretty quickly!
author: Alexandra W.

description:
Great little cantina off the path, prices were great deals, and food was very tasty!  Kind've a quick service place where food is brought out to your table, but you do the rest.  Great chips and salsa too while you wait.

If you don't have a huge appetite, consider getting one of the baby burritos, which is a smaller portion burrito, but was more than enough to fill me for lunch.
author: Joe H.

description: Good burritos.... and the salsa bar is excellent. Added bonus? This and the other chains have a rule in place by the owner that they MUST PLAY BLACK SABBATH AT THE BEGINNING OF EVERY SHIFT. Yup. Black Sabbath for breakfast. HORNS EARNED, CHIHUAHUA!!!!!
author: Cole B.

description:
Dirty table, never cleaned by employees.  Basically had to keep flaking off old chips off my arms while I ate bad Mexican food.  

Too expensive for what it is.  Bathroom was marked as not being cleaned since 12:00 pm, it was 8:30 when I went in and it was filthy. 

Floors were disgusting.  

Nachos were mediocre, carne asada was decent.
author: F G.

description:
There food was pretty amazing. I had their plantain and black bean burrito and it was basically perfection. They also have a salsa bar, which contains various types of yummy salsas. 

The guy at the cashier register also bended over backwards to help my party out. 

I highly recommend!
author: Morgan C.

description: Little Chihuahua makes good California style burritos and decent tacos. The regular size burrito is a classic large/huge burrito, but they also have a "baby" burrito which is a more normal size. It's nice that they offer this choice, so you don't leave feeling like you are busting a gut because you just ate a giganitc burrito. The place can get crowded and for some reason people like to bring their young children here to go nuts and make a mess at the first come first serve tables in the front. They also offer to-go service. Little C. has a great salsa bar and free chips, and the veggie burrito is pretty good, but certainly not the best in SF.
author: R. J.

description:
Going to start this off by saying that I'm from San Diego, and there is no Mexican food that is better than that of San Diego. Not even in Mexico.

This is a great place! One of my regular spots on Divisadero. Lots of options, especially since their menu is vegetarian friendly. The quality of ingredients is top notch. You can even order a 'baby' burrito if you're watching your figure.

Niman ranch stuff is great. Keep it going! Tasty wild mushroom burrito. 

Probably the only place where the chips are even good. Usually the taquerias that I've been to have solid burritos but are often paired with shitty chips.

THE ROASTED TOMATO SALSA IS TO DIE FOR.

The only thing that kinda sucks is the seating space, it often gets cramped and you may end up sitting at one of the large tables eating next to someone you don't know. Not that I'm an anti-social person, but I do like some elbow room when I eat.
author: Harold C.

description:
Arguably the best restaurant in San Francisco. 

- Delicious healthy food
- Beer on tap
- Lively atmosphere
- Fast service
- Very nice staff
- Awesome salsa bar
- Meets anyone's budget
author: Alex G.

description: The steak tostada was amazing! Fresh ingredients and great service. We were impressed!
author: Michelle M.

description: Great place to eat at a reasonable price and to top it all off it is non GMO. My brother and I came to this restaurant hearing about its praises from vegetarians, to our surprise. Thus, we were extremely curious because if anyone knows about Mexican delicacies is that they are not seemingly meant for vegetarian diets. In turn, our orders consisted of grilled chicken tacos, and a carne asada burrito.  Both were well prepared and delicious.  My brother in fact, said that it was the best carne asada he had ever had. Coming from a mexican household that tends to be a great compliment. Overall, my next trip to San Fran will definitely include another visit here!
author: Jimmie B.

description:
Super casual, small place, small menu, yummy food. 

Came for brunch, chilaquiles was good, inexpensive, left full.

Yum :)
author: S Y.

description:
Don't go too often, but when I do the food at Little Chihuahua is awesome. But what got me to write the review (actually to get a Yelp account in the first place) was because when I was there recently, the place was packed and our order got messed up. People behind us got their food well before we did and when mine did come, it wasn't the right thing. I didn't think it was a big deal; they were clearly slammed and the food was great anyway. 

But a guy working there (long blonde hair) comes up, apologizes like crazy, takes my info, and then continues to run around delivering food, etc. Anyway, that went down Thurs. (8/21) ... come home today from work and what do I see? A nice letter and a coupon for a free entree at Little Chihuahua. Big thanks to long-haired blonde dude. I'll be back for sure.
author: Emily D.

description: The little Chihuahua reminds me of how delicious the original Chipotle in Denver used to be; fresh, organica and flavorful.  However, they add more variety to the menu including free chips w/ various sassy salsas on the side and for dessert; sopapillas & ice cream!  -Time to think outside the tin foil.
author: Russell C.

description: Walked past this place and thought the name was catchy. There was a bit of a wait for dinner, and was difficult to find seating. That said, the plantain burrito was fantastic and filling, and the wine margarita hit the spot!
author: Drew B.

description: With a group of 5, we got a table right away. The food was great, and a really fun atmosphere.
author: Kirsten B.

description:
I feel like this place had been hyped up for some reason, and while it was good, there are definitely better Mexican food places.

Granted, I didn't order a burrito, I only got a tacos, so maybe the burritos are the thing to try?

I got a carnitas taco and a carne asada taco, and the carnitas was far superior. Don't waste your time with the carne asada taco, just go straight for the carnitas (or some other potentially better taco meat). The salsa bar, while having ~8 choices, wasn't as awesome as I'd hoped. I found two salsas that I really liked, and kept going for more of them.

Without a drink, the total came to about $10.

I'd come back, but it probably wouldn't be my first choice for the area.
author: C S.

description: The food is a-ok. I like the chicken enchiladas, but this place is always so super crowded when I come, I can't get a table to eat at, so I have to take my food to go. When I get home, my food is cold :-/ Eghhh, I know its not their fault that its super cramped, but like I said, the food is just a-ok.
author: Michael T.

description: Good, not fantasico but good! I think I need to try something other than the chicken. I will update my review after I try the tortilla soup!
author: Meredith M.

description: Easily the best burrito I've ever had. Fast service. Nice neighborhood. Cool atmosphere. I had the fried plantain burrito. Fantastic. Will definitely go back.
author: Kat R.

description:
Tostada salad: black beans, mango, avocado, roasted red peppers, and a creamy cilantro-lime dressing over baby greens.  

Served with sangria - definitely a fan.
author: Elizabeth M.

description:
This place has a great salsa selection. The plantain burrito is a must try, especially for vegetarians looking for something new in their burrito. 

a little pricier than the taquerias in the mission but the variety is really interesting and it is still a good deal on a meal.
author: Leuwam T.

description:
That's right. A mission-dweller is giving 5 stars to Mexican food in another neighborhood. Little C is awesome!

As mentioned in other reviews, the salsas are all to-die-for. Great chips, yummy guac. Mmmm. I had a tofu taco which came in a really generous portion and with another great sauce on top. 

They have Mexican beers on tap/in bottles. Perfect spot to grab anything from a snack to a full meal. I'll be back!
author: Gretchen S.

description: Had an unremarkable burrito. Not bad, but nothing special. I'd eat here again if friends wanted to, but wouldn't bring it up myself.
author: Rajesh S.

description:
Little Chihuahua is my personal favorite mexican joint/ taqueria in the city. This place is not quite a full service restaurant but yet has a more upscale feel to it compared to a regular taqueria. The ingredients are top noch. The thing that I love most here is the salsa bar. The have about 4-6 different salsas here, spices levels ranging from mild to burns in your mouth spicy!. Additionally they are very flavorful. 

My favorites here
chorizo burrito
garlic shrimp burrito
tortilla soup

Also $3 for draft beer. You gotta love that!

When you first enter here, especially on a busy night, the place will be packed. But the folks are considerate and you should get a spot within 10 minutes.
author: Aditya J.

description:
Two words: Seriously amazing.  Portion sizes are perfect, if not too large. Their chicken soup is very traditional and has great flavors. I have also tried the tequila and mexican hot chocolate ice cream they have. Both are very good and spot on. 

This restaurant uses really great ingredients. They have an amazing salsa bar- all of the salsas are rich in flavor and there is a variety. They have Pico de gallo, tomatillo salsa, roasted tomato salsa (which tastes like chevys' salsa) and some others. The Chilequillas are perfect- delicious tortilla chips smothered in this orange delicious sauce with onions, poblano peppers, inside and an egg on the top. Perfectly cruchy and devine.  Their tortilla soup is pretty authentic and overall delicious. All the food they make looks excellent and I plan on going there often.

Seating is limited because the place is very small. Sometimes you can get seating right away, sometimes not. 

I recommend to anyone and everyone!
author: Tosca B.

description: Wow! The food here is delicious, fast and fresh.  I tried the chicken fajita burrito, my wife tried the avocado enchiladas and my kids had 3 different things off the kids menu.  The staff was really helpful and the overall look of the restaurant was very inviting.  We will be back!
author: Rob S.

description:
This place is awesome. I can't wait to return to SF and eat more of their fried plantain and black bean burritos. A plantain burrito is like a normal burrito except that its got a banana in the middle.. sounds strange, but tastes like awesomeness.
They give a decent portion of chips and have a nice salsa bar.
My only problem with this place is that its too small. Tables are a little too cramped up together.
author: Aditya M.

description: Fantastic tacos. Plantains will always get me coming back. Friend of mine who works in the Lower Haight comes here all the time - recommended it to me - I'm recommending it to you. You could do a whole lot worse. Stop by and get yourself a burrito or some tacos stat!
author: Brad C.

description: This is my go to take out place. I use to eat here but it's getting ridiculous with people. But that's fine I'll take my burrito to go and chill by my Xbox. The Little Chihuahua is a solid consistent place.
author: Johnny B.

description:
Big tacos. Ordered the chile verde chicken and carne asada. I found the rice too hard and a bit bland and the pinto beans were good, but not great - I'd recommend not to upgrade to the plate.

I hope to return for something else and give it more stars.
author: Judy L.

description:
LOOOOVVEE their Super Burrito with re-fried black beans and chicken. The Plantain Black Been burrito was also super yummy (if it's what you're in the mood for, it's salty sweet)

I give it 5 stars for their dinner menu. 

But I give it a 3 for the Brunch menu - very disappointing. Could barely tell the breakfast burrito was indeed a breakfast burrito.

Will ABSOLUTELY return for dinner. Will NOT for Brunch.
author: Alison M.

description:
I had a craving for fish tacos, so I convinced a friend to meet me here for dinner. The salmon taco and the shrimp tacos were delicious! But the surprise for me was the refried black beans. They're AWESOME, almost addictive. Sangria is also tasty. Not the best I've ever had, but still good.

The one drawback is the limited seating situation, but as long as you're not in a rush or have a party of more than five, it's a small price to pay for the great food.

The prices are great and the food is tasty. What more could you ask for?
author: Dani D.

description: Plantain and black bean burrito cannot be beat. One of the best things I have ever eaten, so glad I live around the corner.
author: Ashley G.

description: Excellent food! Best Mexican I've had in ages. Service is super fast too and it's cheap. Only downside was you have to order before you take a seat so if people aren't moving on quick enough you may be left standing :/
author: Hayley L.

description:
5 stars. Hands down...Paws up? There's a reason this place is always crazy busy. The food is clean, light, and delicious. Not traditional taqueria faire. I rarely touch a carb but LC is straight with me. Go all out with the burrito drenched in sauce and cheese or go light with one of their salads. You can't screw up here. One of my favorites is the chicken burrito, which my companion always kindly orders so that I can order something else and then eat most of his too. How sweet! 

Clean interior, friendly fast service and I think they even have alcohol. I'm more of a to-go person but I'm positive I'd love dining in sometime too.
author: Autumn K.

description:
A friend didn't agree with my review so I went back and tried it again.  He recommend the plantain burrito, but when I found out that it didn't have meat in it, I couldn't justify the $9 price for it.   

I did spent $9 and change on a carnitas burrito, which the person at the counter said was really good.  What I had was mediocre at best and not worth anywhere close to $9.   

Perhaps it's that I value the dollar, and most everyone else that goes here has a ton of cash and doesn't mind blowing  it for the better ambiance (as compared to most mission burrito shops).  I use a metric that's simply described as the ENJOYMENT  divided by the COST.  If it's super fantastic, the cost doesn't matter.  If it's ok but cheap, then that's OK to.  But if it's ok and expensive, then the place is to be avoided.
author: reza n.

description:
My experience is relative... he he, I have tried better days of this place. 

PRO's: good food for after heavy drinking.  A place to show off if you are pretty or dress trendy. 

CON's: I suspect they use Maggi cubes or large amounts of salt. Meats are not halal. Doubt it's kosher. 

Summary: it's OK food for my likes.  I wish the crowd were different. No, no for a salad eater. This is a burrito place, duh!...
author: Emir A.

description:
I was pretty excited to try this place as it's got a lot of veggie options, but the execution is just...meh...at best. It's what I would call Mexican food for white people. I'm white, but I love my Mexican food authentic and CHEAP, thank you very much! 
Two burritos, chips and salsa and two beers were over $30! That is just ridiculous. For that kind of scratch I expect to be blown away. Blown away, I was not. 
Ugh, and the communal seating in such tight quarters blows, I had a child's storybook poking into my arm the whole time. BOO.
Sorry, El Farrolito, I will never betray you again!
author: Susie D.

description: 3.5 Stars is the more accurate review.  Went here around 6:00pm on a Friday night before it started to get very crowded.  Ordered a guac enhcilada dinner and a margarita.  Food came out nice and quick, but the cheese in the enchilada wasn't even melted.  I pulled out large, cold triangular chunks of cheese, boo :(   The margarita was about what I would expect from a taqueria.  They did give ample chips and there was a salsa bar.  I'd go back again but ask them to make sure my enchiladas are cooked thoroughly.
author: Felicia M.

description:
The plantain burrito from here was TERRIBLE.  After hearing rave reviews and reading about this place on the 7x7 list, I decided to forego my regular Cuco's burrito to try out this place. 

#1 - These people do not know how to fry/cook plantains 
#2 - The chips/tortillas they are working with are subpar
#3 - Does SF not know what authentic Mexican food tastes like? 

I couldn't even finish half the burrito (which was small to begin with).
author: Sabrina S.

description: Yum yum! For the veggies -  you can get tofu chile verde or wild mushrooms instead of meat in like everything! I got the mini burrito with the wild mushrooms and you get vegetarian beans too. I wish I had gotten the tostada - it looked AMAZING. Or the tacos. Cute place, good food.
author: Christina K.

description: Been here twice and tried the veggie burritto and the garlic shrimp burritto.  Both were pretty good and also large.  The garlic shrimp burritto was a little drier than what i was expecting but still good.  They have a good selection of different salsas here.  They serve warm chips which are good.  Limited seating inside.
author: Irfan R.

description:
5 stars, 2 thumbs up, and 1 huge grin on my face after DEVOURING my plantain and black bean burrito.

I'm a vegetarian, so pretty much every Mexican place in the Mission is a no-go for me.  I don't trust any authentic taqueria to keep meat, beef flavor, and pig fat out of my food.  Alas, I am constantly on the hunt for non-authentic burritos aka the truly vegetarian kind.

Enter The Little Chihuahua.  My boyfriend and I had both heard good things and were absolutely FAMISHED after doing pre-Christmas shopping all day.  Those 5 stars come from both of us, and here's why:

1. Food tasted fresh and flavorful
2. Free chips and salsa, and very salsa at the very diverse salsa bar was delicious
3. The employees all speak English (I'm sure this is an inappropriate thing to say in California, but as a vegetarian I always have a million questions for the restaurant employees and I really hate getting a blank stare when I say, "Are your black beans vegetarian?"
4. Great seating.  Love the carved wood.

No idea what kind of burrito my boyfriend ate (might have been chorizo), but he was just as enamored with his food tube as I was.  We just moved to the city last week, but as we finished our meal we looked at each other and said, "We have our first haunt!".  We fully intend on becoming regulars here.  Deeeee-LISH!
author: Bliss F.

description: I don't normally eat Mexican food because they don't have many restaurants back in England but this place is good! I can't remember exactly what I had but I believe it was a chicken burrito. I recommend it if you are in the area
author: Catriona A.

description: They give you delicious chips while you wait. The salsa options are to die for. The shrimp salad is full of many delicious ingredients. I crave it on a regular basis. Good little spot for a quick bite to eat.
author: Ali A.

description:
Went here on a rainy Tuesday night. Was looking for a place in the neighborhood with cheap eats. It was quite a surprise to find this really cute place!

The food is good. I had the carne asada burrito and tried some of the tortilla soup. The burrito was delicious, the meat was a little dry though. The actual tortilla was so fresh and all of the ingredients were, too. You could  taste it. The soup was O.K. Huge! The avocado and chicken pieces in the soup were almost too big to eat. I couldn't pick it up with my spoon. I don't want to have to employ a knife when eating a bowl of soup. The salsa bar is pretty neat, though, it gets so crowded in there it was hard to get to.

$15 pitchers of sangria and cheap beer, too. But this place was PACKED and (not that this is the restaurant's fault) but I was astonished by how long people lingered. Once I ordered my food I was looking for a table to sit at and everyone was just lounging, so when my food came (probably 7 minutes later) I had nowhere to sit! It was kind of ridiculous.

My friend loved her fajita burrito. Said the chicken was to die for, but it was messy. Will be back again, for sure.
author: christine c.

description: Good quality Mexican food. Quick and friendly service. I like the atmosphere, Mexican without the sketchiness.
author: Heather R.

description: I don't understand the hype. It's not really authentic, it's not even good Tex-Mex. The food came out pretty quickly, the decor was alright, but something just irks me that I'm paying almost double the price for 1/4 of the authenticity and flavor. The plantain burrito sounds interesting, but for some of these prices, I would rather buy a burrito and ordered a side of plantains separately.
author: Tony H.

description:
A taqueria with good food AND ambiance? Who knew! 

This joint on Divis is my new favorite hot spot for Mexican grub and SF cheer. Complete with stained glass windows, a fireplace, and cute chairs and tables, why not dine in with a glass of wine or beer with some neighborhood pals? That's what I did, and what a great experience it was! The tortilla soup with fresh cheese was divine (and with a spicy kick!) and the tofu and cheese enchiladas were authentic Mexican veggie delights! 

What's cool is that they have all the great traditional faves but with subtle twists that you don't get just anywhere (but should) like shrimp tacos and grilled veggie nachos. And the meat they use is actually quality stuff, not just your standard mystery hash you find at some joints. You can tell the new owners are really putting their hearts and souls into the place, which makes me like it even more.

Go for the fresh, quality food, stay for the cute ambiance! (Oh, and did I mention the bathroom is sweetly furnished and spotlessly clean? Joy!) And if you happen to have a dog (such as a little chihuahua), you can tie their leash on one of the convenient handles on the outside of the shop. Now that's handy!
author: A Y.

description:
Fantastic burrito/mexican place in Lower Haight! My wife and I both had guac and chips, a couple of beers, and some great burritos.

I think what makes this burrito place a little better than others is that it has a little bit more of a restaurant feel. Beyond the amazing food, I really appreciated that I could get a seat, order a beer and not be elbow to elbow with a dozen other people.

The guacamole was solid, though not the best i've ever had. It did have just a little bit of a kick to it, which I appreciate. I went with the Garlic Shrimp burrito and it was fantastic. 

I'm very excited to have such a tasty, reasonably priced place just around the corner.
author: Scott W.

description: The burrito tastes so wholesome. But the place is always so packed that I order for phone pickup which is a different line.
author: stephanie l.

description: So good every time! Consistent. Delicious. Not too greasy. Not too fancy. Just so good.
author: Dee Dee C.

description:
Olla Yelpers! 

Convenient place.  Its a fun place if you want to go grab a few drinks and nibble on some mexi cuisine.  

As for food, its ok.  As you plan for a meal here - just so you know - that you need to order first and then sit down.  We divided and conquered - while a portion ordered - another went to stalk tables.  The actual place is relatively small - they tend to have decent table turnover, but I could imagine that Friday and Sat peak hours being challenging.  

Food wise - we had salmon tacos, nachos the sangria.  All were standard mexi fan-fare - nothing special.  The sangria on the other hand - was fantastic.  They only have a red wine sangria - but it is amazing! 

I would go back for the sangria - its balanced, smooth and goes down like water!  Yes probably had a little too much - but its good!  

Food wise and overall seems a bit over-rated to me. Worth trying if its conveninet otherwise nothing to write home about.  I would never try and go here with more then 4-6, the seating is small - so it will get tight!
author: Bhavin M.

description:
you had me at the name alone, but when I actually got around to trying your delicious burritos I became an instant super fan!! It's pretty quaint, so be prepared to swoop on seating. No worries though, peeps are friendly and will share their table with ya! I tried the garlic shrimp burrito which was huge (i didn't finish, but I love me some leftovers!) and perfect---full of flavor without being overly garlic-y. The chips were great, and they have nice selection salsas, and some beers on tap. 

What more could you want? I think I've found my new favorite pre-show (the independent is just a few blocks away) spot!
author: Caddy M.

description: I think I just found my favorite burrito place in SF (at least so far), and it's walking distance from my new digs, score! I got the black bean and fried plantain burrito, and I got free chips (score 2). They have 3 beers on tap for $3 (score 3) which I gratefully indulged in (Sunday hair of the dog). Finally, the salsa bar. Oh, I love me a good salsa bar (score 4, 5 & 6).  And the burrito wrapping skills were notably superior. Seriously, I have no idea how they do it (and my first job was at Taco Bell..) Definitely will be coming back here again.
author: Jen R.

description:
I didn't think it would be that crowded here around 9pm on a Friday. I thought wrong. The place was packed to the gills with people. That's usually a pretty good sign. 

I got the garlic shrimp burrito ($9.95). The shrimp was plump, juicy, and garlicy. Exactly as advertised. But you know what I liked the best? Their various sauces. The tomatillo sauce was excellent, and their habanero hot sauce packed some real heat. If I'd eaten a lot more of it, I would've been sweating bullets. Also tried the carne asada taco. Nice flavor

Staff was cool. I'm not sure how the seating situation works, but it kind of seems like you just stake out a spot and wait for people to leave. There aren't that many tables, so it seemed like a lot of people were doing the communal thing. We just took ours to go and headed over to Buena Vista Park. 

Definitely worth a return visit.
author: Saunders C.

description:
They always seem to be playing Radiohead when I come in, which already gives this place three stars right there. :)

Another star for their super spectacularly delicious, deliiiiiiiiiiiiiicious, delicious food. Oh my! Their cheese enchiladas are my favorite, as is their horchata. Yum!

Only downfall is that the seating kind of sucks here-- the only reason why I'm rating this place 4 stars and not 5. Not their fault, obviously. They have a small restaurant. Can't help it. But it is kind of a bummer to always have to squeeze in right next to people and feel kind of awkward about how close you are to them while you are eating. lol. 

Oh well though. For the bombness of their cheese enchildadas, I don't even care. :) Yayyy Little Chihuahua! My favorite Mexican restaurant in the Haight, hands down!
author: Shari B.

description: Soo happy to find a place in SF that has plantain burritos!! You should get it.. Their chips and salsa aren't my favorite, but the plantains make up for it. Also, cheap sangria. Great place to stop before a show at the Independent.
author: Colleen M.

description:
pretty damn tasty, but definitely SF prices, just be forewarned.  

Garlic and Shrimp burrito tasted great!  

I called in my order prior to heading there.  Food was ready by the time I walked in!  Thanks guys
author: Matt V.

description:
One of my favorites for Mexican food. The food has an addictive and smokey punch to it that puts reqular taquerias to shame. It's a small and homey space so there's not always a place to sit, but the wait is usually not that long.

Favorites: Black bean and plantain burrito, fajita burrito, roasted tomato salsa, chilaquiles (brunch item)
author: Kai C.

description: Love the food here. I have had carne asada tacos and the chicken fajita burrito. Both were great! The tacos are huge in the sense that they come with a lot of meat. All of the ingredients are high quality and super tasty. You order at the front, grab a number and wait for them to bring you your order while you sit and eat tortilla chips with their selection of great salsas. I definitely recommend it.
author: Chris D.

description:
I really want to love the Little Chihuahua, but everything I've had here has been just plain old average. Steak, carnitas, chicken, I've ordered it all. And it has all been dry. Nothing worse than a dry burrito. 

Please try a little bit harder, Little Chihuahua. Stop overcooking your meats and clean up your salsa bar. I love that you offer healthy, non-carnivorous options, but please...everything you offer should be as good as your veggie options!
author: Colette H.

description:
This is one of my favorite places to eat. Possibly the best burritos in the city! I can't really think of a better taqueria... Their Salsa is great, everything is clean, well cooked, and as spicy as you need it.

My favorite is the plantain burrito. I'm vegan so i substitute the cheese and sour cream with avocado. yummm, i'm going to go get one right now (srsly).
author: Tim R.

description:
This is a great little place to take a casual date. Casual because it's small and rowdy sometimes but that adds to the character. The food is straight forward Mexican food with a Gringo twist. Big portions and the best salsa's outside of the Mission district. 

The service is quick, friendly and will refill your chip basket with a smile. 

Try the Pozole, Wild Mushrooms tacos and the Shrimp Burrito. 

Seating is a little tricky so try to visit off peak hours.
author: Jorge N.

description:
Always a solid choice. Incredible diversity on their menu. You could eat here twice a week and almost always have something different each time. Plenty of veggie options for the vegheads as well.

I love their horchata. Its made fresh and isn't all watery (even at the end of the day). Their most famous dishes are the Garlic Shrimp Burrito and the Plantain Burrito. Both are great although I would HIGHLY suggest you ask them to chop up the platains. They get the request all the time and it makes the burrito much better than biting into big chunks of awesome.

The only drawback to this place is that the line can be long and it takes some effort finding a table. I'm hoping all the new branches they're opening up will cut down on the crowds.
author: A.J. T.

description:
Went some Little Chihuahua food for the first time this weekend.
Had a Chorizo Quesadilla. Simple, I know, but delicious. And they tossed in a bag of chips with my order, which a lot of joints charge extra for.
The ambiance of the place is pretty cool, too. Small, but cozy.
I wish they were open later, though.
author: Matt D.

description: Only for people who don't know where the Mission is.  So-so and overpriced.  The carnitas has a weird flavor and I kept tasting seafood when I bit into the plantains (I ordered no seafood).
author: M H.

description:
I was just thinking of stopping here today and I didn't, but I can't believe I haven't given my thumbs up (way up) to Little Chihuahua on Yelp until now! This place rocks and they make the best plantain burrito, as others have pointed out. Their other burritos are really tasty too (chicken, carne asada) and you should definitely order the Super Burrito versions, but definitely one of the best things is all of the salsas at their salsa bar. 

Also, I just have to rant here for a sec... thanks Yelp! I just want to say that the tomatillo (roasted green tomato) sauce rocks my world, it's simply awesome. Most places are content with an onion-y green liquid, but at LIttle Chihuahua you can see the slightly burnt pieces of tomato that make the whole salsa just work. It's sweeter than most, so change your expectations and stop eating that stuff from jars or canned Goya-like stuff; I, for one, haven't had this type of tomatillo salsa anywhere else! Their pico de gallo and other salsas are great too and made fresh all day!  

Anyway, the place itself is realllllly itty bitty small, with community tables (so if you're not into sharing tables, you need to get out more often) and one TINY bathroom. It's also really cute, love their stained glass windows. This isn't the place I'd take my girlfriend to for a romantic dinner at night, but it's our go-to place for solid, delicious, awesome burritos outside of the Mission area. 

Keep it up Little Chihuahua! I will be back soon!
author: Ben G.

description:
This place is blah. No spice, no flavor. I'm used to traditional Mexican places. I ordered the enchilada and it was enchinasty. 

Skip this place and head to the Mission....

Oh..and it was way overpriced!
author: Jocelyn J.

description:
Still good!

My roommates and I come here . . .. oh. . . maybe 3-4 times a week :)
My suggestions:

Chile verde chicken burrito
Salmon taco
Mushroom burrito
Grilled veggie burrito
Grilled veggie quesadilla
Margaritas 
Sangria

yum!!
author: Katherine B.

description:
The food looked great. But I wish I didn't get a burrito because it tasted like Chipotle. I'll have to try again soon.

Thumbs up for the salsa bar and friendly staff.
author: Jenny K.

description:
One of the best Mexican Places in the city.

Highly recommend the Fried Plantain Burrito.
The wild mushroom nachos are great.

They have a salsa bar, which can be hit or miss (sometimes out of random salsas).
author: Ayall S.

description: I just had gallbladder removal surgery a few days ago. In prepration, for the past month i've been living off of toast and vegetables, and I have NOT been happy. I've basically been counting down the days until I can eat a giant, soul-comforting burrito, and today was that day. I felt ready. Since i've had to change my diet to accomidate the lack of gallbladder I have, I've stopped eating meat and saw what great veg options Little Chihuahua offered and was really excitied. I went with the plantain and black bean burrito and was BLOWN AWAY. It was moist, had a great balance of peppers, black beans, spices, and hefty chunks of plantains. It was salty and sweet and hearty. I also brought back a few of their different salsas and they were all amazing. There was one that I especially recommend for this burrito, it's a smooth bright red salsa that is super smokey. Holy mother of JESUS, SO GOOD. I actually cried a tear of joy when I ate this burrito. I'm looking forward to coming back and trying their other options, but I might just keep ordering the plantain burrito! I don't even know!
author: Alaska G.

description:
I wanted to love this place. I'd heard great things about the Noe Valley location. The five-star service was great and fast (I ordered take-out) but the garlic shrimp burrito was just sort of okay. Granted, I didn't eat it with any of their salsas - I though they were included in the to-go bag but should have checked. It was a massive burrito but only 2-3 shrimp inside. And oh mama did my mouth require a tube of toothpaste afterward - garlic is no joke here!

And now I continue to search for a really tasty Mexican place that's *not* in the Mission (too far for me)...
author: Christina K.

description: Tostada salad is seriously SO GOOD! Also i really liked their salsa bar where you can find bunch of fresh, spicy salsa & sauce varieties.
author: Beril Y.

description:
I've had four or five consistently tasty burritos from this place over the past couple of months. I don't know what an "authentic" burrito is (one of my friends from Mexico City was skeptical there was such a thing). I do know they toast the tortillas; they'll hold the rice if you ask, and don't go overboard if you don't. The carnitas and al pastor are both tasty and tender. Overall the burrito is balanced and delicious, and most importantly for me they seem to hit a reliable level of quality (nothing like craving a burrito and being served a cold, lumpy, congealed roll of crap, you know what I mean?).
I dig it.
author: Giacomo F.

description:
The great Notorious B.I.G. once asked, "What's beef?" Is beef when you need two gats to go to sleep? Or is beef guaranteed to be an ICU every time I see you? Or should we use Taco Bell's definition of beef; beef is made up of a mixture of 88% beef stuff and 12% secret stuff. Though there is nothing tastier and juicer than secrets, I'd rather have 100% beef stuff in my, well, beef.

Thank goodness for The Little Chihuahua. Despite the (oxymoronic?) name, this place is filled with BIG and BEEFY stuff, big portions and big taste. No mystery meat here. When you walk into this place, it's hard not to get the local taqueria vibe. There is just something very welcoming about this place. 

I highly recommend the garlic shrimp burrito. Hell, all their specialty burritos are delicious (fajita steak burrito is also good as well)! At a regular Mexican establishment, I feel like I am eating a sour cream burrito half the time. But at The Little Chihuahua, the specialty burrito stands alone (very much like the cheese). You don't have to drench your food in Tapatio to mask the blandness of your food. The food tastes good by itself with no additional sauces. What a novel concept. 

Did I mention the portions?! The burritos are huge and come with a side of coleslaw. You will definitely be stuffed after this meal.

Big kudos on their homemade tortilla chips and salsa bar. Keep the chips coming and go with the green salsa(s). And please do order a horchata and/or agua fresca, incredibly delicious and refreshing.

You can't go wrong with The Little Chihuahua. Just have a look inside, this place is always packed to the wall!!
author: Allan Y.

description:
Little Chihuahua has been nicknamed "little doggie" amongst my girlfriend and I who work right down the street.  It may sound horrible but it's just the opposite - we love this place.

Not only do my girlfriend and I make frequent visits throughout the week my co workers in my office love it too.  Decently priced and great portions. For Christmas last year we purchased 20 gift certificates for our employees because we love this place!

I swear by their chicken tortilla soup - fresh and made to order soup.  Fresh blocks of cheese,  big pieces of shredded white chicken, diced tomatoes, sliced avocado, peppers, corn and topped off with tortilla chips. 

Their salsa bar is also ridiculously good and fresh and you can choose from mild to the spiciest blends.

I also love their refried black beans that you can order as a dip - it goes well with their chips and the green salsa.

There was a time that my co workers and I were going there 4 out of the 5 work days and ordering our chicken tortilla soup, and black bean dip.  Their staff is also great.

Two things - I did notice they switched their tortilla chip vendor cause it doesn't taste the same though still fresh and I hate the feeling of walking out with the aroma of Little Chihuahua for the rest of the day but it's always hard to take soup to go.
author: Caroline C.

description: I only had a takeout burrito once here, the garlic shrimp, yet it was very good. For this I think they deserve 4 stars. The food seems to be really solid. Great salsas too. I'll be back next time I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Brian C.

description:
High quality, niman ranch meats and clean fish shrimp
Everything is environmentally friendly (even the straw covers!)
Thick, creamy refreshing horchata
Excellent fresh salsas
You get a lot of food with your order
Interior is very cute, with stained glass windows and wooden tables/chairs
author: Karen W.

description: Its a hole in wall joint. decent Mexican food. Didn't like sangria or margarita there. They have a salsa bar. Service is ok too
author: Astha S.

description: Went here for lunch today and thoroughly enjoyed it. I ordered the carne asada taco and the camarones taco. Both were great - quality ingredients and flavorful! Also, the salsa selection was legit. I especially liked the roasted tomato - yum! I knocked one star off for the price. My bill came out to just under $11 for 2 tacos which seems overpriced for tacos. However, if I'm ever in the neighborhood and jonesin' for some Mexican food, I'd stop by again to try the plantain burrito and the horchata.
author: Jess L.

description: I am of latin descent and must admit I came here because I misread the name of the restaurant as "Little Chihuaha" as in the state.  The place is called "THE Little Chihuaha" like the small dog.  The food is not very authentic but is of good quality.  The food reminds me of "Chipotle" chain restaurants.  It seems they don't have a spirit license so margaritas are made with "agave wine" as compared to tequila.  Its a great place if you want clean, well prepared food.
author: Victor D.

description: So delicious!! Order at the counter and take a seat. Try the different salsas -- soooooo good! I had the nachos, friends had burrito, tacos, and pozole. All big portions and reasonably priced for the size. Homey and comfortable vibe. Will definitely be coming back often!!
author: Amy F.

description: good meat. 4 stars because its a bit on the pricey side and the place is quite small.  i would suggest ordering take out because it gets super crowded in there.
author: Maybelline P.

description:
As Mexican goes, this one is pretty darned good.  A solid choice, and you'll never go too far wrong.

For lunch and dinner I'd say 4 stars.
For brunch I'll say 3 stars.
It can get very crowded in the dinner hour, hence the 3 star rating.  However, if you're willing to wait for your food in sit in close quarters, then this is a very good choice.

Nopalito is an even fancier Mexican place nearby.  Nopalito is much higher end, more expensive, and tends to fill up even more so than Little Chihuahua.  So if you're going at an off hour and want to pay more amazing Mexican food go to Nopalito. If you don't want to spend half as much for more traditional (but still very tasty) Mexican food, go to Little Chihuahua.  You'll be happy either way.
author: Eric H.

description:
**This location is in Noe (4123 24th St @ Castro) but Yelp wants to auto-change the address back to Divis on me***

A fresh look in the petite, formerly Bistro 24 space. Let's hope their existence is as sustainable as their Clean Fish shrimp or plantain burrito!

With Rocky Jr chicken and Niman Ranch meat-stuffed tortillas, this is no Mission taqueria.

Bring it.

(Lunch & Dinner for now. Brunch coming soon)
author: Alissa A.

description: Here is what I like: Garlic shrimp burrito, salsa bar, and pic of chihuahua on the wall. : )
author: Laura F.

description: I don't get it. In a town with such great tacos this place gets notoriety? Under-seasoned, watery, mess of a taco. Plantain burrito is not good. Lived a block away so would stop in for a quick meal every so often and each time I wished I hadn't.
author: Eric W.

description:
Nom nom nom. Super tasty. Maybe not 100% authentic, but I don't care. Love the food. Love the people who work there. Love that the meat is naturally sourced. And the carafes of Sangria aren't too shabby either.

I almost always get the baby tofu chile verde burrito, but once in a while I switch it up for the plantain black burritto, which is equally as tasty. Even with the baby, I almost always have enough leftover for lunch the next day.

Their salsa bar is incredible. My favorites are the tomatillo-cilantro and the habanero-lime salsas, but I can never quite refrain from getting one of each. It's just those two that keep calling me back for seconds (and, yeah, okay, sometimes even thirds).

It can get pretty crowded, but the tables move relatively quickly even during prime dinner time. Great for take out, too.

The lock on the bathroom door always creeps me out a bit - if the knob is turned perpendicular to the floor, you're all good. The handle still jiggles a bit though. 

Haven't tried the pozole, but excited to see it on the menu.
author: Monica C.

description: Plantain burrito and veggie burrito are AWESOME! Cheap beer, good music, and its only like 2 blocks from my place.
author: Stephen F.

description:
Came here after the Giant's win in game 3 against the Braves (woooo!!), so I was a little tipsy and not that hungry from the all the bar food we'd been munching on.  Nevertheless my friends were hungry so we ended up here after heading to Divisidero.  It was pretty crowded and we waited about 10 minutes in line before ordering.  I got the a regular pollo asado burrito ($8), and it was good, although I wouldn't say it was anything to write home about. Next time I would get the larger burrito with guac and sour cream, it looked a lot larger.  Definitely a good quality place to come with friends.

edit: BTW other reviews say the burritos were huge.  They are not. I came already full and ate half of it without trying, and I am neither overweight nor a huge eater.  They are average size at best. And that's not to take away from them, it's just the truth.
author: Eliot C.

description: Hands down best veggie burrito! Who can deny a burrito the size of a small baby with plantains, black beans, rice, guac, sour cream, and pico de gallo? Sign me up!
author: Keegan M.

description: I had a delicious enchilada at this hybrid-cafeteria style Mexican restaurant. My meal came with unlimited tortilla chips and a Negra Modelo, totalling $13. That is a fantastic deal in my book. If you want full waiter service, look elsewhere. Friendly staff.
author: Matthew H.

description:
Went in for the first time and ordered the heavily hyped fried plantain and black bean burrito.  I must say, I was not disappointed.  It's hard to describe as it's unlike anything I've ever had.  I guess it's just a semi-sweet burrito.  With the fixin's.  

Overall great experience, friendly staff, tasty salsas.
author: Aishling R.

description:
I finally convinced the coworkers to go here for lunch yesterday since I've heard things about Little Chihuahua for awhile now, and I can say they were all very impressed.  

We showed up around 2, so it was pretty empty, which was nice.  Our food was on our table in probably about 3 minutes after we ordered, which was great considering how starving we were.  We enjoyed the salsa medley, and all the ingredients tasted quite fresh.  

Two of my coworkers ordered the tacos.  Between them they tried the steak, shrimp, and carnitas.  Both raved about their meets.  My other coworker and I both got the tostada salads, I opting for carnitas and she for chiciken.  I don't know if she liked hers, but the plate was completely empty at the end of the meal.  I thought the portion sizes were huge (big plus), and had trouble finishing my tostada (a rare issue I have at restaurants).  I was not completely blown away by my tostada.  The tortilla shell was really good, and the ingredients were plentiful.  I think the lettuce was my least favorite part.  It was very big, so hard to eat gracefully, and the flavoring was a tad on the bland side.  However, I really liked the added mango salsa (something I don't usually see in tostadas), and my coworker didn't like avocados so I got hers in addition to mine.  

I think I would order the tostada again, but it wasn't my favorite.  Hopefully next time I'll be in a burrito mood, but I definitely see us taking lunch here more often.
author: Anne Marie B.

description:
Super Busy.. but Super Good.

Try their Super Burritos!

I had their horchata... and to tell you the truth i've had better.

If you're going to eat here, have patience (it's a virtue) and get a sangria.
author: RJ S.

description: Ok so today I tried their so-called prized plaintan burrito gross! It taste like bananas wrapped in a tortilla, not exactly appetizing and by bananas, i mean at least 2 whole bananas were stuffed in that bad boy.. I got so tired of eating what tasted like a dessert, too sweet, I had to deconstruct the burrito and pull out all of the rest to eat, which left me with a few beans and rice. Thoroughly disappointed for nearly a 10 dollar burrito, which probably is suitable only by NYC standards. I posted a picture of the bananas, which filled my plate because I am not exaggerating.
author: Onika C.

description:
After a hard weekend of moving, I was tired, sore, hungry, and extremely cranky. Thanks to a personal recommendation and Yelp, I decided to wander myself over here to alleviate my pains and reward myself with the plantain and black bean burrito. My boyfriend ordered their wild mushroom quesadilla.

That burrito is no joke, folks. I know it's lauded here repeatedly, but it is so delicious. I think plantains are among my favorite foods. It was so filling, so tasty, and so MASSIVE, it felt like a culinary hug. I tasted the quesadilla, which was excellent quality and grilled to perfection, but I'm just really not the biggest fan of shiitake mushrooms. (I do have to give them credit for using a more interesting mushroom than just plain old white button.)

As an added bonus, the guys working there were SO friendly and directed me to where I could pick up a carton of soy milk on the fly. Hooray!
author: Mea H.

description: Decent burritos and also they have specialty ones like plantain burrito. They are super expensive though.
author: Balaji B.

description: A great spot to get a quality burritos that is full of taste and is not overwhelming with grease! All you have to do is try the salsa and you know this place is quality. Everything I have tried is great and I highly recommend the platanos burrito for those of you who are vegetarian.
author: Jacob L.

description:
BEST SF YUPPIE BURRITO!

the fried plantain and black burrito is delicious and although it'll cost you $9.72 with tax i don't think you can get it anywhere else in the city. real tasty and sweet, if you want spice you can slop on some salsa and peppers from the salso bar.

i also really like the tostada salads, big and yummy.

definitely not a mission style taqueria but this is the best you're gonna do for mexican food in this neighborhood that's for sure.
author: ben s.

description: Look, some people will call it a yuppie burrito. It might be a yuppie burrito, but that's the way the world is going. They have fresh, tasty meat (al pastor is great) or plantains if you fear meat (just as good as cucos used to be). And if you don't love the salsa bar, there is probably something wrong with you.
author: Suvi N.

description:
I tend to be hypercritical so let me explain:

Carne Asada super burrito.

Pro:
The beef was  fresh and cut in decent chunks. The green salsa was thick and good tasting, albeit not very spicy. The staff was friendly, I actually made the girl recommend me a meat choice and she didn't seem to mind.

Cons: The habanero salsa is way too sweet! I understand trying to counterbalance the spice but this isn't the way. The beef was a bit chewy, probably could have been seared on higher heat.

Another ~$8 burrito place, I'd take Balazo over this if you're in the area.
author: Name R.

description:
After 4hours of walking during Bay to Breakers, my friends and I decided we needed some food to fill our bellies. I skipped breakfast that morning so my hunger was definitely catching up to me. I had their Shrimp burrito and practically ate the whole thing. Admittedly, I'm a pig, but part of it could most certainly be credited to the yumminess of their food. 

This place also has one of the BEST and I mean BEST horchatas I've ever had. It's so good it makes me want to sing, "In December drinking Horchata, I'd look psychotic in a balaclava. Winter's cold is too much to handle. Pincher crabs that pinch at your sandals...OH OH....lala...."

Horchata reminds me of the milk at the bottom of your cereal bowl; Cold, creamy,and gritty...other places are always watered down. I considered it fate when V.W.'s latest album also had a song written about it.
author: Alesia T.

description:
I go here every Monday night because my wife takes a Yoga class next door. This is one of the better, and more importantly, consistent Mexican spots in town.

It makes a lousy review, but I always get the same thing because it rules: the steak quesadilla.

The steak is well seasoned and cooked to perfection. There is just the right amount of cheese, onions, and peppers. Served with fresh, delicious pico de gallo, guac and sour cream.

The tortilla chips are also on point and the salsa bar is outstanding. There's always a wait to order, but such is good food in a city of foodies. Definitely order ahead by phone if you can.

I've gone here with friends and observed many other dishes they serve. From their reactions, it seems this place is great all-around. Parking is kind of a pain in this neighborhood. I'd say this is one of the 5 best Mexican spots in the city and definitely the best so far outside of the Mission.
author: Dan R.

description:
Yes, it really is THAT good or maybe I'm just easy to please. This place is friendly, consistent, and has damn good food every time....fresh, yummy, and quality! My burrito shop can kick your burrito shop's ass anyday! This ain't no every-other-cookie-cutter-Mission-taqueria. Trust me, after 9 years in the city, I'm a burrito connoisseur.  So it can be a bit crowded sometimes...so what?! Call ahead and get it to go. If you don't like it, please go somewhere else. 
 
Their carne asada taco and burrito are oh-so-delish and tasty (high quality, Niman Ranch beef, yes please). Their Pico de Gallo is the best in the city (IMHO - fresh, tasty, and just my style). And their guacamole is drool worthy (LOVE IT!).

Oh and the peeps that work there are super cool and friendly too! No complaints here.
author: Sarah L.

description:
I've been here three times and my last visit was finally a four star event. 

First time here I had a super veggie burrito and was not impressed. It just lacked flavor. I guess the Plantain burrito is the one to try. A friend I was with really liked his Tortilla Soup. 

Second time here I tried a super quesadilla and again was not impressed. I didn't like that all the superness was on the side; just chicken an cheese can only be so good. A friend had the Tostada Salad and I couldn't stop staring. It looked great! 

Next trip here, surprise surprise, I ordered the Carne Asada Tostada Salad. Delicious! Meat was blackened perfectly and tender. The dressing was very good and the cucumber, which I typically don't like, worked well in it. 

Learn from my mistakes, go straight for the salad. I'll be back to try this plantain burrito as well.
author: Michael C.

description:
This place isn't as consistent as I'd like. If my stomach turns, then it's usually because something not so fresh was put into the food.

When the place is good, the burritos are good. They're not like the burritos in the Mission but definitely will hit the spot. The meat is high quality, and there's a selection of salsas to choose from. The salsa could use better QC in my opinion because on a hot day some of the ingredients tend to wilt.

But since SF isn't always boiling hot, this is a good place to get your burrito fix when you're not in the Mission.
author: Jim B.

description:
I moved to the neighborhood and was dying for a good burrito place. The burritos are great and like ,most places let you customize, meat, beans, tortilla wraps etc. The ingredients are really fresh. 

The salsa bar is one of my favorite parts. They have at least 6 very decent options.The chips are warm and amazing too.

They have decent selection of beer and great Sangria!
author: Subhash J.

description: TLC is a solid spot to grab some slightly overpriced, pseudo Mexican food.  The salsa bar is legit, with the green salsa being my top choice. The portions could be more generous, especially since you're paying about $10 for a burrito.  I mean let's be real...$10 for a burrito and about $4 for a taco?  Either way, solid 3 stars.
author: justin a.

description:
It is hard to find fish taco spots in SF, but these salmon tacos will have me swimming back upstream. The pieces are thin, long slices that have a crispy edge that adds to the enjoyment of these tacos. The salsa bar is also great, especially  on the hotter end. 
Mrs D says her shrimp burrito was great even the half she took home and finished the next day cold.
The place was bustling.  You come in and order, and are brought your food to your seat at the long shared tables. This worked to our favor as we had a chat with a regular who loves this place. 
The biggest factor in support of the hidden 6th star is the level of concern and attention that i was shown when I expressed my need for Gluten Free food. They were very helpful and took the time to make sure everything was sorted out.
We await the opening of the new location.
author: Bo D.

description:
As dry and bland as a Walt Whitman essay.

$8 something for 2 Pollo Asada tacos is little high for a taqueria but still not expensive.  Plus, they in a small bag of chips, which turned out to be the best part of my meal.

the tacos were a good size, it was filling but I didn't feel bloated afterwards.  But the tortillas were dry as was the chicken.  The guacamole was uninspired and heavy with lime.

Ambiance was fine, a cozy little shop.  Staff was very friendly and provided good service.

They have a salsa bar with several selections.  I tried the pica de galla(not very good), and both tomatilla salsa's which were ok.  I did not try the habenaro salsa which I regret now as the three that I did try were on the bland side as were the tacos.
author: Max Jonathan S.

description:
The menu at The Little Chihuahua is straight forward and simple, but not. Burritos, enchiladas, quesadillas, tacos and salads make for a seemingly basic offering of "mexican" fare. And while the ingredients for these include staple items found in almost all mexican dishes (tomatoes, avocado, cilantro, onion, etc.) the quality of these ingredients is what makes Little Chihuahua a pretty good deal in a great location. 

I got the tostada salad, with half a serving of grilled vegetables and half a serving of carne asada. That they were accommodating in my wanting both without having to pay an extra fee for each is noteworthy in the customer service category. The carne asada was tender and juicy, and the vegetables were well cooked and well-seasoned. I downed that salad!! Accompanied by a mix of their wonderful house salsas, the cilantro-lime dressing also gave it a good kick. Arrriba!

The chips here are decent, but a little too airy for my taste. And the sangria was a disappointment, to be honest- hardly fruitful and not even mildly strong.

Service is quick, though, even when busy- and that everything is made to order this is an impressive feat, because they sure do seem to get busy!

Overall, I think there is a hype surrounding this place that isn't quite justified. It serves good quality, well constructed, basic mexican food at a good price, but it isn't blow your mind outstanding. I have not yet had a burrito here, so maybe that experience will sway my final verdict, but for now I'm sticking to my guns that says you won't be disappointed, but you also don't need to wait in line 20 minutes just to place an order.

Also, be mindful of the limited seating. You might get lucky (like us) and find a table for 4 clearing up right as you're ready to sit down, or you may find yourselves unfortunate as the group of 6 who ordered after us and were forced to either spread out or half sit and half stand. Not so good for big groups.
author: Raquel C.

description:
After reading other yelp reviews I decided to get the black bean and plantain burrito (though I probably would have ordered it  anyway - I really love plantains) and it was yum. yum yum yum.

If I lived in this neighborhood I'm sure I would be a frequent visitor. The salsas were great. Laid back atmosphere. Great drink prices. The whole menu is fresh and delicious. Is the Little Chihuahua authentic taqueria food? No, but it is damned delicious and a great value.
author: Emily C.

description:
walking to the little chihauhua someone will comment on how nice the  median is on divis, how it went in so quickly, and has done wonders aesthetically and in terms of traffic.    we'll pass the Page and reminisce about the good times and wonder why we haven't been back in so long.  And someone else will say "phuket" thai.  out loud. again.  we'll laugh. 

i was prejudiced about white dudes making burritos so I went with the housemade pork pozole one night, which was good, even though I wasn' really in the mood for vermillion soup.  the burritos, by the way are also fantastic, so I stand corrected. 

Food is  fresh and place is clean. friendly service and they take AMEX.
author: Nikki F.

description:
There's so much emphasis on Mexican food chains and places that you go to WHILE your intoxicated with the munchies. If you're one of the very few people like me though who wants to have the go-to Mexican food joint the morning AFTER a wild night out and will help cure your hangover, go to The Little Chihuahua. This place will do you and your body justice by nourishing it back to normal again in little to no time.

This place is the opposite of cheap, greasy, and questionable. 

It does also mean that it is a bit overpriced, and overwhelmingly, "white" people tend to eat here a lot.

Regardless, it is worth coming here to order their pozole rojo and anything that has plantains in it. Their portions are huge, so if price is a concern, rest assured that you will get what you pay for here.
author: Megan D.

description: I am from San Diego, where the mexican food is on another level. BUT, after recently moving to San Francisco, it has not been easy finding good mexican food. Little Chihuahua is one of the best places for Mexican food in the city! I really especially love their tostada salads (steak)...quite amazing!
author: Sheryl P.

description: I could eat here every night of the week. Both vegetarian burritos are some of the best I've ever had. The fried plantain and black bean burrito is maybe even why I looked into living in the Alamo Sq. area... well, I live here now and I couldn't be happier. Thank you Little Chihuahua!
author: Katie M.

description:
Flavorful, fresh, fast, fenomenal.  (Let's pretend that's how you spell it for alliteration's sake).

I hate waiting.  I see a line, I turn the other direction.  Luckily one of my girlfriends knows me better and convinced me to stay in line by bringing me a bag of chips to munch on.  

Chips: thin and perfectly salted.  Salsa: several to choose from, all very spicy, best green salsa i've ever had  Burrito: Plantain and black bean? Sounded different, opted for it.
