Personally didn't like it cause i don't like banana- I was expecting fried plantains for some strange reason, not large chunks of perfectly carmelized mushy plantain.  Once I pulled out all the banana, the burrito was SO F-IN GOOD. 

I saw the sign that said "order first, then sit"- now typically I am the "you wait in line while I grab a seat/grab one more thing of the grocery shelves/do something else, anything other than wait in line" kinda people (yes you hate me).  We obliged the sign and waited until our order was placed thinking we'd never get a seat by the time our food was ready.  The place was packed, but the kitchen's efficient, patrons are efficient, and the flow of this joint is PERFECTION.  We had a plethora of seating to choose from the moment we turned around from the register.

Cannot wait to return for fish tacos.
author: Gabrielle J.

description: Tortilla soup! Self service no problem, but getting a table often is. Great food.
author: Noah W.

description: Great Al Pastor burritos. They don't have huge chunks of pineapple like i sometimes like but that's their choice. You can get a quick bite, not too expensive, the habanero salsa is good and fiery and the nachos look amazing. I'll be back soon to try them.
author: Chris C.

description:
The reviews for this place go one of two ways: either the slightly more adventurous and informed patrons are complaining that this yuppie fare is billed and accepted as authentic mexican cuisine OR midwestern college refugees are raving about how inexpensive the eco-friendly "classic mexican" food is.  (Spoiler alert: it is none of these things.)  

The truth is it doesn't matter.  Let's stop chasing and defending the authenticity of this place and enjoy the food.  Sometimes you want to eat cow tongue served out the side of an ice-cream truck and sometimes you want a slightly cleaner, more expensive, less intimidating (english speaking) version of the San Francisco taqueria experience.   Little Chihuahua is that place.  Good for them.

Also, if Little Chihuahua would like people to adhere to its "order before taking a table" sign, I'd suggest putting it at the entrance where it might have some effect.  Putting it up front means the only people who are going to see it are already in the line.  (Or just take it down so fascists like me won't spend my time grumbling to myself about how ineffectual it is.)
author: joe b.

description: We were visiting from Los Angeles and craving burritos and found The Little Chihuahua on Yelp.  Wow.  Definitely in the top 3 best burritos I've ever had.  I had a wild mushroom veggie burrito and the mushrooms were perfectly cooked - incredible.  I highly recommend.  When I return to SF, I'm definitely coming back!
author: Maegan H.

description:
If you're in the neighborhood, check it out. Totally worth it.
Really reasonably priced little burrito place and the burritos are just off the chain. You really do have to get the fried plantains burrito. It will save your life. We also had the grilled shrimp burrito that was packed with firm and tasty garlic shrimp and fresh avocado. They have beer and wine options if you like and authentic Mexican bottled Coke. (Pure can sugar with no corn syrup.) 
They also appear to be dog friendly with a couple of little water dishes at the door for your K9.
Loved it!
author: Carson E.

description:
I could eat their plantain & black bean burrito everyday. This is a step-up from your average mission burrito, and I'm happy for it. Fresh, organic(?), high-quality, and vegetarian friendly ingredients.

Atmosphere is relaxed.
author: Meghan S.

description: Yes, I am still a fan. Have had many great meals here. Last night I had the Tostada Salad, and had a really bad GI reaction. Not saying I am giving up on them. I called them about being more careful washing their greens. It will not stop me from eating here, but I will stick with beans and tortilla.
author: Blair C.

description:
Yum. I love burritos. I mean, LOVE! And they serve good burritos. I enjoyed their garlic shrimp burrito a lot, and for less than 10 bucks, it was even more delicious. I tried their black bean and plantain burrito, but while half of the burrito was good, after awhile I realized I just don't like the sweetness of the plantain in my supposed to be savory burrito. My friends LOVE that burrito though, and it was remarkably delicious for a few bites. Their tacos are also good too. 

The place is pretty small, you seat yourself, and bus your own table. All of that is fine and it can get packed pretty easily. There have been a number of times that we've had to wait awhile before we got a table, but I feel like this is just a San Francisco restaurant trait. It's a little too far to be 'take-out' for me, but the food is good so I don't mind.

The staff are really friendly and helpful. One time 8 of us showed up and one of the guys made a lot of effort to try and figure out a seating arrangement for us. Then he gave us a ton of chips to munch on while we waited. Good stuff.

Also I refuse to compare to Papalote because each has its own perks and cons and I'm happy to support both places!
author: Sarah A.

description: If I could give this place zero stars, I would. I wasted my money on food that wasn't even worth it. I don't know what they serve here but as someone who grew up in a Mexican household I can tell you it is not Mexican. I decided to try Little Chihuahua because it's walking distance from my place and after walking by so many times I figured why not. I had a feeling it wouldn't please my taste buds but I didn't want to pass judgment without actually trying the food. I will say that they only thing they've got going for them is the guacamole. After eating it, I understand why they ran out and why people kept asking for it. Like most places on a Sunday, it was crowded so we took our food to go. I ordered the Chorizo quesadilla that was cut up into four pieces. The first three pieces had little to no cheese and just chorizo and onions, the fourth had all cheese and hardly any chorizo. The chorizo tasted fresh and had flavor which I appreciated but it didn't make up for the lack of cheese. My mom ordered the Fajita burrito (chicken). When she unwrapped, it was burnt and you could smell it. It should've been called the onion burrito because there was more onion than chicken. We also ordered Pozole rojo because we were curious as to what it would taste like (good Pozole is hard to come by in the city). For the price they really don't give you that much. I've paid the same amount at other restaurants and one owl can easily feed two people (with generous servings) and is full of flavor. I opened it and it smelled bland. I took one taste (I didn't want to review it without trying it) and it was even worse. I had to spit it out due to the lack of flavor. If you're reading this and haven't gone yet please do your wallet and taste buds a favor and don't eat here. If you like, Mexican food a la gringo then this place is for you. If you want good Mexican food and don't want to go all the way to the mission, there are other places you could try.
author: Angee R.

description: Love the food but can't stand that they charge for chips now. No real taqueria should charge for chips, especially if you're already paying $11 for the burrito. Hope they change it back to how it used to be.
author: T W.

description: Business must be declining with the increased competition in the neighborhood. Am only a take-out customer, but apparently extras like sour cream on the quesadilla are out. No worries, Nopalito is a block closer for me.
author: V. R.

description: The best veggie burritos I had in San Francisco. I had the Chile Verde Tofu and Grilled Vegetables and both were excelent.
author: Lukáš L.

description: I'm a big fan...every time I'm in town I try and visit the Little and get the wet burrito with a side of guacamole .  Each meal is sized right and priced right.  Try them I'm sure you'll love it.
author: Michael N.

description:
My first time to this place, I ordered the fried plantain burrito. It had great flavor and I think the burrito has good potential.  The plantain was overwhelming as it was just a big, mushy, fibrous piece rather than something that was crispy and came apart with your bite more easily.  The next time I went I made sure not to get that burrito again.

The second time I went I ordered the chile verde chicken tacos, and honestly thinking about those right now makes my mouth water! The chicken was juicy, just the right amount of guacamole, tangy cabbage, and all wrapped in two soft tasty corn tortillas. 

The tortilla chips they serve are warm and salty, and their salsa bar is great! Lots of options, and they let you know what kinds of salsa it is and how hot it is!
author: Meg L.

description:
I love mexican food - but I have been cutting back on my meat consumption these days (opportunistic pescatarian). The b-fast burrito there was really, really good. Seems like the place can get packed. I waited about 5 minutes for my food and buddies 30 minutes behind me had to wait about 20. 

Great salsa bar as well, chipotle, tomatillo, habanero

It's walkable from Danny Coyles if you think 10 am is too early for Rosamunde, like I do, :). 

I had a carne asada burrito here a long time ago also, but can't remember it well enough to review it now.
author: David N.

description:
Note: I went here when I was 100% vegan... So what if it only lasted 2 weeks, I still get credit!  

I had the fried plantain and black bean burrito sans dairy and it was the best burrito I have ever had. Get that? A non-dairy vegetarian burrito was the best I have ever had. 

There is only one way I could imagine improving it and that is to tote along some of the green salsa from La Cumbre and make a marriage in heaven.  It sounds so good, I have just made it a New Year's resolution.  

Damn, we are lucky to live in San Francisco!
author: Hayley W.

description: Oh my god Mexican French toast! Fried plantains and crunchy bacon - perfection!
author: Winston L.

description: On a rampant mexican food craving, I was whisked into TLC on one of my many SF pilgrimages. Last meal of the weekend, and it was perfect. I chose the plantain burrito after being jealous of my dude eating friend plantains for 3 straight days at a High Sierra. It was perfect for my tired, achy, weekend thrashed soul and my huge, pregnant style Mexi crave. Was not super heavy, but still hot, cheesy, perfectly seasoned. A tad pricey for 2 burritos, but I live in SB and understand the $11.25 burrito. Salsa bar is unreal.
author: Sonia L.

description:
The carne asada quesadilla was quite yummy.  Perhaps a bit pricy for portion size but the meat in my quesadilla was of great quality. 
My company had a chicken? burrito and he said he enjoyed it.
Basket of chips weren't bad but we had all the broken pieces -__-

The rice that came with my meal was sooo dry. It was like they had reheated it over and over and over...

More like a 3.5 but I'll round up
author: Rasi A.

description: Overpriced!  Nothing special in the food.  Stick with the Mission for lower prices and much better food. $29 for two burritos and two  soft drinks, give me a break.
author: Osama B.

description:
Great food for the price and I would give that 4-5 stars, really bad customer experience unfortunately which even for a fast food restaurant I think counts.  My buddy and I were super polite but the guy who rung us up was sassy and rude...he was the only Caucasian male on staff at around 1pm on 9/3 picking up phone calls and he had a ear piercing...perhaps he was just having a bad day but even for a fast food restaurant I wouldn't expect that kind of behavior:
-The guy talked down to us twice
-My buddy went back to ask for napkins because none were placed in our bag and as soon as my buddy turned around the guy made a very rude gesture that I caught towards my buddy and said some smart comment to his co-worker
-We went up and asked him "Hey just wanted to see if there is anything we happened to have done/said that offended you?" To which he replied "No no..relax..relax." Then picked up another phone call to curtly cutoff the conversation instead of addressing our concern and letting the co-worker standing right next to him answer the call.

@MANAGER - Not the end of the world experience or anything but it was enough to cause me to  write a Yelp review and rate my overall experience poorly - I hope the manager will speak to the staff since talking him directly didn't have any affect.
author: Alex W.

description: I crave the pastor burrito.  No margis, or proper table service in a lacking part of the city for old school mexican is what restricts me from 5 stars.  Their nachos are damn good too
author: Hans S.

description: Very tasty food and nice location. Went for brunch the other day and had the shrimp burrito and the chilaquiles. Both were very tasty and came out quickly. This is an order at the front and then grab a seat place which I typically prefer since you can get in and out fast. Would totally go back and they have different locations through the city which is great.
author: Nicole S.

description:
The interior is functional, earthy, and dim enough to prevent harsh light from spoiling your conversation.

Big burritos and good beers on tap (pints of Pacifico, Anchor Steam, etc. for $3 all the time?!! For an SF spot, I am practically robbing them). I got the fajita chicken burrito with black beans. Even comes with light and crispy chips with a great selection of salsas (like 6-8). Everything really hit the spot.

Try this place now.
author: Eugene C.

description:
Oh oh oh, I'm the 100th review... I think this must be a sign... I'm not sure a sign for what, but it must be one!

Where to begin... well, I'm renting an apartment in this neighborhood (whose name has thus far eluded me) in the heart of San Fran. And I must say, that in the 4 square blocks immediately surround my present location, posses more culinary delights than arguably the whole of San Diego. 

One of the jewels is this cute little Mexican joint I hereby dub, "a little slice of heaven." I started my culinary experience with the chicken tortilla soup. I don't typically like large chunks of dark meat nor cubes of cheese, but somehow the roasted chilies, the white maze, the chicken, avocado, assorted spices, and whole garlic made the dish devilishly delightful... guess no one will be kissin' their honey afterwards... unless your honey also have this soup, in which case, it's fair game.  I didn't think my meal could get any better, and seriously considered not eating my specialty garlic shrimp burrito in order to keep myself from the inevitable disappointment that always follows a dish of perfection. 

But me, I can't resist food if it's in front of me... so I broke down and bit into my burrito... the taste explosion just blew my mind. WOW. The roasted tomato salsa, the spicy garlic shrimp, the beans, the avocado... holy guacamole... seriously died and gone to heaven. 

If there were six stars to be given, I'm sure this place will be bestowed the honor. Highly highly recommended.
author: Charlie L.

description:
I think I've finally found my favorite burrito in the city. I've been searching for years, and it's finally here. It meets all of my criteria for the ideal taqueria:

*overall burrito quality, with a really good tortilla (not slimy and sticky on the outside)

*good quality and plentiful chips- thin, crispy, not too oily

*several good salsas of varying spiciness to choose from. 

Try the vegan plantain and black bean burrito!
author: Bonnie C.

description: I've been here about 5 times all at the suggestions of friends or coworkers. This place is another example of what's wrong with food in SF...overpriced. $15 sandwiches or burgers, $12 burritos, $4 tacos. Where's the sensibility in food prices?! Ok, enough ranting.  I'll get back to the food.  This place does use organic ingredients and promote "healthy" mexican but it doesn't taste or feel any different than the much better tasting/better value Mexican joints in the city. Maybe it's the fact that there aren't really any other decent Mexican joints in this area but this place is just ok. If you really really really want Mexican in the nopa-lower Haight area then this is a decent place but nothing to rave about. Other than that, you might just be upset at how much you paid for a burrito.
author: Young C.

description:
I came here on a holiday, it was packed and there was no where to sit, and we ultimately got our food to go and walked home (in the rain, no less) and I'm STILL giving it 5 stars. 

Why? The food was phenomenal. right down to the rice, beans and crispy chips. Everything tasted fresh, the restaurant is super cozy, the drink prices are reasonable, and the staff was so, so friendly (even on a busy night!). 

Our take-out was ready fast, and it was still hot and delcious after walking a few blocks. Can't wait to go back and actually sit down!
author: Alyssa G.

description:
I had the wild mushroom tacos, which were okay but nothing special, and a margarita, which was realllly nothing special. I didn't even finish it.

Cute little place, I'd try it again, but it didn't really impress me at all.
author: Anna N.

description: I was on vacation and we came in here to eat. The fried plantain was no joke and wa the bomb. My guy and our 3 good friends all met up here and all of us were very impressed. Our  friend Anthony thinks he could be a food crittic he has eaten at so many place in his life and he usally is bitching about something. However to all of our shock and delight he was full cheeked and chewing pretty much the entire dinner. To all of us this place is a place we will be visiting again next time were in San Fransisco.
author: Angel Y.

description:
A gem in Lower haight.  Definately one of the best burritos in San Francisco.

Breakfast burrito is sub par, dont really agree with any mexican restaurant putting beans in a breakfast burrito.  Go to Green Chile cafe for a bomb b'fast burrito.

Chihuahua is good for dinner, awesome Fajita burrito, chips are fresh, and salsa bar is damn good.

Definately best burrito in Lower Haight
author: Kyle A.

description:
My bf loves their huge burritos and I'm a fan of their tacos


really cute hole in the wall type place

free chips and salsa!
author: Elizabeth B.

description: I love this place.  The food is always on point, the staff is friendly and the seating always seems to work out.  My go to are the carne asada enchiladas and a Negro Modelo on tap.  I've also managed to go there for brunch once and got a burrito with chorizo and it hit the spot.  Definitely a staple restaurant in my diet.
author: Ravi R.

description:
This may not be the most authentic Mexican restaurant, but the garlic prawn burrito is fantastic.  The food served here is FRESH.  Burritos come with , again, freshly made, salted tortilla chips and an unlimited help-yourself selection of salsas.  The fire hot salsa burns my mouth, just the way I like it.  It's what every burrito should have.

The fried plantain and black bean burrito is good too, except there's just a bit too much plantain.  Perhaps you can request half of their usual serving of plantains.  It's unique and different.  Worth a try.

Beware!  This place is clean.
author: Elettra R.

description:
UPDATE: 11/2013  Prices are even HIGHER!  Had a vegi burrito and small drink  and it was over $14.00  I asked for rice in it,,,added quite a bit to cost.

$12.+ for a vegi burrito and soda     ?     I mean it was good but bloody hell !
author: John C.

description: Everything here tasted really fresh.   Great salsa bar, tostadas and tacos.  I'll be coming back!
author: Jerry W.

description:
Just got brunch take-out here.

Service was fast, friendly, and the salsa bar is great. Decent pricing. Decor is cute too, so I'll definitely be back for an in house meal.

BF got breakfast burrito, which was stuffed with WAY too many potatoes, but it still tasted really good. My Mexican french toast was delicious. Perfect sweet and salty combo, and they put the maple syrup on the side so it didn't get soggy on the way home. 

Worth a second try, definitely.
author: Roxane W.

description:
Went here for a Sunday lunch and was lucky enough to snag a table.  The place was packed, so be prepared to wait a little bit for a table, though people are considerate enough not to linger too much.  

Had the carnitas quesedilla and steak fajitas burrito.  Both were reasonably priced (under $10) and tasted fresh.  Good sized portions, and the quesedilla came with pico de gallo, guacamole, and sour cream.  Purists may frown upon this, but it was a welcome addition.  The carnitas had a slight cinnamon flavor that wasn't unwelcome, but it was certainly different.  The fajita burrito steak was a little tough and the vegetables made it a bit soggy, but it was an overall good eat.

The place gets fairly loud when full, but nothing above an average taqueria.
author: AJ L.

description: I finally ordered a burrito from Little Chihuahua and was completely satisfied. I ordered the baby burrito with carne asada. I loved that instead of lettuce they used cabbage. DELICIOUS! I'm hungry for one right now but I honestly don't think my waist/hips would appreciate it ;(
author: Stephanie C.

description:
There is no need for this review. Little Chihuahua has no problem finding fans. Table space is much harder to come by. I have been faithful to this place for 2 years of frequent burrito runs and weekend brunches, and it has never let me down. 

One day I'll get through the whole menu, but it's so tough with the opportunity cost of the utter craveworthiness of their burritos. The meat is high quality and always tasty. The burritos always have the perfect amount of moist sauciness. My favorites are the carnitas and the shrimp, but the carne asada and the chicken are delicious too. 

My favorite is their tostada salad. The tostada is crispy and delicious, not stale tasting like at other places. The greens are fresh and it comes with mango and a huge hunk of avocado! There's the perfect amount of yummy cilantro dressing. Even though I love the meat, I like the salad with their tofu which is marinated in a delicious green sauce. 

I could write a whole paragraph about the salsa bar. Their roasted tomato salsa is the favorite (according to a poll of my friends), deliciously sweet with chips. Salsa verde is tasty and not bitter at all but probably my least favorite. The chipotle salsa is delicious with a little heat and a punch of smoky flavor perfect for dousing on my burrito. And the ultimate is the habanero salsa (which I mix with a little pico de gallo) which is sweet and flavorful and almost ridiculously spicy. 

My most recent discovery was their arroz con leche. Seriously delicious rice pudding, even better than the loving cup (sorry!) with liquor-soaked raisins and delicious cinnamon cookies that are even better when they get soggy and flavor the pudding. 

This is my absolute favorite place for cheap, delicious, relatively healthy food. It is the standard by which I measure all other restaurants. (Was that meal really worth 3 chihuahua burritos?)
author: Ailinh T.

description:
OMG the cabbage slaw that they put in the burritos is DANK. Never tasted anything like it in my burritos before.  

Order the super baby.  It's super and the perfect size.
author: Athena W.

description:
This is my total go-to place in the neighborhood. A friend commented that it isn't "authentic" like the Mexican places in the Mission, but who are we kidding? Burritos aren't even a Mexican food.

Tip: get a super baby burrito. It's almost as big as the regular and you get all the extra goodies for around $7 total. I'm not a huge fan of their tortilla chips, but I am a fan of the fact that they give you tortilla chips with every order and the salsa selection is excellent.
author: Jessie Y.

description: Hard to compete in the city with so many good Mexican food places. Food is alright but not awesome. 8 dollars for a regular burrito that cost 6 most other places isn't a bargain either. Can easily spend more than 9 dollars on 1 super burrito. Just another burrito place in the city.
author: kyle d.

description:
5 stars and two thumbs up! Delicious! 

The plantain burrito is to die for! Their soup is really good as well. I've eaten I can't tell you how many times, and my two go-to items are so good that I don't want to stray! The chips and salsa are also really really good. 

I will seriously drive form the Marina to Little Chihuahua so I can get a burrito they are that good. 

(and ps- forget this 'authenic' Mexican food business- here you know they use good ingredients and are clean in the kitchen! Piece of mind is important)
author: Jennifer K.

description: Delicious food, fair prices.  I eat there at least twice a week.  Many different meals to choose from.  Always satisfied.
author: Jerome N.

description: Go here. Get the Huevos Rancheros.
author: Justin S.

description: Salad was huge! Bf enjoid his Tortilla Soup. Tortilla chips were alittle salty but the salsa was great, i love being able to choose between the salsas. They give you alot more chips than necessary though. Food was great but the place is small and you order upfront. It was crowded during 4:30pm. Their chairs are also so close together you can barely get in them- minus 1star for ambiance.
author: Brittainie B.

description: I'm local and have been a patron since your opening.  I've waited in your line that stretched almost out your door. I've phoned in orders and ran in the rain for your burritos during the winter. But tonight, you crossed the line because my wife found the dreaded hair in hair burrito. No, I'm not talking about the beautiful straight locks of your cashier but the other kind.  Now you're on notice that your biz is slipping. I hope you bring your game back, LC.
author: Joel A.

description:
Everything you want in a Mexican place, nothing you don't. Cheap beer, delicious food, lots of salsa/pico options. Their margs are a bit heavy on the orange juice, but for five bucks I can't really complain. 
Go here if:
You like good, cheap mexican
Don't if:
You're pretentious
author: Casey J.

description: This place used to be good but unfortunately has gone downhill :( Overpriced.
author: Kelly K.

description:
My broseph Tristan was like "Brah, put on your black, tapered jeans and hop on your bike without any gears and roll up deep hard style son, to the lower heezy for this sicknasty B-toe."

I hate Tristan because he took me to Treasure Island '07 and I got body pressed by hot 12 year old girls to the hard sounds of Justice but I had this realization that justice is all religious and that SUCKED hard. Tristan what a douche.

But I can't resist a ride up the hills on my fixie so I headed over.  Imagine my disgust when I found that there was construction out front and there was only 1 bikerack.  ohh emm gee.  Plus it's like, get a bigger sign idiots. It was dusk and the hazy grey, churning, transquilescent evening made it like, mad hard to find.

I hate when my Mexican food isn't made out of rat meat and dripping unnatural orange or green Crisco chunks.  Someone should call delicious STEAK and tell him that Little Chi is pretending he can actually be good in a taco or burrito - he will be outraged.

Food was ok.
author: Arbitrary Yelp Review Guy G.

description:
update: someone positively reviewed their chilaquiles. WHAT!? they are HORRIBLE! 2 eggs on the same chips I just ate a big bowl of with a tasteless sauce present in depressingly small amounts.

Still, five stars for this; the best Mexican food in San Francisco! (I'm not rich; I'm taking into account the great prices here- along with the superb quality and exquisite flavors... and heart-warmingly generous portions...)

The shrimp tacos, carne asada tacos, and pollo asado tacos are AMAZING.
author: Dr. A.

description:
As far as Mexican food that's not coming from a dive -like taqueria in the Mission this place rocks! Much better than Tortilla Heights or Taco Bar which are closer to where I live but I still venture to Page and Divisidero for the awesome Super Baby Burritos. 

The place is clean, cute, and they have delicious beers and sangrias. I've only tried their burritos but they are REALLy awesome. They offer a selection of tortillas, too. I like the whole wheat :) 

I see other people with tacos and the chicken soup and always see smiling faces. This is a great place to stop for a quick lunch -- maybe a date or double date? Food is awesome, inexpensive, and consistent. Parking is never easy but the Divisidero Bus stops right in front. 

Check it out, I highly recommend!
author: Pilar P.

description: Amazing food; totally excellent neighborhood dining experience. Our favorite spot!
author: Justian O.

description:
This is one of my favorite restaurants in SF.

Their dishes are fresh, flavorful, local.  And, best of all, they have tons of options for vegetarians!

The plaintain/ black bean burrito and the wild mushroom and grilled veggie tacos are my favorite.

The word is spreading, so it can get very crowded here on the weekends - FYI.

People rave about their brunch.  But, I wish they would expand their morning menu.
author: Grasshopper R.

description: Ordered a salad here and it was really yummy!  So many toppings included.  Can't imagine it was super healthy, but hey, we chose for a fast food Mexican place so can't argue there anyway!
author: Rebecca D.

description:
I don't do the 5-star review very often, but there's not a reason to NOT give the Little Chihuahua a perfect score. 

Not to say there's anything wrong with the neighborhood's two other options, Papalote and Green Chile Kitchen; both places are great in their own rights. What sets Chihuahua apart from its competition is the delicious salsa bar: 4 unique creations, plus jalapenos and more fixings. 

All menu items -- burritos, tacos, quesadillas, etc -- are outstanding. And don't forget about brunch, served from 11 a.m. to 2 p.m. on weekends. Really hard to beat a Mexican breakfast by these guys -- I highly recommend the Huevos Rancheros. 

Space is limited so I don't recommend coming with more than 1 or 2 other people.
author: Jordan D.

description:
I was previously living in NOPA and The Little Chihuahua was my only go-to for Mexican food in the area. Now that I'm living in the heart of the Mission, surrounded by acclaimed burrito joints here and there, I have to admit that I miss my Little Chihuahua. Until I moved, I was ordering their super burritos, nachos, and salmon tacos at least twice a week. The freshness, and taste of their food is always top notch, and despite how busy it often gets in that tiny little space, they always manage to maintain their quality. The guys and gals at the register are also always super nice, and now that I'm away I miss them!

Also, I suggest always getting a side of guacamole... it's always so tasty, and is a great addition to their fresh chips!
author: Tiff C.

description:
During Treasure Island Music Festival, I waited on line for the ferris wheel. I waited for a good hour, maybe more. I was with friends, and as we got closer and closer to the front of the line that there were 5 of us. 2 couples, and me. Each seat accommodated exactly 4 people. Yikes. The crushing reality that I would have to ride with strangers hit me and hit hard. I looked around, and there were nothing but drunken ne'erdowells around me, which normally I'm ok with in your typical bar setting where your exit strategies are clear and mutually agreed upon. No such luck. I would be trapped in a small rotating box with strangers. Possibly for several minutes. All I have is 5 minutes of interesting material. Tops. I'm from New York. I work in advertising. Oh really, wow- so interesting. Then nothing but a long devastating cold silence. Or so I anticipated.

I wound up riding with an older couple. The woman was part of the event planning committee for the Treasure Island music festival. She asked me if I was enjoying myself. The husband took pictures and wondered what neighbored I lived in in the city. I told her yes I enjoyed myself, and I told him I lived in lower haight. He said the best burrito in the city was in the lower haight, and we simultaneously blurted out "Little Chihuahua on Divis!" And then- he preceded to blow my mind. He said they best burrito wasn't even on the menu. He said go in and order plantains and black beans. Depending on who's working, they may or may not make it for you, but if you can convince them to- it'll be the best burrito you've ever had.

The man on the ferris wheel was right.
author: Jarrod B.

description:
I'm a fan particularly for their nachos, great variety of choices in terms of meats, beans and other toppings; and the portion is huge. The margaritas with agave wine are really good, even though they're served on the rocks rather than frozen (my preference). The deal I got here was buy one entree, get the second 50% off.

The one thing I don't like about this place is that the line to order food cuts right through the middle of the restaurant. There are tables on either side of the line and it can get packed rather quickly because it's a relatively small space.

Also, no Jarritos grapefruit?! I decided to take a risk and try the Tamarindo flavor and was actually pleasantly surprised.
author: Alyssa G.

description:
zomg so delicious nutritious and cheap

i had two tacos -- one shrimp, one carnitas. the shrimp one blew me away. the carnitas was very good. 

i had a lovely glass of sangria as well.

my total tab was $11.50.

heaven!!
author: Tasha D.

description:
This place is fantastic and offers REAL vegetarian food options that don't taste bland at all.

It's pretty tough to get a table which sucks and people give you dirty looks when you cut the line to pay for take out (like you're supposed to! calm down hipsters!), but the only major problem I have with it is that it's a bit expensive. I walked out last night paying over $17 for two vegan veggie burritos which really made me think a little bit.

Oh and the chipotle salsa is insane!
author: Paul C.

description:
This place has great food, and their salsa bar is tops. Ate guacamole enchiladas, rice and refried black beans, my husband had the fried plantain and bean burrito-AMAZING. The guacamole is fresh and delicious.
On the downish side, it's small, and there is no table service. It gets crowded in the evening, so you may end up waiting for a table to clear, or you may end up sitting with a stranger. In my opinion, what it lacks in space it makes up for with fresh and delicious Mexican food. 
Prices were average, between $-$$, depending on your dish and what sides, drinks, etc. you might order.
author: Maeghan G.

description:
Dear Little Chihuahua tacos,

I'm sorry I neglected you for the first 3 months I lived in San Francisco. I was too preoccupied with burritos. I'm sure this is a common mistake by newcomers and regulars. It's hard to pass up a black bean and plantain or garlic shrimp burrito (both amazing. In a duel, plantain and black bean would win). But don't make the same mistake I did. Go for the tacos! Particularly the chile verde chicken. If you're feeling frisky, mix and match with a carne asada or maybe a grilled veggie (I know grilled veggie taco sounds weird but just go with it). Now if you're looking for typical mexican street tacos, you're going to get the opposite of that. One taco contains 2 corn tortillas topped with a mountain of whatever you choose. Two tacos is the perfect meal....unless you're a giant. You can eat them taco style (2 hands required) or with a fork (don't judge). And don't forget to hit the salsa bar. The roasted tomato salsa makes for a real party in the mouth. 

I also have to give a shout out to their weekend brunch. If you live nearby, call in, go pick it up, return to your couch and wait for your hangover to magically disappear.
author: Mary L.

description:
I tried the breakfast burrito but it was overloaded with potatoes and eggs. Very average 

My wife tried the breakfast tacos which was a bad decision because it had the same ingredients as my burrito.

To summarize my experience, the decor and ambience for this place is good, the salsas were yummy and the chips were crunchy, the servings are generous. However the burritos and tacos didnt quite deliver the punch that I was expecting after seeing all the reviews for this place. 

Next time I may try the plantain or the veggie burrito or tacos and update my review.
author: Rahul P.

description:
This place is super good and super consistent. I've been going here regularly for over a year so about time I reviewed the darn thing.

The burritos are awesome. My favorite is the chicken chile verde, and LC is one of the few places that has refried black beans! So good! There's also a choice of tortillas and the whole wheat is solid. They come with fresh chips of course and there is a selection of 6 really good really fresh salsas - try the tomatillo or roasted tomato!

Another favorite is the pork pozole soup - it's rich, complex and delicious!

Finally, I recommend going for brunch! The breakfast burritos are even better than the regular ones (by far the best I've ever had), and the huevos motulenos are great too.
author: Teo W.

description: This place is hip. The staff is laid back and cool. They were super friendly and the service was prompt despite the long line. The seating is communal, you order at the counter, and the food comes out fast. We ordered the tortilla soup and a carnitas burrito. Enough food for an army and the beer was super cheap. Cheap beer, pork burritos, and laid back atmosphere usually add up to four or five stars in my book but something was off. The burrito was just okay and the soup was watery. However we had just moved, were super stressed, and had just started work. So it may have been me and not little chihuahua's fault.
author: Kim K.

description:
The guys at Little Chihuahua are the tops! 

Oh, and the food is killer too. 

I go here fairly frequently. Usually I get the sangria, (nicely soaked fruit included, no weak microscopic apple chunks tossed in as an afterthought like some places). 

Other things I've eaten here in the past include the black bean/plantain burrito everyone is raving about, (it is as good as everyone says) and the garlic shrimp burrito (also as good as everyone says it is). 

Last night, I ordered something I didn't like very much. (Basic carne asada quesadilla) I was hesitant to say anything, as I'm not a big fan of rocking the boat, and they didn't do anything wrong, I just happened to choose most likely the only thing on their menu that is mediocre. 

Well, I gave in to my worries, walked the plate to the counter and explained the predicament. I ordered something new, and the guys agreed with a smile that it wasn't a problem and didn't even charge me the difference. 

An added bonus is that both guys behind the counter were from my home town, and one belonged to the same local bank as I did, busting out his matching card to prove it. 

Repping OC, nice guys, good service and good food are why I'll never hesitate to make it a Little Chihuahua night.
author: Allie F.

description:
Until the rumored taqueria opens near Divis and McAllister, The Little Chihuahua is going to remain my go-to for burritos and nachos in the Lower Haight/Western Addition/NOPA neighborhood.  CuCo's is a good alternative, but I really just can't resist the delicious Niman Ranch carne asada they serve at TLC.  I'm all for down-and-dirty, authentic, gristly-pieces-and-all steak, but I'm never going to refuse huge, tender chunks of lean, succulent meat from Niman Ranch in my burrito.  

Ah, the burrito.  While a carne asada super burrito here is a little pricier than your average Mission taqueria, it's made with quality ingredients and its size is pretty comparable to, say, El Farolito or Taqueria Can-Cun.  The nachos here are also large and there's no skimping on sour cream, guacamole, beans and meat.  However, be warned that "smoky chile sauce" is served on top of the nachos, which has kind of that weird chipotle flavor.  I don't like my nachos to taste like someone just poured liquid smoke in the beans, so I always ask for no sauce and am cheerfully obliged.

Both the agave wine margarita and sangria here are available by the glass or in carafes and are so ridiculously delicious that I'm considering stopping this review mid-sentence and going to get my drink on.  The agave wine margarita is particularly tasty.  Since it's made with agave wine rather than tequila and comes with orange slices mixed in, it takes on a more subtle, sweet flavor than a traditional margarita, which is a refreshing change.  At $18 a carafe, which works out to roughly four glasses, that's less than $5 a drink for you and your friends -- or, if you're like me, just little old you, relaxing at 3:45 p.m. on a weekday, savoring each sip of margarita and each bite of burrito.
author: Christy J.

description:
Excellent food, cozy atmosphere, clean establishment, and excellent salsa bar.  It is (as everyone has noted) a bit pricier, but I would say that you certainly get what you pay for.  I head here probably once every week or two.  If its cold and rainy outside, have some of the delicious tortilla soup - it will make you feel warm all over.

Overall - excellent establishment.  Lots of menu items to try - you can't go wrong.
author: Jon B.

description: Coming from the East Coast, I'm not use to good mexican food, so I don't know if I would be considered a connoisseur of burritos.  With that said, I do enjoy the burritos here.  Ingredients are always fresh, and I like the variety menu options for the burritos.  I usually can't eat a lot, so the baby burrito is a perfect amount for me.  The salsa bar is an added plus.
author: Priya J.

description:
Not necessarily that most authentic mexican place; although I do come from southern California where there is authenticity everywhere, this place was a pretty good find. First trip had the shrimp burrito which I loved, more of a modernized burrito but damn good. The second trip I had two carnitas tacos that were mammoth. I am used to ones I can finish in three bites tops. These were basically an open burrito. They were ok, but I think next time I will just stick with their burritos.

Also, my friend and I took our food into The Page (bar next door) and ate our food in the lower pool table area. Ordered ourselves a beer and had a nice, quite meal. We did this mainly because there is not very much seating in The Little Chihuahua. All in all, pretty good mexican food for the Bay Area. Since I live within a 5 minute walk, I will be back.
author: Jordan L.

description:
It was my last night in SF and my friend got off from work late on a Saturday night, so we decided to check out The Little Chihuahua. Good thing that they're open until 11pm at night. 

When we got here, the place was filled with people, which led me to believe that this place must be good. Bad thing was that we didn't have a place to sit. The seating area is like a first come first seat basis BUT after you order your food. So in the end, my friend and I had no place to sit so we took our food "to go". 

Overall, I thought that this food experience was pretty good but sadly this little chihuahua didn't make it to best in show. The size of my shrimp with garlic burrito was generous; however, the flavor wasn't all there. I mean it tasted okay, but I felt like it was lacking something.. perhaps salt? *shrug* However, the saving grace of this meal was their tortilla soup. This soup was bursting with flavor and I would beg like a dog to get more of this. I just wish that I came here in the beginning of my trip so I could have ordered the soup again. Well good to know where I can get good tortilla soup when I'm in SF.
author: Norm D.

description: I came here to get take out lunch. After reading Yelp reviews I decided to go with the fried plantain and bean burrito. It was absolutely delicious and huge. I could only eat half. The tortilla on the outside it perfectly crispy, soft, and delicious. The sweet fried plantains had great texture and were a great contrast  to the beans and the spicy salsa. The chips on the side are actually served warm and so yummy. The roasted tomato salsa in the salsa bar is the best! I just moved close to this joint, I will be coming back often! :)
author: Vrushali P.

description:
I'll give this place 4 stars based on the food, but the service had some issues. They were completely overwhelmed when we visited last night (a Thursday). We asked for cups for water 3 times, and each time the manager with a phone nestled between her shoulder and ear and serving dishes in each hand said she would get right on it. They also ran out of forks and some of the salsas for quite a while.

But the food was quite good. I ordered the garlic shrimp burrito, which tasted strongly of garlic, just the way I like it (I'm aware that this is not something I would get in Mexico). I liked the salsa bar, and I was glad that the various salsas were actually labeled, unlike most others I've seen in the city. That way I didn't have to try each one to find the hottest, and normal people don't accidentally singe their tastebuds. The habenero salsa (4 stars, the hottest) had a nice cool taste but packed a huge punch. Yum!
author: Adam B.

description:
I hope my experience was just a bad day.

After I ordered and before I paid, a cook walked out from the back to the cooking area, and pulled something out of his mouth.  Not sure if it was food or what, but the guy's fingers were in his mouth.  Then he went on to handle food, bare-handed without washing his hands.  I watched him take chips barehanded and put them in to-go containers.  This is not safe, and an excellent way to transmit Hepatitis or other pathogens. 

I worked in restaurants for years and know we have all suffered worse, so I mentioned it to the cashier/front person, and he sort of casually said he'd tell the guy to go wash his hands.  He did not seem particularly alarmed.  Gross.  Every place that serves food to the public needs to understand basic food safety, and have someone on staff to train the employees.

Then I got my food and there was a gigantic hair underneath my taco when I picked it up.  I am not sure if this was a special gift because I complained, or just a really bad hygiene day for this place.

It was my first visit, and I had heard good things about the place.  But my personal experience was really gross.  

At least the counter guy gave me my money back... 

Gross experience.  The good news was... I wasn't hungry anymore even though I didn't eat.  Maybe I lost an ounce.
author: Zach S.

description: Ask for half the plantains in the plantain burrito and add sliced avocado. This is vegan heaven, trust me. Apart from the awesome Mission burrito gems, this is the spot for something a little more fancy. And by fancy I mean small and cute, clean bathrooms, and nice communal tables.
author: K S.

description: Delicious. Veggie burrito is by far one of the best I've ever had. Also the horchata was fantastic - homemade and not syrup-y at all! We'll definitely head back next time we are in the area!
author: Maura K.

description:
Yippie, I have finally found a Mexican joint I actually love!!! This little innovative Taqueria gets kudos for having not only many vegetarian options, but a plantain burrito...I had dreams about this burrito!  
Also, the chips were warm and tasty!  My bf had the enchilada and he loved it, but the only thing he said it was missing was sour cream and salsa.  Overall though, the food was great tasting and fresh.  I will be back there very soon!
author: Molly M.

description:
While not as authentic as La Taqueria or El Farolito in the Mission, it's a great option for being out of the area. Decent prices, really good quality ingredients, fresh and tasty salsas. Yes, sometimes you'll want the place with cow tongue, pig intestines and metal chairs, where you're elbow to elbow with the workers on 24th Street and shouting above the din of Spanish families.

But then there are the other times, where you might want to take a date to a different joint with pretty wood tables and carafes of sangria. And don't worry, you're not any less authentic for doing so...
author: Kimmie N.

description: A friend and I ate here around something like 8pm. We ordered a shrimp burrito and a shrimp quesedilla, chips and guacamole, and agave wine margaritas. We enjoyed our meal, drinks, and the atmosphere was pretty fu*kin cool.
author: Jessica R.

description: Though the food is great, the customer servicing is the worst i have ever experienced. Even their manager is distasteful. I called just to inform them of their 3rd time mistaking an order and he questioned my claim stating "they rarely ever make mistakes" rather than trying to correct the issue. After I explained the mistake he nonchalantly replied, "is that all?"  Then tried to bribe me with a discounted entry card, i declined and will never order from them again.
author: M L.

description:
How delicious! Arrived with 4 other friends for dinner one night. I was glad we got there before it got packed. Silly me, I ordered tortilla soup AND a quesadilla. The soup was HUGE and so good. 

I must admit, the community table thing freaked me out at first (coming from the east where you don't talk to people you don't know unless you're a nut job, you want something, or you're trying to start some shit). It was really nice chatting with the couple who sat with us. 

So, in closing, great food, good people, and a cute name...what more do you need in a restaurant?
author: Liz A.

description:
I like this place...ok. 

The first time I came here was a while ago on a Friday night around 10pm and it was packed. We still got seating though, so I'm not complaining. I got a carne asada baby burrito and really liked it. the cabbage is a little spicy and makes it unique and the meat is really good. 

But I went back last night... and got a regular carne asada burrito with green chile on it... and I didn't like it so much. You know when a burrito has the perfect proportion of everything? This one didn't. Way too much pico de gallo, not enough beans and rice. The meat was still good though!

Oh, if you go make sure you get the roasted tomato salsa. yum.
author: Abbey S.

description:
The other night we were on our way to a place nearby, (yes, shame-shame!) BUT when I passed by the Chihuahua I just HAD to stick my nose in there and then grab a business card. I know a good place when I see one, just like cafes :-}
So tonight 4 of us headed over and .... drum roll... 
LOVED the HELL outa DIS place!!!

The gluten free items on the menu were a total bonus, and that their meat is "Organic" (gotta love that term, like what else is meat? -Synthetic? Not yet).
So, Salmon Taco's, very yummy, Fried Plantain, HOLY COW ! best I've had in ages, Black Bean re-fry, nummmies. We didn't need any alcohol here, the atmosphere was so festive and the food so good I was in my own happy bubble for the rest of the eve.

Yo quiero Poquito Chihuaha ! Pronto! 
arf!
author: Roanna Z.

description:
Went for brunch...

Killer menu with chilaquiles, motulenos, rancheros, breakie burrito, mexican french toast.....

But not that tasty or zesty, and too tough to cut....  Motulenos (huevos tostadas) = like cutting cardboard w/ a plastic knife. But it was a corn tortilla, and it was a metal knife.  Bummer.
author: Melanie C.

description:
We affectionately call this:  our crack burrito place.

Fast service (always gotten it take-out).
It's ALWAYS busy.  

my favorite:
super burrito (duh)
Carnitas
sub avo for guac
black beans
author: sUper j.

description:
Little Chihuahua is a total favorite and an "I don't know what to eat for dinner" go-to. I love the atmosphere of the place, the art and the communal tables. The guy who takes orders (dont know his name-Sorry!) is probably the nicest person in the service industry I have ever encountered. Even if there is a ridiculous line or the phone is ringing off the hook he takes 30 seconds to say hello, smile and never rushes, small things that I appreciate. 

Anywho...to the food. I usually get the super baby burrito with chicken, love the whole wheat options and have never found the burrito to be dry at all. Also love the tacos, Pollo Asado tostada salad and the bf likes the carne asada quesadilla and burrito. 

LC has numerous salsas to choose from and we get all of them because they are delish! Also have a great assortment of beers, sodas, Mexi-Colas which are the best and yummy agave wine margaritas! 

All around LC has wonderful food, service and atmosphere and I am hooked!
author: Alissa C.

description:
Basic Mexican in a small semi-self-service enviroment. As a :"light" dinner before my red-eye back to NYC, we shared 2 beef burrito bigger than my head, an order of fresh-made guac and two juicy pork tacos filled with cilantro and other tasty green things. 

Thank god my stretchy pants were able to conceal my subsequent food baby...otherwise the flight attendants might have thought I was pregnant, and made me give up my exit-row seat.
author: Lady O.

description:
You know when you order the same thing every time you go to a certain place? Well, at the Little Chihuahua I get the cheese enchiladas with extra red sauce and black beans (rather than refried). I am a cheese-enchilada connoisseur, so I have had many. These are not greasy and the sauce is fresh and spicy and like no other enchilada sauce I've ever had. It is light yet very flavorful. They recently changed their cheese enchiladas to include onions, chiles, and sour cream, to which I'm adjusting. But I do appreciate that they always ask if the new version is OK, and sometimes I do revert to the old-school with just cheese, tortilla, and sauce. You can have it your way at the Little Chihuahua.

OK, I occasionally have the tostada salad with carne asada, which is also an excellent choice (I love the real mixed greens -- not iceberg lettuce -- and the mango salsa), but I order the cheese enchiladas nine times out of 10. Why fix it if it ain't broke?
author: Heather G.

description: Good burritos at a decent price. I abuse their salsa bar when I go there all their salsas are good especially the habanero boy will it burn your mouth . If you're looking for a decent mexican restaurant near the haight this is it. Staff is friendly especially the cashier Tara.
author: Lawrence F.

description:
I'm so glad this place has been successful- all the previous joints in that spot didn't  last very long, but Little Chihuahua definitely delivers in a way that the previous occupants could never compare.

Their brunch is off the hook, their burritos are amazing, and when I want something light their grilled chicken tostada (with mango, cucumber, avocado, beans, mixed greens, and yummy dressing) is great. Most of the time though I just want the garlic shrimp burrito or the salmon tacos (which are generous in their portions - a full fillet of salmon!).
author: megan k.

description:
YUM! I just had mind blown here for the second time last night!

The Plantain & Black Bean Burrito is the best vegetarian burrito I have ever put in and around my mouth!

The sweetness of the the plantains and the meaty texture of the fruit are divine with the spicy beans and salsa. If you are anything like me you put a jalapeno on every bite, belisimo! I rarely am able to eat all of my burrito but I tore that mofo up!

The restaurant is currently going under a renovation to make the seating more efficient but that doesn't keep people away. I called and placed a pick up order and got a busy signal the on the first try. The second try i had to wait awhile to get someone to pick up, but no worries that's just how busy they are. They still had my food promptly ready within 10 minutes. When I arrived to pick up the food MAN they were PACKED! It was definitely a happy sight to see since so many other businesses are empty. 

I want to come back and try the chiliqueles & the Mexican French Toast. They do brunch from 11-2 Mon - Fri :-D
author: Brittany D.

description:
I wanted to pick an environmentally conscious place for our late night dinner especially after viewing Food Inc. Little Chihuahua was perfect and it's open late too (11pm Thurs-Sat). 

The place was still bustling with late night diners when we walked in. Green Zebra came in handy again with a "buy one, get one half off" coupon. They give out big bowls of chips and they have a nice selection of homemade salsas for the taking and tasting. 

I really enjoyed the Garlic Shrimp Burrito. It's made with sweet, plumb shrimp instead of those bland baby ones. Their Carne Asada Burrito is made with Niman Ranch Steak so it's very juicy. I just wished it had more guacamole since I ordered it super burrito style. You can also pick toasted flour, whole wheat, spinach, or chile-tomato tortillas with your order. I love choice.

They even have desserts! I was debating between Rice Pudding with Agavero Spiked Raisins or Chocolate Chili Cupcakes. I figured it'd be easier to share the pudding with the group so I went with that. I loved how they stuck two almond cookies into it. For some reason, it didn't taste as fatty as I'm used to with rice pudding. That could be a good or bad thing depending on your mood. 

I definitely want to come back and try their brunch. I even know what I'm going to order, Mexican French Toast and a Passionfruit Mimosa!
author: Julia T.

description:
I will update this review again someday I am sure. But I went here for lunch yesterday and had the enchilada plate with chicken. It was tasty, but I have honestly had better. That being said, I have had worse too. So far, the food here sits right in the middle for me. I wasn't as impressed as I had hoped to be after reading the other Yelp reviews. The flavor was kind of sweet and not as much of a party in my mouth as it was more of a "casual gathering" than anything. 
The service was really friendly and fast - I would return here just for the service behind the counter. I really liked the set up inside too. Very comfortable place to come in and have lunch. I did get mean-mugged by two cyclists having lunch across from me - but that's not the Little Chihuahua's fault.
author: Jena D.

description:
[Green Zebra Coupon: 50% second item valued the same or less]

This place seemed to have really good ingredients but my super shrimp burrito just didn't come together that well and cost over $10. The avocado was fresh, the beans and rice were well done, ample salsa and sour cream but -- it just came out average. Maybe I'm jaded from living really close to the Mission my whole life. (Not to say that the Mission is the only place for a good burrito, Ocean Taqueria is surprisingly delicious, albeit overpriced.)

If I could, I'd give them an extra half star for having really fresh-tasting horchata (probably made with real, not-from-goop rice)
author: Elena C.

description:
Surprised how crowded this place always seems to be.  Although It wouldn't have been my first choice (or second), with all the reviews on it, I decided I had to try the plantain and black bean burrito for myself.

Honest opinion: not bad ... but I get the sense that most of the reviews were by vegetarians who are thrilled with a unique, non-meat Mexican alternative (other than your standard bean and cheese burrito).  I think a chicken or carne asada burrito option would be better (btw, the burritos are huge) ... so I'll give that a shot next time.

I tried a bite of the garlic shrimp burrito - pretty good but a little too garlickly imo.
author: F. P.

description: I really really liked the tostada salad, the dressing especially, the fact that they use organic ingredients, that you don't feel rushed, even if it's packed, that you can grab a beer, that they have lots of seafood choices, and fresh shrimp (not farmed), and lots of buttery avocado. It's really good, really fresh, and I will go back, perhaps a lot.
author: Andrew K.

description: Great neighborhood burrito place that's not in the mission. You order at the counter and choose your own seating, but it doesn't feel like a typical taqueria--a lot cozier and a more hip vibe. I got a margarita and the veggie burrito, both of which were decently priced and delicious. I'd definitely go back for a quick casual dinner.
author: Will A.

description: I grew up near the Gordos on Clement St in the Richmond district, so I've been incredibly spoiled (and mostly biased). Since moving to the panhandle area I've probably come here every week with my fiancé. We love the carnitas, and I dig the chile verde chicken burrito & the fajita-style chicken burrito, too. Unlike my childhood burrito love, Gordos...Chihuahua gives you free chips and free reign at their salsa bar. I'm pretty much obsessed.
author: Cat S.

description:
Classic Mexican, high quality ingredients and a good price... but is it worth the anxiety?

Dinner B and I decided to make the walk out to Divisadero, through the rain,  in the pursuit of good Mexican food. As usual, we start with the positive stuff... which is unquestionably the salsa bar. Beyond the usual pico de gallo options, the salsa bar had four salsas each rated between 1 - 4 peppers. Being spice loving fellows, B and I went straight for the Habanero and Chipotal options. I should have written down which was which, but I do remember that the most spicy one was also the sweetest. Both were delicious and, to quote my guacamole loving compatriot, "I won't have to bother paying for guacamole next time."

I ordered a specialty burrito, fried plantains with black beens. It was big, and it was fantastic. I ate it over the course of two meals, such was its size! Adding the super spicy + sweet salsa made it all the more outstanding. And to be clear, these folks didn't skimp on the good stuff... it was bursting with flavorful plantains.

So, why not five stars? Because the ordering process made me anxious... so very, very anxious. Like all too many SF locations, Little Chihuahua is small. Maybe, 10 tables. When we walked in there were but one or two open tables and more than enough people waiting to order to fill them. Restaurant policy is to not allow anyone to take a seat until after they have ordered. As I stood in line mulling my options, all I could /really/ think about is what would happen if all the tables were taken by the time we ordered.

As it would turn out, there was one table left by the time we ordered... and several open by the time we left. But the combination of the small location, popularity, and ordering before claiming a seat put me on a serious edge. Thankfully, once I sat down with my spicy salsa, it was all good.
author: Sean K.

description:
this restaurant is one of 7 numbers i have in my speed dial.  it shares equal billing with my father, girlfriend, and best childhood friend.

nuf said.
author: Daniel M.

description:
Good SF burritos made by white people. The salsas at the open salsa bar are fantastic. The burritos are just-OK, but made with real quality ingredients. The location is very convenient if you like running along the Panhandle in the morning. It's really refreshing to stop in here for a filling meal after running 5 miles through Golden Gate park. I once had the garlic shrimp burrito, which is a bit overrated. It was delicious, but not crazy-amazing. 

Overall, it's well-located, reasonably-priced, reasonable tasty burrito fare. But that's it. Don't get your hopes up, it's not usurping the regular Mission establishments by any stretch. But if you're in this neighborhood, there's no reason not to spend $6 and get some good filler with awesome chips and salsa.
author: Tolga E.

description:
Little Chihuahua is another really good Mexican restaurant in a city of great ones. There are some things that make it really exceptional though, including their unique menu featuring vegetarian items like the plantain burrito which is a little sweeter than most burritos but very good and filling. Every burrito and taco are filled with tasty meats and come out very quickly. Each order also gives the customer a basket of chips, which can be accompanied by one of many salsas offered at a serve yourself salsa bar. These can help make your experience especially great if you find the right flavor for yourself and your meal. 

There are some issues though that keep it from being great. Burritos occasionally get uneven distribution of the ingredients throughout the burritos. Also, the price is a little higher than many other Mexican restaurants in the city which should imply a much better product. However, despite the bigger bill Little Chihuahua's food does not exceed expectations (which are usually high).

Its neighborhood location and decor help add to the experience. It feels very local and the staff is incredibly helpful. Beers are also very affordable, which helps off set the price issues of the food. Definitely worth going to if you are in the area, but maybe not worth a long trip to this taqueria. Good but not great seems to be the best way to categorize Little Chihuahua, but ultimately as Yelp suggest...Yay! I'm a fan!
author: Dan H.

description: I went in to grab lunch to go this afternoon and had my order taken by a rude female employee. When it was my turn to place an order, I received a blank, impatient stare rather than any sort of greeting. No complaints about the food (my burrito was great), but it wouldn't hurt for employees who interact with customers to lighten up!
author: Kelly M.

description: What a pleasant experience.  Casual, relaxed atmosphere, great shrimp burrito, awesome salsa, friendly staff, crispy, warm chips and only ten bucks....
author: Nobody M.

description: This place gets a little too crowded.  I like the spicy shrimp burrito.  I ordered the taco salad which was really good too, sangria was yummy.  If the wait was shorter and more seating, I'd give it 4 stars.
author: Ting B.

description: The Chihuahua is the best Mexican/Californian taqueria type restaurant in the neighborhood. The prices are higher than the typical taqueria's in the Mission ($9+ burritos vs $7-8 mission burritos), but the quality is very high. The tortillas are great, meat is fresh, and if you are a salad fan - try their chicken tostada salad (comes with dices mangos, fresh avacado, and a sweet dressing). The employees are super friendly and always get my take out orders right. I consider myself a burrito snob, and give this place two thumbs up.
author: Matt D.

description:
Pretty damn good fish tacos. Pretty damn good fish tacos. Pretty damn good fish tacos. 

And if you don't like fish tacos, just try the fish tacos, they are great.
author: eric m.

description: I love the Garlic and Shrimp Burrito. So tasty and delicious. The lime-salted chips and salsa are a wonderful compliment to the tasty burrito heaven that is The Little Chihuahua.
author: Steven G.

description: By far the best mexican food in the city. High quality ingredients, consistent cooking, fast/friendly, great atmosphere. I recommend the chicken super burrito with pinto beans. Try the habanero salsa!!
author: Chris C.

description:
When they first arrived in the neighborhood, I loved it.  I loved it for awhile.  The chips.  The salsa bar with pickled jalapenos, chipotle, habanero, roasted tomatilllo and roasted tomato salsas.   Sometimes I would get greedy with the salsas and take too much.  The carne asada and carnitas burritos.  The horchata.  The $2 pints of Anchor Steam (now #3...boo.)   I would bust a gut every time!

Then I got bored.  I stopped and went back to Cancun.  Then I came back.  Then I went to Cancun.  I ran back and forth for awhile and one day I came back and it wasn't so good.  Then I left.  Then I ate Papalote.  Then I came back.  Then I had Green Chile Kitchen- I thought, YES! Hard shell tacos.  Then I had a couple bad meals there.  Then my roommate and I started coming to LC to eat together (he'd get enchiladas and I'd get chicken baby burrito.)  I loved it again.  Then the salsa bar got kinda so-so.  

Then people started cramming in the place like nobody's business.  It got noisy and crowded.  So I would just call in and take my food away to eat at home, all spread out on the living room coffee table, watching old firefly and simpsons episodes on dvd.  then i would go and try something new and not like it.  (ie the salad, the fish tacos, some of the burritos are so-so)  Then I left again.  Then I came back and got re-addicted to the carnitas baby burrito (which is still amazing but you know it's the fast track to heart disease and obesity.)  My boyfriend got addicted to the rice pudding which is awesome...so awesome that we'd sometimes make a late night run for 3 or 4 servings of it to share with friends.  

THEN, I started eating the plantains and black burrito and I am totally and completely smitten.  It is heavy.  It's not for everyone as it is sweet and kinda on the mushier side with smoky sauce, rice, sour cream, cheese, onions and pico de gallo.  But oh, my, god.  It is amazing.  I will always come back to Lil Chihuahua for that burrito.  And their great chips and salsa.  Just like I will always go to Cancun for their vegetarian burritos and spicy green salsa or La Taqueria for their carnitas or carne asada or GCK for their hard shell tacos and ground beef (with green or red sauce) or Publico Urban Taqueria in the Trader Joe's plaza in SOMA for their chicken chile verde (that's right!)
author: erin k.

description:
I am SO happy this place is now open until 11.  Finally, delicious legitimate burritos within foggy-windy-walking-radius (not to be confused with beautiful-SF-day-walking-radius, which is much much larger) from home.

I have to say, Little Chihuahua beats out the competition (Papalote) in authenticity, tastiness, and price.  It's hard to beat that crazy orange salsa though, so it's not over yet Papalote.
author: Jeremy G.

description:
For dinner, I had the garlic shrimp burrito, under the specials. The shrimp was flavored well, but there wasn't a salsa or anything special in the burrito to help it stand out from other burrito joints. I finished it, but it's not something I would ever really crave to have again. The salsa bar is small - 5 typical choices. I will credit the restaurant for having very fresh ingredients and unlimited homemade chips!

To all my East Bay friends, the taste of the food reminds me of a lot of Cancun (in downtown Berkeley). Good food, but not noteworthy.
author: Joyce L.

description:
I seem to have been into "healthy" Mexican food lately, and The Little Chihuahua seems to be up to par with one of my other favorites - Fillmore Mexican Grill. 

It's a cozy, faux-grungy (because it's so faux-Mexican?) kind of place without a Mexican person in sight. That's alright though, because their reduction of fat is offset by their tasty dishes. 

Perfect for those days when you know you'll be burning a modest 5000 calories instead of the usual 10000 to warrant a traditional Taqueria burrito!
author: Ryan V.

description: Food is okay but it's always over packed with people and the food is just good enough to be a standby neighborhood spot.  Order ahead if you want takeout. The clientèle are a bit monochromatic and you will overhear every inane conversation (by virtue of tiny space with bajillion people all shouting over each other). Doesn't feel like the rest of the neighborhood but nice in its own way.
author: Amelie P.

description:
dearest Little Huahua:

My favorite date night involves your super-baby carne asada burrito, paired with a six-pack from across the street, enjoyed at home while watching the Wire or Mad Men.  Sheer bliss.

I love how the "super" part of the burrito means I get all the toppings, and the "baby" part means I can actually consume the whole thing - although it's still pretty big.  Your shrimp quesadillas also do me right, and my man is partial to your steak salad.  

I also like how you offer me bottled mexican-style coke, and how you accommodate my cilantro aversion.  And of course, your high quality products make me feel A-ok about eating meat & shrimp.

Thanks for being so reliably delicious and close to my home!
author: Rachel D.

description:
Thanks to some carefully selected leftovers, many people in my office have destroyed a couple of microwaves while at the same time stinking up an entire floor.

I swear the last one smelled like 5 day old salmon mixed with curry and blue cheese heated for 10 minutes on high.

Because of this, I am damned hesitant to bring anything in that needs to be reheated.  

Especially if that something has any seafood or shellfish in it.

So, I had to make sure I finished my entire garlic shrimp burrito from Little Chihuahua last night.

This place is awesome.

The salsa bar has some nice little surprises too.  My current favorite is the chipotle salsa followed by the tomatillo.

Highly recommend this place.

I need to go back soon to try the carnitas.

Scent.
author: Archie R.

description: Sorry guys, gotta knock of a star.  I was so fond of this place I made repeat visits and a couple of things happened: the salsas (which I mentioned were weak even the first time around have become a major liability,) and some of the things I've tried (for instance the carnitas were so far from up-to-par in a town that has no shortage of superlative carnitas.)  The carne asada remains consistently excellent and lovingly prepared.  I'd stick with that.
author: Mike B.

description:
5 stars in it's class - one of the best salsa bars in for sure.   A HUGE improvement from the taco loco that was here before.   Seriously, you'd think that with the same ingredients there couldn't be such a massive disparity in taste, all taquerias use beans meat and cheese.

I suppose it's like art, give every man a paint brush and most of them paint crap.   Takes an artist to make a mona lisa for your mouth.
author: Rick R.

description:
yum. yum. yum.  Went here for the first time for my birthday and it did not disappoint.  Everything was so fresh and the portions were enormous.  I ordered two veggie tacos, and it was way too much food.  Luckily I had hungry friends.  The margaritas are also really delicious, though I wouldn't really classify them as margaritas- more like a tequila sunrise, with juice and agave wine.  Still, damn good.
Word to the wise, you are supposed to wait until you order and get a number to grab a table.  Some people behind us tried to put their coats down before they ordered, and some other diners told them to get to steppin when we got our food and needed a table.
I will definitely be back.
author: sara b.

description: This place was pretty decent...I've eaten here 3 times, and while the taqueria food that I'm used to in my hometown halfway across the continent is different (and a little better IMO) than San Fran-style joints, the Little Chihuaha is definitely among the best of the bunch with Pancho Villa. Try the Plantain & black bean burrito as recommended by other yelpers.
author: Ben H.

description:
+3 stars for solid, very tasty urban Mexican and pan-Latin neighborhood grub.

+1 stars for really great fun decor, illustrations, Viking-Mead-hall-style seating (some people call it 'family'-style, I guess it all depends on what kind of family you're from. No judging.)

+1 stars for awesome service, slammed or no.
author: Mark S. I.

description:
This place is a great burrito spot in an area without a lot a great burrito spots.  Though not your traditional taqueria, The Little Chihuahua is a little more high-end fancy gourmet style, with Neiman Ranch meats and other flourishes like that, which appeases the eco-conscious meat-craver inside me.

Expectedly, prices are a smidge higher than those at a more traditional taqueria, because of the higher quality of ingredients.  But that higher quality definitely translates to the taste, as the food at The Little Chihuahua is definitely fresh and delicious.
author: Kevin H.

description:
Speak the words "little chihuahua" and my brain turns to the Taco Bell dog and Paris Hilton.  Too bad, because this restaurant deserves more than those media-tastic associations.

I can only comment on the brunch I had here, but if it's any indication, then the rest of the menu is WORTH IT.

The tiny restaurant is stuffed with gorgeous carved chairs, bright colors, pretty painted windows, cool art on the walls and wonderful food.  We ordered up at the counter and waited (not long) for the lone waitress/cashier/table busser (girl was biz-ZAY) to plunk down big ol servings of breakfast burritos, huevos rancheros (mine YUMM), and mexican french toast in front of us.  Everything was soooo good.  This place would be super dangerous for me if I lived in the neighborhood since they are definitely a good option for take-out.

The mex french toast might need some explaining, so I will school you in it.  Imagine thick fresh tortillas lightly fried up and folded over mountains of grilled, carmelized plantains and the thickest bacon you've ever seen....  and did I mention it is served with agave syrup?  

Next time it will be mine, oh yes, it will be mine.
author: Laura B.

description:
20 minutes for a single taco at 9:40 at night.  20 minutes.  I miss Loco Taco.  I miss my neighborhood taqueria.

As for yelp, I have to call out the reviewers.  "$"?  Really?  Food + drink is greater than $10 for one person!
author: Jim S.

description: Now this is my kind of burrito! And dont get me started on the rice pudding ahem! I went for enchiladas once and then the taco salad another time... but nothing beats the burritos!! Go for the special ones. And no joke, the rice pudding is phenom!!! Get it. Make sure you're sitting though, you might faint over it's delishousness.
author: Betsy F.

description:
carne asada is really really really good
tostada salad is HUGE and comes with mango salsa, lightly dressed.  prolly the best tostada i've had yet.

recommended stop for pre show bite near the independent.
author: Josie M.

description:
After passing by the Little Chihuahua many times (I live a few blocks away), and hearing all my friends give rave reviews, I finally decided to hit up Little Chihuahua. 

Result: just an average taqueria. Now this isn't to say that LC is no good, its just that there are so many great burrito joints around that the standard is pretty high here. I forked out around 8 bucks for a chicken super burrito. It was fine, but honestly, my favorite taquerias are in the mission where I can get a better super burrito for 5-6 bucks.
author: Jeff C.

description: This is the most average food that I've eaten since living in SF. The food was incredibly bland and I do not plan on wasting my money or any calories on this place again.
author: Jane E.

description:
On one of those nights, after one of those weeks, I finally tried this place out on a night I was just too freaking tired to rummage through my pantry and make myself dinner.  My pure lack of enthusiasm for cooking that night had an excellent reward when I decided to pick up a burrito from The Little Chihuahua.

I only got take out, but it was great.  I had the plantain burrito which was delicious! I was a little nervous about trying a burrito which I had never seen on a menu, but I will definitely be back for another! It was original, huge and delicious! I would highly recommend it.
