I'm a vegetarian and it is not all that often that I get to be too experimental in my food choices when I eat out, but this was a great opportunity to do so!

The restaurant is pretty small so I'm sure it fills up fast but the staff was courteous and fast and I will definitely be back to eat in!

Bottom line:
-street parking is probably somewhat of a pain
-fair prices ($16 for 2 huge burritos)
-delicious plantain burrito
-great for a night when you just aren't in the mood to cook!
author: Jean K.

description:
excuse my enthusiasm but this place whets my appetite! They serve neimen ranch beef and you can tell the difference from other places (see my review of dos pinas). The salsas are awesome-all with very subtle hints of fresh lime. Yum! The horchata is tasty too. The only thing missing from this place are the jalapeno pickled carrots. I love those!

I hate when yelpers say that its white washed. If its good, then it good and this place is definitely good.
author: Nicole C.

description: Better than Papalote; garlic shrimp burrito and a salsa bar.  Do it.
author: Jenn C.

description: I would have loved to love this place since I live two blocks away but 11 dollars for a burrito!!? Menu did not say it was more for the fish... They messed up on my order (forgot to make it super...annoying) the music is way too loud leading to indigestion and you have to bus your own table...This place caters to the yuppies taking over San Francisco.  I'd rather go to the real taquerias in the Mission where you can still find amazing burritos for under five bucks.
author: Monkey B.

description: You have to come here to try the plantain burrito, definitely worth checking out!  Though, be sure to order it vegan, because it just turns out better :).  Awesome offering though for a meat based restaurant.  All of my friends who join me here order the plantains as well.  It just makes for a great break from traditional american b.s.!
author: Nate W.

description:
I was so excited when this place opened. I've been in the neighborhood a long time and have lived through all the other bad Mexican places that occupied this space. The worst was the one that was there back in 2000 called El Rico's or something like that. It was run by two middle eastern guys who used to make salsa with parsley instead of cilantro. I tried to talk to them about it a couple of times but they just shrugged me off. I even ran into one of the guys at K and J produce across the street one day and showed him a bunch of cilantro. I said, "Here, use this CILANTRO in your salsa, not PARSLEY. I would know, I AM LATINA!" 

And he just looked at me like I was a crazy person. Oh well, I tried. And then there was Loco Taco which was a huge step up but not great. Around that time a great little joint had opened up in Lower Haight called Las Mesas so I would just go there. Loco Taco was average, but not great and I definitely never craved it.

And then the skies parted and god shone his heavenly light down to earth and blessed us with The Little Chihuahua. Contrary to it's silly name, they don't actually serve chihuahua meat there. Just Neiman Ranch Beef and Fulton Farms Chicken. 

Everything on their menu is scrumptious, fresh and amazingly delicious. They are not super traditional Mexican, but they are still more Mex than Cali-Mex or Tex-Mex. How do I know? I brought my Mexican-food-snob-sister here and she loved it too.

When I'm in a veggie mood I order the plantain burrito (but in a bowl because flour tortillas are the devil when you're trying to keep your waist slim) but when I want meat I get the beef tacos. Nothing like that Bay Area hippie meat! Tastes great and is practically guilt-free!

I like their salsas but I don't LOVE them... same with their chips. I like that they have moved all the tables around to create more space, it gets quite crowded in there sometimes (don't go on a Friday or Saturday night!) The people who work the counter are always friendly, helpful and patient.  I highly recommend you give this place a try. And Rico guys, if you're out there reading this, you can shove some parsley in your poo-hole!
author: L. L.

description:
I was excited to go to LC and try the black bean and plantain burrito everyone on yelp was raving about. I have to admit, as a lover of plantains, it wasn't all its cracked up to be. Could have been the burrito I got I guess, but it was rather dry and didn't have enough plantains. I think I would rather just eat plantains and rice and not have deal with the tortilla too. 

My friend got the wild mushroom enchilada, which was my second choice and we both found hers to be bland. Don't get me wrong, the place is good if you are in the neighborhood and really want a burrito, but if I ever really want one, I will travel father from my house next time. 

Also, the salsa bar had a lot of options, but none of them were extraordinary. As we said, "it's not bad."
author: Scarlet F.

description:
Great, "interesting" taco shop. If you are tired of the Mission "authentic" grease pits, give this place a try. It's a little pricier than a traditional taco shop, but for the area, it's pretty good. 

Fresh ingredients, fast, good portions, non-standard options. Never had any meat items, but they have lots of vegetarian/fish options. 

Only sat down a couple times and it gets really crowded, but when you do get a table, its a pretty mellow experience. Try
author: Brian B.

description:
I go out of my way to get my fix here. Really, damn it... I knock people over to get a cab to take me here.... Yes, that's how much I want their grub, when I want it.... Poor guy working there has dealt with me a few times now, coming in at the last minute.... Really, I don't mean to, but you are toooo damn close to the Page, and could make a killing if you stayed open past 11pm... I'll drag them in at 1:30am- I promise... 

Alas, they only stay open until 11pm, and I run up there with puppy dog eyes hoping they will serve me. It's not my fault... my cohorts are just now starting to appreciate the "before 11pm snack". 
Even if they didn't offer effing PLANTAIN and black bean burritos.... I'd still harass them to let me pay them for whatever they still had on the grill. 

But, they are still ever so pleasant and serve us anyway (now, you don't go rolling up there at the last minute.... don't cut yourself short of all they have to offer... and make me look like more of an asshole). 

Not only is the food and salsa wonderful... the interior of this joint is cute, cute with all of the stained-glass and wooden dinning... oh, and some easy-on-the-eyes guys cooking up some yummin's. 
And, if you didn't get your fill of elixir from the nearby bars.... they have some house-made margaritas... beer, and so on. 

Dare I say that they need to become a CHAIN and make more people happy with their delightful fare.... Yes, I said it... and you all know that there are some chains that stared out as little places with groupies, like this little poochy.  Sooo, don't be surprised if you see others leg-humping this place... yes, it's that good.
author: Kara B.

description:
I subscribed to yelp just because I wanted to review this place. That's how much I love it.

I am not big in mexican food as many people could be, since I am italian and my first burrito was just one year ago BUT I know good food and this place is awesome!

I LOVE LOVE LOVE their super burrito, with carne asada and their watermellon aqua fresca. I love it so much that every time I want to change but always end up having it. 
Their tacos and fajitas are super good too.

And their chips. OMGosh! their chips are supreme. especially with their red salsa, the one with black little things inside on the far left corner of the salsa thing. 

Besides, they are super nice and they can spell my name correctly. 

I just wish they did delivery. However, you can order by phone and pick up if you don't want to wait there. Even though you never have to wait long.
And if you eat there, it's super cute, not like the usual mexican places.

Definitely 5stars. I am sad I won't be just a few blocks away anymore. but it's worth a trip.
author: Elena A.

description:
Finally... a purse dog I can respect!

I must salute The Little Chihuahua for delivering me some very tasty treats in the midst of an altogether great weekend last weekend!

As promised, the ambiance was muy autentico, the food fresh, and the service inviting. With great decor and thematic art on the walls, you definitely feel like you'll be getting some down-home Mexican vittles. Yet the ingredients are top-notch (Niman Ranch beef & pork, Rocky Jr. chicken, and Clean Fish shrimp & salmon). (Hint hint, La Taqueria...)

The salmon taco featured salmon that was crispy-yet-moist, and arrived in a portion generous enough for me to share with my dining companion. (Kudos to him for suggesting we eat here, BTW!)

Their salsa bar is great -- includes habanero salsa (quite citrus-y and fiery) and a very good roasted tomatillo salsa.

We also had the arroz con leche for dessert, which was maravilloso! Perfecto para compartir, tambien.

I know I'll be back to The Little Chihuahua, and when I do I must get the plantain and black bean burrito. OMG... what a concept!

I think I'll skip the grilled mushroom quesadilla, though. It was fine, but paled in comparison to the other dishes I had. You know, why limit yourself to cheese and mushrooms when you have menu options like these?!?
author: Lorna M.

description: I am very picky with my Mexican food, but I can deal with this place. Everything is good, can't go wrong.
author: Holly H.

description: I love meat, but the black bean plantain burrito (vegetarian) is, hands down, one of the best burritos I've ever had. Five stars for that alone. The carnitas and carne asada burritos are also fantastic and the tostada shells are delicious. My girlfriend and I eat here at least once a week.
author: Torsten L.

description: Offers vegetarian options as well as other healthy options for otherwise pretty unhealthy food.  The portions are great. The staff is friendly and the service is fast.  Try it!
author: Kara C.

description: Underwhelmed by the food. The tacos were bland. The salsas were bland. Unmemorable. And the place was super cramped. Meh, I am in no hurry to get back there.
author: Nilu r.

description:
The Little Chihuahua is awesome!  It's very small so don't be afraid to wait around for a table if you're dining in.  

I recommend the Plantain/Black Bean Burrito.  Yum!  Oh, and go for brunch.  Do it.  I tried the Mexican French Toast, which was fantastic.
author: Robby N.

description:
Come here at 10am on a Sunday morning and you will receive great service and a kick-ass breakfast burrito! Salsa is fresh, ingredients are sustainable, and they compost! BUT, some of the clientele suck - royally.

My gf was mistaken for someone that works there because she is brown. So not ok. Why don't white people understand their institutionalized racist attitudes? Just because you see a brown person - even if you are "incredibly liberal and progressive" - you shouldn't automatically think they work in a restaurant, especially a Mexican restaurant. Take a look at the world around you, understand the dynamics of race and class, and don't assume a brown person works in food service because they are brown. It will change your whole life.
author: Stephanie P.

description: My friend and I decided to come here for one reason after treking around the city unsure of where to eat in our expanded "hood"... the plaintain and black bean burrito! Everything we had was delicious. The selection of the salsas is great,  the agua fresca is excellent (did a mix of a few flavors not a problem) and if you really feel like tequila, you can quench your appetite with a margie or some icecream. Love that they have "mexican" imported sodas as well, to curb your sugar craving or hangover. We also had the chicken taco salad good too. Second time I went I brought my aunt visiting out of town. It was simply out of this world in her eyes. So what that you have to wait and order in line. It's worth it. No posh here, just good eats and a cozy environment with communal tables if you can't find your own. Friendly helpful staff and good eats. Definitely one I will repeat. Food so pretty I had to take a photo...
author: Jennifer P.

description:
This is a wonderful little casual neighborhood restaurant.

Can get crowded, but take-away is super fast and equally delicious.

They are into the green/sustainable thing.  Which makes me feel good about eating here.  

So: delicious + cute neighborhood joint + guilt free = good times
author: Samantha W.

description:
I just finished two tacos, one carnitas and one shrimp.  Basically, "El Treif-O."  SOOOOOO GOOD!!!!!!!!!  I just needed to put some cheese on it to make it complete.

I live two blocks away and have made this my new default "too tired to cook" joint.  My favorite is the tostada salad, and I get either steak or shrimp in it because I am a classy lady.  Ha.  I also order mine minus tostada shell to avoid the gluten, but I bet it's just as good with the crispy bits.

Also, THE SALSA.  Ohhhhhh.  I like the tomatillo and the roasted tomato.  The latter is similar to Papalote's, but less spicy and more chunky.

Definitely my favorite taco joint in this neighborhood.  Not a lot of competition or anything around here, sure, but delish.
author: Polly Enmity P.

description: Alriiiight! An affordable Divisadero eating option I can get behind. No frills, really, just a little hipster taqueria situation with delicious burritos, chips, and many other delicious things on the menu that I wish I'd had time for. I enjoyed my carne asada burrito (and side slaw, nice touch!) and its slightly crispy tortilla enough that I'll probably return here pre- or post-Madrone/Independent. Downside? It's family-style seating, so you will be rubbing elbows with strangers. Also, I'm pretty sure a small child coughed all over the salsa bar when I was standing right next to it, though that's bad parenting and no fault of the restaurant's. But this ain't no NOPA. You get your burrito, and then you eat it. Simple.
author: Stefanie L.

description:
It tasted good, but the next day was brutal.  I suspect it was the chipotle salsa.

Ok I gave it a second shot and this time they passed with flying colors.
author: Robbie M.

description: This place is insanely good. It always seems to be packed and they make everything made to order as it should be. They have awesome salsa and the food comes with their homemade tortilas that are to die for. To top it off, the staff is super friendly.
author: Zeni B.

description: The best mexican food ever their garlic shrimp burrito was on point! The chips and salsa was delicious! I could eat this 3 times a day!
author: Donte B.

description:
With help from Yelp, I found myself a sweet brunch spot in between the Inner Richmond and the Mission. I don't think I knew what I was getting myself into.

I had glanced over the menu prior to arriving to this cozy joint. I had considered several choices on the menu but the mexican french toast looked extremely mmmm. 

And boy was I right...

Imagine: French toast, not with bread slices...but with FLOUR TORTILLAS.
Next. Imagine these french toast flour tortillas wrapped around
1. fried plaintains that make you say ay Dios mio a million times
PLUS
2. Niman Ranch smoked bacon that you make you say a thousand Hail Marys.

I'm sorry Father, for I have sinned. Mmm...and I'll be glad to do it over and over again. ;)
author: Ileana H.

description: I've eaten here many times, always satisfied! The people are friendly and  the environment is relaxed. Definitely one of the healthier, good burrito places in SF.
author: amber c.

description: Yummy place..always really crowded. Hard to find parking in the area. Good quality fresh food and many creative items on the menu. The salsa could be spicier. I love the name! Kind of expensive for taqueria.
author: Jennifer L.

description: Little Chihuahua is still delicious (fresh ingredients + great salsa bar) but after my taste test (garlic shrimp burrito vs. prawn burrito), I've decided that Papalote is the winner!
author: Wakako U.

description:
I recommend the grilled vegetable baby burrito on a spinach tortilla.  
Mmmm.
Sooo good. 

For some reason I never used to have the urge to go here.  Maybe the name deters me...

But, super good.  Tons of options to choose from.  Great salsa bar.
Totally recommend it.  This is right up there in one of my new favorites.
author: Andrea F.

description:
This place: still awesome. 

Just wanted to say I'm really getting into their burritos now, in addition to their enchiladas. Here's what makes their burritos so awesome: they are JUICY and SAUCY. The meat, vegetables and salsa make the burritos full of liquid goodness, which is so damn refreshing compared to a lot of standard taquerias where the texture you get, especially halfway through, is super dry with cheese/meat/avocado grease overwhelming. Here, every bite is juicy from the salsa and everything else. YUM.

While I balk at the idea of putting greens, like lettuce, in a burrito (yeah I'm talking to you, Pancho Villa), Little Chihuahua puts their cabbage/onion/cilantro salad inside their burritos. At first I was unsure if I approved or not, but now I think it's brilliant. It adds a really welcome crunch and more flavor to the burrito, improves the texture a whole lot.

Oh yeah, and they grill the hell out of their tortillas here, so it has that delicious Maillard reaction grilled tortilla flavor, with those lovely near-burnt dark brown splotches... Seriously, why the hell don't more places do this?

I LOVE YOU, LITTLE CHIHUAHUA.
author: Brendan R.

description: I had dinner here last night before heading to the movie theater.  It was pretty impromptu, so I didn't really have any time to do my normal Yelp scouring and so I didn't have a ton of expectations.  I had the chili verde chicken burrito.  The actual burrito was really tasty, and you get the option of covering it in sauce (!) which I love.  I wouldn't necessarily go out of my way to come here, but I'd not be upset to end up here again.  Maybe next time I'll get brave and try the plantain burrito, which also sounded delicious!
author: Wacey T.

description:
Oh maan...I wanted it to be better.  The chips were stale, my mushroom taco and rice were cold, the shrimp taco was lukewarm, and the place was a little...dirty.  Salsa encrusted to the walls, sticky tables.  I'm down with most of this stuff in a divey Mexican place (esp the stale chips and dirty part), but if I'm paying $4.25 for a taco and drinking a margarita made with agave wine, well, the expectations are a little higher.

On the up side, nice staff, super hot and super good veggie black refried beans, good (for lacking tequila) margaritas, and cool menu.  .
author: Pammy C.

description: Huge portions of yummy Mexican food at a reasonable price. There isn't a ton of seating but seems like just enough, and it's not dirty and has a cozy vibe that taquerias don't have. I'm a huge fan of taco/tostada salads but actually wasn't too impressed with the chicken in the one I got here. But the plantain burrito is definitely delicious and I can't wait to go back and try other items!
author: Richa A.

description: Cool little spot along Divisadero that offers pricey but good Mexican food.  I recommend the fried plantain and black bean burrito.
author: Chad S.

description: Though I'm a carnivore through and through, I always go vegetarian at Little Chihuahua. The plantain and black bean burrito is amazing, a lovely sweet and savory combo that is so filling and satisfying that I could eat only that for a day and be happy. When I need a little extra protein, I'll order the garlic shrimp burrito and it never disappoints. The salsa bar has some nice options and the chips are tasty. It's a small space that is usually pretty crowded so we'll usually order it to-go and beast it in Alamo Square. The walk makes you feel a little less guilty about the calories you consumed.
author: Meena M.

description:
Love it!!!

Fun, Funky Atmosphere.  Clean, and well designed.

Food is delicious!!!  Tried a bit of everything and it was all savory.  Not over priced-beers for 2.50, you can't beat that.

Sat there for hours with friends, and no one gave us a nasty look when our table was full of empty beer bottles, and we were a bit worse for wear.

Anyhow, highly recommend this lovely establishment.
author: Charley C.

description: this is seriously the best mex I have tried in the city. The tostada salads are delicious and everything has very fresh ingredients. just over the hill from the castro.
author: Matt H.

description:
This is a tough yelp to give. I liked the space, and the service was friendly, and after a night of dancing, my breakfast burrito hit the spot.

But demerits for not offering egg whites (the response to my inquiry - the eggs are already made), not warning me the ranchero sauce topping was pretty spicy (after I had asked for no chiles because I'm spicy averse) and for not listing on the menu there are bits of cheese sprinkled on top of the burrito (which is especially annoying, as I had asked for no cheese on the inside).

I expect more, and so should you.

Perhaps a star or two will be added after I try dinner. The tofu in a verde sauce does sound good.
author: Jason B.

description:
Perhaps my upbeat review has something to do with local burnout. I've been binging on Taqueria Cancun for about three years straight now. That came after about the same-length spell at Pancho Villa, and before that, ditto at Taqueria Farolito. Call me conservative.

Little Chihuahua isn't a taqueria-taqueria. Not in my book. You order at a counter, but the food is brought to your table. In this way, it's very much on par with Papalote, which I like, but have recently grown tired of.

Little Chihuahua hits upon whatever it is that makes Papalote good, but ups the ante. LC goes to 11, basically.

Warm and plentiful chips, at least four (maybe five?) varieties of delicious salsa (I'm normally not crazy about chipotle salsa, but LC's rocks!). The freshest, most perfectly grilled meats (Tara had carne asada and I pollo asado). And our tacos came with no cheese, which was odd at first, but ultimately okay.

Points off for the orange-juice-based margarita (seriously, San Francisco -- what's up with that shite?). Somehow it managed to be delicious and refreshing regardless.

All in all, a welcome edition to the maelstrom that is Mexican food in this city.
author: Jeff H.

description: My wife had the nachos and is suffering from food poisoning. She was unable to sleep all night and had diarrhea and was vomitting all night.
author: Vinod K.

description: Didn't think this place was that great-carne asada taco was greasy. Shrimp taco was alright. Best thing were the lighter thinner tortilla chips and the refried beans...otherwise would go to other Mexican restaurants in the mission.
author: Amy S.

description:
This is the only mexican place that doesn't make me feel sick after gorging on a burrito. You have not lived life if you haven't tried their garlic shrimp burrito- never overloaded with sour cream or guac, just fresh avocado, salsa, and delicious grilled shrimp. Their salsa bar is also amazing. They have a total of 6 (I believe?) different salsas- the pico is my favorite, 
Downside: full of hipsters and you can't save yourself a table before ordering, so sometimes you have to stand around awkwardly waiting for someone to leave- best to grab take out.
author: Robin L.

description: Veggies try the Black Bean and Plantain Burrito...Then there's the Garlic Shrimp or the super steak that are all 5 stars.
author: Ryan L.

description: For what it is (a taqueria, more or less), it's perfect! Delicious & affordable food. Mouth-watering salsas on the salsa bar.
author: Lynn m.

description: Nice atmosphere. Kind of a college scene feel. Friendly staff. Reviews were very complimentary so we sought out after playing in Alamo Park with kids. High expectations. Burrittos were Ok. Were sampled 7, 5 different types and they were not great and everyone was underwhelmed given the high Yelp reviews. Fine if you are close for a walk in but no reason to  search it out.
author: Martin D.

description:
Oh Little Chi Chi!  What happened?  

I haven't visited you in months, although I had dreams from time to time about your fried plantain burrito...  And now I come back to what?  A big pile of lukewarm "meh", complete with muddled flavors and much to my dismay, charred plantains.  Nothing like I remember.  This is so disappointing, as I'm a big fan of consistency, when it comes to restaurants.

I'll give you another chance and come back to try your weekend brunch menu, which I've heard good things about.  But if that's also bad, we're through.
author: LaSha G.

description: Fresh ingredients and sustainable meats are a hallmark at this little shop. I usually get the their pollo or carne asada burrito. Good atmosphere for the price. Having Pacifico on tap isn't that bad either. Recommend their Aguas Fresca.
author: Renard I.

description:
I had driven in front of this place a million times and somehow missed it; I think The Page next door has such a great store front that this place just fades into the scenery. It is a tiny, hole-in-the-wall place that is essentially a deluxe taqueria. 

You can order your food for there or to go; if you want to eat at the nice wooden tables there, be prepared for a wait. They will hold your food for you until you find a seat and will then bring it out when you're ready. 

The food itself is a large step up in quality from the the delicious yet slightly divey taqueria's in the Mission that I love to frequent. My taco salad had mixed greens and mango salsa; it was incredible.

I was a big fan and look forward to going back soon to try something else.
author: Kara A.

description:
Mmmm, the plantain and black bean burrito. SO GOOD! I'm also a big fan of the garlic shrimp burrito and the nachos with carnitas.

We stumbled on this place after moving in 2 blocks away, and smelling something delicious wafting down the street. Little Chihuahua was an instant winner for us. They're awesome for pick-up orders. Fast, accurate, and consistent.

Make sure you hit the salsa bar on your way out! Their roasted tomato salsa is delicious.

Quick and friendly service, cute interior, take-out, and are a great neighborhood spot. (Still want to check out the location in Noe, but I'm sure it kicks ass too!)
author: T T.

description:
My gf and I came back here for the second time because we were craving Mexican food on a Saturday morning and couldn't think of anywhere else to go.

Once again they delivered on their food. I got the carne asada enchiladas with red sauce and refried beans and rice. The carne asada was tender and well marinated. The beans and rice of good texture and consistency. My gf got the garlic shrimp burrito, which was loaded with a ton of shrimp that were well flavored with sauteed garlic. Both of the portions were really big, tasty, and filling. Oh yeah, they also have about six different salsa's to pick from. You can never have enough salsa!

This establishment is a little on the small side though, really small. The only complaint I have about this place is when people bring large parties here and camp out forever. Have some common courtesy to eat quickly and leave so other peeps can have a seat too. Other than that, the food is great and worth trying.
author: Gary T.

description:
the icing on that cake was the moment i saw a little chihuahua tied up out front peering in.

i had the breakfast burrito, with no additions. it was delicious, and i only ate half. love the salsa bar and complimentary chips.

remember to bus your  dishes!
author: Ameer N.

description: I've been here twice and it's been fantastic both times. The first time I ordered a regular burrito and had some fried plantains my friend ordered for his burrito ( he got them on the side). These were surprisingly delicious, especially for a burrito, and I was immediately impressed. The menu is fresh and relatively simple. The prices are fair, especially for the area. And the staff is very friendly. I enjoy coming here because it has a homey/ comfortable feel, where you share tables with your neighbors and are served food on colorful plates, with even more brightly colored cuisine.
author: Hannah B.

description:
Big dreams for a little doggy:

Although they have the most rustic guacamole and Tamarind flavored Jarritos in the yay area, el Chi-Wa-Wa Pequeno wont change the way you think about Borat or burritos.

But hey, we only live once, and ze Chihuahua harbors a casual yet magical fiesta atmosphere similar to the likes of Paris Hilton. So if your feigning for some shake and bake in your mouth, grab a fellow cowboy walk down to the Davizadero and enjoy the fuego.
author: Noah W.

description:
Yesterday, I was lounging on the beach in Cozumel with half of the Tampa Bay Rays lathering me with coconut sunblock and begging me to tell them which one was a better kisser.

Between passionate stomach-swooning embraces and unlimited pina colada refills (at the Major League's expense), my baseball players told me they liked their ladies chunky and demanded that I up my caloric intake to 6,000 calories a day.

And then I woke up.  Very much sober, very much alone, and very ready to eat my feelings.

During this year's World Series, I've watched more baseball than ever.  Sure, this is only because my best friend's brother is keeping the bench warm for one of the teams, but I've still become a big "lovetheteamuntiltheytradehimagain" fan.  Note: there aren't as many touchdowns as I'd like, and the players seem to whine a little when they get hit in the face by 95 mph fastballs, but for the most part, I'm enjoying my new pasttime.

Mesmerized by last night's game at The Page (we had narrowly escaped Kezar Pub due to an unhealthy passiveRays to aggressivePhilly fan ratio), the best friend and I couldn't take our eyes off the screen - the rain was pouring down on those gorgeous specimens of athletic manmeat and I was transported back to my steamy daydream and hankering for some grub.

Enter:  Little Chihuahua, conveniently next door to The Page, and with an "order & pay now, come back in a bit" method that's unbeatable.

Friendly service, authentic food, and great atmosphere.  What a terrific hole-in-the-wall.

15 minutes and a free bag of chips later, we were back at The Page, devouring our huge helping of chicken nachos (topped with an abundance of delicious guacamole), and enjoying our newly-discovered eye candy - err...professional sport.
author: Janney B.

description:
Don't know what's appealing about the name the Little Chihuahua.  I mean...years ago I bought a Rotweiller puppy from a kid in Rosarito for five bucks, and that was after heavy negotiating and bartering.  Although Rosie (that's what I named her) ended up getting put up for adoption in the states because I couldn't have her in the apartment I moved into, I always joked about having saved her from becoming a burrito.  Hence, the name of the burrito joint having the name of a dog in it, not so appealing to me....

But I digress.  Loco Taco, the place before here sucked.  So, I was pumped just to have another burrito shop I could walk to.  And you know what?  It doesn't suck.  It's actually pretty tasty, and they even offer a small burrito for those of us who either a) cant finish a large burrito or b) don't want to admit to being able to finish a large burrito.  Either way, their products are fresh, Neiman Ranch beef, and a much cooler vibe inside.  So...although I might have chosen some other name in which to place on my sign...a good burrito is a good burrito...and this is a good burrito.
author: Lauren F.

description: Yum Yum Yum!  Chilaquiles and beer - breakfast of champions.  Do it, you won't regret it.
author: Jenny K.

description: I absolutely love the tortilla soup here! The warm salsa chips that come with every order(happily refilled) and the tasty salsa bar that is self-served. This place is adorable. The people who work there are super friendly and chill(cute too!) and informative. Vegetarian rice and beans. damn good. Its causal, clean, and cozy. I would totally be down if some babe brought me here on a date. Who doesn't look good eating a cheesy  burrito? If the chihuahua is in your thoughts, follow it. let it lead you to blissful tastes and a happy atmosphere.
author: Shea G.

description:
It automatically gets two stars for serving organic, local and sustainable meats and veggies.

Major Wins:
     * Meats marinated in the same way as the whole in the wall taqueries would do it. However, the cows ate grass, the chickens roamed free and the pigs lived the life a pig would enjoy =op
      * They offer beer, sangria as well as homemade Horchata
      * It's taqueria style (order at the counter), but you can stay and dine

Great alternative when Nopalito tells you there's a 2.5 hour wait!!
author: Rana A.

description: If you are looking for spice, flavor and taste in ur food..this is not the place ..been here two times tried butritos, tostada and soup ..bland at many level .. the chips are free but dont feel fresh.
author: Y U.

description:
As a kid, I hated Mexican food.  Then I started drinking margaritas.

The Little Chihuahua doesn't serve margaritas.  The Little Chihuahua doesn't even serve chihuahuas.  Bummer, right?  Because chihuahuas are pretty useless if you can't eat 'em.  Even with these two black marks against it, the Little Chihuahua isn't half bad.  The service is quick, and the food is just fancy enough to justify its price.  I'm not sure if this is clear, but in addition to being bigoted against little dogs, I'm also cheap.  Overall, it's a welcome addition to the neighborhood (unlike my new upstairs neighbors, who I am fairly certain are elephants.  Which is weird, because I can't figure out how elephants can pay rent in San Francisco.  Maybe circus performers make more than I thought?  Questions like that keep me up at night.)
author: Jess T.

description: Good little Mexican place in the neighborhood - delicious salmon taco and great salsa bar. The chips were great but the guac was a-ok. Heard great reviews of the chicken tortilla soup and mushroom taco. Self-service;  busy on weekend evenings but the tables turn pretty quick.
author: Shweta V.

description:
Feels local, interesting interior/artwork, cheap beer, good product, free salsa bar with a good selection of heat and flavors and overall the food it tasty.

With its popularity, it can get crowded although turn over is good. It can also get a bit noisy inside if you're there for a more than grab, eat and go. 

And who can't resist the name?
author: Dave P.

description: This place makes a solid burrito. Definitely recommend.
author: Ari M.

description:
Since my friend pretty much lives next door at the Page, it's a wonder I've yet to try this.  Now, I'm generally not a fan of Mexican food -- it agrees with neither my palate nor my digestive system -- but this place rocked my world.

Maybe it was the half dozen beers I had prior to coming here, maybe it was the other activities I partook before that -- but the food here was absolutely delicious.  I had the green chile chicken enchiladas with more green sauce on top.  It was tasty tasty tasty.  The rice wasn't dry, the enchiladas didn't disintegrate on contact, and the refried beans didn't taste like they'd been sitting out all day (all reasons why I generally avoid Mexican food).  

The agua fresca was also delicious -- I had both the watermelon and the strawberry.  Watermelon wins.  In fact, the only complaint I could think of is that the water out of the water cooler tasted rank.  Rank - like my camelback tastes if I leave water in there for a few weeks.

Other than that one thing -- the place is a big hit.
author: Eugene F.

description:
A taqueria with a bit more of a healthier, slow food, upscale bent than the typical Mission benchmark.

Their take on the burrito is fantastic. It features Niman Ranch meats cooked to order (the carnitas is excellent), a warm-and-flaky tortilla, and super fresh ingredients. You bite into it and it's just heaven without overly relying on cheese / guac / sour cream to get there. It is a normal size, so don't expect 3 pounds of rice and a tablecloth-sized and -tasting wrap. They are about quality over quantity.

I love the veggie burrito. The chef sautes the fresh veggies while you wait.. even does the ignite-the-pan-oil flambe flip move to give them a nice char. You won't even miss the meat. Major props for doing that one right and not just as an afterthought.

Other highlights include the super healthy, light and delicious tortilla soup. I enjoy the horchata, not the best on the planet but made fresh daily with a nice little grit to it. Fine little beer and wine selection too, stuff I actually drink.

But watch out, the tacos were really disappointing. Just a pile of meat on some cabbage. High quality meat, but very mildly seasoned and quite bland. And with the notable exception of the super fresh pico de gallo, the salsas were also bland. And I don't mean I need them to be hot and spicy, but they just lacked flavor, which was surprising given the quality of the ingredients.

But if you're careful about what you order, this can be a great place when you're in the mood for potentially healthier Mexican made with high-grade ingredients. Nice cozy little interior too.

UPDATE: The Mexican French Toast at brunch is genius. Grilled tortilla dipped in french toast batter with Niman Ranch bacon, plantains and homemade syrup.
author: Tom L.

description:
Two dollar beers.  Let me repeat, TWO DOLLAR DRAFT BEERS.  Nope, this isn't the bean bag, and nope they wont hand you a plastic cup.  

I enjoyed my time at the little chihuahua this evening.  The place seems clean, and folks working there are friendly.  

The only downside is the chairs.  Dude, my ass is killing me after 2 hours drinking beers, eating nachos, and sitting in those damn hard chairs.
author: jack p.

description:
I ordered a shrimp taco "to-go". 
When I got home and unwrapped my taco, the shrimp was completely undercooked.  It was almost raw!  I had to throw it away. 

WTF? How is it possible to under cook shrimp?  It takes like 1 minute to cook it on a grill.  I don't know......maybe it's how chihuahuas prefer their shrimp.
author: Kirill E.

description:
Yes, it's finally here: The Yuppie Burrito.

When I walked in tonight, there was a white guy, an asian guy, and a mexican guy behind the counter, as though setting the pretext for some kind of joke. But this new addition to Divis is no laughing matter.

The Little Chihuahua takes the standards of a generic Mission taqueria -- burritos, tacos, quesadillas, etc. -- and infuses them with all the upwardly-mobile love that a Chimay-drinking, blog-reading, Buring-Man-attending San Franciscan can appreciate. 

The steak is not a dubious third-rate meat-like substance from an undisclosed plant in outer Michigan; it's fresh from the grass-fed bovine specimens of Neiman Ranch. Ditto with the chicken -- I can't remember which Local and Organic farm it came from, but rest assured that it is decidedly Local and Organic. They have a tofu verde option as well, which I haven't had yet, but I'm sure it meets only the highest ethical standards of tofu stewardship.

Their burritos get high marks. They even have a Baby Burrito option for a dollar less than the standard one; for someone who often faces the full-after-two-thirds-but-eats-the-last-third-anyway dilemma when ordering a burrito, this comes as a godsend.

Their tacos fall shorter; rather than a burrito in miniature, they place upon your two soft tortillas nothing but a tartly-dressed cabbage salad, a choice of meat, and a smattering of pico de gallo salsa. Your money is best spent on other choices.

Salsa options aren't lacking -- they have five different choices ranging in style and spiciness -- but nor are they remarkable. Most of them lack flavor or savoriness; I never thought I'd call a salsa bland, let alone five of them, but that's exactly what they are.

The ambiance is clean, bright, and slightly sterile. Fortunately, that means that the place feels decidedly clean and sanitary, especially for a taqueria. Unfortuately, it's a less-than-cozy place to take refuge on a cold San Francisco night.

As the only Mexican place on Divisadero, Little Chihuahua serves its neighborhood well. I intend to return for many a burrito more, and eagerly await the day they improve their salsa.
author: Christian P.

description: Plantain burrito= Happy tummy. Seriously this place is such a SF gem. I had never had a plantain burrito, now I bring all my visiting tourists to try this place. The food is always enough and never too expensive and I have never met a rude or condescending staff member here, even when I change an order. In addition, the sangria is great and cheap! Insider tip: Grab a plantain burrito and add chicken...incredible!
author: Logan R.

description:
The Little Chihuaua is pretty much The Little Awesome.  It's not very expensive, the food is delicious, and if you live near there, it's close by.

I don't know who among the reviewing public said that it's a formal restaurant.  Unless there's a martini bar hidden in the basement that I'm not aware of, that couldn't be farther from the truth.  The dude who took my order was wearing a Tool t-shirt.

The closest thing to a complaint I might have is that they play really long songs about electric socks.  That was a little weird.
author: Mike T.

description:
What a tremendous improvement over previous occupants of this address.  The food is flavorful, the staff friendly and knowledgeable, and they have really great salsas.  Almost any taqueria will have the requisite salsa cart, but you can tell these salsas are put together with love.

Would get five stars if it were not for the cheesy decor.  

Oh, I got one word- pozole.  Absolutely the best pozole I've ever eaten.
author: Cheezy P.

description:
I have longed for great Mexican in the neighborhood and wish that I had come here sooner. It used to be another place which is why I stayed away.

This place is delicious, lots of veggie options, great drink selection and super flavorful and high quality sauces, beans and cheeses. I love me some Guacamole Enchiladas!

It will be hard for me to not eat here every week. *yum*yum*yum*
author: K B.

description:
I'd been craving some Mexican food lately.  A big burrito of carnitas, full of all sorts of bad goodness for your cholesterol and probably arteries.  My friend was coming up to the City and wanted to grab dinner.  "You up for Mexican?  I've been craving it.  Or do you have any suggestions??"  She didn't and said Mexican was ok.

I was on Yelp looking up places and came across this place.  I downloaded the menu and I was drooling as I was reading it.  Plus it didn't sound greasy and fatty.  The pics looked cute and it was reasonably priced.  I sent her a text saying we should go to the Little Chihuahua.  She said "Can we sit down there?"  I said "Yes, it's The Frijolito in W-Ville, you can sit down, or get it to go.  Except it looks better!"  

She picked me up and said "I'm starving.  I'm sorta craving Indian right now ..."  Blah, whatever.  She said Mexican was ok, so there's no going back!!  We arrived and she got a salad and I decided to be good and get a regular burrito of carne asada on a spinach tortilla, with veg black beans (not re-fried) with no cheese, no guac and no sour cream.  I really wanted carnitas, but I figured fried pork is something I could not order for once.  I also got an awesome horchata.  I love those things.  So freakin' yummy.  Our food came out and the regular burrito was big!  Her salad was yummy looking and we were both happy kids.  Sadly, I ate the whole freakin' burrito, but it was good.  As other folks have said, it wasn't greasy so that's nice.  My friend said "Ok, you were right about the place, it's good and better than the Frijolito."

When we had arrived, there was only one other guy in the place.  It was about 6pm on a Thursday, so people were still heading home.  By the time we were finished eating, the placed had filled up.  There are about 10 tables or so, all enough for 2-4 people to sit.  It was nice seeing a dad out with his daughter who was reaching up to eat her cheese quesadilla from her chair.  At another table, a family of 4 was sitting down for dinner.  It was really refreshing to see parents out with their kids having dinner, talking with them.  You don't see that as much anymore.  

It's a nice little place, borderline hole in the wall, but super cute inside.  The service was pretty quick and you bus your own table when you're finished.  I'll definitely be back, but to stuff my face with a regular burrito of carnitas, cheese, guac, sour cream and re-fried beans on the highest calorie tortilla they have!!  I also saw one of their specials I think when ordered was arroz con leche.  Totally reminded me of my grandma when I was young and she would make it for me when I had a craving.  I was so tempted to try it.  A must next time when I'm dying for some comfort food.  They also had something up about homemade cupcakes ... *drool*.

Great place to stop if you're in the Lower Haight or heading home out towards the Park as it's just off the Haight 71 bus line.  I wish this place was closer to my hood.  

Thanks Little Chihuahua!!!
author: imelda j.

description:
I love this place but never could remember the name until just recently. This place has the best tortilla soup. It hits the spot every darn time I come here. Again not 5 stars worthy due to lack of seating on a weekend night. Sometimes you have to stand and wait for a table for 30 minutes. No fun.

I say come on a weekday or order to go. Yummy salsas and chips too if you are into that kind of thing.
author: Ali K.

description: I'm used to the authentic taco experience of the Mission so I came here fully expecting a trendy americanized taco experience. I was pleasantly surprised but the experience did not jump out at me. I don't think I'll return.
author: Andrew H.

description: I really really like the green chili tofu burrito  - not authentic mexican but so good. Great salsa bar too (roasted tomato and tomatillo salsas, yum)
author: tara s.

description:
The best Mexican food I've had in this price category.  So cheap, so good.  I mean where else can you get a huge fried plantain and black bean burrito for less than ten bucks?  

Be warned, though... the secret is out.  This place can be packed on weekends and it's so loud that you kinda have to scream over the table.
author: Ryan L.

description:
This is my go-to place when it's Friday night & it's been a long week at work and I'm tired & all I want is for someone else to cook for me. Favorites are the guacamole enchilada plate & the amazing fried plantain & black bean burrito. Love the salsa bar--especially the chipotle salsa. 
Really friendly service & comfy atmosphere.
author: Wan T.

description:
The Little Chihuahua, like its predecessor Loco Taco, is disappointing. When you walk in, you figure the place will be good. But the food's just all right, and every time you come, you forget just how all right it is--it's right in the middle of all right, mediocre. It is slightly better than Loco Taco was, and the pico de gallo tastes really fresh, but if you're expecting anything really good, don't get your hopes up.

I live pretty close to this place, so I sometimes come because I'm just lazy. But if you're willing to walk a little, there's always Zona Rosa in the Upper Haight.

For the Divis old schoolers out there, this is also the former location of L-Rico, possibly the worst of the three incarnations of this place (at least since I moved to SF in 2003). But I did like L-Rico's setup better.

GRATUITOUS-MEAT ALERT:  They use bacon in their refried and whole pinto beans.  If you don't want to eat pig corpses, get black beans.

UPDATE:  4/21/08
==============

So this place is slowly growing on me.  The food still isn't anything spectacular, and if I'm not feeling lazy, I'll walk up Haight Street to Zona Rosa or all the way over to that place on Fulton for a good burrito, but I don't mind coming in here as much as I did when it first opened.  The owner is really nice, as is everyone else who works the register.

UPDATE:  9/16/08
==============

I'm dropping The Little Chihuahua down to two stars again because I just realized that it's completely wheelchair inaccessible.  I will now go through the rest of my reviews and dock a star from each business that is in violation of federal law (the ADA).  All businesses should be accessible to everyone, including people who use wheelchairs.
author: John S.

description: Great food (their french toast and heuvos rancheros are both delicious); salsa bar is fresh/good selection; and the best part...despite the fact it was 10:30am on a Saturday there was absolutely no line. Perfect place to go for breakfast :)
author: Kimya P.

description: I know, I know, I always give 5 stars but I only review when I like something.  A lot!  Little Chihuahua is a neighborhood spot for us and after a long weekend camping, my man and I came here for dinner last night.  The food  was SO good.  As always. It's affordable, high quality and delicious!
author: Lexi F.

description:
CHI HUA WOW! You're not walking into your average taqueria...
Carnitas, cooked so slowly and tenderly
Camarones, changed to Clean Fish Company, much much better. (they saw that something was wrong, and made it better, smart company is my company!) 
Carne Asada, Niman ranch chunks of flavor 
Chile Verde, made on the day it enters your hungry belly
Chilequiles, served at brunch
Chips, from a little place in sonoma! Thin, crispy, salty. que rico! 

All natural, healthy, mexican style delicioso.
author: Daniella B.

description:
After watching the Dodgers win the NLDS by sweeping the Cardinals at a nearby bar, it was time for some real food.  Mexican sounded just right, so my friend and I walked over to this place.  Good call, Ronnie.

I had my heat set on a good ol' fashioned combo meal, and I wasn't disappointed here. 2 chicken enchiladas, rice and some black beans to more specific.  The food was flavorful and the serving size was ample.  I also had a horchata....muy bien. 

The place isn't too big, only a few tables, but it's nice and tidy.  The staff was friendly, and the food came out quick. 

I'm a fan.
author: Charles R.

description:
Mmmm. I have now found the spot for that post-night-of-drinking brunch in this 'hood. Who knew that we would actually beat the crowds by going at noon on a Sunday??? Guess we were actually getting an earlier start to the day than most (by 1pm, the place was packed). 

I had the breakfast tacos. Completely hit the spot. And even more perfect with some of the great salsas they have to choose from. 

Almost looking forward to my next hangover!
author: Jen N.

description: If you like savory and a bit of sweet - try the Fried Plantain Burrito. It was delicious ~ a great combination of flavors, I'm still thinking about it.
author: Cathy K.

description: Yummy burritos! The ingredients are organic, so I thought it'd be expensive but the prices were very reasonable. (I paid under $10 for my burrito.) They pass out free chips and salsa (freshly made). They have an open salsa bar for those who love lots of salsa with their Mexican.
author: Johnna K.

description:
6 words: Black Bean and Fried Plantain Burrito.  Delicious.  My only couple knocks on my several times there are:
1) can get quite crowded and hard to find a place to sit
2) the consistency of the plantains seems to waiver - ie: sometimes they're soft, browner and sweeter, sometimes they're harder, whiter/yellower and blander
Overall though, good vibe, friendly peeps, good aesthetic but definitely in need of a larger space!!  :)
author: David M.

description:
This place is making the same mistakes as the last place that was in that spot. ie, not taking cues from the city which has basically perfected the taqueria. Lordy lordy I wish Castillito or Farolito would move into that spot. This neighborhood desperately needs a real SF Taqueria. This yuppie version of mexican food is laughable. I just paid 11 bucks for a chicken tostada salad with what tasted like canned black beans, no sour cream, nearly invisible cheese and an insulting amount of chicken. That was my third and final try to find something to  look forward to from the menu. Three strikes.

I predict fast failure here, just like I predicted fast failure for Taco Loco.

JUST COPY OTHER GREAT SF TAQUERIAS!. There are dozens from which to choose. IF IT AIN'T BROKE DON'T FIX IT!
author: merkley m.

description: The salsa bar was amazing!  The tortilla soup was ok but I wouldn't order it again.  The chicken was big chunks of fatty pieces of mixed white and dark meat.  I am more a fan of the shredded chicken breast in tortilla soup.  The ambiance was fun and the people were super nice but I think I will keep looking for my go to spot for Mexican food.
author: Vanessa L.

description:
Struck by a sudden hankering for some Mexican, yet feeling too sluggish to schlep all the way down to the Mission, I decided to finally check out the tiny pup place.

Emerging from the groggy fog, I was greeted by a cozy, homey interior; the carved tables and chairs provided a hint of kitsch, while the remainder of the space was decorated rather modestly.  No stray piñatas or sombreros or maracas here, thankfully.  

As per suggestion of previous yelpers, I ended up ordering the fried plantain and black bean burrito, which is accompanied by a springy mound of cabbage salad. On a reckless whim, I also ordered one of their "Agave Wine" margaritas, which I would describe as a sort of fresh fruit tequila sunrise.  Yum. Oh, and did I mention every order comes with a complementary bowl of delicate white corn chips?  And, as in any well-equipped taqueria, there's a salsa bar, out of which I would definitely recommend the tomatillo sauce.
Since I usually have a rather meager appetite, I decided to splitting the burrito with my girlfriend.  But as I neared my final bites, I eyed her remaining portion with jealousy...

Next time, I made sure to order my own burrito.  

If there's any spare stomach space remaining afterwards, the cinnamon-spiced rice pudding topped with liquored up raisins or the spicy chocolate cup cakes are a sweet way to end the evening.
author: Zia L.

description:
I finally, finally found my stride with this place. Uusally, when I want a burrito, I put the iPod on and walk over to Papalote, but once I found out this place had a plantains burrito, I knew it was my destiny to try it. It's really good, and their refried beans are nice and lardy (they taste better, freaks, trust me!) and while I rarely order carne asada, I will gladly get it here. It's super flavorful.  

My only complaint is the plantains are sometimes under-done. I realize, it's not my mom's house, we can't wait for her to lovingly and patiently make them, but still -- if you kept them going a little longer, they would be even better.
author: Maria D.

description: I usually love the food but the last 3 TIMES I ordered, they have messed up on my order!  Their food is fresh and very good but come on... How many times do they have to mess up on a very simple order.  I will not go back even though I really love the plantain burrito.
author: Ammala B.

description:
This is the restaurant that inspired me to join Yelp.

It's just that good.

Not only is it probably the best burrito *ever* (in a city full of 'best burrito's *ever*'), the staff is great, the place is clean, AND they use sustainably & kindly raised meat products.

Amazing!
(and, while you're there, check out Yoga Garden next)
author: Kendra C.

description:
The people are very friendly, the salsa and chips excellent, and the meat delicious.  Great place to take a friend out to a quick lunch in the afternoons, when it's not as crowded.  

Do yourself a favor and order a plantain and steak burrito.
author: Lynn N.

description: We walked into Green Chili Kitchen on Sunday morning and after doing a quick survey, we decided that we didn't want to wait 30-45 minutes for a sit down space. My friends suggested the Little Chihuahua. Hungry and desperate, I complied with them and made the trek down Divis. I was pleasantly surprised. The food was much more authentic than that of CGK and they had delicious and inexpensive offerings for brunch. I have regrets that I didn't get the breakfast burrito...after sampling it off my friend's plate I decided that I am coming back for it next weekend!
author: Mimi T.

description:
I thought for some reason, I had written a review for this place already! Oops! Well, here is my belated review. 

We've taken-out and dined -in on many occasions. I've had burritos, tacos and most recently the enchiladas(one tofu, one cheese). The plates, I think, are the way to go. Comes with beans and rice. And everything tastes very fresh and clean. 

Salsa bar to the side and plenty of jalapenos for this girl who can't get enough of the heat! Hey, I'm Korean! I came out of the womb eating kim-chee! 

But if you get a burrito, I'd opt for the "baby". The regular is HUGE! It's about the size of a baby! Maybe they should switch those names around...
author: Caroline C.

description:
Went here for diner. I had a carne asade steak super burrito. When I received my burrito, I began the inspection. The first thing to notice is that there is not very much rice so you should only get filled up on main content. 

The taste of the food is kind of like Chipotle. The prices are a little high, $7.85 for the super burrito, but 50 cents for the carne asade steak. 

Other than that, this place wasn't all that unique.
author: Andrew Y.

description:
I'm conflicted. There is nothing wrong with this place. I mean the staff are very nice, the food is fresh and drinks arent expensive. Its just that every time I come here I'm just not all that pumped up about what I'm eating. I have eaten here probably..6 times? 

I've had the chicken burrito-GCK'S chicken is 10x better and the flavors just werent right to me. I had the brunch tacos, which were crazy crunchy (not the good kind) while my potatoes were not spiced at all and the bfs were over over spiced. Recently, I had the garlic, shrimp burrito, which again, while not bad, lacked oomph and did not provide me with much excitement. 

I like their ideas and the place is cute, its just that food-wise, I think there are better options for this kind of food. At least for MY taste buds--a lot of my friends really like it.
author: Afton T.

description:
This place is fantastic! The food is good quality, large helpings, affordable, and TASTY. You rarely have to season anything. We love the brunch. I believe I have tasted everything on the menu and it is all really good. 

There are three items I recommend you try: 
The Mexican French Toast for brunch
The Plantain Burrito
The Garlic Shrimp Burrito

I love my Mexican food fresh. I hate when it is really greasy and I feel weighed down after. If this is the style you like you will love this place.
author: Annalee H.

description: After living in the area for almost a year I finally went to try Little Chihuahua on Cinco de Mayo. Bad call. Line out the door. I waited it out and boy was it worth it. I got the plantain burrito. It was delicious and just the right size, big enough for dinner today and lunch the next day. Every burrito should be this big. The line moved pretty fast, but when I came up to the register to place my order the cashier was unnecessarily snappy with me. I asked what meat comes with the burrito. He looked at me like I was crazy and said none. After a pause he said the plantain is instead of meat. How was I supposed to know?
author: Polina S.

description: One of the best taco/burrito spots I've been too.... I usually prefer the truck!
author: baretta v.

description:
Organic, Organic Organic....what else is there to say. 


Owners Background: He brings in allot of experience (Over saw all food at Chevy's Restaurants) I know that may not be saying much...but you have to like where he is aiming which is high quality food that is affordable.

The burrito was damn good...I was reluctant at first try a burrito with this cabbage...I must say it added great zest to it. If you had the homemade chipotle...wow!

I look forward to seeing the place grow...it has only been open a couple of weeks so you can tell he's trying out new things. Give it sometime and It will be a favorite of yours as well!
author: Jennifer N.

description:
Fantastic experience.

If you want to eat good Mexican food and leave feeling  oddly virtuous and not bloated, come here.

Loved the Tostada soup with organic chicken. The  broth was full of flavor and nicely spicy. I chased down the square white pieces of queso fresco in the generously portioned bowl once I realized that they were little cubes of heaven. For my entree I had the guac enchiladas with tofu while the bf splurged on the cheese version. We ended up sharing and it was perfect. They were unlike any enchiladas I've had with hearty toothsome corn tortillas and less grease than most. Maybe even no grease. When you cut down on unidentifiable oils, you can really enjoy the cheese with a clear conscience.  The sauce was great, and everything tasted really fresh. 

I also fell in love with the watermelon aqua fresca.

You bus your own tables here which reminded me of my university co-op days, and if you can get over that and the loud, strident "pseudo-intellectual issues as foreplay" (get a room!) conversations about eco-footprints and sustainable lifestyles by enviro-horny hipsters at the neighboring tables, and just focus on the nourishing yet taste-bud satisfying properties of the food, you'll leave happy.
author: lyra l.

description: Had the plantain burrito as I love plantains and eat it whenever I can, Carribian, Ethic Restaurants around etc. but my burrito was a dissapointment with a hard undercooked tasteless plantains in the middle. I could barely finish half and will most likely not go back.  Also the place does not seem as "clean" as places I nomally like to go to, but I'm a clean freak so that could be it. Guess I'll stick to the Mission for awesome Mexican food. (not that a burrito is Mexican : )
author: Beth P.

description:
I'm addicted to this place and lately since i found it (2 blocks from my place in the castro)  I have not gone to any other Mexican restaurant
First off ---- fresh , organic ingredients and  they use Neiman Ranch beef and the organic chicken( I forgot the name of.)  the salsas are delicious!

also they ask if you want the vegetarian black beans ----where as some places have no idea what you're talking about if you ask if the beans are made in lard or not.

i love this place. it'll be a while before i go anywhere else.
the people that own it are cool too.
author: Barb L.

description: This place is crowded for a reason. Tasty food at reasonable prices. Free chips and great salsa bar are icing on the cake. Since my favorite 5 star Mexican place closed years ago, the hunt has been on for a replacement. Nothing has come close. Until now. The plantain burrito is the sh*t. My fat ass thanks you, Little Chihuahua.
author: Presto G.

description:
Fresh organic produce, grass fed beef, free range chicken, subtle seasoning, 3 premium beers on tap, imported and Cal wines -- this is not typical mexican fare.  The place is clean and comfortable.

I've had the shrimp tostada salad, carnitas burrito, and the enchalades.  I found both the salad and enchalades on the mark, but I prefer my burrito to be juicier, cheesier, and spicer.

My 3 year old daughter also endorses the food and service.

This is a significant upgrade for this neighborhood and I wish them lots of success.
author: David N.

description:
I ate at The Little Chihuahua two nights ago and I am still fantasizing about the shrimp tacos and guacamole there. Great food. The emphasis on smallness in the name carries over into the space- it ain't big. They don't seem to have a liquor license, but the agave wine margaritas were damn tasty, and probably resulted in a better behaved Angie at the end of the evening. 

As a side note,  there is a picture of what appears to be a transvestite Satan on one of the walls. If anyone can explain this Prince(ss) of Darkness to me, I would be much obliged.
author: Angie R.

description: It was good, it was fresh, but there wasn't a lot of flavor in our food. It was good comfort mexican but it was just kind of lacking in anything to make it stand out. Portions are pretty big though, overflowing tacos, 2 plus rice and beans is enough to feed a very hungry girl. I was really not digging the atmosphere. It was kind of dirty (I don't mean hipster dirty, I mean food on the floor, and the bus-your-own-table clean up area was nasty and poorly lit, so people just kind of let it get messier and messier later into the night). It's a fine place to stop in but in a city with so many places to get delicious tacos, I don't think I'd go again. For me the hygiene of the place was just really sketchy.
author: Cam H.

description: Much improved over the last year.  A perfect place for a burrito and beer en route to the Haight.
author: a s.

description:
Don't know how I lived three blocks from this place for almost two years without going, especially when I would crave a burrito and dread having to make the trek to the Mission to satisfy it. Sustainable Mexican food seems to be all the rage in SF (really, a surprise?) and this place is hitting the sweet spot. My favorite Mexican place this side of Market.

The food. Enchiladas are great. Burritos are juicy and a healthy size. My Brazilian girlfriend is especially picky about her steak, beans, & rice, that being her staple meal back home, and she loves the enchiladas & burritos here. Definitely take two of their salsas to try with your meal. I go with the roasted tomato and the habanero (sparingly).

The place. It's a cozy little spot with a few 2-person tables, 1 4-person table, and a couple long, family style tables. Patrons are encouraged to sit down and get acquainted with their fellow Lower-Haighters, I believe. If you stay, you actually get to eat off of real plates with real silverware! Imagine... If you taking out, you may want to call ahead. It's a little bit of a longer wait than the average taqueria.
author: jim o.

description:
This place just can't seem to keep a taqueria for more a year it seems.  I would always come to this place when it was Loco Taco.  Since then I have moved out of the neighborhood but have managed to eat here on two separate occasions.

The first time the food was ordered with a large group of people by phone.  I was not there to look at the menu or ask any questions.  I simply ordered a Super Vegetarian Burrito, I shouldn't need to ask any questions, right?  My burrito comes and I am starving.  I took about two bites and realized that there were actual vegetables stuffed in and poking out of the burrito.  Granted I have nothing against vegetables but when I order a veggie burrito, all I want and all I expect is the simplicity of beans, rice, cheese, guacamole, hot sauce and on occasion some lettuce.  If I wanted corn, carrots and whatever the hell else was packed in there I would have damn well specified it.  I had a few more bites and couldn't eat anymore.  I was no longer hungry at that point.

For my second attempt a friend of mine suggests we eat here.  I was skeptical.  He tells me I should try the Fried Plantain and Black Bean burrito when he himself hasn't even tried it.  It was tangy and sweet which I was not accustomed to.  The red sauce was pretty spicy which I liked.  Half way through I had to stop and save the rest for a late snack.  Overall it was just alright.  I'd probably try it again. When it came time to pay my friend who picked the food up I found out the burrito was $8.95.  I think that's pretty absurd in the burrito world.  

Going back here will be a chore that I am just not ready for.
author: Patrick D.

description:
So, this spot is on it's third taqueria since I've lived in this neighborhood. First two joints were so-so, let's hope this one gets it right. So far, it seems to be headed in that direction, as the quesadilla I ordered was pretty damn good. Came with bell peppers and grilled onions in it, with a side of guac that was very good. Talked to the guy who was running the joint and he said once they get up and running, they would be serving beers on tap and also BRUNCH, which is very good news. Right now they are definitely still in the set-up stage, but it is looking promising.

update: brunch is good. tacos are good. everything is good, except the lack of seating during rush hours. oh well, can't win 'em all.
author: Tom H.

description:
I was hesitant about trying The Little Chihuahua if only because the previous tenancy was a mediocre Mexican restaurant.  After coming here semi-regularly, I can say that TLC is not a mediocre Mexican restaurant. 
Everything tastes fresh, the people that work there are competent and friendly. I really love this place and while I'm happy for their success, I kind of miss not having to wait in a line that's 8 people deep to get my food. Oh well.
author: EE C.

description: Decided to check out this spot because we were craving some Mexican food. It was a lot smaller than we thought. It's definitely not a spot where you can sit down and enjoy a quiet meal. It's a little cramped and can be kinda noisy. The staff was really nice. I got the specialty fajita burrito and ordered the nachos. I wasn't impressed by the burrito or the nachos. The food seemed to lack some authenticity. I was born and raised in San Jose, so I've been spoiled with some good Mexican food. Overall, it's definitely not a bad place, just that it failed to live up to some of the other Mexican food places I've been to. 3 Stars.
author: Steve S.

description:
I recently went here three times in one week.  I think I have issues.  


Seriously, though, it's a great place to grab a burrito. They have some great salsas and the people who work there are super friendly... even when you come in drunk off your ass with 12 people 15 minutes before closing.  It's my new alternative to GCK.
author: Hannah F.

description:
well its a nice spot, cafeteria style food but a twist on your average taqueria.

Try the guac, the burrito is yummy, the beer is cold.Its a good spot to eat.
author: Razza M.

description: Casual burrito joint, friendly staff, and awesome burrito. Got carnitas with red sauce, great salsa options too. About $7
author: Aki N.

description:
LC gets 5-stars for the most delicious vegetarian burrito in the city - fried plantains in the tortilla- YES! 

Minus 2 stars for the indulgent pricing. It's a burrito. It should never cost more than $8, especially in a city like San Francisco with so many great options.
author: Shira Z.

description: I could drink their salsa verde.  OMG!  I took three little cups home with me to eat with my lunch later in the week.  KILLER GOOD!
author: Heidi T.

description:
Someone asked me where I ate today- I said Lil' Chihuahua and they laughed!  woof-woof!

There is some serious high quality/semi-healthy mexi food going on here.  Clean ambiance and clean food.  We ordered chips and guac, carnitas taco w/rice and black beans, and a super baby burrito with the Rocky Jr. Grilled Chicken.  They were also kind enough to let me try their tortilla soup-tasty and would be great for a cold.

Everything was very fresh.  The portions were good sized-lots to eat and some even to take home.

Yo Quiero pequeno chihuahua!

Side note: the brunch menu looked good as well.
author: Cassie G.

description:
Food:

(I tried brunch here one lazy, hungover day.....)

Free chips and salsa ++ 
GOOD salsa with a lot of varieties that actually taste different ++
French toast fried tortillas with bacon and fried plantains....  I was so dubious.  SO dubious.  But let me tell you - it's worth it.  Take the plunge.  You'll never regret it.
Ask for a side of bacon?  You'll get a huge bowl of it.  Greasy, not over-cooked, thick sliced goodness.  Don't bother asking for a side of potatoes, if you order the french toast you won't need them.

Service:

Friendly, fast, but it's mostly do it yourself (get your own napkins, silverware, water).  Can't complain.
author: Kat M.

description: Definitley the real deal.  Fresh ingredients and friendly service.  Visited while visiting from Southern California.   Love Mexican food and this place was great!  The carnitas is super good and tender and tasty.   The grilled plantain burrito is very unique and worth a try even if you're not a vegitarian.  And the homemade sangria is a must try!!!  You won't be disappointed!
author: Kirsten U.

description: Ok, Little Chihuahua. I have to admit, I still cannot spell your name without google's help to save my life. But the other day I ordered a plantain burrito for the first time in probably over a year. And all is forgiven. And I love you.
author: Aimee M.

description: This place is great! I would have given it 5 stars but the two previous times I tried to go the crowds inside were overwhelming and we ended up having to go somewhere else. However, when we did make it in on a random Tuesday I was thrilled to find that the food was delicious and came out in a very timely manor. I had the burrito and it hit the spot perfectly! My suggestion would be to all ahead for pickup or get take out if you are going on a Thu, Fri or Sat.
author: Shanna T.

description:
Finally. F'ing finally a decent burrito joint in Western Addition. I would call it a taqueria but it is obviously a guero enterprise. And a good one at that. The prices are high but WORTH IT. 
Honestly this place is what I've always wanted in a burrito joint.
I get the Baby Burrito with no meat (note: skip the marinated veggies). 

So here are the major perks:
1. fresh Ingredients. No sysco..
2. top notch meat . Niman Ranch for the carnivores. Note that this is usually the weakest link with Taquerias especially the over-hyped ones.
3. salt it yourself. They go easy on the salt here which I LOVE. If you find something lacking flavor add salt or dip a chip. You will be pleased by all the flavors awakened by this step.
4. Love for the chili. Everything here is infused with roasted chili goodness. The kind of flavor experience you remember for life. This, to me is probably the most important and often overlooked aspect in this type of cuisine. It is all about the chilis.
5. Every time I go into this place, Sabbath is playing. Instant comfort for me.
6. Two blocks from home. 

I'll give you five stars if you'll just turn a nice profit and stay put.

Update: April 08

They have new chips! And they are much better. They are what a chip should be: tortilla fried in oil. They remind of the handmade chips at this mexican place my grandmother used to take my brother and I to when we were kids. I can almost smell the rum and camel non-filters breath...wafting in under the light and crispy corn oil flavor. 
Grandma? You sure you should be driving us around town in your Cadillac after all those rum and cokes? Grandma! Careful with that cigarette, you almost burned me again...

Whoa, went back in time there for a sec. RIP Grandma. You were ahead of your time in punk rock-ness.

Anyway, the cool thing about the chip revolution is that the proprietor read a review on yelp, already knowing that this was the one real weakness on the menu, knowing that he couldn't fry his own and found something that works. 
The fresh ingredients, the free range meats, the focus on the dynamic flavors of chile peppers, the recycling efforts and the nice receptive folks make this probably my favorite little family owned place in SF.
author: Derek O.

description:
At first, I really liked this place.  They're within 5 minutes of my apt, had decent food, friendly people working there, etc.  The first few times I ordered food from there it was pretty good. Last night was probably the last time I'll eat here.  They messed up my order at first.  I took it back to the kitchen, explained what was wrong with it, and was assured that they'd bring me the right thing.  Wrong.  It came back 10 minutes later, exactly how it was before. It wasn't that complicated really, I just asked them to hold the rice in the burrito. I did get a free beer out of it though, which is something, I guess.
The lower haight really does need a good mexican place in the hood.
author: Jesse K.

description:
For those times when you REALLY want a burrito but don't want to have the potential for post-burrito-questionable-stomach, The Little Chihuahua is the place to go. Everything here is really fresh and local. The meat is top-notch quality.

I had the Niman Ranch carne asada and some sort of local organic chicken tacos. Both were excellently cooked and very tender. This does not taste like authentic taco truck Mexican food but it has a simpler, cleaner flavors. The salsa bar (always a good sign in my opinion) has five or six options and while the flavors are fresh and crisp, I found the salsas to be a little on the mild side. 

In any case, The Little Chihuahua is a welcome addition to a neighborhood in desperate need of some decent Mexican food. I am excited to try the Mexican brunch on the weekends.
author: Allison G.

description:
I love the little chihuahua.   
My experience with their food extends no further than the chicken  baby burrito, but thats because I can't bring myself to try anything else.  I live right down the street so I do take out whenever I'm feeling lazy or whenever I want a really lovely bit of rice, beans & grilled chicken.  
It's a little "inauthentic" i  suppose (who am i to judge? ive never eaten a burrito in mexico), but I dream about the tomatillo salsa.
author: Alexandra G.

description: Amazing, never thought to have a plantain burrito. I am big meat eater and found the plantain great... awesome breakfast burrito spot
author: Richard G.

description:
Yum - we were totally impressed after our visit to the Little Chihuahua.  

My friend was floored by his plantain burrito -- and I really enjoyed my veggie quesadilla.  The fresh salsa bar was excellent as well.  The prices were ridiculously reasonable and I left stuffed with delicious food. I wish I could eat here more often!
author: Kate N.

description:
I really like this place. It's just around the corner, and sadly I sometimes succumb to the want of convenience to overshadow the overall quality, especially if I just need to grab something quickly. But honestly, the last two Mexican places that were in this location were so bad that I wouldn't even bother. I mean, it's kinda hard to totally mess up Mexican food, yet suprisingly hard to get it really right. So, I was a late bloomer to the Little Chihuahua, fearing it was just another new owner, same bad food.

Not! The food is excellent, wholesome (Neiman Ranch and Rocky Jr. and other tasty organics), reasonably priced, and fast. I can always get my order in under 10 minutes.
