Which is great when the child is ready to eat off my arm after a hard day of school and rowing. And the people there are always nice and have a smile.

I am well pleased that I am lucky enough to have such a good restaurant nearby.
author: Mari C.

description:
Went here for the first time for dinner this weekend and got the garlic shrimp burrito. Yum! The shrimp was great and the tortilla was fresh. I also greatly appreciated the bowl of chips and their salsa bar! We ordered the guac also - it was good, but now that I know the (free) salsa bar so well, I'd probably just stick to that next time.

Note: you order your food at the back counter, they give you a number, you find a table, and then they bring you the food. 

...dinner was such a success that we went back for brunch the next day. They have a nice variety of breakfast (egg) burritos, tacos, and more. I got the tacos (which come with a nice side of potatoes), and ended up not being able to finish all the food. They also have margaritas if you want one with your breakfast!

Also note, at busy times (weekend dinners) groups of more than 4 might not be able to get a table, but breakfast/lunch time had plenty of space
author: Caitlin B.

description: Mmmmmm!!!!!!! So good. I went with my boy  friend for brunch, and we could not stop eating. The food has great flavor, they have a deadly salsa bar, great coffee, and good atmosphere. My boyfriend got the Huevos Rancheros which was a good portion of a crispy tortilla, beans, caramelized onions, and toped with egg and salsa, and a side of red potatoes. My dish was just as good if not better I got the Huevos Motulenos, which is similar but their Nemans ranch ham is added to the mix. The restaurant is located just a couple blocks from the N line, and even though it was a little out of the way for us, we will definitely be going back.
author: Autumn E.

description:
I don't know about you, but I like my burritos and nachos with a lot of meat and the works. Call me fat, it's fine...but that won't discourage me from getting the "Super Burritto" aka the XXL of burritos at Little Chihuahua. They have a "baby burrito" (how cute...for a snack!) and a regular sized burrito. But, for about $8 you can get a super duper burritto with excellent "Niman Ranch" meat, guac and all that tasty stuff. I also tried my gf's nachos which had a ton of good quality steak on it. Highly recommend the nachos. 

All you foodies and health nuts would also appreciate that they have wheat tortillas (which were a bit hard), a help yourself salsa section and a dispenser of cold/lemony water. If you're not in the mood for agua, they've got wine and beer and sangria....I know, important details saved for last.

Try it...esp. if you live in the hood!
author: Deann M.

description: Pretty cool place. Chorizo burrito for the win :) I was psyched when I saw this. Tasted pretty great too. Kind of a cramped so rather than dining in for 1, I took it to go. Smelled good the whole way home and it was worth the wait when I got there. I will be back :)
author: Greg G.

description: Tasty, but nothing crazy amazing.  I might come back, but honestly there are so many other places nearby that i'd rather try something new than come back.  Had the junior burrito with tofu in it and i enjoyed it well enough.
author: Phil J.

description:
You know when you're tired of the same taqueria decor and same taqueria taste?  Bump it up a notch by going to the Little Chihuahua.  This place is like an upscale taqueria - in both taste and setting.  

Super Bonus Points: The cheese enchiladas (tried with the verde sauce) 

When to go: 
1. When you want a sit down taqueria place that doesn't remind you of every other taqueria.
2. Chilled Beer and hot chips and tasty salsa
3. When you crave mexican food of southern california (try the enchiladas)
4. Lots of vegetarian options (there are two types of beans that are veggie safe)
5. Ambiance is nice if you want a quiet sit down dinner with the wife
author: Sheetal S.

description:
One of the best Mexican places outside of the Mission. We eat here, probably, three times a week. The kid loves it! The Guacamole Enchiladas are unique and delish. Their soups and salads are also divine. Decent salsa bar. Friendly staff. And the burrito tortillas are grilled, not steamed. Haven't been here for breakfast yet, but I'm sure its excellent. 

My only gripe, and its not big, is they don't have a standard veggie taco on the menu, so each time I go in I have to order it one ingredient at a time: "I'd like a bean and rice taco with cheese and guacamole and salsa and sour cream" Just put it on the menu already, guys!
author: Mark F.

description: Delicious, simple to get your food, and more inventive than your usual taqueria. I don't like root beer but I appreciate that they have tequila ice cream root beer floats. The sitting area is cool and there's a back patio too for nice days.
author: Aaron E.

description:
MUY BIEN.

 the staff is always friendly, super cozy  and clean atmopshere and just delicious. Not so much "authentic" so dont come here if you are looking for that. It really hits the spot and they give good amounts of guac with orders, which is crucial for me. LOVE the quesedilla's, superburritos and nachos.  Inexpensinve, but not scary-is-this-really-chicken- cheap (see my popeye's chicken and biscuts on hayes/divis review for comparison).

ALSO they just started a champagne brunch, which I have yet to try but I'd bet the farm on it.

suerte.
author: Serene M.

description:
I had heard some really negative things about this place that had kept me out- stuffing burritos with zucchini and cabbage, or really strange meat to rice proportions...but I was pleasantly surprised when I finally went in to give it a go. 

Their menu offers a "baby super burrito" so you can get all the yumminess of guac and sour cream without ordering the usual massive burrito that is associated with a super. I made sure to say no cabbage as it is a standard ingredient here (be warned) but they were helpful and quick.

While I was waiting I noticed they have a weekend breakfast menu  that I will have to pop in and try first hand soon.
author: Beth M.

description:
We found this place because it was next to the only parking spot on Haight!

And how lucky we were.  The carne asada is incredible, we had it on the nachos.  Guacamole: good.  Habenero hot sauce: GOOD.

Fried plantain black bean burrito is an AMAZING idea and tasted amazing, definitely going back for it.  $3 draft dos X on the Saturday afternoon we went is not a bad deal either!
author: Jordan S.

description:
OMG OMG OMG OMG. So goooooood!

My favorite is anything with their shrimp. Also the place is sustainable. So you can eat like a pig and feel good about it.

The salsas are fresh and tasty.  

One time I got their shrimp I burrito and ate all of it. I couldn't stop. The thing was huge! Totally enough for two or a good leftover meal (or a binge eater like myself, who swore not to eat for 5 days after).

Really order anything, you won't be disappointed.

The place is small, and you MUST ORDER BEFORE YOU SIT AT A TABLE! The system always works out somehow, that is if all the clients follow thew rules. I have never been served my food before I got a table.
author: Suzy M.

description:
I don't know what took me so long to come here; it's around the corner from home, it's Mexican and I love the Mexican food, and it's not identical to the 500 taquerias in SF (which are good, but a man needs a little variety now and again).

I'm veg, and Mexican for me is often that really excellent Carne Asada burrito, minus the Carne Asada, which sucks.

That's why the Black bean and Plantain burrito is a revelation.  It's sweet, it's tasty, filling, and mixed with a lot of neat flavors.  It's also light: when's the last time you had Mexican and described it as 'light'?

The arroz con leche is an excellent dessert- I would expect something this good from a fancy $50-a-person restaurant.  People who complain about the prices are forgetting that they are getting a fantastic high quality fancy meal on a sub-Sizzler budget.

My only critique with La Chihuahua is the physical space- it's small, loud, and take-out orders dominate.  If you don't take it away, I don't think you'll find it as enjoyable an experience.  It is very fast, though.
author: Mark G.

description:
Good stuff. I walked in here last night and tried the shrimp tacos. For $4, it was pretty big, and an extra few bucks for rice and beans made it quite the meal. The staff was friendly and there's no credit card minimum. Since I'm just down the street I'll check it out some more and update this review, but so far, based on the food and the people who work there, I think I"ll like this place.

Edit: Haha, look up "Little Chihuahua" I got the name of this place wrong. I think my name is more memorable--feel free to steal it for a new biz or restaurant, not necessarily a Mexican food place. I think it would make a fine name for a bikeshop, bar, or pet supply store.
author: Josh K.

description:
Some days during the week this is a 5 start spot.  Others its probbaly below a 3 star.  When the food is fresh its some of the best SF has to offer and a great salsa bar too.

At its worst it has stale chips and dried out chicken.  

All the same its great spot for a quick bite!
author: Jordan S.

description: Fajita burrito- yum! Cute little place, good food, very nice!
author: Dana S.

description:
In my moderately-experienced opinion, Little Chihuahua has the best burritos in San Francisco. The meat quality is fantastic, the consistency is well-blended so that each delicious bite contains most of the ingredients. The salsa choices are much better than the standard spicygreen/picodegallo of most tacquerias. The employees are friendly and very good at what they do. 

Really the only possible negative aspect is that their prices are slightly higher than most other tacquerias. But as a burrito lover in the city of burritos, I am happy to pay that small price for perfection. 

Oh and from what I've heard their other (for instance, vegetarian) options are the bomb too, but I see no reason to stray from the classic super steak burrito.
author: Dan M.

description:
Came here with three friends for a pre-bocce meal and we were all impressed!  Solid decor, prices and options.  Standout green salsa.  I am getting sick of Papalote as the only decent burrito in my 'hood and am SO glad TLC replaced whatever that hole in the wall that came before it.  

Also props for the "baby" option that gets you a smaller burrito!  Those of us who have zero portion control need all the help we can get.

Can't wait to go back a few times and try the rest of the menu.
author: Matt S.

description:
So far this is my favorite burrito place in the city.


First of all the place is adorable - light blue walls, red candles and tapatio on the table, wooden chairs with big sun motifs, and a fireplace with possibly a mayan symbol - not fancy just an adorable taqueria.

The chef who designed all the recipes is behind the counter making the food.

The meat is organic hormone free from Neiman ranch. 
There is beer and wine offered.

I ordered the green tofu and I love it! 

I look for two things in a burrito fresh ingredients but it must blend well, which I call "dirty". It's sometimes hard to achieve both but this place does it!

Beware: The burrito was pretty spicy...and I didn't know it was going to be. Thankfully I like it that way....
author: Sari G.

description:
People kept telling me to go here for my Mexican food fix. I kept heading west down haight, but, now I go EAST straight to Little Chihuahua.

This place has great food, a cozy, busy, fun atmosphere with a local's feel and a major plus: the help there is actually - drum roll, please - professional and polite. The guy at the counter knew the menu, had recommendations, was fast, courteous and just plain nice.

I was prepared for the worst experience, just because it's sorta like that in general when you go to restaurants and, i admit, my expectations can be low. But Little Chihuahua gets high marks from me!!! 

Yay - good food and good service! Now that's a place that's worth my time and money.
author: Margaret T.

description:
So we've been back maybe ten times since this last review was written. And although I have tried to expand what I eat there, I am always drawn back to something containing plantains (which they will reluctantly put on other things besides the burritos).

But, although the price is a little higher than say El Toro, the food is better quality. Totally worth it. 

These guys really take their food seriously, and want you to like it. The service (which is why you are paying more here than CanCun for example), is exemplary. It's pretty hands-off until you have a problem, then they are right there to help. An all-around great place!
author: Freud R.

description:
I think my bf and I have been to every restaurant on Divis in Nopa at least once so yay for a new place!  AND yay for a good mex place with FREE chips and $2 beers (I'm sold right there).

Well we've tried a few things. Some OK. Some stellar so see below:

Plantain Burrito- THE BEST thing we've tried thus far.  Super duper good.  Lots of flavor.  Good size. A definitely must to try.

Regular steak burrito smothered- eh, go for the plantain or get sour cream and guac.  This burrito was missing something.

Guacamole enchiladas-  Not bad. Not bad at all.  Still prefer the plantain burrito but these were pretty good and came with your choice of beans and rice.  The black beans had something about them that were pretty good.

Tostada salad-  This was also decent.  We got the chicken one and it came with lots of avocados and a crispy yummy shell.

So in conclusion Plantain burrito is awesome.  Everything else is ok BUT the salsa bar is a-ok and the beer is a GREAT deal
author: Rachel S.

description:
YUMMMMM!!! I always get the same thing when I come here! Super Baby Camerones Burrito! So good!! I have no idea what is "baby" about my burrito, it looks the same size as a regular but I'm happy to pay less & still be full. 

This place seems to fill up fast. Usually the seating is first come first serve.
author: Angel P.

description:
You will never have a burrito make you feel so good!

Seriously this place is delicious they use quality ingredients and its amazing how it makes all the difference in he world.

It can get a little packed and there is a strange savage system of waiting for tables. So plan ahead if you can or call in a togo order. 

My all time favorite here are the shrimp tacos... I've never known such tastiness!
author: Danger R.

description:
I'm happy that I finally have a place close to home where I can get fresh, deliiiiicious tortilla soup. And now they're open later into the evening, so what's not to love? Everything is really fresh and the wait time is surprisingly short. I'm into the baby super burrito with carnitas, which is basically the perfect amount of food, or a soup with a chicken chile verde taco. So many options!

6/24 edit: I keep coming back here. Several times a week, in fact. It's a hit every time, not even remotely disappointing in any way. The plantain burrito is to die for, although it took me forever to finish it. The chipotle salsa is so good. Just superb.
author: kay v.

description:
The San Francisco burrito is a phenomenon (I found this out listening to an NPR special). If you don't live in the Mission, or if you want your SF burrito to be sustainable and cow-friendly, the Little Chihuahua is the place to go. It's a little yuppified, this is true. And there is a kick missing in the flavor of the SFB. But I always feel a little healthier when I eat here. =) Except for when meals involve the pitchers of Sangria. Also, it's hit or miss with the crowds: I've been on a Monday night at 8 and it's been so packed we couldn't find a table. I've also been on a Tuesday night at 8 and 3 people were in the restaurant. It's a small space, so be prepared to wait at popular times. 

My favorites: the chips and salsa (gratis, try the tomatillo), carne asada $5.95 for a nice-sized "baby burrito"). 
Must try: so they have their "famous" black bean and plantain burrito ($8.95). I love plantains. I love black beans. Together in a big burrito...meh. I say try it, but don't expect too much. For example, I've learned that I like my burritos savory.
author: Lydia C.

description: I guess after 400+ reviews, one more doesn't make a difference, but I am liking Little Chihuahua more and more. I've been a few times, and my last trip was probably the most delicious. The roomie and I split a mushroom queso and a shrimp salad, and it was delicious. Super fresh and flavorful. The first time I came in, the chips were a little stale which I think affected my perception, but I'm definitely a fan now!
author: Emilia S.

description:
Really great place and they are the the Green Coupon Book! We decided on take out becuase it was a late night, but next time we will definitely eat in. Things get soggy and we couldn't  try the drinks. My shrimp tacos and his shrimp burrito we really amazing. The regular size burrito could be for 2, so next time we will try the mini-burrito. The salsas were good. The next night we both wanted to go back, it was hard not to. 

New place in our hood!
author: Erin L.

description:
Last week when I was just about to dig into my burrito from LIttle Chihuahua my roommate suggests, "hey, you have to be one of their top customers, huh?".  This is in all seriousness.  I think about it for a few moments and I have a bit of a realization - I dine in or order take-out from this place at least 3-5 times a week, no joke.  I've got to be at least a top ten right?  It just doesn't get old for me.  Let me explain why I think Little Chihuahua is so great, it is quite simple:

1. Delicous burritos (tender carne asada, amazing tortillas, everything else is above average)
2. $2 beers, all the time
3. I have never had to wait for my take-out, if they say 5 minutes it has never been a second more
4. Brunch is amazing
5. I created a Yelp profile just to review this place (not exactly what makes it good, but it does show how strongly I feel).  

While Green Chile kitchen is good, I don't think it comes close to Little Chihuahua if you live in the neighborhood.
author: Patrick B.

description: This place is great! Tasty , cheap and relatively  healthy. Quick to go and awesome staff!
author: Chris L.

description:
I love this place. Their chicken tortilla soup is delicious relatively healthy (if you skim some of the oil off the top), full of spice and very filling. You really have to try it! They make it unique and extra tasty by adding grilled corn, queso fresco and chile de arbol 

I know that Chicken Tortilla soup is most likely a dish that you skip right over on the menu when ordering. I mean if you're going out for Mexican I'm sure you are prepared, and even excited, to ingest lots of cheese, corn, guacomole and grilled meats. I know.... I know.... it's hard to pass up cheesy enchiladas, mole chicken tacos or sizzling fajitas... So, you might ask who in their right mind would choose soup in such an establishment? Well, I do. I probably get a taco too but I def have the tortilla soup if they have it. This might honestly be because i LOVE soup or could be because this soup is just so flavorful, but either way I love it
author: sydney k.

description:
totally what you can expect when you pay 8 dollars for a burrito, high quality ingredients. I bought the super with the neman ranch steak, it wasnt that super in size but it was quite a tasty. Had a nice bite but seemed to be lacking in some department, 

thats what all the amazing salsa's are for!!
they had five different kinds in a bar style, which was nice, but the main thing was that they all were near mind blowing! they have really really tasty salsa and not one skimps around. even have a habanero one that tends to sneak up on you.

not a big line for me and a table opened up right when we got are food. only one complain and not a big one, by the end of the burrito it was more than a battle to keep it together. I have also never used so many napkins in my life lol. 

in the end its a good ass burrito but you pay a little for it.
author: Zachary B.

description: This place is one of my favorites for all around solid choice. Good atmosphere good salsa good friendly service food good locations plus kid friendly. Nicer than most taquerias you cd meet friends and sit for a while! However their beans are somehow kind of bitter so I dont get them. Other than that its great here.
author: Precita M.

description:
I decided to check out this brand new restaurant walking past the bustling joint @ 8pm on Tuesday. The place was packed and everyone seemed to be hanging out and enjoying the food. I ordered up the pollo asado nachos and the tortilla soup. Both were fantastic. Very original flavors well above the taqueria standard. So I ended up going with a friend the next day, this time trying out the chile verde pollo quesadilla and was again blown away. 

They have a great selection of bottled beers (Negra Modelo, et al) and on tap is Peroni, good ol' Anchor Steam and Fat Tire. In addition to the beer, they offer a fine selection of spanish and domestic wines. 

A little love goes a long way and you can really tell that the new owners are working hard to bring top notch quality food and drink to the growing divisadero neighborhood. The Little Chihuahua is close to new hot spots, NOPA and Ziryab.
author: Mason Y.

description:
AAii Chi WOW Wa!

This place is just one more little gem in my Divisidero corridor neighborhood.   It's a small place kinda nestled in, with just a few windows. But it is well lit, and clean, with really cool furnishings.

Just my first time so first report. I loved it. My Super Carne Asada burrito was warm and toasty. They grill the tortillas. The Neiman Ranch steak inside was tender, juicy and full of carnal flavor. The rice, ..and this is important... the amount of rice to meat ratio was right. Not an all rice carbo bomb that you get at other burrito joints. There was only just enough rice to fill it out, letting the steak be the star of the show. They have refried black beans too. which was nice. And the salsa bar was just a small table of a half a dozen or so salsas, jalapeños and such. But that is all you will need. I have never had Tomatillo salsa this good! It is thick and rich.. and super tasty.  The habañero salsa is hot and good too.

I am going back to try the other goods on the menu. Clean shrimp and Petaluma Pollo as well as plantain burritos for a start. There is a brunch there on weekends which I will also try.

The prices were nice for the quality, cleanliness and authentic taste. They have only organic, sustainable ingredients. For this, you could be paying more. shhhhh. don' tell the chihuahuas.

Oh, and the service for my take out order was simple, friendly and quick.

No lies.. just love.
author: Jacky J.

description:
I'm not convinced this place is 4 stars but the reviews reminded me a choice mexican joint is hard to find. I had a Carnitas Taco and there was a TON of CHOICE amazing meat to it. Quality of meat is super fine and I definitely tasted the tinge of mango or whatever they claim to have....mmmmmm

Chips were above average and the salsa I chose had a nice hint of mango but was too spicey for my blood. But the others might have been better. Well, it was nice stuff.

I ate well for under $10 I will tell you. 

I was expecting more of a full service restaurant and this wasn't it. You have to order at the counter, get a number, and they bring your food to you. But, pretty good so far
author: Mike T.

description: I love Cuban food, (I'm from Miami Bitch).  Why does that matter if The Little Chihuahua is a Mexican restaurant? Because they make a vegetarian burrito with sweet plantains and black beans, and when you add delicious Niman Ranch pork (carnitas of course) you get a (non-vegetarian) mini Cuban dinner wrapped in a tortilla.  My favorite burrito of all time.  It doesn't stop there, they also make a fantastic fajita burrito.  I hear the pozole is great but I keep ordering burritos (I'm a mom on the go)!
author: Tiffany P.

description: Two words: plantain burrito!  Found this place after their booth at outside lands. A winner!
author: John V.

description:
Came here a couple of times - once for take-out and once eating in.

Food would have been really good (especially the smothered super burrito), if it hadn't cooled to room temperature by the time it got to us - both visits. Very disappointing!
author: Tim H.

description:
I originally gave Little Chihuahua 3 stars because of one salsa, which I hated.  It's the habanero salsa.  My friend Jeff hates it too.  The tomatillo and salsa fresca are much better.

But ever since I gave Little Chihuahua 3 stars, I've been feeling like an asshole.  You see. . . I go there all the time.   

It's one of the few taquerias in the whole state where I don't fear the red meat.  I had a carne asada taco yesterday and the Niman Ranch beef was relatively unadorned.  No beans, not a ton of salsa or onions (though you can certainly add those).  Why unadorned?   Because with out so many garnishments, you can taste the beef, and the Niman Ranch quality comes through.  It's succulent with a perfect texture.  

And I keep coming back for it. . .again and again and again.
author: Penelope D.

description: Consistently delicious burritos! Great staff too.  You will not be disappointed at Little Chihuahua! Go now!
author: Lisa E.

description:
I had the plantain and black beans burrito with carnitas (i was hungry, haha). it was really excellent!  everything was seasoned deliciously, and it was well put together.

the best burrito i have had in the bay area so far!
author: Michael C.

description: Often after eating a burrito , I reach a stage of fullness that is barely manageable. I feel so full I could take a nice little nap by the salsa bar. This is both good and bad depending on who you ask. Good for me because naps in my book always good! Not good for my friend who probably doesn't want to watch me nap. Note to self: Need friends that like to watch me nap. Anyhoo, the burritos so not make me want to nap. They are perfectly filled with just the right amount of goodies and good quality ingredients at that. Bonus points for amazing salsa bar.
author: Sophia C.

description:
ok, i have admit, i was first drawn to this place because of the name (i'm a sucker for anything "chihuahua" as many of you know) but i soon found out they had the most amazing chipotle PLANTAIN BURRITO w/ black beans and roasted red peppers.  put some of their salsa verde on it and you too will be hooked.  they have a great fresh salsa bar and those home made chips are mmmmm delish.   

i've been to this one and the one in noe valley and they do it right in both places.  and noe valley has some specially made humphrey slocombe ice cream flavors.  now it's almost $10 for the burrito, but it's huge and i can eat half for lunch and have the other half for dinner...

and yes, when i went in to get my burrito, my little chihuahua was tethered right outside waiting for me.  how perfect is that?
author: Suzanne A.

description: Best burrito I've had in SF. I've been looking for a good one for a while and I've finally found it! I got a carne asada super burrito and the citrus was just right. Furthermore, chips and salsa upon order. YUM!
author: Lissette L.

description:
Update!

Dan and I went here for dinner before The Mountain Goats show. I had the chicken chile verde nachos, and dan had the garlic shrimp burrito. Oh. My. Gawd! Both of them we re soooo delicious. I don't even eat leftovers usually, but I was looking forward to coming home to my nachos the next day. Unfortunately, Dan was looking forward to my nachos the next day too and he beat me to them. Gah! Oh well, just another excuse to go back, right?
author: Naomi C.

description: Super good salsa, beer on tap, awesome rice & beans.  The tofu tacos were not the greatest, but were good.
author: Tyler G.

description: I had a bitchin grilled veggie enchilada here tonight. The place was packed so I got mine to go since I live around the corner. Staff was friendly, nice little salsa bar, and fresh tasty food at a reasonable price. Can't really complain.
author: Damon P.

description:
friends and i came here after an afternoon at a barley-wine fest but since i already stuffed myself silly with a rosamunde sausage, i only had a couple margaritas and noshed on nachos. 

the space is small with seating for maybe 30-40, well-lit w/o being too bright, homey-feeling and clean. 

the margarita carafe was reasonably priced and the nacho plate was wiped clean after 20 mins. 

i'll need to come back one day and try the standard usual fare.
author: Ida C.

description:
I went here with my group of friends after meandering through the Haight Ashbury Street Fair. The place is on the smaller side with seating for 30-40. It was pretty full when we arrived, but the waiter guy was kind enough to get us seats for 6. 

There is a salsa bar with some amazing fresh choices like salsa verde and roasted pepper. I was getting over a cold and the habanero salsa really cleared up my sinuses.

I think everybody should try the plaintain and black bean burrito once in their lives. It is simply bliss. The combination of the sweeter, bland plantains with the spicy, earthy black beans was phenomenal.

Did I mention they serve pitchers of margaritas? Order it.
author: Ableen T.

description: Have been coming here regularly since I moved across the street a few weeks ago, and have to say we've tried pretty much everything on the menu. Apart from the inconsistent "service" (such that it is as I have to frequently clean my own table before eating and bus my own table), and the bad air circulation (hate smelling of brunch for the rest of the day). Yes, it's overpriced for Mexican food, but, despite all the above, the food is good and it doesn't make me feel like I ate a brick of lard for the rest of the day.
author: Mi M.

description:
palabra...this place is awesome. Not only does this help the bottom dollar...but it gets props for organic, original, sustainable...and really all things SF. 

Now...authenticity...maybe not. I'll wait for my epicurean vacay to make judgement.
author: Kaleb L.

description:
this place does Mexican just right (outside of the mission dist., which means they're a little more expensive too).  from their fried plantain and black bean burrito to their tostada salad (served a variety of ways), it's just all around delicious.  but let's start with the experience:

if you have a dog (there's a couple dog parks near by) the restaurant set up a leash holder on the wall outside the front door.  They also provide a water dish for those thirsty pups.  Very thoughtful for their animal loving patrons.

It's a small establishment with "first come first serve" rules.  You'll probably wait in line to order at the counter during the regular meal hours.  If you come with friends, you're not allowed to reserve seating until you've placed an order.  Seems harsh for a popular joint, but it's understandable considering the size of the restaurant.  For those busy hours, you can order to-go or call in for pickup.  If you decide to dine-in, you're asked to bus your own table after you've enjoyed your meal.  They have a bus station where you separate recycling/compost/and trash.

The food is delicious.  They have very large portions filled with extremely flavorful, healthy, organic, locally supported, fresh ingredients. They prepare everything as its ordered so you know nothing has been sitting around under heat lamps all day.  They're also vegetarian friendly providing tofu substitutions.  Their alcoholic beverages are delicious and strong.  I recommend their agave wine margaritas. Split a pitcher with friends, you won't regret it.* But they also have a variety of nonalcoholic drinks, including homemade horchata.  Lastly, I must mention their salsa bar.  I love condiments, and they don't disappoint.  They have everything from salsa verde, to habanero that first starts sweet and then brings on the flames.  Taste a little of everything, you'll love it all!

All in all, The Little Chihuahua will provide delicious healthy flavorful food and drinks that you'll absolutely enjoy, as long as you don't mind waiting a little while and busing your meal.  Just think casual dining with rich delicious food.  I think it's well worth it. 

*that is ordering and imbibing, I don't guarantee you won't regret what comes thereafter.
author: N F.

description:
Pleasantly surprised to find such a coordinated and hip Mexican joint to have such tasty shrimp tacos.  Props to the fresh ingredients and to not overcooking the shrimpies to a shriveled crumb of protein.

Woof Woof.
author: Dubs W.

description:
On par with Papa Lote, but without papa's signature salsa. I recently tried the baby super and the plantain burrito. The plantain burrito is top notch - Cuco's is the only other place I've had one, and this easily tops theirs.
Chihuahua may be pricier than most taquerias, but they have fresh and high-end ingredients (high quality meats and salsas) and a more interesting selection.
You may see the place fills up on random week nights... could this be because they have $2 draft beers? Yes! Maybe I should go there again tonight!
Two more things: I didn't find the Sangria to be very good, but the rice pudding was really good - did i detect a touch of cardamom in there? Surprising and delicious.
author: Julien R.

description:
i finally made it and i really enjoyed it! i ordered the huevos motulenos with chorizo rather then the ham it comes with, so good! my boyfriend had the super burrito wet and had only good things to say. we also tried 4 of their salsa selections and their sangria. their food ran sweet to us rather then spicy which was interesting and i enjoyed it. i will come again and look forward to trying some of the dishes i eyed at tables around me. 

be warned that its counter ordering and seat yourself, some tables are shared based on the party sizes but everyone is friendly and we had no problem sitting comfortably.
author: Barbara C.

description: anyone else notice that the prices have gone up?  one regular burrito and one quesadilla were more than $20!  kinda ridiculous.
author: Patrick M.

description:
I loved the Little Chihuahua.  For the past year I have completely changed my diet and been on a health food hype.  Mexican and Spanish food, though wonderful, do not exactly qualify as the the healthier cuisines.  The Little Chihuahua seems to have given it that healthy twist while keeping the authenticity and taste. 

The Sangria was wonderful, not too strong (or I am an alcoholic), but tasted wonderful.

I got the baby burrito (great for those who don't like wasting food on a huge burrito) with the half Chile Verde tofu menu option and half the wild mushroom menu option.  The burrito came with fresh avocado, black beans (vegan), rice, sour cream, and all the fixin's.  I have to admit I was hesitant about the tofu or wild mushroom idea in a burrito, but it was absolutely amazing.  Such a great idea for vegetarians and/or vegans.  

Typically after tearing up a whole burrito, i feel stuffed and gross, though I was full I didn't feel all greasy and yucky. And let me tell you I appreciate that feeling.  I am a huge fan and plan on coming back for sure.
author: N S.

description: I am a big fan of this place.  Like many other reviewers have said, it is not the most authentic, but quality is the name of the game at Little Chihuahua.  They have awesome salsas and an excellent habanero sauce.  Some favorites of mine are the carnitas burrito and the garlic shrimp burrito.  Hibiscus agua fresca and pozole are other things worth trying.  Also there salads look really good, but I never had one.
author: Dan L.

description:
Me Gusta La Chihuahua

They have fresh ingredients, Niman Ranch beef and pork, $2 draft beers, and plenty of good salsa verde.  The interior is reasonably nice, people complain but I wonder what these people wold say about El Farolito or one of the mission spots.  I think this place is better than any other burrito spot on Divis and I look forward to many more visits.  Hit it up!
author: Brian L.

description:
Mexican brunch! Well deserved. 

1. beautiful day in SF
2. walking blocks and blocks in heels
3. starving!

the Oasis of The Little Chiuahua thank you yelp! Food was pretty good. The super baby burrito is seriously only a little smaller than a regular burrito you would get somewhere else. I had the mexican breakfast it was good. I think there could have been more flavor to be honest. But with the salsa bar and some tapitio i was good. 

Negatives...we sat next to this group of people that were super loud and there was another guy who brought his dog and left it outside the restaurant that would bark at anyone and anything moving! So we could barely talk to each other because it was just so loud. Also the prices were a little high, I'd rather go to the Mission for some good mexican food. 

Would I go back? Probably not...well Maybe I'd go to try a few other items that were on the menu that caught my eye, but there are a lot of other great mexican restaurants out there. If you are looking for something good and not hole in the wall. Definitely check it out.
author: Jess O.

description: I am not kidding, I ate burritos from many places around the states. But, I am telling you these guys have the best burritos and qasadias.
author: Sulaiman B.

description: The garlic shrimp burrito is soo good! Tender grilled shrimp with all the fixin's. Great rice and yummy salsas too!
author: S P.

description: Wow, who knew this little place could make a mean chicken enchilada.  And the pinto beans and rice hit the spot.  Their sauces were awesome too.  In a city with more mediocre taquerias than you can shake a tortilla at, this place stands out, tip!
author: Jason D.

description:
So good - Only negative is it's a bit pricey ($9 for a burrito?) But it's so worth it!

There's also a dog leash tie up out front, so it's a great place to walk the dog to get food to go!

GO - You wont regret it.
author: Nicholas C.

description: My boyfriend and I just moved to SF and we were craving Mexican food! We've been on a hunt for really good nachos! The kind with real shredded cheese, not that con queso stuff...  This review is for dinner / late night meal. One star for the quick service. Another star just for the free chips and salsa bar. I had to order the chicken nachos, and was disappointed. Compared to the free chips and salsa, I think the chips used in the nachos must have been stale. My boyfriend had the chicken super burrito, ordered "wet" with the red sauce - that was very tasty!
author: Linh P.

description:
This is not your normal little burrito spot.  I grabbed food to go last night and was pleasantly surprised. The small spot was crowded with hipsters, and we made our way to the counter to order.  

Carnitas burrito was packed with meat, cheese, rice, beans, guac and goodness.  Seriously one of the better burritos I've had in a while. My friend got an order of nachos - again, lots of toppings although the chips weren't particularly crunchy.  (Then again, since it took us a little time to get home to eat them, perhaps we were somewhat to blame!) 

Nice salsa bar.  $2 drafts. Quick service.  All around, a good experience.
author: Todd S.

description:
What's not to love about this cute, yet tenacious, little pup? Wrap him up in a warm tortilla and I'll take one to go!

Yes, adorable and friendly staff, warm decor, sturdy wooden chairs and tables, and the MOST scrumptious plantain burritos.  And yummm veggie or meat super baby burritos.  And the best, THE BEST, Margaritas! In addition to lime, they add some other wonderful citrusy juice. Watch out, they're stronger than they taste, or maybe I just feel the effects from downing the whole glass before my meal's served.

Sure, it gets crowded during peak hours.  Sure, it's not cheap.  But it's SO GOOD!  And the customer service is beyond expectations (I love how they don't wince when I get on a roll with my minor, yet numerous, made-to-order requests).  It's the little things...
author: Bamboo T.

description: Nom! I'm still thinking about the first Little Chihuahua burrito I had nearly two years ago. I remember I took a photo of it. ... it was that good! Also, the blue plates are so cute. You must try this place!
author: Jennifer S.

description: I've tried the grilled chicken, steak, plantain and bean, and garlic shrimp burritos here and loved each one.  The tortillas are lightly grilled, the size of the burrito is manageable, and the salsas are also great.  The lack of enough seating at rush times is my only complaint, and it's a small one at that.  Also love that they are open until 11p, so I can usually grab a burrito when it's been a long day/night at the office.
author: danny b.

description: The Little Chihuahua is seriously one of my favorite mexican restaurants. The garlic shrim burrito is one of my all time favorites! But when your iin a healthy mood... which I am trying to be in.. ha... the Chicken Tostada salad is delish!
author: Meagan B.

description: Came in by myself on my way home from work. The gentleman at the counter was very friendly, I ordered the carne asada nachos. What I got was a huge plate of deliciousness. The meat was wonderful, pretty big chunks of meat that were a little raw in the middle and with a great flavor. Other than that, they were your standard nachos, melted cheese, beans, salsa, sour cream, guacamole. Pretty good and well priced at like $10. I couldn't finish it and I was happy. Bonus for a good selection of salsas at the salsa bar, plus free chips!
author: Stephanie W.

description:
Go to the weekend brunch and order the Mexican french toast: fried plantains and bacon wrapped in a crepe covered in maple syrup. It's to die for. 

Any other day, go for the fried plantain and black bean burrito. Amazing. 

They know how to cook their plantains.
author: Stephanie H.

description:
Mmmmmmmmmmmmmmm. There are very few places that I could eat at every single day, this is definitely one of them.  There are a lot of people out there (mainly stupid, i'm too cool for you hipsters), who claim that you can't get a good burrito outside of the Mission.  Well I guess they are just too cool to go outside of the Mission without having their Rep damaged amongst their stupid hipster friends.

Enough ranting and onto the review.

The burritos are a great, reasonable size that doesn't make you waste half of it in the garbage but enough to let you know a burrito is in your stomach. The ingredients are great and the whole thing is slightly toasted which is the key.

The Nachos are definitely the best I have ever had, try the chicken chili verde. 

They used to have $2 Fat Tire, but no more. I guess because of the economy. (joke) I really wish they would bring that back, however I would be in there twice as much and end up fat and drunk.

Service: always done with a smile and always quick.

Down side: No parking for out of towners. But, if you are eating a burrito then you may want to think about taking a walk anyway.

Verdict: I love this place and will continue to eat here multiple times a week.
author: Jackson D.

description:
Mmmmm, The Little Chihuahua me gusta mucho. The plantain and black bean burrito is delicious! There were plenty of other veggie options as well.

Their chips were thick and crunchy, too. But most importantly, they actually toast their tortillas instead of steaming them. Yessss. I'll definitely go back!
author: Tamara M.

description:
Really cute place for a really good price.

Their good food, relaxed atmosphere, and $15 carafe of sangria made the night a good one.
author: Christine C.

description:
I am a tortilla soup freak. I have to order it if it's on the menu. I've walked by this place numerous times and finally decided to check it out.

take a wild guess what i order.

DELICIOUS! It's a broth based tortilla soup with a great mix of spicy flavors and fresh vegetables. I wish I could have asked for extra extra cheese... little cubes of heaven!

And try the house margarita- they're great!
author: Melissa J.

description:
I desperately want to like the food here, because I support the notion of eating happily raised animals. But I keep being disappointed. 

A few weeks ago I tried the chile verde chicken burrito, but it was bland and I threw half away.

Today I tried the tortilla soup and garlic shrimp burrito. The tortilla soup was really really good, but the garlic shrimp burrito was overpowered with garlic and the tortilla was burnt.

I think that fundamentally I just really like greasy mission style burritos with refried beans. I'll be back for the soup, and to try the breakfast burrito (hard to imagine that can be messed up)...

update: came back for breakfast and was sorely dissapointed. Maybe I'm asking for too much but there is a seriously lack of seasoning. The beans are just not good and the breakfast burrito was the worst one I've ever had. I'm starting to get pretty irritated with restaurants that plan to skate by on good quality ingredients without putting in any efforts on flavor. Even the best ingredients require salt to bring out flavor!!
author: Corinne R.

description:
Leaps and bounds better than Toco Loco that was in the same location before.  They used to cook up your pretty blah Mexican fair the kind you could go get in Des Moines. 

Now Lil' Chihuahua is a great Mexican food place.  The agave nectar margaritas are great on a hot day.  The burritos are huge and made from quality Clean Fish or organic chicken/beef.  Come hungry.  Warning even the Baby burrito is more like a baby Huey, in that its not that small. 

Also leave a bit earlier if its after work as this place lines up pretty good during rush hour.

I have not had the chance to try their breakfast yet but I will report back once I do. 

Note on improvement I wish they gave more than one taco with the taco plate maybe two or three.
author: Ryan H.

description: Great food, awesome salsa bar.  My fav Mexican place in SF
author: Steve M.

description: Little Chihuahua is a good neighborhood burrito place with fresh ingredients and a fresh salsa bar.  Pricing was alright - wasn't a good nor bad deal.  It's worth checking out if you're looking for a healthy and fresh burrito.
author: Leo C.

description: I miss this place. It's making me want to move back to San Francisco. I mean the black bean plantain burrito and the tostada salad. And I'm going to add tacos to that list as well.
author: Rebecca G.

description: Recently discovered this little gem.  They have several vegetarian and vegan options.  They identify which beans are vegetarian/vegan (whole black beans and refried black beans). Rice is vegetarian/vegan.  For vegetarian/vegan burrito filings, they have a chili verde tofu (amazing), grilled veggies or wild mushrooms.   You can even order a "baby burrito" when you want something smaller.  By far, the best guacamole I have ever had.  It's hard not to eat the entire bowl by yourself.  Agua frescas are fresh and tasty.
author: Dana P.

description:
My whole family and I stopped there twice during their two-week visit to the US for some quick lunch. Both times we've been positively impressed by Little Chihuahua.

The spot really looks like the usual Mexican fast food place, where you are supposed to order at the counter and wait for your food to be ready. But, differently from other spots I've tried so far , quality of food is really high and portions are very generous! My favorites are the carne asada quesadilla, the super burrito and carne asada enchilada. My dad Aldo tried the camarones (shrimp) quesadilla which wasn't bad. 

Also, I like the fact that they give you very many different sauces to pick freely at the counter, and it's always very easy to park nearby, even on a Sunday when the spot was quite full.

I Definitely recommend this spot for some quick Mexican food in sf.
author: france d.

description: Everything, and I mean everything here is terrific - not much more to say - really nice people, fresh and tasty food = sometimes a bit loud and busy - but hey, it is one of the city's best.
author: Susan A.

description: had a burrito. pretty damned good. $9 is a few bucks more than i would pay for what is mostly a rice based food item. i had the al pastor special burrito, and the pineapple was a great touch. i will go back, but probably try another one.
author: Michael J.

description:
The superstitious owner has Ozzy playing every Saturday morning when it first opens. It must be working because their business is booming.

I live next door which is unfortunate for my waist line but damn I love everything they have. Everything. Really. (Cashiers all rock as well)

breakfast: Chillie Quilles (best in town, spicy yet flavor packed fried chips in cream sauce topped with eggs, jalapenos, fresh salsa and sour cream is ...heaven)

Grilled Vegetables for your burritos (or anything) are fresh and delish

Salmon for fish tacos is excellent - 

Great selection of inexpensive beers, some on tap
author: nicole m.

description:
The salsa is very bland and the chips are very packaged. I'm used to Sonoma Taco, which is amazing on both accounts.

It is also wayyy too loud in here (especially for mornings with a headache, which is when I crave Mexican Food.)

The enchiladas are plain but yummy.
author: Aaron W.

description:
Finally the neighborhood has a killer Mexican joint. I love it here, everyone is so nice, the food is absolutely scrumptious, and there hundreds of tiny little chihuahuas running around with buckets of Coronas strapped to their backs.  

OK, I admit there are no chihuahuas, but there is Coronas; you just have to get them yourself. 

Try the chipotle and the roasted tomato salsa. Taste, smile, die happy.
author: Big W.

description:
salsas- 5 stars for variety and spiciness.

Came here for dinner a few weeks back. Ordered a burrito. My complaint is that everything was a either over or undercooked, e.g.  the beans were too soft and the plantains too hard.

Decided I would give it another chance so I came back for brunch. I ordered the huevos rancheros. Ugh, nothing special. I have made better ones with leftovers. 

Oh and their horchata is tasty, but I gained 10 lbs. from one.
author: Lee M.

description: i love that i can get a veggie taco here as a dinner plate for around $6. makes this a super affordable meal in the city.
author: Elise H.

description:
I have only eaten here once and my experience was a pleasant one. 
All of the 4 different salsas they offer are really good and the orange colored one (mango I think) was super spicy! :) 
I am intrigued by the breakfast options and will def return to try it out on a weekend.
The prices were reasonable and the staff was friendly... everything tasted fresh and came quickly. 
I had the pork burrito and it was nicely put together, tender and flavorful.

Oh yeah .. also they have music playing (trip hop/downtempo) which I like and it's nice inside. :)
author: Jeremy R.

description:
I used to live right around the corner from this place and i will say it was one of my top 5 places to eat in the western addition.

My absolute favorite is the Tostada salad con carne. But no matter what I've tried the ingredients are always fresh so you cant go wrong.
author: J. C.

description:
This is the best burrito business in this location to-date.  

Many have tired.  Many have failed.

I like the meat selection/quality, the service, even the salsa to go.

No complaints here!
author: Jeffrey N.

description:
My neighborhood burrito joint.  Busy and friendly!  Not sure if the very good burritos are as good as the very very good burritos at Castillito on Church, but today I had the best chilaquiles Ive ever had in my life.  A "wow" moment.
And all the ingredients are free-range-organic-local-worship-worthy, so the burritos cost a buck or two more than the places in the Mish, but, like I said, they're very, or very very good.
author: Rob B.

description: Definitely my favorite mexican (texmex?) joint around my place. Sometimes we go once a week... yes a lot.  Salsa....YUM. The garlic shrimp (clean fish) burrito is amazingly good and the shrimp ALWAYS tastes super fresh. The salads are large and yummy too! Plus did I mention the music?  They do have good taste when it comes to that! I also hear they really care about the environment and have a great recycling program! Go Little Chihuahua!!
author: Sonya D.

description: Delish tortilla soup on a rainy day.    Loved it.
author: Nicole K.

description: Love the name, love the food, even the background music (Edward Sharpe). We ordered the salad, red enchiladas, and tortilla soup, and were not disappointed with anything! Deliciousness!
author: Erin J.

description: The Pozole Rojo on a cold San Francisco night is a little piece of heaven.
author: Leo V.

description: Really good burrito spot.  When my buddy suggested it, I wasn't sure if I wanted a burrito but quickly was impressed.  You have several choices on size and ingredients.  And everything seemed very fresh and high quality.  I'll be back for sure.
author: Joe K.

description: Plantain burrito has changed my life in a seriously positive way. Thin crispy chips & amazing array of salsa are the sexy co-stars of my food fantasies.
author: Stumbalina b.

description: Went here last night and Little Chihuahua is a little dream.  A dollar or two overpriced, but I'm a firm believer that you get what you pay for.  The carne asada is legit and not gummy!  I got the carne tosada salad, BF had the carna asada nachos.  The nachos of course surpassed the salad, because why would a salad ever taste better than nachos... but both were very tasty and large portions. We split the tortilla soup, but took it home because we over ordered.  Best tortilla soup Ive had since Christmas at my aunts house.  The beers are only like $3 and its order and sit kind of service, but the staff is really nice and accommodating.  Overall very satisfied!
author: Jessica B.

description: The one on 24th St.  has delicious food, a little expensive but the quality of the meal is worth it. Clean place, friendly service. My order is usually complicated but they get it right.
author: Pant SF T.

description: I am blown away by the veggie burrito with plantains-what an awesome idea! Their salsa bar is also amazing. Not too into the chips, but man, did I mention the delicious plantain burritos?
author: Sara W.

description:
I'm going to have to strongly disagree with Merkeley. The if it ain't broke philosophy definitely doesn't apply to Papalote. While it's not really my favorite place for a quick Mexican food fix, they have significantly deviated from the standard taqueria formula. 

That being said, Little Chihuahua is MILES ahead of where Loco Taco left off. That placed truly sucked. Poor quality ingredients and in poor portions.  LC, however, has both Niman Ranch beef products, and that other company from Marin that is essentially the poultry version of Niman. Anyway. 

The chipotle salsa is great, even though I'm not big on chiopotle itself and I don't understand how it has completely invaded just about every taqueria. Everything is fresh. The meats taste like they were actually cooked the same day - don't get me wrong, I do love over-stewed heavy meats as well. If you want non-traditional but delicious Mexican fare, this is your place, Panhandle/Western Addition people.

And I'm not entirely sure that you can order a chicked tostada salad, live in the Panhandle, and call ANYTHING yuppie. Plus, do we really need a Farolito in our neighborhood? Is it really all that bad to go TWO MILES for a specific taqueria?
author: Cameron O.

description:
Inexpensive burritos. We had dinner for less than 12 bucks and they used chicken breast!! May not be as authentic as those in my neighborhood, but it definitely hit the spot and the staff could not have been nicer.
UPDATE:
In the last month, I have been here 7 more times at least and have never been disappointed. Their Brunch is fantastic and the carne asada tender. Try the chilaquiles!
author: Adrienne G.

description:
Let me set the scene...

5:45 a.m. Sunday morning: Alarm goes off for Bay to Breakers
6:38 a.m. Shot-gunned my first beer of the day
7:12 a.m. Start walking to the race with friends, sipping on a water bottle full of cranberry vodka
8:00 a.m. until noon: Continue drinking along the race route, playing flip cup along the way and consuming as much alcohol as possible
12:07 Drunkenly reach the 3-mile mark and re-connect with two of our friends that we had lost along the way in the madness
12:11 The crew decides we are "over it" and set out immediately to find food
12:22 We stumble upon Little Chihuahua and are in heaven

Yes, the prices are a little high, and yes I was wasted...but it was one of the best burritos I've ever had, along with some pretty amazing nachos. Go with the Niman Ranch carne asada and you won't be disappointed.
author: Jaymee S.

description:
I have found good Mexican food in San Francisco. It took me a month since moving.

SOMA is very lacking in good, well-priced food.

I went the Little Chihuahua with a few friends last night and was blown away. The salsas are amazing. The portions are great. And the prices seal the entire deal. $2 for draft beer? In San Francisco? I know it's Haight, but I don't recall taking any substances before walking in...
author: Kelly S.

description:
Try the carne asada tacos. It has a delicious flavor, better than anything I have found in the Mission. If you love carnitas like I do, you will be happier getting the beef over the pork here.

The salsa bar has 5 different condiments 4 of which are outstanding with flavor and spice. And if you need a little more heat you can get a cup of Jalapenos to munch on! Chips are average. 

Order a Tamarind drink, set back and look at the paintings of the Mexican card game Loteria on the wall, and enjoy the meal!
author: Ray R.

description:
First Impression: Stale Chips

I tasted some of the salsa choices and they helped, but stale chips in the middle of a Monday afternoon is almost unforgivable.

I hope the rest of the meal is better.
author: Scott H.

description:
Where do I even begin with The Little Chihuahua!! Im a regular there and can not get enough of this place! I live right down the street so I definitely make an appereance here at least once a week- usually more!
I love just about everything. Right now I'm love their enchiladas- one green chili chicken n one guacamole, however if you just get a side of gauc. its just as good! 
I also love their tacos, chicken, shrimp or steak are all good. 
You could also go with a classic burrito! deeeeelish!
Tortilla soup is very yummy but be careful the big white cubes are cheese not tofu but very tasty.
Chihuahua also has Pacifico on drafts which I think is pretty rare, but I like the get the Negro Modelo.
Last but not least, and they have been getting more popular around the city, they have a Mate Tea drink that has changed my life! It gives you such a healthy great energetic feeling, I could drink one everyday!!
Thanks you Chihuahua for the great times, GREAT service, and great food!
author: Kelly P.

description: After getting a delish Indian burrito at SF food fair, my friend had Mexican food craving. I wasn't a fan of Mexican food and although I had TLC on my bookmark for a long time, it's only because I love brunch and they opened for brunch. Anyhow, I went here with my Asian-turned-Mexican friend. I got the plantain burrito. My friend got the plainest burrito probably. This time, she got it right. Hers was better than mine although mine was also delicious too. Either one, I am now converting to Mexican.
author: Cliff T.

description:
I love The Little Chihuahua...the chilequiles are amazing and i love all of the burritos there...especially the plantain burrito...haven't ever been disappointed. I tried out Nopalito around the corner the other day and was totally unimpressed...would rather go to TLC anytime.

I usually get my food to go because the place is small (but super cute-ly decorated) and the wait for a table can be a pain, so to-go is the way for me...YAY!
author: Kitten W.

description:
This place has really turned itself around. I was very happy with my Limon pop and carne asada quesadilla. The chips were warm and fresh, the service was prompt and friendly and I even think the atmosphere at this place is pretty good. 

I'll be back and recommend it to anyone in the general neighborhood! Good Mexican food at decent prices.
author: Al B.

description: One of the best taquerias in the city, and good vibe. Great location, friendly staff, get chips while you wait for your burrito, nice salsa bar. They represent that they care about the quality of their ingredients, which is already leaps and bounds ahead of the competition, whether or not those ingredients really measure up to my standards of quality.
author: Justin K.

description:
We got lucky enough to find a table, those behind us had to wait quite a while. The place was packed and REALLY noisy. We had to yell across the table to try & speak (which we kind of gave up on).

The plantain burrito was interesting and pretty good.  I'd recommend that.

But I had the $10 shrimp burrito was a huge loss. After 2 bites I couldn't eat it - I picked out the shrimp & threw the rest away.  It either had too many spices (I do have a low tolerance for spicey)  or I had an allergic reaction to something in it.  The lower half of my face is itchy and my tongue is still kind of burning.  

I think I will stick to my $4 burritos in the Mission.
author: Kyra T.

description: Delicious, fresh burritos with tight Mexican flavors and a great salsa bar.  Since I'm stranded from my childhood standby of El Burrito Express, I would just consider myself lucky to be within walking distance of a serviceable taqueria.  Lucky for my fiancee and me, we happen to be near Chihuahua and probably spend more time burning through habanero salsa than we should admit.  I always go with a carnitas super burrito, but you can't miss with anything on the menu.
author: P D.

description:
I've eaten a lot of burritos in the US of A (in San Francisco, San Diego, Boston, New York) and this one is so far my favorite. The slightly crispy tortilla is delicious.

I'd also recommend the salad.
author: Roman N.

description: Great shrimp burrito. Made me think food can be a good substitute for guns.
author: Andreas G.

description:
Bowl of tortilla soup - very nice. Loved the avocado & mozzarella like square cheese in the soup. Didn't care for the chunky piece of chicken. Would have been better shredded. 
Vegetarian Taco with Wild Mushrooms - Yummay! (this is making me rate 4 v/s 3 stars) 
Vegetarian Taco with assorted vegatbles - eh.. didn't like it.
Salsa's were alright.. even the spicy ones weren't as spiked. Pancho Villa has spoiled me!
Mimosa - Had passion fruit + orange..made it very soda like. didn't like it.
author: Nilofer M.

description:
I ordered 2 tacos, some nachos, a beer and a drink, and it was $22
Not too bad for a yuppie taqueria.
The food was good, but I think the "cabbage salad" needs to go...
I will definately be back here again.
author: Tom S.

description:
I love this place.  It's a neighborhood restaurant for me, so I go there at least once a week.  It's all about the meat here:  Their shrimp, grilled chicken, and carnitas, are all outstanding.  My personal favorites are the chicken tortilla soup, the shrimp tacos, and burritos with either grilled chicken or carnitas.

The service is very friendly, and it's always a good sign when you see the owner of the place eating there with his family and friends.

I took one star off because the place has been somewhat a victim of its own success.  It is often crowded and the food sometimes suffers during crowded times.
author: Josh T.

description: Recently had their plantain and black beans burrito and it's de-licious!! My new favorite burrito from there. After this burrito I've learned that meat is not a requirement! They also have a good selection of salsa and I love the inside. So welcoming to want to eat there instead of taking it to go.
author: David C.

description:
I typically don't crave Mexican food due to a food poisoning experience at Chevys years ago, but my mouth waters every time I think about the tortilla soup at Little Chihuahua. I'm new to this neighborhood, and I can tell that I will become a regular. 

I came here first when I was [practically] on my death bed...the tortilla chicken soup brought me back to life. The chicken itself was incredible. Definitely not that flavorless, rubbery stuff you usually find in chicken soup. The veggies were perfectly cooked, the broth spicy and flavorful. 

I came here again and got a carne asada burrito, and let me just say Papalote could learn a lesson from the Little Chihuahua. It was moist, tasty, the ingredients clearly very fresh. 

I docked them a star because of the price (I guess that's an SF thing to charge $10 for a burrito), but the food is near perfection. Also they have chilaquiles! I have yet to try them, but I suspect they will be amazing.
author: Em G.

description: Little Chihuahua is by far my favorite taqueria in San Francisco. Its modern Mexican decor, heavy metal music blasting from speakers and updated Mexican food are incomparable.  The NoPa section of Divisadero was in dire need of a Mexican restaurant and L.C. doesn't disappoint.  My favorite item on the menu is the chile verde tofu burrito and the vegetarian nachos.  My carnivorous friends love the chile verde chicken burrito.  Their agua frescas or intoxicating sangria are great beverage options for washing it all down. It's best if you can hit this busy restaurant at lunchtime or pre-dinner rush. 5 p.m. is a great time to savor all the fresh, flavorful goodness.
author: Josh R.

description: I'd come back. Maybe not a go-to, gotta eat there once a week spot, but it does the job. Ordered the shrimp taco. A little less than 5 bucks. It was all piled up on two tortillas, but were perfect for two tacos once they were separated. It got me full. Salsa was decent. It's cozy in there. Probably would only want to go there with one person if I go back. It's just a bit tight, spacewise.
author: Natalie S.

description:
How long has this place been here?!?  I live really close and probably walked by about 8 times before I went in, and I'm kicking myself for taking so long.  The food is good, and the atmosphere is as well, and they even have cheap beers (although I'm a bigger fan of grabbing food here and heading over to the Page next door).  

Excellent place to have a low key and quick dinner that still tastes good and is reasonably healthy... as long as you don't drink all the beer I usually do :)
author: Chris G.

description: Muy delicioso! The garlic and shrimp burrito is the bomb. All organic...can't go wrong!
author: Jaime K.

description:
four stars for the name alone! it reminded me of buster! just kidding! (no, i'm not.)

the bruch here is incredible, the ingredients are always fresh & high quality, the place is a bright & beautiful little hole in the wall, and it's a short little walk from my (best friend's) apartment. everything i could want AND bacon/pancake tacos. GENIUS!
author: Irene S.

description: I ordered a burrito and didn't finish it. I just wasn't impressed. I've had fantastic Mexican elsewhere. I wouldn't return.
author: E. N.

description:
Great atmosphere- Friendly service** Worth the wait if crowded and they turn the tables over fast, so i just stand there and gulp my beer as i crunch my chips--The food- AMAZING- Creative twist with quality ingredients 

Plantain and Black Bean Burrito - Sweet and savory- Da Bomb
Tostadas Salads- Off the hook 10 stars - Best Salad i have ever had!!
I love this place and they showcase local artist/farmers.
author: Rianna N.

description: For a quick eats lunch. I like their garlic shrimp burrito! As a sauce mix I propose chipotle habanero together with pico de gallo. I'd guess that half of the customers take out from this place and half eat here. Little bit tavern style for a date restaurant but seeing mexican renovation crew from around the corner order here similar to three university student girls is a good sign. If there's a line it moves quick.
author: Jari S.

description: The Super Fajita Pollo Asado just went Platinum for me in the San Francisco burrito scene. When someone has to be crowned champion for the Best Burrito in San Francisco at the end of the day, its Little Chihuahua right now. Their Super Carne Asada is legit as well. Complimentary chips and salsa bar before I go Nuclear? "Dios Mio!" This place is legit and offers a relaxing atmosphere for me to crush burritos in. I came in here starving and destroyed a bowl of chips while I stretched, I was simply offered another round of chips while I awaited the main event, thats customer service I can get behind. They also have a garlic shrimp burrito worth putting in your rotation. This place kicks ass. Quit apologizing to yourself and light a fire under your butt and get in here, the time is now!
author: Michael G.

description: They had as two of their burrito filling choices steak and wild mushrooms. I wanted both and they indulged me. Got it super with refried black beans, and it was pretty damn good. Probably the best quality steak I've had in a burrito in the city (though not as flavorful as the king, El Farolito). Even the chips were all-you-can-eat, something places in the Mish charge for now. And the salsas... holy smoke! The only knock is that it's pricey and tiny (you have to queue for a table). Otherwise, I'll be back. Great stop before a show at the Indy.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
Well, I heard good things about this place so on Monday we decided to take a long walk and go check this place out.

It was pretty crowded but we were able to get a table.  Walk up to the counter and order.  Pretty easy.  We were served with chicps that were mediocre.  Tadted like the chips from the huge bag they sell at costco, but the salsas were great.

I liked my tacos.  One carnitas, one veggie.  The carnitas was really juicy...not what im use to.  But tasty.  Beans were pretty bland, though.

My boyfriend was pretty dissapointed as they got his burrito wrong.  But he was hungy and they were busy, so he ate it and thought it was pretty flavorless (or def. flavor lacking)

So all in all, it was OK.  I'd probably go back and give it another try, or to pick up another carnitas taco.
author: Claudia M.

description: Have been to the Little Chihuahua twice so far: They have amazing quesadillas (both the chicken and the steak ones), pretty good nachos and OK enchilladas. Their tortilla chips are great as well as the selection of salsas. Overall, a clean and standard taqueria. 4 stars for the quesadillas!
author: Chris D.

description:
I'm reviewer number 101 which looks like a plate between silverware.
So I am destined to keep writing this even though I rather be watching Death note.

I rave about Taqueria Cancun because they grill their tortillas instead of steaming.
I rave about Cu Co's on Fillmore and Haight because of their "secret menu item" of fried plantain burritos that the lady worker gets really exited about if you order.

Enter Little Chihuahua.
Or rather enter me into ..forget it.
Anyway, This place grills their tortillas AND has a plantain burrito.
I ate it.
and now I rave about them.
Its saves me 50 percent raving.

And the chipotle salsa with chips are the perfect hotness.
Just hot enough to linger to the next bite, but mild enough to keep you dipping.

I never would have come in here without having read good things on yelp.I have passed by dozens of times on my way to get comics at Comix Experience.
I recomend you hit both up soon.
A perfect combo for a perfect day.
author: Micah M.

description:
I ordered a baby burrito with grilled vegetables and black beans. It was good, but nothing special, and the salsa that comes in the burrito was a little too spicy for my taste. Beware if you are sensitive to spicy.

$2 beers, great atmosphere and decor.
author: j o.

description: After an afternoon of absorbing the lively atmosphere on Haight Street, we were at a loss of where to eat for dinner.  My friend pulled out her itouch to seek help.  Luckily, fellow Yelpers directed us to the Little Chihuahua.  We both tried the specialty burritos; she the fried plantain and I the garlic shrimp.  The burritos were a pleasant change from the usual Americanized Mexican fare, where variety only meant switching up the type of meat and beans in our burritos.  Although the restaurant was crowded and bustling, we had enough elbow room and were still able to have a conversation without raising our voices.  The only complaint I had was that the chips were slightly stale, but slathering it in the delicious salsas concealed the staleness, and all was well.
author: Andrew M.

description: I found this place on Cinco de Mayo and wanted some good mexican food.  The place was super cute and tiny.  The food was amazing!!  I got a burrito which was HUGE and pitcher of margaritas to share.  It was all amazing and the service was great.
author: Hillary B.

description: Killer burritos (I had the Plantain) and really tasty nacho chips and salsa bar, which are unlimited. Very hectic inside; you need to queue for food and then hangout and hope to get a table (with strangers) but it all works out, and the staff are surprisingly polite and not brusque at all. Great "real" burritos, with pinky-up fillings and sweet nachos!
author: Michael H.

description:
Love this joint. Their sangria, tortilla soup, plantain burrito, and garlic shrimp burrito are all super yummy. And the carne asada super baby burrito consistently hits the spot.

The thing I love about this place is they get the logistics right, too. They re-designed the space to improve the flow for placing orders and bussing dishes. When they are busy, they ask that people claim a table only after they place an order (not before). Small things perhaps, but they make a difference in the dining experience, and it keeps up coming back as regulars.
author: Michelle A.

description: Wow, the plantain burrito is so delicious (and heavy)...it knocks me out into a coma every time! I literally had to take a 2 hour nap yesterday because of this burrito! Have others had a similar experience or is it just me?
author: N S.

description: I drool over the garlic shrimp burrito.  It's so flavorful, you don't need to make it a super.  Mr. got the plantain and black bean burrito  with pork added, cuban style!  Of all the salsa's, the unanimous favorite was the chipotle.  The tomatillo was too sweet for my taste, and the roasted tomato was on the watery side.  It's not cheap, but its worth it.
author: Lauren M.

description:
While it's probably not the most authentic mexican food around, it sure is damn good. What made this a 5 star place for me is that they use niman ranch and petaluma poultry meats. And their salsa bar is awesome.

While I normally get the chile-verde super burrito, I've also had their carnitas, which are delicious, as is their plantain burrito.

and they have a few beers on tap for $3 a pint, always a plus.
author: B S.

description: Best mexican food I've ever had!! The quality of the ingredients was absolutely unbelievable, especially for the price, and so deliciously seasoned. The ambience is pretty hip and the food doesn't really remind me of "authentic" mexican food at all, but it doesn't matter because it's just unbeatable quality and taste. I am constantly looking for excuses to come here!
author: Keighley M.

description:
This place is great for a casual, fast Mexi-Cali meal. The black bean and plantain burrito is fantastic! 

I do not recommend ordering the sangria or margaritas...but the food is good.
author: Cristin W.

description: I went here with a crowd that is *somewhat* hard to please and let me just say - everyone loved it ! I got the plantain burrito; it was great, and HUGE. I couldn't finish it. The guacamole gets an A+ as does the roasted tomato salsa. I also had the sangria: tasty and potent: perfect. Next time I'm getting the salmon tacos, for sure. Not a place for groups - I wouldn't go with more than four people. Also, it's counter service, FYI.
author: Anne T.

description: Dope food, quick service, great prices, cool interior. Great food stop while drinking on divis.
author: Matt M.

description: great food... not greasy mexican. nice staff! new fave in my hood.
author: Christopher N.

description: I love the plantain and black bean burrito. The extensive salsa bar is great too. Order ahead for pickup and you'll avoid the long lines.
author: brian b.

description:
For starters, not only are the burritoes DELISH... they're huge! After my first visit to the store on 24th st (between Castro and diamond) and splitting a burrito with a friend, I knew I wouldn't be able to devour through one on my own. Skimmed through the menu and decided on a super baby burrito- smaller portioned (still BIG) and the super comes with the goodies----guac and sour cream. Yum! 

Have ordered many veggie baby burritoes from this place and have never been disappointed. Take-out or dine-in (the store on 24th is really nice!!! Lots of seating too), doesn't matter which you choose because the food is consistent either way!!

Recently I decided to try tofu in my burrito...again, so delicious!!
author: Tess B.

description:
I came here on a Wednesday night when I was just too tired to walk down to Castillito (Church at Duboce).  I had heard mixed reviews about The Little Chihuahua, but after my experience, I have to say I was impressed.  To put it frankly, when I go burrito, I go BIG.  I went for the super, smothered steak burrito and was in now way dissatisfied.  Let me tell you that the biggest plus of this place is that they use Nieman Ranch beef, which ups the cost a couple of dollars, but its still as much as some of the terrible burritos you can get for the same price in the Financial District.  

I was very full at the end, but anyone who knows me can attest to the fact that I don't leave any burrito stranded.  Someone once told me a burrito is like a child, but I think its better than that.  A burrito is like Planet Earth: No matter what happens to us, its always going to be around. - Old Samurai Proverb

Also, don't ever go to the Lions Pub in Pac Heights. They are racist! Please refer to my review, which can be found on my profile!
author: Trevor J.

description:
If you like eating spoonfuls of powdered garlic, you will absolutely love the garlic shrimp burrito.  It has an amazing burn that you just can't get from fresh garlic.  

The carnitas are pretty bland.  Instead of cooking it the delicious traditional way, which is by simmering in lard, they braise it in broth.  There are ways to make good carnitas the braising method, but you have to do it right. 

The chicken is okay, but not amazing.  The quesidillas are good, but simple and not worth the price.
