If you go here, I'd recommend the carne asada burrito, as well as the nachos.  Both those options are rather decent.  This place also has $2 beers on tap at any hour, which is great.  The atmosphere is comfortable and enjoyable and the people behind the cash register are friendly and welcoming.  

This place has endearing qualities and it's really the only Mexican option within a reasonable walking distance.  I don't really think it caters to people like myself, but to those looking for a healthier option at the sacrifice of taste and satisfaction.  I'm hoping they switch it up so I can give them a higher rating, but currently 3 stars is fair.
author: kiely c.

description:
Haven't had brunch for ages and finally got the chance to when I took a day off Sunday. And it's my first mexican brunch! yaay
The restaurant is small and we almost missed it when we walked down on Divisadero. However, the decor is really cute! Love the chairs and pictures!! I am surprised they have a pretty extensive menu-- one regular menu and a brunch menu. Although there are only a few selection on the brunch menu, everything looks yum and it took me a while to decide which one to order! Anyhoo, so I ordered the one with 2 scramble eggs (forgot the name sorry!) and Pirate ordered a super burrito(from the regular menu). We also got coffee and horchata The food came pretty fast and they are delicious! What could be better than scramble eggs on top of tortillas with yummy salsa. I am not a big fan of horchata but it's house-made! I had a sip and it's very smooth and flavorful. 
Good food, nice and friendly staff. What a great way to start a sunday
author: Doris H.

description: Sooooo delicious! I want to try other things here but I can't ever stop myself from getting their garlic prawn burrito. It is everything a burrito should be. Plus an agave margarita (good and strong and a little tart). Everything is right in the world.
author: Rhi G.

description: dellicious delicious.    carne asada burrito with guacamole, shrimp burrito, never know which to choose,  good thing i go with a friend and share.......  love the choices in salsa and the little takout containers, i usually get it to go and get some salsa with it.  i try to go at off times/days to avoid the crowd, was in a yoga training a few years ago across the street and lunch it was, small inside but we all make do, friendly place
author: Logyn L.

description:
if you're awake on the weekend to have brunch here, please do! their mexican french toast blew my mind. also, their eggs are organic! all of them. i love being able to eat everything on the menu. 

plus, you can have chips and salsa with your brunch, which at 11am, still feels like i'm getting away with having cookies for breakfast. healthy cookies. 

oh oh oh, and their mimosas are amazing too. (and a little on the strong side)
author: Heidi J.

description: Best burrito. I could eat the plantain burrito every day and never get tired of it. Enough said! Great for takeout. Dine in is fine...if you can find a seat. The chips that go along with the meal is also great. This place is good for a quick stop after work or casual night out with friends.
author: Christina G.

description: This some the best "Mexico inspired" food I've had in sf
author: Leah S.

description: Meh. Not that great. New Valencia white people food. Got the $10 Garlic Shrimp burrito (two strong flavors) that somehow was bland as fuck. While not horrible, you can get better at any of the 100s of real Mexican restaurants in the area.
author: Walter P.

description: Its your basic White washed Taqueira. The food is descent because I can be lazy and not want to walk down to a really good spot. The mushroom quesa-dilla is pretty good. They also have a couple of great soups on the menu!
author: Ethan S.

description: This place is amazing. I love the intimate atmosphere and the staff is so friendly. Not sure if they're still doing the pozole, but I had it for breakfast one weekend and it was TO DIE FOR!
author: Topher G.

description: I've been here twice recently.  Once with my boyfriend to try it out, and then a week later we brought some friends there. While it's not instantly my favorite burrito in the city (hard to beat Papalote) its damn good, and a good place to sit and chill with friends. I've had their chile verde marinated tofu burrito, and the signature plantain burrito. The plantain burrito is really good, but I got a little sick of the plantain about halfway through...they put like a whole plantain in that thing! Still, it's worth trying the plantain burrito experience at least once. The stencil art on the walls is neat too. I recommend this place for a small group of friends or for take-out, as it can be very crowded and seating is limited.
author: Jill H.

description: I'm thinking this might be a hit or miss place because I got nachos to go and they were definitely a miss--we only walked 2 blocks away to a friends house and by the time we got there the chips were soggy and there wasn't enough cheese on them at all to qualify as being called 'nachos'-- but I had several friends tell me to check it out so I may give it another shot since I'm moving to the area soon--but 2 stars stands till it proves otherwise.
author: Krystha B.

description:
Was a bit skeptical of this place at first cause im a mexican food connoseiur, but it turned out to be suprisingly good. I had the plantain burrito(im a plantain connoseuir as well) which comes with all the fixings and was so tasty. Plantains are sweet so it is definitely for those who are down for the sweet/savory combo but topped with some of their wonderful salsa (from the self serve salsa bar), it made my day and was so big that it also left me full for dinner that night and breakfast the next morning- so it made my day and a half! 

Downside would have to be the prices but after just now finding out that they are on their organic grind, i cant completeyl hate on that- its just that i rarely pay $7.95 for a burrito unless it has some type of seafood in it.  All good though, go and support them if you are in the hood.
author: James A.

description:
I am biaised since this one block from my house and unlike many of you, I had no particular animus toward the last incarnation of Loco Taco, though I had become adept at eschewing certain items and basically only ever ordering the same things, but this turned out to be a dream come true.  Andrew and his wife are very friendly, the ambiance is just more freindly and conducive to sitting down than it used to be and since the food is better, there are more people doing so which makes it feel cozier.

The burritos are good, especially the baby, the quesadillas, tacos, nachos and tostados are great.  Unlike some other reviewers, I rather like cabbage on tacos and burritos and I'm also a fan of their salsas.  Since I live nearby, I feel like my input has been heard and considered - the food was a tad insipid at the onset - and now I feel like a 'regular'  which is nice.

More than any other thing, though, I really, really love that they have two wines perfectly selected for this kind of cuisine, a Portuguese Vinho Verde and an Austrian Grner Veltliner, and cheap, too.
author: Michael W.

description:
Great and funky!  Cute little place, wasn't packed for a Saturday brunch.  Service was quick and cordial.  

The food was great.  Interesting menu, eclectic mix of stuff.  Mexican French toast is worth a try!
author: m k.

description: Not worth seeking out. There are better places in the mission for alot less.
author: D C.

description: OMG. I went here for brunch with my brother and a girlfriend of his. She was like... you have to try the salsa. Score. The salsa alone was worth the 10 second wait. ;-) Coming from southern CA I know a few things about Mexican food and salsa. It felt like home. I am going back with a siphon and a refrigerated purse.
author: Nichole S.

description: I have a hard time reviewing places because everything starts to taste the same to me, but I can tell you that I ate the regular burrito with the regular chicken and re-fried black beans. In spite of my dull taste buds and all the regulars I've thrown in this burrito, it was great! The bonus was that it filled me up for the night (which is rare) and didn't make me sick to my stomach (which happens a lot). I'm heading back to Little Chihuahua whenever I need a healthy, filling dinner for way under $10.
author: Corey V.

description: My favorite taqueria in SF (even though it is a little Americanized)  Everything is cooked fresh and the meat is cooked to order.  Love the steak burrito.
author: Michael F.

description: Pretty good.  The only taqueria I've found on Divisadero.  I usually get their Super Vegetarian Baby Burrito and I'm always satisfied.  A little pricey for what it is, but always good if you don't feel like trekking over to the Mission.
author: Marie H.

description:
mm...went for brunch on a sunday, and saw a host of colorful san franciscan kids all around my age. i think i'm just out of place because i always feel out of place and underly pretentious around that lot. ::sigh:: i should try to be more friendly to strangers.

its a small but snug place, with people waiting in the front and the back for tables, pouncing on whatever's free. we just happened to find a little table after we ordered our food and i jammed over to snag a seat. it was mad crowded when we first arrived, but soon dissipated over time, so its probably okay if you don't go during rush meal times.

the salsa bar is awesome, the chips don't seem freshly made, but thats alright because they're free! yay! the food is a little expensive, but the meat makes up for it. got the enchiladas with carne asada, and the steak was blow your mind off amazingly good. almost got in a fork fight with my bf after accusing him of slicing the enchilada with more steak to everything-else ratio. luckily no one was stabbed. the beans and rice were good, but not mind-blowing. the carnitas burrito was alright, but did not compare to the carne asada. get the carne asada. get the carne asada. its the key to head exploding happiness.
author: Jade L.

description: Delicious food made with fresh ingredients and cooked to order - it doesn't get much better than that for Mexican-inspired food in SF. You can actually eat a whole burrito and not feel sick afterwards, because it's not dripping with grease like most other Mission burritos.
author: Viola T.

description: Mike and I really just needed to go to the bathroom and ended up here. We got a quesadilla and some beers while trying to figure out where to go next. The quesadilla was good- nothing special - the beers were pretty cheap too.
author: Mel C.

description: Plantain and black bean burrito, where have you been all my life? Accompanied with a $2 draft Fat Tire, do I need to say more?  Oh yah, free chips and salsa (yummy, crunchy, thick chips and a homemade salsa bar) and great service!
author: Sarah M.

description: I love this place.  Its delicious, clean and has great service. I normally do tacos but the quesadilla is great to.  You can really taste that quality of chicken.  It's quick, cute inside (nothing fancy) and has a great salsa bar. 5 stars!
author: Leah C.

description: Best Garlic Shrimp Burrito! Weirder tasting salsa ever.
author: I G.

description: Garlic shrimp burrito: yummy going in...yeah...we'll leave it at that. My luck didn't get any better with the black bean plantain burrito either :( Don't get me wrong, burritos like me, but not these.
author: Bluey B.

description: The chips and salsa excellent. The service excellent. The aguas excellent, the decor, music and vibe excellent. The fried plantain burrito? Agh! It had the potential to be excellent but the person who took my order mistook my question about what kind of salsa the burrito had, for a request to add pico de gallo (which I HATE in my burritos). So, as a result my burrito was just okay. I'll be back to try it again. I have faith in it's potential for excellence.
author: Dee I.

description: Can't go wrong here. Baby chicken burrito and plantain and black bean burrito always deliver. If you care about such things, watch out for lots of raw onions on tacos and enchiladas.
author: Seth B.

description:
I love Little Chihuahua,  but I also have a love hate relationship with them.  I live a block away, uphill on the way there, downhill on the way back. They are a temptation no one should have that close. I love the sustainable proteins, the garlic shrimp queasily ( haha that was the spell check version) quesadilla and the amazing plantain burrito- due to overexposure in CA (Central America to all you californiacentereds) i don't eat fried banana or plantain unless here or at Zazie. 
Back  on track, my phone has upgraded LT to a "favorite" without asking so that shows the love. BUT twice recently i got a shrimp quesadilla and only had  two shrimp on one half, that sucked!  Unfortunately i really have to say since it got popular - the consistency is def a bit sketchy.
 Being the fan and I do mean fan, that I am and that I eat there a ton I mentioned it good naturedly and the guys behind the counter were awesome and responded they would send me a coupon or something in the mail for a discount or something.  I dont care about a free thing or a discount I just want my shrimpers. Never got either the shrimps on both sides of the quesadilla or coupons in the mail- whatever they were .

hat was a bit disappointing, especially since i doubt shrimp or coupon got lost in the block between my house and the LT.
Last time I ordered the Shrimp Quesadilla I asked for extra shrimp, that cost me $3.50 and sorry but  the shrimp was not much more at all than what I usually get. 
Damn I love you all but are you saying im eating too much shrimp? 8-9 (that's including the extra) shrimp  on a quesadilla for $ 13.00 was pretty disappointing. 

As I said I do love you so i may just order today, but im hoping someone else will read this rather than the very friendly dudes who listened to my bitching before. I don't want free stuff, I just don't want to pay for an empty  tortilla with cheese.

Hmm maybe ill use a nom de plume
author: Alanna M.

description: Awesome fresh mexican food. The shrimp tostada salad is delicious and their salsa is amazing. Can get very crowded and the table clearing tends to take a bit too long, but other than that this place is legit. Try the strawberry aqua fresca!
author: Mariah M.

description:
My hopes weren't high for this place -- the neighborhood generally suffers for good Mexican/Latin fare. But Little Chihuahua is at least a substantially better joint than what it replaced, El Taco Loco. It smells better and it tastes better. I found the variety and taste of the four salsas to be better as well. When it was Taco Loco, the green sauce was sometimes flavorful and sometimes tasted like it was missing ingredients. Some days spicy, other days not.

I ordered my usual -- super carnitas burrito with black beans -- and I thought it was great. It wasn't ridiculously juicy and fatty like the previous folks prepared it sometimes. The serving of chips (when taken to go) comes in a dinky little paper bag, though -- a glorified handful.

Prices aren't down near the competitiveness of the Mission, but now I feel like I'm getting what I paid for. It won't make you cross Cancun or Tonayense off your list, but it's a more than decent substitute.
author: Tom M.

description:
Great service, awesome family style place . Really good food, very clean, and fresh. We go in so much they know us by name, and remeber what we want every single time. 

The Food:
Freshest meat in town, the salsa's have morphed from good to amazing in the last months. excellent quality food!

we eat here almost 3 times a week, and honestly if i had the cash id be there every night, cheap beer, all sorts of other beverages, a wide variety of items on the menu, and just a overall great experience.
author: John R.

description:
GOOD FOOD.  LARGE QUANTITIES. TWO DOLLAR BEER ON TAP.  TAKES CREDIT CARDS.

This would be the best restaurant in the neighborhood if there hours were open later to accommodate late-night drunken eating.
author: Eric B.

description: This place is not joke for good traditional flavors but with better sized portions. The salsa's they make on premises are fabulous, I bring some home to make huevos rancheros with the next day. The food is solid, you come out feeling like a pimp or drug king pin from the real Chihuahua Mexico. Uncle gives 2 thumbs up.....
author: Gomerio G.

description: solid.  i had the carnitas super burrito which was a TON of food and a horchata which was tasty and really creamy.  we also started with some guacamole to have with our chips and salsa- it was pretty tasty, though super limey.  it was definitely full, but we were able to get a table by the time our food came.  yum!
author: Lisa C.

description: I have been waiting to come to this place ever since I saw it on television and on yelp. Then I finally came here on a very rainy after noon. I came in with my cousin puzzled and asking where were we suppose to sit so you can come and wait us(look/attitude) I bet the worker thought I was a snob or acted like one. I got the Garlic Shrimp Burrito and my cousin got the Pollo Asado Enchiladas and two horchata drinks, the total was $27! What the fuck? I guess it is coool since it is organic and local.  The food was okay, it just tasted like normal Mexican food. The burrito had a shit load of shrimps and I like that, but the enchilada seem kinda flavorless! It is pretty cool that there was tofu in there! Gave it a special texture.The horchata drink was too grainy and not enough sugar and cinnamon. I felt like I was drinking water and blended rice.  It is a okay because I thought every thing would be better. I guess it always looks better on TV, right?
author: Janet Z.

description: Forever a Taqueria location at this spot right next to the Page Bar.  Little  Chihuahua opened about a year ago.   This is probably the better of the three recent businesses at this location.  Several great Burrito selections top my choices whenever I come.
author: Anna G.

description: This place has not failed me yet.  A bit above the quality of other burrito places; slightly fancier than street food.  Not that I have anything against street food, but sometimes you want something that feels a little lighter.  Or an interesting menu choice.  There are always huge crowds, and they seem to handle it well.  Delicious salsas.  Just don't forget to get your salsa from the bar, i did the first time i went. Amateur.
author: Corey p.

description: Just had brunch here today. Pretty darn good. I had the huevos rancheros, and my friend had the french toast (if you can call it that). We did have to make a few substitutions to get the vegetarian version but the meals were still quite nice.
author: Jerry S.

description: I've been hearing about this place for a while and everyone says it's so much better than Green Chile. I couldn't disagree more. The food was decent and the prices reasonable, but it was way too spicy and the quality was not as good as Green Chile. I will, however, give it another shot because everyone raves about it.
author: Kandace K.

description: The Little Chihuahua is awesome. they have a good beer selection and I am happy to say that I have never had an average dish at this place. Eveything is fresh, tasty and affordable.
author: Sean K.

description:
The Little Chihuahua is a great alternative to the Mission taquerias.  My go-to orders are the super salmon burrito or super chicken chile verde burrito, with black beans on a whole wheat tortilla.  There's also an option for baby burritos, which are slightly smaller, and 2 bucks less.  Everything is cooked to order, and has a lighter, healthier taste in comparison to the greasy goodness you'll typically come across in the Mission.  The salsa bar is very good too.

One of the downsides is that the Lower Haight location does get crowded.  But, there is a new location in Noe Valley that has the exact same menu, but not quite as popular yet.
author: Alan C.

description: In addition to the information below, I just found out that everything in their kitchen is biodegradable or recyclable. Their poultry is from Petaluma and their vegetables and produce are grown organically and locally. Thumbs up for Little Chihuahua!
author: SF N.

description: After a recent Mexican food debate with some friends, I was surprised to find that The Little Chihuahua was my top south of the border pick in the city for food+atmosphere+location combo (for food, the burrito deluxe at Jay n' Bee is my #1, but it's kind of a pain in the ass to get). Thought this was an important note to add.
author: Stephanie P.

description: pretty good burritos, nothing special
author: Michael E.

description: Just went for brunch - fabulous.  The second thing on the menu is really good but I can't remember what it's called.
author: Reggie G.

description: Ah, my neighborhood taqueria has gone hipster, and now there are lines.  Good for them, sad for me.  Nevertheless, the chicken verde tacos are amazingand I love the nachos (but not to go.  They don't make it well even the 3 blocks I need to go to get home).
author: Karleen O.

description:
i wanted to love this place from the moment i heard its name and love it i did. i came for brunch and got the breakfast burrito and also got to try the mexican french toast. both were delicious! i was stupid and didn't think to add bacon to my burrito but i won't make that mistake next time. 

my only gripe would be that chairs/tables were so close together that i kept bumping my knee under the table and getting in and out was kind of a hassle (we were at a table of 4 against the wall) but the service made up for it. the place is really bright and cheery from what i remember and as an added bonus, the coffee is really good here too.
author: georgette y.

description: Check, check it out! Cool spot to grab some excellente Mexican food. Anytime I don't feel like cooking, I go here. If you live close by, call in your order and by the time you walk over, your food is ready to be picked up. Not the best place for groups to go because it's quite small inside, but if it's a nice day outside, I would suggest eating in one of the nearby parks.
author: Lauren F.

description: The salads are AMAZING. The ingredients are super fresh & they never use too much salad dressing. All I've got to say.... is give this place your business. Yes, you have to bus your own table, but it's truly a gem of a mexican place in the city!
author: Becca O.

description: Say it with me: sustainability, Sure, it's, like, sooo in right now, but if ever something should become (and remain) trendy, might as well be something that's good for this earth. Mad props to Little Chihuahua for going this route (more restaurants need to). And it doesn't hurt that the food is tasty. Love that you can get a baby version of the burritos (and I can't even finish on of those). I get take out from here all the time and it has yet to disappoint. Mainly stick to the burritos; yummy salsa too.
author: Jasmine F.

description: Little Chihuahua is the best Mexican cuisine around the Haight. It's a small place, nice, but don't expect background music or fancy interior; all you'll get is tasty, nice food, and that's exactly why you are there.
author: Tamas K.

description:
High quality ingredients, friendly wait staff, ridiculously flavorful and fresh food with a GREAT variety of salsas (must have with ANY entree) make this place a neighborhood gem. I eat here almost every single week and I love it. Some of my favorites are their carnitas (in enchiladas or a burrito), the garlic shrimp burrito, and on weekends their huevos rancheros. Honestly though, everything there is tasty. 

They are even eco-friendly: unlike most restaurants they actually compost and recycle and they use local and organic ingredients. My ONLY complaint is that it's sometimes a long wait and really crowded (like many delicious restaurants). if you're close-by please do yourself a huge favor: GO.
author: Evan W.

description:
simple good mexican food
consistent in its quality

will be back many times
author: Trent D.

description: This place is good if you are craving a burrito and don't mind salsa bars, which I personally find creepy and weird. I'd pass on the margaritas.
author: Irene P.

description: Lots of fresh salsas to choose from that are all amazing!  I am a fan of the taco soup and my boyfriend always gets the carne asada smothered super burrito.  Both are fantastic along with the rest of their menu!  So good and very authentic!
author: Alex W.

description: Being half Mexican & from LA, I know good Mexican food. This spot really impressed me. We were wandering around SF doing the tourist thing and decided to stop for a bite. I was apprehensive at first, but that carne asada burrito & pozole blew me away. Everything tasted fresh and healthy. No greasy Mexican food here! Most importantly, they hit the spices dead on! Their dark red salsa & torilla chips were insanely good as well.
author: saul g.

description: The carnitas here are fantastic.  So is the salsa bar, and the tortilla soup, and the nachos.  The decor is pleasant and the tables can be moved around with a little effort if you have a big group.  It does get really crowded at dinner time on a weekend, so try to avoid coming during that time.  Takeout available so call ahead and save the waiting.  Cheep beer on tap is a plus, too.  Lovely neighborhood spot as a fancier alternative to the nearby taquerias.
author: kate m.

description: The fancy sign out front and the mood lighting is about all I found interesting here.  My tacos with rice and beans were underwhelming with very little flavor.  The chicken was somewhat tough and the chips and salsa uninspiring as well.  I had a superior taco plate at La Salsa (of all places) a few days back.  Lil Chihuahua needs a chef to oversee the flavors here.  Until then I'll be gettin' my taco on at Papalote or Green Chile Kitchen when I'm in these parts.
author: P H I L H.

description: Came here with some friends to have a chill dinner celebration before heading out for the night. Off the bat they get extra points for letting us bring in champagne to drink - AND they serve alcohol (don't know if I've ever been anywhere that sells drink and still lets you sip your own). I ordered a delicious super burrioto and friends had the salman tacos - which looked delicious as well. The vibe was chill and a good spot if you're in the area and want some quality Mexican eats.
author: Lindsay A.

description: I wanted to like this place so bad! Sadly, I couldn't. The guac was flavorless, the burritos gave me heartburn (I do not get heartburn), the salsa was not tasty, the burritos were just... Not authentic. However, if authentic isn't how you like it (and I know some people don't really like authentic Mexican), this may be a good place for you.
author: Andria M.

description: This place is great. It's a little more upscale than the taquerias in the Mission, but totally worth it. It's in a great location (really easy to get to and plenty of bars around to go after), so that's always a plus. The salsa verde is to die for and their portions are nice and big!
author: Daryah N.

description: Love. Loved everything about this place except that the door was wide open on a very cold day - no major biggie. It is also a refreshing change to see a place not so heavily dependent on plastic utensils and such. Great choice of tortillas/salsas/beans/meats and veggie options. I recommend!
author: Jack G.

description: I'm from Seattle where the burritos are average. The burrito I ate at The Little Chihuahua rocked my world. I deduct one star because there was a small rock or bone fragment in my burrito that added an unpleasant crunch for one bite. That said, I can accept a simple mistake and will definitely be back when I return to San Francisco. The salsa bar is  wonderful.
author: C F.

description: The chili cup cakes are really quite delicious. The horchata is among the best I've had: silky, thick, flavorful and refreshing. The plantains are really good. The tomatillo and fire roasted tomato salsas are Excellent. Definitely stock up on them. (They sell pints but I always find myself just carting away 6-8 of the little condiment holders...) Decor is very much upscale, kind of hip, kind of white. Also, decidedly fresh ingredients, also name branded meats (niman, rosie, etc.). Solid, solid taqueria, if not the most culturally authentic. (Haven't covered burritos in this review, but they're obviously quite good. focusin' on peripherals.)
author: Will T.

description: The burrito is decent enough, the chips and salsa are wonderful. Staff is great. Building is usually crowded.
author: Alex R.

description: Cozy (read small and tight fit trying to avoid bumping into people sitting at adjacent tables...and adjacent may be a misnomer, they're all stacked right next to each other, so make a friend) groovified Mexi tacqueria with hip staff,  assortment of excellent salsas(though their habanero salsa has a tad too much vinegary-lime taste) with durn tasty food..try their plantain burrito for something different...small selection of some good beers, pleasant ambience..I liked it, and thats not always easy for someone who hates Americanized Mexi food, having substantially grown up in the wilds of the East Los barrio.
author: Tom B.

description: Had the chicken tortilla soup and a chicken taco. Both were very good. The chips were slightly stale, but the salsa selection and quality made up for it. All this and $2 beers add up to a great addition to the neighborhood.
author: Dustin E.

description:
I was working from home today, and phoned in an order at Loco Taco, simply because it's a burrito and it's within two blocks of my abode.  

"Little Chihhuahua" they answered.  I thought I had the wrong number, and had a revelatory moment when the nice girl on the other end of the line informed me that it's no longer Loco Taco.  New owners, same location.

I got a grilled chicken burrito with guac.  They grill-to-order, like Papalote.  Not heat-up-the-diced-meat-scraps, but actually grill a chunk of animal on a rack.  If you're not into that, which it seems like a good amount of SFers aren't, they also offer grilled tofu verde- which I'll get next time.

Service nicer than previous place, food definitely better, but yeah if you want cheesy nachos and a pitcher of Bud, perhaps it's not the place for you.  +1 for playing Manu Chao when I came in.

And yes, the 'ambience' is basically the same as Loco Taco, with different chairs.  It's a taqueria, folks.  Just be psyched that it's actually good and close by!

UPDATE:  I went back twice since for the tofu chili verde, and it kicks the chicken's ass!
author: Arlo J.

description: I wanted to love my dishes, but in all honesty - I'd rather have any Mexican dish from the Mission any day - price beats it, flavor beats it.. their salsa bar is fun though... but yeah.. Mission.
author: Jeannette L.

description:
meh is right.
i call this kinda place "honkey-mex."
i'd eat there again, but not in any rush.
author: Alland B.

description: This was outstanding, best burrito I have had. Staff very nice and friendly. I highly recommend eating here.
author: Mike P.

description: I love the Little Chihuahua! Their tortilla soup is very unique and delicious. I think their burritos are only second to Papalotte burritos. Their  carne asada quesadillas are super delicious, too!! I think their best marks go to their steak and their tortilla soup. I can't say their salsa or pico de gallo is especially amazing. I return here again and again!
author: Majel B.

description: So many Mexican restaurants in San Francisco. This one didn't disappoint. Four of us split two burritos and two nacho orders. We also ordered the chili pepper chocolate cupcakes. Not great - very dry. But hey, we were there for the savory stuff so now we know to take our sweet cravings elsewhere.
author: Steve J.

description: Kid friendly, tortilla soup is incredible. Staff is extremely friendly, restaurant M.O. Is self serve - order at counter, access to water, salsa; bus your own table with recycle and compost bins. We will definitely be visiting again next time we're in town!
author: Steven K.

description: I wasn't completely miserable but for what you can find elsewhere, it was bad.  Maybe the secret is not going for breakfast, but I was unimpressed.
author: Max A.

description: Black bean and plantain burrito=heaven. Thank you, God.
author: Bee H.

description:
You know how after a couple hours at the gym, pretty much anything tastes good? Well, LC managed to totally eff it up tonight. I was super excited to get the black bean & plantain burrito, since I hadn't made my own (need I say great) version in a while. The menu said it came with roasted red peppers, cheese, salsa, rice, sour cream, onions and cilantro. I asked them to nix the last 4 items, and while I understand that can complicate things, if every taqueria east of Divis makes me a perfect burrito every time, I figure LC can too, especially if the thing costs $8.50.
  The burrito I got had plenty of plantains, a TON of sour, watery salsa that made the tortilla soggy right away, the onions and cilantro I asked not to get, and about 20 black beans total. I'm pretty sure there was no cheese or roasted red peppers either.
  They botched our other order too, but I'm not even gonna go there except to say that they skimped on beans (beans!) in that one too. $20 later I feel gipped and nauseous.
I dedicate my one star to the chips and salsa.
author: June D.

description: This is now my official neighborhood Mexican spot, goodbye Papalote, hello Little Chihuahua. First off they make four or five salsas, and don't screw you on the chips. The counter guy is super nice, never get the order wrong. The Camarones quesadilla is super good, as well as the burritos, which also conveniently come in a 'baby,' size if you're not starved. The beef is Nieman Ranch and they have no problem scoopin' out the sour cream. Store is clean and they put lots of tasty veggies into their food. Can;t give a five because when compared to Lap Palma on 24th and Bryant or or my all time fave , el Farolito it's just not as divine, but still, pretty damn good. Bravo!
author: Steve l.

description: Honestly the name of this place managed to turn me off every time I walked by. But today I looked inside and saw all of the carved wooden chairs, the cozy homeyness of the place... I went back to try their fried plantain and black bean burrito. O.M.G. The flavors were so perfect I ate the entire thing in one sitting, savoring every last bite.  Washed it down with some cheap red wine and I was in absolute heaven. The chipotle salsa was rich and scrumptious too. The space is tight and awkward for maneuvering around in, but the service is hard-working and extra nice.  :)
author: ella j.

description: I love this place! It is close to my house and the food is delicious. Also, the margaritas can't be beat. I tried the tortilla soup the other night and I was not disappointed, it was very good and there were large chunks of chicken, avocado, and other veggies. Seating can be tough, but the staff is good about keeping track of who is next to be sat. Also, if you are a true lover of spicy salso, the habanero wont disappoint you.
author: Julia T.

description: Ack - the neverending garlic aftertaste.  Adjust this and I'd switch to 4 stars.
author: Dr. K.

description: If I happen to be walking by this shop and I have already eaten I still stop in and order something.  Dining in is always a treat.  The atmosphere is always festive and shares a hint of the gourmet with the food.  Whatever you choose to order, try adding a bit of grilled veggies to it.  I've heard some good things about the brunch menu, too.  The Little Chihuahua has a big bark.  Woof!  Me Encanta!
author: Erin F.

description: Thank god for The Little Chihuahua, or there would be days when I wouldn't eat. Yes, I'm that lazy. I was nervous for the change, having frequented Loco Taco and quite enjoying their burritos. But, a girl's gotta eat. So, a couple weeks after the change I gave it a try. At first, I wasn't too sure. It seemed as though the burrito wasn't as tasty as it used to be. And it seemed as though the people not as friendly. Perhaps I was imagining things because I've been back many many times (like every other week) and I love their chicken super burrito. And the people are quite nice as well. Soon they will be serving weekend brunch. I look forward to it!
author: Nina H.

description:
$2 anchor steam & fat tire on tap. any time of the day. 5 stars.

6 different types of salsa. 5 stars.

4 different tortilla options. 5 stars.

fun decor & fireplace. 5 stars.

talkative, friendly, and polite staff. 5 stars.

hot chips brought to your table. unlimited. 5 stars.

above average food, not great, but very good.
small portions for a big boy :(

still trying to get over those $2 draft beers....
author: Victor B.

description: Casual atmosphere, good prices, love the protein choices (tofu tacos. ...yum!) and good beverage choices (both alcoholic and alcohol-free). The staff were efficient and helpful. The habanero sauce was sooooo good! Really, they had me at "tofu" and "habanero".
author: Sarcastic T.

description: I really like this place!! Parking is pretty bad- what do you expect in Divisadero, huh? The place is tiny but the food is good and the meats are all natural. We ordered the super burrito with grilled chicken and the nachos with carne asada. Both were delicious. The portions were very generous and the quality of the meat was fabulous. They put this delicious red chile sauce on their nachos that gave them an extra kick. Absolutely delicious. I'll definitely be going back.
author: Grace G.

description:
i love this place!
so i'm a bit biased, because right now my art is hanging on their walls, but aside from this, i still think this is the best mexican food around that also has a great setting (the taquerias in the mission are always on the dingy side).
i've had brunch there and i've had the burritos. i have yet to have the entire menu, but all of it sounds delicious. great sangria and mimosas for brunch and cheap beers on draft as well. i love it!!!
author: Kerri B.

description: Super Mexican in the neighborhood. Better than all the cheap taquerias around. Try the Agave Wine Margarita. Mmmm.
author: Kurt O.

description: Delicious. Fresh. Always packed but super quick. Their nachos and carnitas are the best around. I wish the carne asada was more thinly sliced but that's just my preference.
author: Leeroy B.

description:
Very, very good new taqueria right on Divis.  Tacos are delicious and you get a lot of great food for your money.

Cheap beer on tap is a huge plus and it never seems too busy to find a table.  Welcome to the neighborhood!
author: Kris E.

description: I love this place! Good burritos, nachos with generous toppings, choice of Niman Ranch beef, and spicy habanero salsa! I like coming here with friends for dinner and a beer. It's not too small, it's kinda cozy, and is a safe pick for quick, yummy Mexican food.
author: Rose R.

description:
i'm a mission burrito snob. whenever i leave the mission i tell myself i won't eat burritos because how could they be as good as in the mission?

but last night i was pleasantly, ever-so-pleasantly, surprised by the plantain burrito. fantastic. flavorful. wonderful. i loved it so much that i drooled on it -- and it wasn't even my burrito. that's how good it was.
author: omar k.

description: This was recommended highly by my boyfriend's brother. We got, as recommended, the plaintain and black bean burrito - which you absolutely must get! It's a small place but has a nice atmosphere, the food is good and fairly reasonably priced. I've gone vegetarian this month and it had lots of options for me. I definitely recommend it!
author: Rachel P.

description: They were one of the vendors at Outside Lands this year and I saw they had a PLANTAIN BURRITO. That sounded supper interesting. I was hesitant at first cuz I was like.. no meat? That's bananas!!! Lmfao. Anyyyyywaaays. I was not at all disappointed. It was sweet and savory all at the same time. Soo full of goodness. I'd love to try it again.
author: Mila B.

description: Long Live Little Chihuahua! You killed the evil Loco Taco...the wicked witch of taquerias.
author: Whit P.

description: I love that they have "baby" sized burritos that I can actually eat in one sitting. Lots of options. Love the plaintains!
author: Ashley M.

description: Their plantain and black bean burrito makes me reconsider becoming a vegetarian.  But then I have a carnitas super burrito, and my mind changes again.  Cute place, great wood furniture and awesome art on the walls.
author: Padraic W.

description: The best bowl of tortilla soup in San Francisco is not in the MIssion--it's in the Lower Haight, at The Little Chihuahua!  Succulent chunks of chicken, toothsome cubes of cheese, generous slices of avocado...just sublime!   Even after a week in Puerto Vallarta, I still couldn't wait to come home to this stuff!  Spice it up with one of the homemade salsas, and for a really hearty treat, ask for a side of chopped chorizo and dump it in.  Enjoy it with an agave wine margarita.  The rest of the food is quite good, too, but what can I say?   My name is Michele, and I am a Little Chihuahua tortilla soup addict.
author: Michele W.

description: I really love this place.  I've tried most of their dishes.  It has the good feeling of the young couple who own and run it.  It clearly is a great value for the money.
author: ROCCO S.

description: I love The Little Chihuahua! The rice and grilled vegetables are fantastic for people who are on limited diets and the tortilla soup is a work of moderately priced art. I am so happy that there is an accessible, organic, fresh, Mexican restaurant near me. Also, the staff is friendly and helpful. I heard a complaint about the music, but today they were playing Ozzie, and how can you not love I am Iron Man? Also, they have sweeter touches, like house made chocolate spice cupcakes. Yay!
author: Anna K.

description: Very good Mex, but not your cheapo burrito. It's priced for hipster gringos, and also increasingly packed with same. If what you want is high-quality $8 burrito and you don't mind standing in a cramped line for 20 minutes to get it, you'll be very satisfied. If you want cheap and quick, head to the Mission.
author: K C.

description: I love Little Chihuahua. The golden lighting is flattering (good date spot), there are nice tables and some mex. beer (good friend spot) and as my friend Julie noticed, there is consistently at least one cute boy to stare at if you get bored of your company. Pollo Asado Super Burrito with pinto or black beans = Heaven. My friend from philly came to visit and we ate here three times during the week. So tasty. A good dinner for under $8. Aviso: the chairs are top heavy, take care getting out of them or suffer an embarrassing chair toppling scene.
author: Dana H.

description: I miss living around the corner from their carne asada super baby burritos.
author: Mr. T L.

description: My husband and I came here for dinner and were very impressed. The agave wine margarita was a fantastic meal-opener, and the fried plantain burrito was wonderful. The plantains were just sweet enough to be a good counterpoint to the spice in the salsa. Speaking of which, the salsas and thick, crunchy chips were awesome. My husband had chicken tacos with the vegan black refried beans and loved it. And it was only $25 dollars! We'll definitely be back.
author: Ramon E.

description: Fresh, high quality, delicious. I was so impressed by the tostada salad (and really, how impressive can salad be?). It was so tasty I didn't use a drop of salad dressing - just some of Little Chihuahua's delicious tomatillo salsa. Order the salad with carnitas and you will not be disappointed.
author: Beth T.

description: The Little Chihuahua is a bit overrated, I must say. We had the Garlic Shrimp burrito and the Fajita. I insisted on ordering the plantain and black bean burrito, but my family believes a meal with no meat is no meal at all. Sigh. So we ate. The chips are all-you-can-eat, so don't be afraid to ask for refills. The burritos were nothing out of the ordinary. They don't taste bad, but they're definitely not superb as well. The steak doesn't really have a special grilled taste, nothing was extremely aromatic. I loved the salsa and condiment bar. Self-serve and you can take all you want without feeling embarrassed. That's a plus, since most taquerias and Mexican joints nickel and dime you with the sauces and extras. The chips were a bit stale, but good since they weren't drenched in oil. I guess I'd come back here if I was around in the neighborhood, but it's definitely not something you should go out of your way for. Let's get some real authentic Mexican food!!!
author: Colleen W.

description: The Little Chihuahua was pretty good, the dishes we all ordered were the salmon tacos, fried plantain and black bean burrito, and the chicken tostada, all which were good. I want to go back to try the brunch specials.
author: Carol B.

description: Only four blocks from my house, this place is perfect for a hangover Sunday morning meal. Their mock margaritas are like 4 bucks and help with the hair of the dog you need so badly. tap beer is two or three bucks always. The chicken tostada I got last time was epic. And I hate to use that word, but really. It had chopped mango, cucumbers, a touch of cotija cheese, grilled tender moist chicken, tomatoes, crispy shell, black beans. I ate two more meals at of this big bad boy! The enchiladas were wonderful the last two times I got them as well. They have a variety of awesome salsas they make in house as well. I combine the smoked chile with the habanero and it hits the spot! I dont know what happened, but apparently they worked whatever kinks they had to out, because A group of us go every couple of weeks and it's the shit!
author: monika l.

description:
aye chihuahua! 

while the name itself is alluring, the food made our visit completely worthwhile. really cute place! even though you order at the counter, it feels like a sit down restaurant. it feels very authentic, beautiful art lines the walls and the furniture is rustic. 

we intended to go for brunch, but ended up having lunch instead. i ordered the camarones tostada, which was a nice twist from a regular tostada salad. the shrimp was well seasoned, placed on top of a blend of mixed greens with lime-cilantro dressing evenly dispersed throughout the salad. a thin layer of black beans was placed at the base of the tostada , which was nice because there was more room for other ingredients. the salad definitely felt hearty, and I was completely stuffed afterward. the tostada also had pico de gallo, cucumbers, mango salsa and roasted red bell peppers, that all complemented the flavor of the salad. I also had a nice margarita with my meal for $5. really clean flavors, and not overly sweet. great margarita for a great value! i'll definitely be back for brunch some time.
author: Jessica S.

description: Excellent little place that goes beyond your local ho-hum burrito hut. Having a Negra Modelo with a burrito also goes a long way. Street parking is pretty easy on that part of Divis, and it has great ambiance. Good work.
author: nico w.

description: So this place tries to take a healthy fresh California twist on Mexican food and it does an ok job doing so.  I had some tacos and I like the quality an flavor of the meats: carne asada niman ranch and carnitas.  However some other things were total misses.   The salsa was watery and flavorless.  The tortillas looked just like the ones you buy at trader joes.  The dessert we ordered had cookies that they sell at trader joes.  The tortilla chips we got were also pretty much like chips that you would buy at a grocery store.  That all put me off considering the amount of money I paid to have all these things.  So overall I thought it was kind of overrated.  Not the worst place I've been to though.
author: Ben K.

description: Salsas are excellent! Tried the tofu taco - not a winner for me! It was too bland. But the mushroom tacos were an interesting change - kind of smoky flavor and I enjoyed them.
author: Taisha R.

description: Yummy burritos!!! The super baby burrito is my favorite--filling and reasonably priced.  Their salad is also delicious in addition their agua fresca!
author: Susie B.

description: I was only a couple doors down from Little Chihuahua, at Madulsalon having a friend of mine work on my new cut and color. We were getting hungry, so she told me about this great Mexican restaurant  within sight from the salon. I ordered a Super Burrito with Niman Ranch Steak.  It was a very good size. I love getting burritos that are huge and this one was up to par with wat I like. I bit into it and the flavors mixed in my mouth, everything tasted so fresh and awesome and the steak was soooooooooooooo yummy. I woofed it down with in 5-6min. It made sure I was full till I went out for dinner at 7pm.
author: Jonathan W.

description: You know that guy, whose number you keep in your phone, just in case you're home on a Friday night and bored. Well, that's The Little Chihuahua. If you want a real man, or a real taco, you've gotta go the distance, and that means hauling your butt over to the Mission for a real Mexican meal. Yes, the tacos are toasted, yes the ingredients are fresh, and the decor is pleasant. But, the food has no flavor and the menu is limited. Like I said earlier, this place will do for the Sadie Hawkins dance, but you gotta go to the Mission to find your prom date.
author: I B.

description: This place is an okay solution to a busy, run-around Wednesday night when you haven't even THOUGHT about dinner plans, and are too lazy to cook. Standard burrito, which is not the best in the city, but is also far from the worst.  Acceptable prices, acceptable food, but nothing to write home about.
author: katie p.

description: The food here is outstanding, and the staff are friendly.  The only downside is it's been totally crowded every time I've been there-- presumably because it's so awesome.
author: Kurt M.

description: This is one of the more enjoyable little Mexican places in the area. The food is more creative than your basic tex-mex, the atmosphere is pleasant, and they have good beers and sangria. I go here frequently.
author: Mark C.

description: So... I recanted my not-my-first but second, not-so-nice review about this place as I felt the owner was respectable and really cared about his business. But having now been confronted by him (albeit politely so), I can no longer frequent the place. I'm a fuzzy creature being run over by a car. He could very easily  recognize me.
author: D'arcy N.

description: I agree with a lot of comments already made and found the carne fajita burrito to be really good.  The plantain burrito was also really good, but i have to admit a little too plantainy, and i am a big fan of plantains... maybe would have been better with a little less plantains, and maybe the addition of some chicken or something... Sangria was fine, but nothing special.  Pretty good salsas and chips, but also nothing to write home about.. nice place to chill in the neighborhood and not have to make the trek down to the mission - but also lacking in some areas.
author: David F.

description: Chi-WOW-WOW! Cozy, casual and reasonable, The Little Chihuahua is a great find.  Order at the counter; the staff will bring you your food, drinks and will bus the tables. Dishes are generous, fresh and pretty. The tortilla soup and taco salad were ENORMOUS. Start your meal with chips (included) and salsa from the bar. Watch out for the habenero salsa -  I loved it, but it is HOT. In fact, most dishes were spicy. Carne Asada is a must try!  Tender, smoky and great with homemade guacamole.  The Sangria Carafe ($18) was enough for 2 to get really tipsy; 4 could easily share.  The sangria was tangy and spicy at once; the fruit was plentiful and oh so tasty.  Staff was friendly and, as I said, prices were more than reasonable. Dinner for two with a carafe of sangria was approximately $35 before tip. Yum.
author: Jenni D.

description:
i feel very lucky to live a block away from this place. It is great for high quality, fresh, gringo mexican food. their wild mushroom tacos are delicious! they also have a tasty brunch menu- which is great for lazy weekends when the first meal of the day invariably starts after noon. 

my two objections are that it's a little on the expensive side, and it can be hard to get a table. overall though, an awesome spot.
author: hannah c.

description: Ordered a chicken tostada salad.  Great veggies - nice use of red peppers.  A little too much dressing for me.
author: Dean H.

description: The plantain burritos are amazing!  It's the perfect marriage of savory & sweet.  I know I've had other things from their menu and they were all good, just not as memorable as those delicious plantain burritos.
author: Sarah C.

description:
Clean fish salmon taco = so good.
Not sure how they put it together so well, but here are two things I noticed.  Cream seemed sprinkled on for perfect distribution.  Not the normal blob plopped on in taquerias that you bite into and get a mouth full of bland oily cream and gag.
Red onions cooked to that perfect point where they are still a little crunchy but soft and sweet?  I've never had red onions that good outside of my south american mom's kitchen.  Kinda crazy. That's huge.  I think it's why most people don't know how good red onions can be?  Anyway...
So good.  Thank you Little Chihuahua I LOVE YOU.  You make all my sucky days instantly better.
author: h i.

description: Great burritos, good prices, friendly people, I like!
author: R S.

description: Holey Moley, I'm not a burrito lover, there's always just too much rice and it's too filling. The Garlic Shrimp burrito in the chili-tomato tortilla I just ate, however, has just converted me into a burritophile of the grandest scale! Good thing I live across the street from The Little Chihuahua! Or is that a bad thing?
author: N. L.

description: Just wanted to update my old review for this place and say that the food has remained fantastic.  I got a chicken fajita burrito here the other night and couldn't have been more pleased with it.  This place is a real boon to the neighborhood.
author: Joshua W.

description: just want to say that the Noe Valley location is just as awesome. it was so nice of Andrew to open a location over here on our new side of town. and i love that they were able to include an outdoor seating option at this location. yay!
author: Ellen S.

description: Cute spot. Went last night before a show at the Independent. Love the idea behind this spot - fresh, healthy, Earth-friendly Mexican food. The chips and salsas were great, and our burritos were both delicious. I had the garlic shrimp - and let me tell you, they're not kidding about the garlic. But, it was really good. It's a tiny place but there are nice tables and pretty windows, way higher end experience than your typical burrito shop. You're paying closer to $10 for a burrito, but for these kinds of ingredients and this kind of setting I think it's definitely worth it.
author: Sarah R.

description: This is my neighborhood taqueria...I eat here several times a week. Everything is great - tortilla soup, tostada salad, black bean and plantain burrito and of course the usuals (tacos, burritos, enchiladas). Brunch is also a hit.
author: Jason P.

description: Damn good meat (especially the carne asada).  Awesome tortilla chips. Burritos used to have an unusual tangy quality, like salad dressing, but now feature more standard burrito flavor.  $2 bottled sodas - not just the Mexican coke, but also the Jarritos (which should honestly be cheaper).  Agave wine margaritas are really good, especially if you don't want the alcohol kick that tequila provides. This place is totally packed around dinnertime on weekends, so plan to wait, or visit during non-peak hours.
author: Brett N.

description:
Came here last night for dinner at around 19:00 the restaurant was half full.  But by the end of our meal the tables where packed and their was a line to place your order.  Try to come early to avoid the wait.  The restaurant is on the small size and can get claustrophobic and hot due to the kitchen.  At first I was a bit confused on the ordering, either "A" do I sit down and they take my order or "B" go up to the counter/kitchen area and place the order.  The answer is B you make your order at the counter grab your number and pick a table. Just like Farolitos or a Tres Amigos whole in the wall restaurants.  I wasn't expecting that here, since the restaurant looked more nicer then a Farolitos.  After placing your order and picking your table you can then go to the small salsa bar. Get your salsa of choice and your utensils and enjoy with your free tortilla chips.

The food came out fast and hot. I had the two enchiladas in red guajillo sauce rice and black beans.  When I first saw the enchiladas, they looked smaller then regular size tortillas but that could of just been an optical illusion?!... anyways. One of the enchilada was grilled chicken and the second was carne asada.  Both very tasty meat moist and enough cheese in the enchiladas.  The red guajillo sauce had a nice spice which lingered in every bite from beginning to end.  I love having that spice through out my meal.  The black beans where a nice side, a bit creamy and went well with the rice.  My friend had the carne asada burrito, whole wheat tortilla.  I had a bite of the burrito and to my surprise it was very tasty.  Next time I will opt for the burrito.  Don't forget to wash everything down with their home made horchata.  It was spectacular! Not like you would get at any other Mexican place.  It had a fresh taste and the cinnamon was not over powering, a bit thicker then most horchatas but not as sweet, very tasty.

One thing that I did notice eating at Little Chihuahua is that for once I was the minority in a Mexican/Tex Mex restaurant.  From start to finish of the evening every customer coming in and out of the place where caucasian.  Oh and yes I do think this is more Tex Mex (Americanized) Mexican food.  Thus adapting to the caucasian crowed.  Nothing wrong with that.  It does give boring/regular everyday Mexican food a twist.  Which I enjoy every now and then.  Would I return to Little Chihuahua? Yes I would!  One thing I did not enjoy are the bulky chairs, its so hard to move around, pull in and out of the tables.  I'm thinking its the tile and the wood that are not getting along.  Wish they can slide in and out more easily.
author: David P.

description: I had their mexican french toast for brunch and it was hearty and delicious.  the staff is super nice, the environment is chill and the chips were fresh and tasty.  great place.
author: Frances L.

description: I dream about that wild mushroom burrito! The food is yummy and I enjoy eating it here, the ambiance is way better than it used to be. So glad they got recognized on Best of Bay! Now I can't wait to go try the plantain & black bean burrito!
author: Gwen V.

description:
my man and i go here pretty much every Sunday. they've got something to say about chilaquiles ... while i love them at Los Jarritos on South Van Ness @ 21st, i don't necessarily want to trek across town on a Sunday, right?  so we go down the hill to Little Chihuahua. 

it beats the shit out of the dump that was in the space before, Taco Loco i think it was, which had nothing but the usual disinterested staff ... more disgruntled than the bitter folks at Azteca on Church near Market.  there're two dudes who man the register in the evenings, both kind of hot/cute in their own distinct ways. but the person we really love is the most wonderful woman on weekend mornings ... we talk tattoos and alternative family arrangements while ordering.

they could do with new furniture since the chairs are too high for one to get their legs under the tables which is annoying. 

and they could do with a more adult-behaved clientele; i am so fucking tired of people who roll into order-at-the-counter places and get in line while one of their party take a table ... that's so high school cafeteria and typically self-centered Californian behavior.  but that's another story.

UPDATE: there's a new person working here who makes the aforementioned hot guy aspect of the place a triple threat!!!
author: Kevin M.

description: I really had no idea this place was so affordable. Pretty good food - I especially like that they servce breakfast/brunch. Although the chilaquiles weren't close to "authentic" they were still pretty tasty. I think I will definitely try something else on the menu next time. But it's a cute little spot with delicious value.
author: Jon N.

description: ay chihuahua! I love this place it's my new favorite. Everything is fresh, it's like having authentic Mexican food but without the rotating spool of flesh and Manteca lard. Everything I have had is so good and I love that they have those wine margarita's so I don't get too buzzed while I'm working during the day. God loves a chihuahua!
author: Elle M.

description:
I was so happy to have discovered this place!  The enchiladas are amazing!!!  Not typical mexican food, but it is so good! 

Seating is hard to get, but that is the only complaint I have.
author: Moana S.

description:
The BF and I spilt our loyalities between here and GCK.  Brunch is the showstopper for both of these places.  $2 beers, that passionfruit mimosa, the chilequiles, the mexican french toast.  Late nights with the tostada salad are like making it to 2nd base with all your clothes on.

We always offer to share a table as its packed.  Could others do the same?
author: M M.

description: Excellent Mexican food, nice place, garlic shrimp burrito is the way forward...
author: Sean H.

description: Delicious food, big portions, fast service, and great decor!  They also have lots of fresh tasty salsas to choose from!
author: Alexandra W.

description: La taquieria in the mission is better because I felt these burritos are way expensive for the skimpy meat you get. But if your willing to PAY extra extra the sweet plantains were a good add. I would also suggest the black beans over the red/pinto.
author: Manorah R.

description: Great little place, nice, casual ambiance.  Chocolate chili cupcakes were unique, but slightly dry.  Guacamole and salsa were good and authentic, quesadillas were also pretty good.  Huge portions.  Prices are very fair.
author: clarissa m.

description:
Fresh and Tasty!!!!
I love the taco salad. It is so good. I just wish they would give you a little more meat because I usually split everything with my boyfriend and we fight over how much carne asada we each got. Otherwise though....mmmmmmm. And the cabbage is salad is yummy.
One thing I would love them to add to the menu is Al Pastor and then Little Chihuahua would be perfect.
If the owners/chefs are reading this, please add Al Pastor.
author: chicka d.

description: I live nearby, but I will keep walking to the Mission for my tacos.
author: Tim G.

description: This place is good!  And they offer a baby burrito! Burritos are so goddamn big these days, I can never finish one.  Also good salsa and guacamole.  Finally, a place that salts their tortilla chips enough AND serves them hot! Just wish they were open later.
author: Suzanne L.

description: Brunch here was good.  The salsa bar was amazing, I love the roasted habanero salsa.  So tasty!  The quality was great, and the coffee was quite good.
author: Joann C.

description: The Little Chihuahua has definitely grown on me since they opened.  It's definitely not authentic Mexican food and it's also much different than the version of Mexican food you've come to know and love at your favorite taqueria in the mission.  It took me a while to get used to the flavors, but I'm liking it now.  They use high quality ingredients and its definitely noticeable.  I would also say it's healthier, as in less lard and salt.  You can get a burrito here and not have to immediately go home and take a 3 hour nap like after eating at some of my other favorite places.  Also, they have some good brunch items on the weekends that are worth trying.  If I recall, beers are pretty cheap here as well, but I wouldn't consider it a hang out spot.
author: Zach J.

description:
went about 3 weeks ago and loved it.
super cute ambiance with stained glass windows and charming wooden tables/chairs and stylee artwork.  
the food was stellar. v fresh ingredients - generous amounts and super cheapy..!  
we shared:
tortilla soup -  on par! yumyum. 
pollo nachos - ginormous and hands down the best nachos to date! right distribution of cheese v. tortilla chips v. pollo and guac.  
veggie tacos -  very delish and muy satisfying.  
and the sangria..  omg. super refreshing and delish. 

they have a fantastic salsa bar and all the varietals of salsas were sooo good. spicy and definitely homemade.  
craving it now!
author: Caroline S.

description: This is the best mexican food in the city.  All highest quality, freshest ingredients.  Tons of menu options, 7 or 8 different bomb salsas, beer on tap, the list goes on.  I ate here every other day for 6 months
author: Allison C.

description: I live across the street and this place has really good food. Like the meats are really good and they do some creative stuff like the fried plaintain burrito...sounds a little weird but I think I'll try it per a suggestion on here. The tortilla soup is good and the tortilla salad is also really really yummy and healthy. For Mexican, it's pricey though, but they have some delicious guacamole and their salsas are pretty good as well. Overall, I've never regretted eating there, even a taco is good!
author: Gina R.

description: Who would have thought that with a name like "Little Chihuahua" one would actually find authentic Mexican food, and this is coming from a Mexican.  Well look no further for your next favorite Mexican food restaurant, this place is the shit.  Sumptuous food, captivating decor, and friendly staff await you!  You may have a small wait to get a table Friday and Saturday nights, but it's well worth sitting and enjoying your meal there. OH!!! and don't miss out on the $2 draft beers on tap!  What else can I say?!?  I love this place.
author: Ethan K.

description:
While not what I would consider the most traditional Mexican food, I am a huge fan of the shrimp and grilled veggie tacos. Their salsa bar is also quite good. I like the assortment of veggie options rather than just 'bean & rice' and this is the only place in town where I eat their grilled vegetables.

I would have considered a 5 star rating except I always wait a really long time even when i call ahead since they don't have a separate line for picking up orders. Sometimes they don't even answer the phone at all when you try to call ahead (like tonight for example).
author: Sara C.

description:
Woah.  This place is seriously delicious.  I happened upon it while in the neighborhood one night and was floored.  The tortilla of the baby super chicken verde burrito was a promising start- warm, fresh, and grilled to perfection.  The other noteworthy parts were the gooey melted cheese and the nice combo of all ingredients- nothing was too overpowering.  

I'll be back to try the Garlic Shrimp and the Plantain burrito.  

Until then, I'll dream of you lil' chihuahua.
author: Annie N.

description: Finally, a Mexican joint in my 'hood that, unlike the previous 2 restaurants, will prob last way longer than a couple years at this spot. Sustainable shrimp, Niman Ranch beef & pork, and free range chicken on their menu def caught my attention. So, my BF and I went there last week and were pretty satisfied w/ our meal. Everything is super fresh! I got a shrimp taco, a chili verde chicken taco, rice, and black beans. The BF got a carne asada enchilada w/ rice and refried black beans. Pretty good, but I recommend the shrimp taco for sure. The chili verde chicken needed more zing, so I dumped one of my fave salsas on top to give it full flave and it was bomb. Prices and portions are great. We can't wait to go back to try their burritos! And hooray for the little chihuahua....for having whole wheat tortilla as an option for their burritos. We'll be goin back very very soon.
author: M L.

description: Excellent black bean and fried plantain burrito. Strongly recommend.
author: Zain A.

description: I have to take off a star because last time I called to place an order with them I was put on hold for 5 minutes and then they just hung up. I think they've gotten so popular that they're letting those things slip by, which is upsetting... but I'm keeping it at 4 stars because I'm still obsessed with their carnitas... and in general they are nice there.
author: Kate A.

description: Great little neighborhood place and a million times better than the previous Mexican taqueria that was there before. I went for brunch this past Sunday with friends, two of us had the breakfast burrito - YUM and it was large! The other person had the Mexican french toast - fried tortilla, fried plantains and bacon with agave maple syrup - she was almost licking the plate! Service was very quick. The space is clean and cute inside - I really like the chairs. Plus, they have 4 or 5 different yummy salsa's - a major plus in my book. I didn't have any but did notice draft beer was only $2 - CHEAP! If Papalote wasn't 3/4 of a block away from my apartment I would go to Little Chihuahua instead but given I'm about 6 blocks from Lil'Chi' - I will continue my regular Papalote trysts but will definitely wander the few extra blocks every now and then!
author: Erin S.

description: One of my favorite local spots. Menu items are fresh, tasty, juicy and flavorful. Love the plantain burrito! The food always arrives quickly and service is friendly.
author: Barbara B.

description: It's the only decent taqueria in this hood and it's pretty good. I had the tacos today which we solid...they use good meat and the ingredients are fresh. Great selection of salsas including a sweet habanero salas that's great. I had a burrito here before that was just so-so.
author: Bill R.

description: The shrimp garlic burrito my fiancé and I got was really good but it could be bigger. I enjoyed the little salsa bar - everything was spicy just the way I like it. Our total for two beers, a margarita, and the burrito was roughly $20.
author: Selina L.

description:
Having lived in Southern California for most of my life, I know good Mexican food.  The Little Chihuahua whips up a pretty solid burrito that isn't perfectly authentic, but good nonetheless.  I got the Super Burrito with chicken.

I'm giving 4 stars instead of 5 because the price was a little high; each burrito is circa $8, but Mexican food is supposed to be cheap.

I'm definitely going back.
author: Alex L.

description: Only had one meal here - the wild mushroom quesadilla, but it was good! so I'm looking forward to going back for more...
author: Sapna M.

description:
Went there after reading the reviews.  As soon as I stepped in I wished that I had decided to eat in instead of take-out.  Really cute and great atmosphere.  Although I didn't see any kids there, I will definitely take mine.  Food is great.  Had a baby burrito and the soup.  Quality of the ingredients is way superior than other taquerias in it's price range.  however, I wish that they would use small tortillas so the burrito didn't taste so doughy.  The broth of the soup was excellent but the chicken was chewy.  I just took out the chicken and ate the rest of the soup.  More like smacked it right up.  The salsa bar was ok.  Panchos has way better salsas (actually the only thing they have that is good).

Will definitely be coming back here and will try the other stuff as well.
author: k p.

description: good quality ingredients and good flavors, but the breakfast is pretty blah.
author: Roman H.

description: Had the super burrito.  The ingredients were very fresh and high quality.  Burrito was a good size, but for $9 it should definitely be a larger in my opinion.  Doesn't replace the burritos at Castillo, but will be back.
author: E L.

description:
Live just down the street and this place is one of my faves. Best burritos in SF. Favorties: Veggie Burrito, Breakfast Burrito, Garlic Shrimp Burrito.

Staff is kickass - laid back and uber friendly (even when they're slammed). 

Love it!
author: Marie D.

description: I want to preface this by saying I am not a big fan of Mexican food, especially burritos.  But I will compromise and go to Little Chihuahua and I will enjoy it!  I usually get their shrimp tacos or the black bean and plantain burrito.  That may be the only burrito I really like anywhere.  Their assortment of salsas are amazing!  It is worth it to go their just to try all the salsa. It is more expensive then a taqueria, but worth it, especially for someone who does not like taquerias.
author: Kathleen Y.

description: their website calls the food here "mexican-inspired;" it's not what many of my fellow san franciscans would consider "mission authentic." but that's fine; i think the little chihuahua's better. yes, this place has what i consider to be the best burritos i've had in the city. ditto for their chips and house-made salsas. after raving about the roasted tomato salsa the nice young man behind the counter offered me up a sample of a "secret salsa." you'll get nothing but the freshest ingredients here. it's a bit pricey and, like i said, about as authentic as nopalito (but better, IMHO), but there's no better way to blow ten bucks then on a garlic shrimp burrito!
author: Brett W.

description: I can only vouch for one item as it's the only item I have yet had: the steak baby burrito.  It was sublime, with tender non-scary beef and yummy refried beans (made with organic lard?  I forgot to ask).  It was the perfect amount of food.  Although I should add that I was extremely hungry and ate it in 2 bites.  Oh well.  Let's just say it was good enough that I shall return to try a taco.
author: sheena b.

description: I was disappointed to see taco loco go because sometimes I don't feel like going all the way to the mission to get a burrito but this new place did not disappoint.  In fact it may even be better that taco loco.  The burritos are great and they have cheap beer.  The name is a little weird but the food is very tasty.
author: Ryan R.

description: Sooo good! I love the different Salsa's! The employees were very nice and helpful and recommended the wine Margarita-so yummy.
author: Kathryn S.

description: Um, yum! I took fellow yelpers advise and ordered the fried plantains burrito. It's just the right amount of sweet and boy is it filling! I love whole black beans so it was refreshing to see this is what this burrito came with. They gave us a healthy helping of very good tortilla chips. Usually I don't like the free chips but these were thin and crispy and just salty enough to keep me grabbing for more. Their salsa bar is off the chain. Fresh pico de gallo and very spicy red sauce. I love the atmosphere and the chairs. A very traditional setting. Highly recommend this place to eat in and enjoy!
author: A S.

description: Little Chihuahua has a great brunch menu with lots of yummy options. The space is small, and can get crowded, but the salsa bar makes waiting for a table well worth it. Dinnertime take-out is also pretty great.
author: Melissa J.

description: Love it, love it, love it....super fresh and not heavy.  Great full flavors!
author: Lisa R.

description:
best mexican in the hood
not really a burito fan, but the super chicken or a carne asarda/ carnitas mix are freakin good
best tasting chips too, like super fresh
staff are cool, the owners always up for a chat
all the sauces are done in house, green tomato salsa rules
and grab one of the many mex beers in the fridge (negra modella for me)
author: david s.

description: Great mexican restaurant, that is super green! the food is good, especially the green chicken (i'm from san diego and i'm very picky with my Mexican food). They also have a good beer selection (Negro modelo, yum) and all their take away packing is compostable!
author: Katie M.

description: Best place ever!  Authentic food, Great tasting, My FAVORITE.  Also, its nice inside and you can grab a beer.  Way better than the ratty places in the mission.
author: Marc C.

description: I've been several times and haven't been impressed by anything - burritos, tostadas, chips & salsa were all pretty bland despite the moderately high prices.  The cramped interior makes me feel really uncomfortable as well. Seems to me that their success lies in being the only burrito spot in the immediate area.  Edible but not incredible.
author: Karthi X.

description:
Pretty good. Nothing too fabulous or anything, I don't think the salsa is bland, but it's nothing to write home about. I wish it were a little cheaper. 7.50 for 2 tacos is outrageous! Esp. at lunch. One taco usually does me, but they don't put any beans and rice on their tacos (though for the price they should) and the meat sure ain't no pile. I can't eat flour, so baby burrito is out. I would like to go more, and even for $6 I would... I also don't like the fact that the hot salsa verde is the same as the cold, but heated. Plus it's too sweet. Carnitas is DEELISH though. And i always judge by the pork. haha. Not bad, not awesome. But I think this is their first restaurant adventure so maybe it'll get better!

forgot to mention, the 2 tacos for $7.50. no sour cream or avocado. that's extra. sorry, but that's freakin ridiculous.
author: Burleigh Girl G.

description: Best burrito in town! I love this place... Everything is great from the Steak to the salad... and great wine very impressive! I had a glass of some red wine not sure what it was and it was great. A good place to come for dinner chill out and eat some home cooking!
author: thomas P.

description: I LOVE this place!  It's unique flavor and fresh ingredients makes burrito-eating a whole new experience.  I am so happy they moved into the neighborhood.  In my opinion its far better than any other taqueria in the Haight or Duboce Triangle.
author: Kimberly P.

description: It's alwasy great to have more good mexian places on Divisidero! The salsas are dangerously awesome. There are camerone enchaladas, tacos, burritos, etc! Only the high prices dissapoint me a bit. But it's awesome grub!
author: Paul Y.

description: Great spot. I have been going a little too often since I moved to the neighborhood! Friendly staff and I love that they have Session Lager!
author: Meesh S.

description: Wow - I can't believe it took me almost a year to find this place! I live relatively close by, more towards USF than Lower Haight but I'd bypass Papalote and Green Chile any day for this REAL DEAL spot. Not sure what it is but they serve the BEST re-fried beans I've ever had in my life. The prices are reasonable and the carnitas was great.
