I will definitely return to try the brunch and everything else on the menu for that matter.
author: Brian W.

description: i love this place.  the wild mushroom tacos are fantastic.  customer service is excellent.  they uphold sustainable restaurant practices and have fresh and high quality ingredients.  buy local!
author: Heather C.

description: I've heard some remarks about my reviews and about how I only write one liners. Well, this place only deserves one sentence and that sentence is: $8 for a burrito that they think is special because it has plantains in it, but it isn't even as good as Castillito or Cancun. :-P
author: Lucy G.

description: Yeah! I'm not a big fan of the average san francisco taqueria, but fortunately this isn't one of them.  Tasty, tasty yet simple mexican food.  And, if you're not in the mood for a burrito the size of a house cat, you can get a "baby" burrito that's just the right size. cover it with pickled cabbage and roasted red salsa and you've got yourself a nice meal.
author: nicky c.

description:
This place is total hipster-ville. Somewhat rude, "I'm way cooler than you" front-house staff. Decent prices considering its very hard to get a burrito for under $8 these days. Interesting menu selection.

Good cheese enchiladas, yummie beans. Don't get the agave wine margaritas--they are straight-up orange juice with a splash of wine. Not worth $18/pitcher. I'd give their carne asada a try next time cause I heard it's good...also, I'd try the brunch.
author: Cassie C.

description: What a pleasant surprise to find this little place tucked away on Divisidero. The staff were great, the food was so fresh and came quickly. We shared a garlic shrimp burrito (the small one was more than enough) and the tostada salad. I recommend both. But the crowning glory of the lunch was the arroz con leche with the marinated raisins. It's not listed on the menu, but I read about it from a fellow yelper. If you like rice pudding, this one is the world's best..........trust me.  Oh and I forgot to mention how good the fresh salsas were. Try them all
author: cathy n.

description: A little pricey and they forgot my whole order a couple times.  But, they made it up to me.  Lovely fresh burrito in the non mission!
author: Velvet V.

description:
Try plantain burrito! Fantastic and people are  nice. I think Papalotte has a better ambiance, but plantain burrito is better than the usual burrito papalotte has to offer. I did not like chips though, it  smelled funny.
I give it a five for reasonable price, cleanliness and good food.
author: Kingshuk g.

description:
Excellent Tomatillo salsa.  

I had the Chile Verde chicken nachos which were a bit spicier than I expected due to the smoky chili sauce they add.  There was less cheese than I prefer on my nachos, but overall they were quite tasty and there was a good ratio of chips to toppings.  

My husband had the baby burrito with Carnitas which was nicely flavored.  He didn't seem to notice the cabbage in the burrito and I quite enjoyed it.

Overall good food that is reasonable when you take into account the quality of the ingredients (organic and fresh).  

I will definitely return to try the plantain and black bean burrito.
author: Allison S.

description: Yum!  Finally some GOOD Mexican food in the hood!  Can't wait to come for brunch...
author: Amy P.

description:
very un-Mexican, but then again burritos are pretty American anyway.  they put all kinds of fancy shit in their burritos, and it's delicious! they add cabbage salad and pico de gallo, which i love. there's the black bean and fried plantains burrito, also delicious.  my friend is a big fan of their garlic shrimp burritos... have yet to try anything else.

and the best part is they are right next to my house. the end.
author: Hella M.

description: I still love the food here as much as ever and am so glad they partner with all sorts of cool local eco-friendly businesses, live Viv and Green Zebra. Great food and great business practices! Kudos!
author: Cher E.

description: Excellent food, nice staff, great salsa bar, relaxed and clean decor. I esp love the fajita burrito! A little more expensive than some places, but the quality makes it worth the price.
author: Margo G.

description: This place is overrated and overpriced.  Unfortunately, this is the only carry out burrito joint in the neighborhood so they still get my money.  Burritos are small.  Get the baby burrito - it is almost exactly the same size as the adult version.  For some reason they like to cook the crap out of the tortilla so it is crispy with little burn marks on the outside.  I don't like this.  They do the same thing at Taco Bell.  Also, when you aren't paying attention they will put shredded cabbage in your burrito.  Salsa is pretty meh...  Good atmosphere inside with the exception of the generic concrete/spray paint art for sale on the walls.  The staff normally have a pretty hip taste in music.  Long story short - this is the best burrito in the neighborhood but not nearly as good as something in the Mission.  Expect to pay a little more for the convenience.
author: James C.

description: came in for a late lunch and it was perfect, no smelly hipsters!  i had the niman ranch carnitas regular burrito, which was filling and yummy, while my boy,  had the pollo enchilidas.  he said it was as good if not better than the taqueria's in ATX.  finished the meal off with 2 drafts and the bill was $20 and change, left $5 tip.  next time i need to order the niman beef which smelled amazing on the grill.  someone needs to bottle that smell and sell it as cologne.  :}
author: Pickle R.

description:
atmosphere: bright little place, very homey and cozy
service: very fast 
food: great for being outside the mission, very fresh and hot-the nachos are huge
price: fair - good price for good food
author: A D.

description: I live around the corner. Thank you Little Chihuahua for coming into being. So far I've only done the chicken and veggie all ways. I was addicted to the tostada salad (looove the dressing) but now I have discovered the super baby burrito and eat it every week. Seriously - perfect high quality for a little bitty price. I can't stand a greasy burrito. I have never had one here. The chips, green and red salsas are amazing. The guac is better than my homemade stuff, which is highly impressive. Go here. They are super nice peeps too. This is food is truly San Francisco to me.
author: K T.

description:
Cannot say enough about this place.  Discovered it months before leaving the hood.  Such good fresh food and great service.  Fab salsa bar.

Go here!
author: Alysa T.

description: Had one of the best shrimp tostada salads ever, with mango and a slightly sweet dressing. Thought I'd had every type of 'mexican' salad possible but this one was definitely a new one and a big hit!
author: P G.

description:
my fiance does not eat mexican food.  usually it's because there are not many choices for vegetarians at a taqueria.  however, since we were meeting a couple of my other friends for dinner on sat night, he was not going to have a choice in the matter since we already chose the restaurant w/o him.  

when you get here, it is a bit chaotic.  you order at the counter and get a number, but you have to wait to get a seat.  it's seriously a dog eat dog situation as people are fighting for a table.  the fiance and i got there before my friends did, as this neighborhood is not the easiest one to find parking.  i got the shrimp baby burrito on whole wheat tortilla w/ veggie black beans, and he got a grilled veggie taco and a tofu verde taco.  we grabbed a table for four and sat down to a bowl of chips and salsa that you get from the salsa bar.  we got our food before my friends even arrived, but they soon got there and ordered as well.  the baby burrito was huge and definitely enuf for a hungry girl.  they messed up my order and gave me a grilled veggie burrito, but it was so tasty that i didn't even realize it until i was halfway done.  my fiance loved his tacos and now concedes that he may like mexican food after all!
author: Helen T.

description:
Ok so there have been a number of owners in this same spot who have tried and failed at a Mexican restaurant; but finally we have a winner!!!  The area has been hurting for a good place like this for over a decade.  My family is very picky when it comes to Mexican food and for me the shrimp burrito is the bar-setter. Little Chihuahua not only nailed it but as I ordered they mentioned the garlic shrimp burrito which I tried the second visit.  Both were good but the garlic shrimp had a little extra kick that really hit the spot.  My son loves the carne asada burrito which is prepared to order and not slopped out of a bowl.  My wife tried the plantain and black bean burrito and loved it.  She's not a big burrito eater and prefers tofu tacos which she felt theirs could have been better. 

Overall this place is a gem in the neighborhood.  Freshly cooked meats, organic ingredients, good portions, the list goes on.
author: T M.

description: I love you Little Chihuahau. . . your tortilla soup is light and delicious.  Just the thing when your man insists on Mexican for yet another night and you are in no mood for a greasy burrito.  The ingredients are fresh, the establishment clean and the wait time, lightning fast.  I'll be back again and again.
author: Helen T.

description: Great brunch spot when you are in the mood for a change of pace. Crowded when we walked in but we ordered and turned around and a table opened- after busing it ourselves and sitting down the chips and salsa was great- the passion fruit mimosas were surprisingly good and the Mexican french Toast and Breakfast burrito were huge and tasty. The crowd there, at least that Sunday, were pretty laid back and normal- the service was very fast and friendly. We bussed our table and left and it was taken right away- but I didn't have the feeling that the table vultures were hovering and hungry. Just happy to get a timely seat. I will definitely return for brunch- maybe a weeknight dinner too. a great little spot!
author: Vanessa C.

description: By far the best burrito in the city.  It isn't as authentic as other places in SF, but still the best.  All organic meats and high quality ingredients which gives the meal a much lighter feeling.  Salsas are fantastic as well, with some that have a lot of heat.  I usually stick with the burrito, but the tacos and salads are also really good.
author: Ryan H.

description: Cheap beer and good food. Solid neighborhood Mexican place that's a bit more upscale than the usual neighborhood dumps.  Great to linger over beers after a meal.
author: Bill P.

description: I have only gone once so far. I got the chicken nachos, which took super long to make and was basically mediocre. At first I thought there wasn't even any cheese in it but there was, just barely any. And when I get nachos I want helluv cheese.  The service was really good and the new owners have cleaned up the place quite a bit. Now this "ambiance" everyone is talking about is actually the exact same way it was when it was the Loco Taco.  Now I understand that I need to try something besides the Nachos and actually sit down in there to eat it right off the grill to see if this is actually above the taco shop level. But the food seems about the same as it was before, just more expensive. Since I live a block away I'm sure I'll end up eating there more and will adjust this review if necessary. By the way, if it's gotten so that in my neighborhood (The Lower Haight) that people give a fuck about "The Ambiance" while they are picking up a fucking burrito then I don't know what to say....
author: Dave C.

description: i was amazed to find that i'd never been to -- or even heard of -- this yummy mexican joint in the lower haight. it was really yummy!  i got the garlic shrimp burrito. it was big, well-seasoned and chock full of tasty goodness. the chips were excellent; the salsa was so-so. the vibe here was fun and friendly; it was crowded, but not hard to get a seat. would def come here again (if papalote is closed ;).
author: Elle B.

description: yeah for responsibly farmed, sustainable meats! The baby super burrito with steak was superb.
author: Cynthia s.

description: Seriously, this place is great. Their burritos are ridiculously good, they have $2 pints of Fat Tire all the time, and the Mexican French Toast on their brunch menu  is just genius. Stop reading reviews and just go to this place. It rocks in every way.
author: Gavin W.

description: best ever the staff their rock's, food is top notch...
author: rob a.

description: I had the Salmon Taco upon the recommendation of one of the dudes behind the counter.  It was good, just nothing particularly special.  I've had much better fish tacos.  Perhaps I ordered poorly, but I was a little disappointed because the reviews were so good.
author: Luke P.

description: Cozy.  Great food, reasonable prices.  The room is small and not exactly suited for hanging out for long spells, but for the time you're there, you'll enjoy the reasonably priced and flavorful food, the pleasant decor, and the thoughtful touches (small tables and a newspaper rack for people dining alone--and lots of diners are in fact solo).  I give them extra points for using Niman Ranch meat; you can really taste the difference.  I strongly recommend the Tortilla Soup. Delicious!
author: John G.

description: I met a group of friends here two weekends ago for brunch.  I had the huevos motulenos (basically a breakfast tostada with eggs and ham) and a passion fruit mimosa.  It was delicious!  You order at the counter and seat yourself.  Small restaurant and basic atmosphere, but inexpensive and a quick enjoyable breakfast.  I will be back for more.
author: Katherine D.

description: plantain burrito AMAZING sweet but spicy and cheesy . sooo good and cheap!
author: L V.

description: Very fresh and healthy tasting food. My favorite is salmon tacos. This is a spot I get lunch at a couple times a month. They also have Mexican cokes, which are my secret splurge for a sugar rush.
author: Ste B.

description: Great spot for a burrito!  Everything comes with a side of chips, very good prices for SF.  The plantain burrito is delicious.  Great atmosphere and staff.  An enjoyable lunch or casual dinner spot!
author: Tyler S.

description: Great hidden treasure.  Low key but cool.  Good value.  Carne asada tacos are made big pieces of steak.  One is pretty filling, two a whole meal.  Good guac. Good rice pudding dessert thing.  Good music.  Kid friendly.  Check it out.
author: E. Z.

description: just had breakfast with the man here, and it was deeelish.  he got the breakfast burrito and i got the huevos-something-molteno?  the one with the over easy eggs, and ham.  yum, the ham totally makes it.  all washed down with a carafe of agave wine margaritas.  yummmm.
author: Kimby T.

description: great, clean and tasty mexican not in the mission. lovely addition to the ever growing nopa/divis foodie strip. excellent salsas and warm torilla chips. they did a great job on the interior, super cozey, big chunky wood tables and artisan inspired chairs. a must try!
author: casey c.

description: ate here for the first time today. i got the carne asada nachos and a fat tire, the boyfriend had a carne asada super burrito. the burrito wasn't all that big compared to some of the other places we've been around the city, but when he was finished he was able to finish off my heaping mound of nachos. the food was very flavorful, although the red salsa that they put on the nachos caused a 4 alarm fire in my mouth (but i'm a big baby when it comes to spicy foods). went in around 2:30, had to wait for a table. there isn't a lot of seating here. i'm giving the place four stars mainly for the taste of the food and the 2$ draft beer. the decor was nice and the "salsa bar" was pretty impressive, but i wish it weren't so cramped. be prepared to possibly have to order togo, even if you planned on dining in.
author: Shawna M.

description: This place is way too over hyped. The burritos are OK.  I'll admit I'm lazy and haven't found a better alternative in the area (and burritos are a staple in my diet), so I continue to patronize this establishment.  However, it's rare that I am disappointed with the quality of a burrito...but the Little Chihuahua let me down.
author: John S.

description: this place is a real gem -- nicer atmosphere and better food than the average taqueria.  the brunch is downright fantastic.
author: Joshua S.

description: Look, i like little chihuaha, i really do. as mentioned before, the carnitas are excellent, and i like the baby burrito, which to me seems pretty much like a regular one, just cheaper, but there are some serious complaints i must lodge. 1. The salsa is terrible. While all the flavors are ALMOST ok, they all miss somehow. the tomatilla is too sweet, the habanero too hot, the roasted pepper too "roasty", and 2. What's up with all the cabbage? seriously, lettuce tastes much better in most mexican food except maybe fish tacos. that's all i got.
author: jon m.

description: good food, sustainable meat sources, cheap drinks and it's in my neighborhood.  what more could you ask for?  i'm partial to the fajita burrito.
author: Kumar D.

description: Went here for a steak burrito, it was great.  They put cabbage in the burritos which give it a nice texture.  The whole wheat (yay!) tortilla was flaky and warm, the guac was fresh and there was tons of it on my burrito.  The steak was great quality, very tender and yummy, but it was a little salty.  Not sure if this was the meat to begin with or their seasonings.  Came with chips and I thought their salsas were good, they tasted fresh.  Maybe not complex, but still yummy.  I mixed the chipotle and tomatillo ones together and it was perfect.  All in all, a great burrito, I'll go back again for sure.
author: Kristen T.

description: The tacos are awesome, and the free chips and salsa that you get while you wait for your food rocks too!
author: AJ V.

description: I think there were at least 2 other burrito places in this location before and they were terrible.  This one is a welcome change.  I enjoy the shrimp burrito and the roasted vegetable burrito.  And usually I do not like specialty burritos and go for the regular bean and cheese variety.  I liked the plantain one at the beginning but am sick of it now--too heavy on the plantains.
author: Bobo R.

description: I may be addicted to the chips and salsa here.  I've been here two nights in a row and I'm contemplating going again tonight.  I can't get those thin, crispy, warm chips and their thick guacamole out of my head!  I have to say, I haven't tried that many items off their menu.  I keep going back for the chicken enchiladas and can't seem to order anything else.  But my boyfriend had the carne asada burrito last night and it was fabulous.  Even though it was meat, it just tastes healthier.  Maybe it's the fact that they use good ingredients like Niman Ranch and Rocky chicken.  Anyway, I saw the tortilla soup and if I can stray away from the enchiladas the next time I go, I'll try and order that!
author: Ming Y.

description: Brunch rules at this place...it's quieter than at dinner, and they feature lots of unique dishes with very fresh ingredients.  No matter how far I wander around the menu, I've never been disappointed with the food I've ordered.  There's not much more to say that hasn't already been said here, just go and be happy that there's a great Mexican joint in the neighborhood (good riddance, Loco Taco!).
author: Jon M.

description:
I have loved this place since it opened, and it's definitely a perfect addition to the area. Lets face it, there are great taquerias in SF, tons of them, mostly in the mission. There is "authentic" Mexican food, (is it just me or do only white people ever actually gripe about the authenticity of their Mexican food?), there are Americanized joints, and all number of other manifestations built around beans and tortillas. Little Chihuahua, in my experience, occupies its own distinctive place as a taqueria, so any review that tries to talk about what it SHOULD be fails to realize that they SHOULD have just gone to the place that serves that type of food.

The first thing I noticed when I ate their food was how boldly the tomato flavor stands out in the sauce on their smothered burrito. I've had spicy, mild, watery, red, green, but I don't think I've ever had a sauce that really brought out the flavor of the tomatoes that form its base, and I love it. Aside from that, they have several salsas at the bar, nothing totally spectacular or rich in flavor, but I do like the particular tart-zinginess of the habanero salsa.

The menu isn't huge, but the ingredients in everything are a notch above your typical taqueria faire. If you order a carne asada burrito, you'll be surprised to find not some leathery brown strips of meat in there, but juicy, tender slices of neimann-ranch steak, still a little pink in the middle, seared just right on the edges. Similarly, the shrimp burrito is stuffed with large jumbo shrimp, bursting with flavor. Their tostada salad is a nice light option, emphasizing the salad and dressed with zesty lime, piled on a fluffy, crunchy tostada. 

There are only really two things I can complain much about. First would be that I'm not a huge fan of their chips. I'm much more of a fan of the greasier, sliced-up-corn-tortilla style chips you get from most taquerias. The other would be (and this is perhaps both a function of how many times I've been there, and the fact that they are still just starting out) that they are sometimes a little inconsistent. Most of the time, the food is great. The first few times I went in, I was more than impressed. But there have been a few times when it didn't live up to what I know they're capable of. Whether the shrimp ends up being slightly over(or under)-cooked, or they are maybe in a bit of a hurry and don't throw enough of something in the burrito, I've been disappointed maybe 2 or 3 times, only once where it really diminished my appetite for the food. That's out of several dozen times eating there, though, and nobody's perfect.

Stop in. Get a carne asada burrito, or a shrimp burrito. Make sure it's super and smothered. You won't be disappointed.
author: Cooper B.

description: This is a great taqueria for vegetarians.  The fried plantain burrito is out of this world.  Good salsas, cheap draft beers, and nice folks.  The only thing that is awkward about Chihuaha is the seating.  The chairs are WAY too close together so it's hard to squeeze into a seat.
author: Sarah K.

description: This is a great taqueria, but don't expect Mission prices.  You'll end up spending about $10, but it's worth it.  Plus, they have a great selection of salsas.
author: Sarah K.

description: rock solid regular burrito that didn't leave me feeling like i'd consumed 18lbs of cafeteria food.  the salsa's were flippin phenomenal.
author: Barley G.
